Q: But even as the judge, Scott McAfee of Fulton County Superior Court, rejected the claim by one of Mr. Trump’s co-defendants, Mike Roman, that the relationship raised an actual conflict of interest by giving Ms. Willis a financial stake in the case, the judge also ruled that it raised “a significant appearance of impropriety.”

The judge gave her two choices: either Mr. Wade leaves her prosecution team, or she and her office must step aside from the case.

Here are highlights from the 23-page ruling:

A combination of factors raises a legitimate question.

Alone, each of the two main issues raised by the defense — that Mr. Wade is being paid by the hour, and that two members of the prosecution team were having a relationship — would not be a problem. But combined, they raise an deeper issue, the judge wrote.

Financial gain was neither proven nor shown to be a motivating factor.

The judge wrote that Willis’s claim that she had reimbursed Mr. Wade in cash for trips they took together was “unusual” and “understandably concerning” but was “not so incredible as to be inherently unbelievable,” and the evidence did not establish that she had received any material benefit as a result of her decision to hire and engage in a romantic relationship with Mr. Wade.

And, more important, the judge found, the evidence demonstrated that financial gain was “not a motivating factor” on Willis’s part in indicting and prosecuting the case.

Willis showed a “tremendous lapse in judgment” and acted unprofessionally.

While deciding that the evidence did not show there was an actual conflict of interest, the judge nevertheless suggested that the prosecutor’s conduct was problematic in a way that others — including an ethics commission and voters — may wish to address.

The situation still raises an “appearance of impropriety.”

Even when no actual conflict exists, the judge wrote, “a perceived conflict in the reasonable eyes of the public threatens confidence in the legal system itself.” The combination of factors that made the question of whether Ms. Willis had a conflict legitimate, he wrote, means such an appearance of impropriety persists in the case.

The judge also wrote that “reasonable members of the public could easily be left to wonder whether the financial exchanges have continued resulting in some form of benefit to the District Attorney, or even whether the romantic relationship has resumed,” adding that, “As long as Wade remains on the case, this unnecessary perception will persist.”

A lingering “odor of mendacity” means the two cannot continue together on the case.

Expressing skepticism about testimony regarding when the relationship between Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade evolved into a romantic one, the judge portrayed the continued commingling of professional and personal relationships as untenable.

There has been no showing that the two prosecutors’ relationship violated the defendants’ rights or hurt them in any way, the judge wrote, and disqualifying Ms. Willis is unnecessary when there is a less drastic remedy available: Mr. Wade can leave the prosecution team.

A gag order may be coming.

The defense had also asked the judge to disqualify Ms. Willis over public remarks she has made, including at a church in Atlanta on Jan. 14 in which she complained vaguely about her detractors and accused them of playing “the race card.” While finding that her comments did not amount to improperly trying the case in public, the judge nevertheless scolded her and suggested that he may soon issue a gag order to prevent further public comments.

The relationship is an unacceptable distraction.

Summing up, the judge wrote that regardless of the outcome of the case, it is important that how it unfolds instills public confidence in the fairness and legitimacy of the process. While there is not a legal basis to support a finding that the district attorney has an actual conflict of interest, he found that the appearance of impropriety must nevertheless be addressed — signaling that Mr. Wade needs to leave the prosecution team in one manner or another.
A:

*   Fulton County
*   Atlanta

Extract locations mentioned in the article.

Q: "The IMF team has reached a staff-level agreement with the Pakistani authorities on the second and final review of Pakistan’s stabilization program supported by the IMF's $3 billion SBA approved in January," the IMF said on its website.

"Pakistan’s economic and financial position has improved in the months since the first review, with growth and confidence continuing to recover on the back of prudent policy management and the resumption of inflows from multilateral and bilateral partners," it added.

However, the IMF warned that since inflation was above target, Pakistan will have to increase gas and electricity prices during the current fiscal year, it added.

The development followed a visit by an IMF team, led by Nathan Porter, during 14-19 March for talks on the second review of Pakistan’s economic program, it also said.

The agreement is subject to approval by the IMF's Executive Board, the report added.

See also: IMF criticises Pakistan ministry's declaration on loan programme - news report

Source: Dawn website, Karachi, in English 0700 GMT 20 Mar 24
A:

*   **Pakistan**
*   **Karachi**

Q: A Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) spokesperson said the country's patrol vessels - BRP Cabra and BRP Sindangan - faced "dangerous manoeuvres and blocking" from the CCG and Chinese maritime militia during a resupply mission to troops stationed at BRP Sierra Madre in Scarbourough Shoal.

"Their reckless and illegal actions led to a collision between [BRP Sindangan] and China Coast Guard 21555 that resulted in minor structural damage to the PCG vessel," the spokesperson said on 5 March. 

Meanwhile, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr on 4 March said his country will cooperate with China in talks on the disputed South China Sea but will push back when its sovereignty and maritime rights are ignored.

Source: The Philippine Star website, Manila, in English 0800 GMT 5 Mar 24

Q: In a statement issued online, European Solidarity accused Ruslan Stefanchuk of exploiting martial law to disrupt lawmaking sessions and infringing on the opposition's rights.

"It has already become a tradition for the current leadership of parliament to justify unprofessionalism and inaction by blaming martial law," the statement said.

"We demand the leadership of the Supreme Council [parliament] resume parliamentary work as usual, consisting of at least two working weeks per month, a window to ask questions, transparency and highlighting of activities, to return journalists, to stop blocking inter-parliamentary activities, and adequately form the agendas of plenary sessions."

Q: "In reality, these nine subcontracting companies belonging to the Russian shareholders of Kazakh of the ERG Group that operate in four mines of DR Congo, hold markets worth hundreds of millions of dollars," the director-general of the Authority for Regulation of Subcontracts (ARSP), Miguel Katemb Kashal, said during a press conference. 

He added that in addition to Kazakh, the authorities dealt with with the Canadian company Barrick and the Chinese company Sicomines the same way in the past. 

Kashal further said that the eliminated contracts of the Russian companies, which were focused on the mining of copper and cobalt in south-eastern DR Congo, would be handed over to companies controlled by DR Congolese firms.

The development comes after the DR Congolese government recently denied that it had signed a military agreement with Russia.

Source: Radio France Internationale, Paris, in French 12 Mar 24

Q: Allan Pagh Kristensen, head of the EU Anti-Corruption Initiative in Ukraine (EUACI), was quoted as saying: "Recently, we have seen a lot of progress in the fight against corruption. We, as an anti-corruption programme, have studied progress in this area... Ukraine is fighting, the war is ongoing, but at the same time Ukraine is demonstrating perhaps the best results in all the years in part of the fight against corruption."

The EUACI chief said that there were significant anti-corruption legislation and improved investigative processes.

He added: "There is still a lot to be done... And we hope that progress will be seen in the future."

Source: Interfax-Ukraine news agency, Kyiv, in Russian 1258 gmt 11 Mar 24
A:

*   Ukraine
*   Kyiv

Q: “When people ask us whether it is OK for the United States to abandon Ukraine, the answer is no, because the world is operating not in a black-and-white way, or if you only look at one theater at a time,” he said. “The world is interconnected.”

If Russia is able to occupy more of Ukraine and claim victory, he added, “it would be seen as a victory of authoritarian states because Russia, China, North Korea and Iran, they are now linked together.”

Mr. Wu’s comments, made in a wide-ranging hourlong interview in Taipei, come as the Biden administration tries to get Congress to pass a supplemental funding package that would give $60 billion of aid to Ukraine.

Many House Republicans are staunchly opposed to giving more aid to Ukraine, adopting the “America First” posture embraced by former President Donald J. Trump, a pro-Russia candidate who has pressed them to reject the package. For months they claimed they would be willing to consider providing more assistance for Kyiv if the Biden administration imposed severe immigration restrictions at the United States border with Mexico. But at Mr. Trump’s urging, they balked at a funding package that would have done that, calling the border measures too weak.

The package also includes $8 billion of aid to counter China in the Asia-Pacific region, $1.9 billion of which would refill stocks of U.S. weapons sent to Taiwan. And it includes $14.1 billion of military aid to Israel.

Some Republican lawmakers contend that China is a bigger threat than Russia and that the funding proposed for Ukraine should go toward countering China. But other Republican officials in Congress and many Democrats make the same argument as Mr. Wu: that Taiwan’s security is linked to that of Ukraine, because China will see weakness on the part of the United States — and a greater chance of success in a potential invasion of Taiwan — if Ukraine is defeated.

Chinese leaders have said for decades that Taiwan, a de facto independent island, must be brought under the rule of the Communist Party, by force if necessary. Xi Jinping, China’s leader, has continued to promote that position.

The U.S. and Taiwanese governments have been trying to deter China from notions of invading Taiwan, including through military buildup in the region and bolstering alliances with other democratic nations.

If the United States abandons Ukraine, Mr. Wu said, China will “take it as a hint” that if it can keep up sustained action against Taiwan, “the United States is going to back off, the United States and its allies are going to back off.” The thinking among Chinese officials would be this, he said: “OK, since Russia could do that, we can do that as well.”

“So the U.S. determination in providing support to those countries suffering from authoritarian aggression, it is very important,” Mr. Wu said.

After U.S. troops withdrew from Afghanistan in 2021, China pushed propaganda through traditional state-run media and social media that “the U.S. commitment to anything is not firm,” Mr. Wu said. “We suffered from a huge wave of cognitive warfare.”

China has also spread disinformation stressing Russian narratives of the war, Mr. Wu said, including the idea that the expansion of NATO forced President Vladimir V. Putin to attack Ukraine, and that the United States is ultimately not committed to supporting Ukraine.

On the eve of Russia’s invasion in February 2022, Mr. Putin visited Mr. Xi in Beijing, and their two governments announced a “no limits” partnership.

Mr. Wu said some Central and Eastern European nations seeking to forge anti-authoritarian partnerships had strengthened their relations with Taiwan during the war.

His comments on the need for the United States to keep supporting Taiwan echo those of other senior Taiwanese officials. In May 2023, Bi-khim Hsiao, then Taiwan’s de facto ambassador to the United States and now the incoming vice president, made similar arguments to reporters in Washington.

And in February, Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, Democrat of Illinois, said during a visit of American lawmakers to Taiwan that the current president, Tsai Ing-wen, and the president-elect, Lai Ching-te, made clear to the lawmakers that “if for some reason the Ukrainians do not prevail, that will only encourage hostilities against Taiwan.”
A:

Q: "The Russian ships will take part in the Marine Security Belt 2024 joint exercise, which also involves ships, boats and marine aircraft of the Iranian and Chinese navies," the ministry said.

"The practical stage of the exercise will be held in the Gulf of Oman in the Arabian Sea. The primary objective is to practise ensuring the security of maritime economic operations," it said.

"Besides the Varyag missile cruiser, the exercise will involve the Marshal Shaposhnikov destroyer, upgraded to a frigate, two warships and a supply vessel of the Chinese Navy, and over ten ships, boats and supply vessels and three helicopters of the Iranian Navy," the ministry said.

"Naval representatives of Pakistan, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Oman, India and South Africa will serve as observers," it said.

The exercise aims "to provide regional security for the common good," Iranian media quoted Iranian Navy Commander Shahram Irani as saying in February.

Iran has said that the drills will be completed by the end of the Iranian year, i.e. 19 March.

Russia, Iran and China have held similar exercises before. In particular, the exercises included live artillery fire.

Source: Interfax-AVN military news agency, Moscow, in English 1239 gmt 11 Mar 24

Q: Quirimba Island in the Quirimbas Archipelago is an area where IS had not been known to operate before. While the group's supporters and some local news outlets earlier said that the jihadist group had captured some or parts of the island on 3 March, IS itself made no such claim in its first comment on the subject.

IS issued the claim on 7 March through its weekly newspaper al-Naba (issue 433), via the messaging app Telegram. 

It said that on 3 March, Mozambican armed forces tried to advance on IS positions in Quirimba Island, prompting clashes between the two sides that allegedly led to the killing of two soldiers.

Another two soldiers died drowning as they "fled to their boats" to escape the militants, according to al-Naba.

The remaining five, the IS mouthpiece continued, were captured and later shot dead by the jihadists.

The publication featured a picture to illustrate the execution-style killing of the five soldiers, four of whom were dressed in military fatigues, all sat on a beach. 

Local media outlets said that "at least" eight soldiers were killed by militants in Quirimba "since the occupation of the island on 2 March".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2350 GMT 7 Mar 24
A:

Here are the locations mentioned in the article:

*   Quirimba Island
*   Quirimbas Archipelago
*   Mozambique (inferred from "Mozambican armed forces")
*   beach

Q: Mirza further noted for the first time in the history of Pakistan, the Senate (upper house of the parliament) has been "practically inactive" as its elections are to be held on 9 or 11 April.

Mirza contacted Imran Ismail, former governor of Sindh and an estranged member of the PTI, and asked him about his activities after leaving the party and quitting politics. Ismail said leaving politics was difficult as he had been affiliated with Imran Khan (PTI founder) since 1993. He added after leaving politics, he has been focusing on his business and family.

Responding to a question on whether he would go back to the PTI, Ismail said political conditions are very difficult for the party at the moment and several of its members are in jail. He added he does not know who is managing the party right now, so he will think about it later, but he is currently not planning on returning to politics.

Ismail said he believes the PTI is a good political party and not a "terrorist party". He added it is a party which stands with the military and other institutions like the judiciary. He claimed no government in Pakistan can work "without the support of institutions", and as long as the PTI was in power, it enjoyed full support from the Army and other institutions of the military. He remarked it is very encouraging for a government to "remain on the same page as the military".

Ismail mentioned after a vote of no-confidence against the PTI government in the centre, he resigned from the governorship of Sindh because he felt he could not get along with the new government. He was of the view that former president Arif Alvi should also have resigned if he was "unable to work freely".

Ismail strongly condemned an alleged negative social media campaign against military personnel martyred a few days back and called the people involved in it "criminals of the nation". He said he decided to leave the PTI after the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged PTI members after the arrest of Imran Khan).

Mirza asked senior journalist Muhammad Malick about politicians in the PTI feeling that the party has been "hijacked by lawyers". Malick said Khan gave party tickets to a large number of lawyers before elections, thinking that lawyers would not be disqualified and the courts would also be lenient towards them. He noted the PTI stands divided into four to five factions at the moment as there is a "communication gap" between the party and Khan since he is in jail.

Malick was of the view that the issue of reserved seats is not important because the PTI will not be able to form its government even if it gets those seats in the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament). He remarked the issue is between two individuals: Imran Khan and Chief of Army Staff Asim Munir. He added if these two individuals "take two steps back and reach big decisions", things would become better for the PTI. He predicted some relief would gradually be given to the PTI, but not to Khan.

Talking about Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur's meeting with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, Malick said it should not be seen as "defiance" to Khan. He added the two would continue to meet in future as well because they are constitutional office holders.

Source: Dawn News TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1700 GMT 17 Mar 24
A:

*   Pakistan
*   Sindh
*   Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
*   Karachi

Q: "The Sudan Doctors’ Union’s Preparatory Committee has accused members of the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) of sexually assaulting three girls, one of whom is a nurse, at the El-Hasahisa Children’s Hospital in Gezira state," the website said.

"In a statement obtained by Radio Tamazuj, the Sudan Doctors’ Union affirmed that RSF members raped two girls who were accompanying patients at the children’s hospital and assaulted a nurse who tried to intervene and help the victims by raising an alarm," it added.

The group "urged those RSF elements responsible to be held accountable for the violations," it further added.

Human rights groups have repeatedly accused the RSF of committing atrocities including killings, rape and looting in areas under their control. The group denies the charges.

Source: Radio Tamazuj website, in English, 19 Mar 24

*   Gezira state

Q: El 25 de marzo de 2024, nubes carmesí, esmeralda, añil y azafrán se ciernen sobre el país para celebrar una de sus fiestas más vibrantes, alegres y coloridas.

“Jugar al Holi”, como dicen los indios, se ha extendido mucho más allá de las fronteras de India.

El jolgorio comienza al atardecer

También conocido como el “festival de los colores”, el Holi (que se pronuncia como santo en inglés, holy, con una hache inicial aspirada), comienza la noche de luna llena del mes phalguna del calendario hindú, que cae alrededor de febrero o marzo.

La celebración comienza con el encendido de las hogueras. La gente se reúne en torno a las llamas para cantar, bailar y rezar durante un ritual nocturno llamado Holika Dahan, que recrea la desaparición de Holika, una demonio hindú mítica.

Se arrojan al fuego todo tipo de cosas, como leña, hojas y comida, en una purga simbólica del mal y el triunfo del bien.

Archie Singhal, de 24 años, va de Delhi a visitar a su familia en Gujarat la víspera del Holi, cuando se enciende el fuego por la noche. A la mañana siguiente, Singhal se prepara para las ráfagas de polvo, llamadas gulal, aplicándose aceite en el cuerpo para que los colores no se le peguen a la piel. También se pone ropa vieja que no le importa descartar.

¿Por qué los colores?

Las raíces del Holi se encuentran en el hinduismo. El dios Krishna, maldecido por un demonio de piel azul, se quejó con su madre preguntándole por qué Radha, su amada, era de piel clara y él no. Su madre, Yashoda, le sugiere juguetonamente que pinte la cara de Radha con los colores que desee. Entonces Krishna la pinta de colores para que ambos se parezcan.

El Holi es, en parte, una celebración del amor entre Krishna y Radha, que va más allá de las diferencias. Hoy en día, parte del gulal que se utiliza durante la festividad es sintético. Pero tradicionalmente los colores proceden de ingredientes naturales, como flores secas, cúrcuma, hojas secas, uvas, bayas, betabel y té.

“Hay un ambiente de libertad”, dijo Singhal, y añadió que ella no duda en lanzar colores sobre su hermano menor, sus padres, sus tíos y sus vecinos.

Todo el mundo participa

La antigua fiesta hindú evita las divisiones religiosas, sociales, políticas y de casta que apuntalan a menudo la sectaria sociedad india. Hindú o no, cualquiera puede ser salpicado con polvo de colores brillantes, o incluso con huevos y cerveza.

Algunos participan en el culto, llamado puja, ofreciendo plegarias a los dioses. Para otros, el Holi es una celebración de la comunidad. El festival involucra a todo el mundo, incluidos a los incautos transeúntes.

“La gente olvida sus malentendidos o enemistades durante esta ocasión y vuelven a ser amigos”, dice Ratikanta Singh, de 63 años, quien a veces escribe sobre Holi, en Assam, en el noreste de India.

El banquete

Cuando no están lanzando gulal, amigos, familiares y vecinos participan en un bufé de platos y bebidas tradicionales. Entre ellos, gujiya, unos dulces fritos rellenos de frutos secos; dahi vada, unos buñuelos de lentejas fritos servidos con yogur; y kanji, bebida tradicional elaborada con zanahorias fermentadas en agua y especias.

Algunos celebran el Holi con thandai, un brebaje de leche verde claro, pétalos de rosa, cardamomo, almendras, semillas de hinojo y otros ingredientes. Desde hace miles de años, la bebida se adereza a veces con bhang, u hojas de marihuana trituradas, que contribuyen al ambiente de juerga.

El Holi tiene raíces ancestrales

La festividad está documentada desde hace siglos en textos hindúes. La tradición es observada por jóvenes y mayores, sobre todo en el norte de India y Nepal, donde se origina la mitología del festival.

El Holi también marca el inicio de las cosechas con la llegada de la primavera en India, donde más de la mitad de la población vive en zonas rurales.

Las tradiciones varían según el país

Las celebraciones del Holi son tan diversas como el subcontinente indio. Son especialmente intensas en el norte de India, considerado el lugar de nacimiento del dios hindú Krishna, donde los festejos pueden durar más de una semana.

En Mathura, ciudad del norte donde se dice que nació Krishna, la gente recrea un relato hindú en el que Krishna visita a Radha para enamorarla y los amigos vaqueros de ella, ofendidos por sus insinuaciones, lo expulsan con palos.

En el estado oriental de Odisha se celebra un festival de un día de duración llamado Dola Purnima. Las grandes procesiones de gente que cargan al hombro carruajes ricamente decorados con estatuas de dioses hindúes son una parte importante de las festividades. Las procesiones están llenas del sonido de tambores, canciones, polvos de colores y pétalos de flores que se lanzan al aire.

En el sur de India, donde el Holi no se celebra tan ampliamente, muchos templos llevan a cabo ritos religiosos. En la comunidad tribal de Kudumbi, en el suroeste, los devotos de los templos cortan palmas de areca y transportan sus troncos al santuario en un ritual que simboliza la victoria del bien sobre el mal.

No solo se celebra en India

Holi se celebra en todo el mundo en donde haya ido la diáspora india. Más de 32 millones de indios y personas de origen indio están en el extranjero, la mayoría en Estados Unidos, donde residen 4,4 millones, según el gobierno indio.

También se disfruta mucho en países tan variados como Fiyi, Mauricio, Sudáfrica, el Reino Unido y otras partes de Europa.

El Holi se conoce como Phagwa en las comunidades indias del Caribe, como Guyana, Surinam y Trinidad y Tobago.

El gobierno indio también ha utilizado el festival para proyectar poder blando y rediseñar su imagen como parte de su campaña turística “India increíble”.

Durante el festival, “el mundo es una aldea global”, dijo Shubham Sachdeva, de 29 años, vecino de un suburbio del este de Delhi, quien añadió que sus amigos de Estados Unidos celebraban Holi con sus compañeros de piso, fueran o no indios. “Todo esto acerca el mundo a los demás”.

John Yoon es un reportero del Times afincado en Seúl que cubre noticias de última hora y de tendencia. Más de John Yoon

Hari Kumar cubre la India desde Nueva Delhi. Es periodista desde hace más de dos décadas. Más de Hari Kumar

Q: “When Putin launched his brutal war of aggression against the people of Ukraine, he thought he could weaken Europe and divide NATO,” Biden said in a statement.

“Instead, in May 2022, Sweden and Finland — two of our close partners, with two highly capable militaries — made the historic decision to apply for full NATO membership," Biden said. ”With the addition of Sweden today, NATO stands more united, determined, and dynamic than ever — now 32 nations strong."

Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson was a guest of honor Thursday evening at Biden's State of the Union address to Congress, where the president welcomed him to “the strongest military alliance the world has ever seen.”

Earlier Thursday, Kristersson and Secretary of State Antony Blinken presided at a ceremony in which Sweden’s “instrument of accession” to the alliance was officially deposited at the State Department.

“This is a historic moment for Sweden. It's historic for the alliance. It's historic for the transatlantic relationship,” Blinken said. “Our NATO alliance is now stronger, larger than it’s ever been.”

“Today is truly a historic day,” Kristersson said. “We are humbled, but we are also proud. We will live up to high expectations from all NATO allies. United we stand. Unity and solidarity will be Sweden’s guiding light."

NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg also described it as “a historic day.”

“Sweden will now take its rightful place at NATO’s table, with an equal say in shaping NATO policies and decisions,” he said in a statement.

The Swedish flag will be raised outside the military organization’s headquarters in Brussels on Monday. Stoltenberg underscored that the Nordic country “now enjoys the protection granted under Article 5, the ultimate guarantee of allies’ freedom and security.”

Article 5 of NATO’s treaty obliges all members to come to the aid of an ally whose territory or security is under threat. It has only been activated once – by the U.S. after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks – and is the collective security guarantee that Sweden has sought since Russia invaded Ukraine.

“Sweden’s accession makes NATO stronger, Sweden safer and the whole alliance more secure,” Stoltenberg said. He added that the move “demonstrates that NATO’s door remains open and that every nation has the right to choose its own path.”

Sweden, along with Finland, which joined NATO last year, both abandoned the long-standing military neutrality that was a hallmark of the Nordic states’ Cold War foreign policy after Russia invaded Ukraine in early 2022.

Biden, in his speech to Congress, stepped up calls for reluctant Republicans to approve stalled military assistance to Ukraine as the war enters its third year.

“If anybody in this room thinks Putin will stop at Ukraine, I assure you he will not," Biden said. “But Ukraine can stop Putin. Ukraine can stop Putin if we stand with Ukraine and provide the weapons it needs to defend itself.”

Biden and his NATO counterparts have vowed that Ukraine will join NATO one day, too.

Sweden’s membership had been held up due to objections by NATO members Turkey and Hungary. Turkey expressed concern that Sweden was harboring and not taking enough action against Kurdish groups that it regards as terrorists, and Hungary's populist President Viktor Orban has shown pro-Russian sentiment and not shared the alliance’s determination to support Ukraine.

After months of delay, Turkey ratified Sweden’s admission earlier this year, and Hungary did so this week.

___

Cook reported from Brussels. AP writers Jan M. Olsen in Copenhagen, Denmark, and Fatima Hussein in Washington contributed.

___

Follow the AP's coverage of NATO at https://apnews.com/hub/nato.

Q: Mersal, who was then a graduate student, thought the author might be related to a novelist and prominent anticolonial figure, Latifa al-Zayyat. She bought the book for one Egyptian pound.

What Mersal found instead was an intimate, introspective novel, an essential but largely forgotten work by a female writer in early contemporary Egypt. The voice, Mersal later wrote, was “modern, strange, limpid and beyond categorization.”

The book moved her, she said, and set her on a nearly 30-year journey to learn what she could about the author, a young Egyptian woman called Enayat al-Zayyat who died by suicide in 1963 after overdosing on pills. All she left was a note by her bed for her son, Abbas, that read: “I do love you, it’s just that life is unbearable. Forgive me.” After her death, her writing fell into oblivion.

In “Traces of Enayat,” translated by Robin Moger and to be published on April 2 in the United States by Transit Books, Mersal revives the story of the late writer. The Arabic version, published in 2019, won the Sheikh Zayed Book Award two years later and was a regional success. A mix of literary genres, the book is a subtle and universal exploration of identity.

“A sense of longing for a place and a self that has left you comes through in the pages,” Adam Levy, the book’s U.S. editor, said.

The book feels like a biography, he said, but it is more ambitious, and more interesting, than that. “As you read,” he added, “you start to feel Iman’s presence in it subtly.”

Mersal, who is now 57 and one of the most consequential Egyptian authors of her generation, grew up in Mit Adlan, a village in the delta of the Nile, in northern Egypt. As a child, she loved language and songs, often shutting herself in her room to listen to music, plays and narrated movies on the radio.

She lost her mother at a young age, and wrote her first poem, a critique of Mother’s Day that started with the phrase “against motherhood,” when she was in fifth grade. She wrote it in anger, she said, and read it out loud during a celebration in the school courtyard.

“One of the toughest teachers cried,” said Mersal, who has two sons. “I call myself a writer since.”

Al-Zayyat came of age during a golden era for Egyptian literature, in the 1950s and 1960s, during Gamal Abdel Nasser’s government. Many influential writers in that era were driven by the urge to transform society. Mersal, too, socialized with writers who wanted to change the world, and joined a feminist publication, “Bint al Ard,” in 1986. But she wasn’t sure what kind of intellectual she wanted to become.

“The literary scene was controlled by the old guard who believed in Arab nationalism or communism, who believed that literature can change the status quo,” she said. “I was thinking about figuring out my own voice. Expressing my relationship with my father, my relationship with Cairo, my city. It was about individuality.”

In 1992, she visited Baghdad to meet with women affected by the Gulf War in Iraq and the brutality of the regime in their own country. It was then that Mersal started questioning her purpose.

“It was transformative. I faced many questions,” said Mersal during an interview from her work studio in Edmonton, Alberta, where she lives. “What does Arab nationalism mean, what does it mean to be a committed writer?”

New perspectives opened up when she discovered “Love and Silence,” another woman’s honest chronicle of suffering and self-discovery. The book, which came out four years after al-Zayyat’s death, tells the story of Najla, a young woman who is grieving the recent loss of her brother and figuring out her place in a fraught political context. The narrator’s unfiltered voice sketches Najla’s attempts at finding herself, failing brutally each time.

Though al-Zayyat’s book had its flaws, Mersal said, it was life-altering. Mersal had been facing depression and searching for meaning in her life, she said. “This book spoke to me in a way no other female writer spoke to me.”

Mersal moved to the United States in 1998 and later to Canada, where she has lived since as an academic, poet, translator and author. Al-Zayyat grew up in a very different world, among the high society of Cairo.

Over the years, Mersal took her time to carefully navigate al-Zayyat’s world. She includes this journey in her book, taking the reader to places few can access, such as a meeting with al-Zayyat’s childhood friend, the iconic Egyptian actress Nadia Lutfi.

Al-Zayyat grew up in a loving family and was particularly close to her father, but struggled with depression most of her life. She had a passion for drawing and painting but stopped studying before she turned 19 to marry a man from an affluent family. The marriage was agonizing, and soon ended in a bitter divorce.

In Mersal’s book, an entry from al-Zayyat’s journal dated 1962 captured her pain. “I don’t mean a thing to anybody. Lost, found, it’s all the same: Here is as good as gone. The world wouldn’t tremble either way. When I walk I leave no tracks, like I walk on water, and I am unseen, invisible.”

What led al-Zayyat to end her life is uncertain. A commercial film and a radio series were made based on her novel. Both disappointed Mersal and al-Zayyat’s niece. They felt that, among other issues, the productions had erased the substance of the novel and focused on elements of the plot.

During her last months, al-Zayyat lived in an apartment that her father built for her on the second floor of their villa in Dokki, then a wealthy residential suburb of Cairo. She wrote on a newly-acquired Optima typewriter, and was committed to getting her book published. At the same time, she was losing custody of her son in court.

After her mother received a call from the publishing house saying that the manuscript had been rejected, al-Zayyat chopped off her hair and locked herself in the apartment. According to Mersal, who spoke to the author’s sister and to her best friend, she was found dead the next day.

It seemed that being part of the upper class limited her possibilities, Mersal explained — as if society had disappointed her so much that death was the only form of protest that remained.

“The idea that a young woman would kill herself — a young woman with a son, a father and a best friend — and all because of a book, was genuinely tragic, but it was also seductive in its tragedy,” Mersal wrote in the book. “I pictured Enayat painstakingly acquiring the rudiments of good Arabic grammar and inflection, then carefully setting down everything she wanted to say in her novel, then refusing the suggestion that she should self-publish.”

Mersal had many questions that she attempted to answer over her long years of obsessive research, but her intent never was to write a biography or a history book, she said.

“Telling the story of searching for Enayat was my way of reading her life and not displaying her life,” she said. “My dream was to tell our story, my story, her story, this interaction between us. The past is not that glorious. It’s the collective and individual wounds of this past.”

When Mersal finished writing the book, she struggled with emptiness and sadness that echoed al-Zayyat’s.

“It felt like a friend died,” she said. “It was a weird feeling of mourning.”

Q: Japan to provide $6m in grant aid to Maldives

The Maldives and Japan on 25 March signed four agreements, under which Japan will provide $6m in grant aid to the Maldives. The agreements were signed by Minister of Foreign Affairs Moosa Zameer and ambassador of Japan to Maldives, Takeuchi Midori. The four agreements were on the provision of a patrol vessel to the Maldives Customs Service (MCS), a grant of 260m Japanese Yen for the implementation of the project for the enhancement of ability in maritime safety and security, a grant of 600m Japanese Yen for the provision of equipment toward strengthening Maldives' national response capacity to high frequent natural hazards through community empowerment, and a grant of 56m Japanese Yen for the provision of equipment to support operations of patrol vessels to the MCS. [Online, Approximate Words: 120]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Mihaaru

'Miscommunication' behind India boarding Maldivian vessels

Minister of Defence Mohamed Ghassan Maumoon on 25 March said India has officially informed the Maldives that its navy officers had boarded three Maldivian fishing vessels in Maldivian waters due to a "miscommunication". Responding to questions from lawmakers in parliament, the minister said India has also informed the Maldives that its navy had boarded the vessels because they had had satellite phones and that they had believed it was illegal. The minister said while the use of satellite phones in Indian waters was banned after an amendment to certain Indian regulations, it was mandatory under Maldivian regulations to have one, especially if the vessels venture outside a certain distance. Responding to a question by Member of Parliament for Hulhumale, Ali Niyaz, on whether the minister believed in the response, the minister said he believed it had been a miscommunication, and that the Maldivian Chief of Defence Force, who had been in India on an official visit at the time, had also been informed by senior policy-level Indian officials of the same. The minister, however, said there are various established channels between neighbouring countries to provide information to each other when such operations are undertaken on the seas, but that it was surprising that no information had been shared on the operation undertaken where the Indian Navy had boarded the Maldivian vessels. The minister also confirmed that the Maldivian vessels had been inside Maldivian waters prior to and when the operation was conducted and had not ventured into Indian waters. He added that future measures will include increased coordination between all countries and establish a mechanism to work together, as well as increase the capability within the Maldives to monitor its own borders, which the government has already started. [Online, Approximate Words: 560]

President says drones to be operated by Maldivians

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu on 25 March said the military drones being utilised to monitor the Maldives' Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) will be operated exclusively by Maldivian military personnel and that no foreign soldiers will be based in the Maldives to do so. Responding to a question from a member of the public on the daily "President's Answer" series, the president said he does not support any foreign military presence being established in the Maldives, and noted that a team from the Maldives National Defence Force (MNDF) has undergone training in Turkey on operating the drones, and that further teams will be trained in the coming days. [Online, Approximate Words: 330]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

Minister clarifies approval given to Chinese vessel

Minister of Defence Ghassan Maumoon on 25 March said in parliament that approval for Chinese research vessel Xian Yang Hong 3 to enter the Maldives Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) had been provided after considering established procedures and that no approval had been given for the vessel to conduct any kind of research in the Maldives. Responding to questions from lawmakers in parliament, the minister added that the vessel had been active in the Maldives region in 2022 as well, similar to its recent visit to the region. The minister said that approval had been given only to dock to change crew and take on supplies. [Online, Approximate Words: 360]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

Minister to share drone purchase details at closed session

Minister of Defence Ghassan Maumoon on 25 March said in parliament that he will provide information on the drones purchased by the government for the monitoring of the Maldives' EEZ at the parliament committee on security services. Responding to questions by lawmakers on the cost of the purchase, the minister said given that it is information related to the military and national security, he cannot disclose such details at a general session of parliament but will share it at a close session of the committee. He assured the parliament that the drones had been purchased in accordance to the Maldivian constitution and laws, and that the government will share all documentation related to the purchase at the closed committee meeting, if required. Opposition Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP) has alleged corruption in the purchase of the drones. [Online, Approximate Words: 260]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

President says China to develop all roads in capital

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu on 25 March said all roads in capital Male will be developed by China under grant assistance. At an event to inaugurate the campaign hall for a candidate contesting in the forthcoming parliament election, the president highlighted that the government's top priorities for the Male region are housing and road development. He announced that China has agreed to develop all the roads in Male under a grant. [Online, Approximate Words: 100]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 26 Mar 24

Q: "Lithuania and Poland share the same understanding of security threats," Nauseda's office quoted him as saying in Poland. "We will continue to work together to strengthen the security of our countries and the entire NATO Eastern flank."

Nauseda emphasised that Russia will remain the main and long-term military threat to the Alliance as a whole, thus Lithuania sees close security cooperation with Poland as a strategic priority, his office said.

According to the president, Poland is directly involved in bolstering the security of the Baltic region, actively participates in NATO's Baltic air policing mission and takes part in joint military exercises.

"I am confident that we will continue to strengthen our partnership through security initiatives, as well as through the joint development of the defence industry," he said.

Nauseda and Duda observed allied forces' joint operation of crossing the Vistula River.

Dragon 2024 is part of NATO's Steadfast Defender 24, the largest NATO exercise in Europe since the Cold War.

The exercise in Poland "will certify Allied forces for deterrence and defence tasks, prepare for a potential aggression against NATO Allies and executive combat actions across land, air and maritime domains", the Lithuanian Armed Forces have said in a press release.

"The centerpiece operation of Dragon 24 is deployment of the Very High Readiness Joint Task Force in assistance to an Ally in the event of aggression which will also highlight the nuances and potential challenges of military mobility across national borders," the military said.

After the exercise, Germany's "enhanced Vigilance Brigade battalion will relocate for continued training in Lithuania as of March 7".

The exercise is taking place amid discussions in Lithuania about whether Poland's laws would allow it to defend its neighbour in the event of an attack.

Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte said last week that Poland's legal restrictions "do not provide for an obligation" to send troops abroad, even in the event of war.

In response, Nauseda said that joint Polish-Lithuanian exercises were aimed at the two neighbouring countries acting together.

Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk said during his visit to Vilnius on Monday that that the solidarity between the two countries was unquestionable.

Q: Sweden’s accession to Nato is like the last piece of the puzzle that will turn the Baltic Sea region into one whole picture.

"It means a faster exchange of information. It also means that it will be easier to plan with them. If we look at the geographical map, it is clear that there will be no gaps in the Baltic states, that we know that Sweden is with us from the start," said colonel Eero Rebo, chief of the Defence League’s [voluntary arm of Estonian Defence Forces] General Staff.

"In this context the Gotland island is very important, which in principle is a big lock of the Baltic Sea. Somewhat similar to what Iceland is for the Atlantic, hence strategically very important," noted Margus Kolga, former Estonian ambassador to Sweden.

Sweden has a strong navy with long-lasting traditions, which can skilfully operate on the Baltic Sea. Its submarines are also important.

"Militarily, submarines are a hidden resource or hidden capability. Those who have them can conduct operations with other, significantly more comprehensive methods than others," said Kolga.

Sweden’s navy has been specifically developed for operation in the Baltic Sea region. The submarines are therefore smaller, they have never been designed for operation in the North Atlantic, for example," said security expert Martin Hurt.

There has been much talk about the strength of Sweden’s navy, but they have also other capabilities.

"Certainly one key capability is air superiority. To my knowledge, Sweden has 120 Gripen fighter aircraft, which is a very, very potent military force," Kolga said.

"Sweden’s airports will increase options. Also, all kind of dispersion of aircraft is good and this allows to add depth to our defence activities," Rebo said.

Sweden also contributes to Nato with advance warning systems. They also have significant intelligence capability and defence industry.

"Sweden is allegedly one of the few European states that produces military platforms in all military dimensions and for all weapon types. There are supposedly only four such states in Europe. Besides Sweden, also the United Kingdom, France and Germany. These are also historically very deep and long-term and technologically advanced solutions," Kolga said.

But Sweden’s land force has decreased in the past decade. According to Hurt, after the Cold War it focused on expedition forces and field operations.

"When Sweden’s defence forces began to be strengthened after Crimea’s occupation in 2014 and the start of Russia’s aggression against Ukraine, then clearly too little money was allocated for that, hence this defence capability is certainly in a developmental stage," he said.

"If we look at Sweden’s 12-billion annual budget then this allows them develop very fast in the future. Especially because they have in industrial base," Rebo noted.

Even though Nato’s Baltic Sea puzzle is now ready, there is still the outstanding question of how well various pieces fit together. The military command and planning of the alliance has been divided between different joint force commands. Denmark and Finland are under Brunssum in the Netherlands, while Norway is under US-based Norfolk. Now Sweden is also looking to the USA. This has led to a fear that the Baltic states will remain on the border of two commands and planning.

"Sweden is partly a Baltic Sea state but partly also an Arctic state and it is looking towards the north, and historically has always done so. Sweden has somewhat different interests than Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. The decisions about where those borders will be drawn between different Nato joint force commands, have not been made yet," said Hurt.

This border is an imaginary border, which can be coordinated and about which either additional plans can be developed, or partial plans with which Sweden can also support the Baltic states," Rebo said.

According to Rebo, it is obvious that with Sweden’s membership, Nato’s defence activities will become more effective and that this will also reduce the Russian threat.

"If we speak about Kaliningrad, then from the Russian perspective their chances of success on the sea and in skies will decrease, which means that the defence of the Suwalki gap will be an increasingly important issue for our southern neighbours," Rebo said.

"Supplying Kaliningrad is complicated already in peacetime, but in a time of war it will become even clearer that Sweden would not passively observe when Russia is trying to supply Kaliningrad," Hurt said.

According to Hurt, no military-technical revolution will take place in Sweden upon accession to Nato.

"Rather this is about changing the mindsets of people, which is important and will certainly take years. Until now, Sweden has gotten used to being outside alliances, which means that for a long time it has assumed that it will remain outside military conflicts," Hurt said.

(See the original here.)

Source: ERR News website, Tallinn, in Estonian 1922 GMT 3 Mar 24

Q: The 22 March assault, which claimed the lives of over 130 people at a concert hall on the outskirts of Moscow, came a day after another IS-claimed bombing killed over 20 people in the southern Afghan city of Kandahar. Condemning the Moscow attack, the Taliban have called on the region to coordinate efforts against IS.

Speaking to Afghan Shamshad TV's Tawda Bahsona (Heated Discussions) talk show on 24 March, a Kabul-based analyst, Habibullah Janebdar reiterated the Taliban stance on the region's coordination, criticising regional countries for failing to recognise the ruling group and engaging in "proper" interaction with it.

"If there was coordination, such incidents would not have happened," he told Shamshad. "Neighbouring countries should learn a good lesson from such incidents and engage in full interaction with Afghanistan if they really want to work for peace for their citizens."

Janebdar lauded the Taliban fight against IS over the past three years of their return to power, saying that the group is preventing the threat to regional countries for free. 

Asked what assistance Russia should provide to the Taliban in the fight against IS, Janebdar put recognition of the ruling group as the first step that Moscow should take followed by encouraging Russian investments in the country, saying that internal shortcomings of the Taliban should be set aside.

When asked about Russia's recent hosting of anti-Taliban figures' conference, he advised Moscow to "learn a lesson from its past" in Afghanistan, saying: "Those pursuing good relations with Afghanistan make a gain, and those pursuing the policy of expansionism towards Afghanistan, be that the then policy of the Great Britain or tsarist Russia, have made a loss".

Another analyst from Moscow, Yahya Chaosh, accused France and the US of being behind the Moscow assault, which according to him was carried out by Tajik nationals, saying that Paris is "practically at war with Russia".

According to him, France has established close ties with Tajikistan through "fugitive" anti-Taliban former Afghan government officials, who he alleged have allied with IS's Khorasan branch to fight the Taliban.

Asked what are the objectives behind the attacks in Kandahar and Moscow, Chaosh described IS as a "common enemy created by Western intelligence to gain common interests in Afghanistan, Russia and other countries which oppose the policies of the United States of America".

Asked how regional countries would be able to fend off the IS threat, Chaosh stressed the need for intelligence cooperation between regional countries, including Afghanistan, saying he believed that "after his re-election, Russian President Vladimir Putin is determined to have very close relations with Afghanistan".

Another commentator, the US-based university lecturer Samsor Safi said: "I would like to condemn in the strongest terms the terrorist attacks in Kandahar and Moscow." He alleged that Tajikistan and Pakistan were involved in orchestrating both the Kandahar and Moscow attacks, suggesting that these assaults were conducted under the "direction of the West". He warned that the recent growing ties between Pakistan and Tajikistan could pose a "major threat" to the region.

"These two are going against the normal tide in the region, and this normal tide is the fact that the world has now become bipolar with Russia, China and India being in the East block… whilst Tajikistan and Pakistan are acting in contrary, which clearly shows that they are guided by the other side." 

He also called on regional countries to cooperate with the Taliban in eliminating the "common problem", saying: "The first thing Russia should do is to recognise the Afghan government, with China and Central Asia countries following suit."

According to him, regional countries should hould refrain from blaming the Taliban's internal policies and focus on regional cooperation against the "major threat" of IS.

Source: Shamshad TV, Kabul, in Pashto, 24 Mar 24

It speculated at the time that the reasoning behind that may have been that it should be easier to make a convicted person go back to war.

IStories said Russia had secured the release of a total of 2,000 service personnel since the start of the war, but it could not give the exact figure because in some cases the Russian authorities withheld numbers.

It also said it was aware of cases of Chechen units "buying out" Ukrainian prisoners of war to subsequently swap them for Chechen troops. There have also been unofficial swaps on the front line.

Khochu Zhit is a Ukrainian government project set up to encourage Russian servicemen to surrender. It promises humane treatment in line with the international conventions and opportunities to seek asylum in Ukraine or outside it or return to Russia in a prisoner swap.

Q: He had last played a T20 against Sri Lanka in July 2024, when coach Gautam Gambhir took up the job. Since then, India has experimented in the T20 arena with Suryakumar Yadav as skipper.

Gill, who leads Gujarat Titans in the Indian Premier League, scored 650 runs in the 2025 season and couldn’t be ignored further after his success in England.

“He was the vice-captain when we last played in Sri Lanka and the new T20 cycle had begun. However, we got busy with test cricket and he didn’t get opportunities (in T20s). We are happy to have him back,” said Yadav, who has been retained as skipper.

India and Pakistan resume cricket ties

The 2025 Asia Cup will be played in the United Arab Emirates from Sept. 9. Dubai and Abu Dhabi will host the 19 matches, with the Dubai International Stadium hosting the final on Sept. 28.

The tournament will also mark a resumption of cricket ties between India and Pakistan – after escalating military tensions earlier this year with both the IPL and the Pakistan Super League halted briefly.

India and Pakistan will first meet in Group A on Sept. 14, with another game slated for the next round – Super Four – potentially on Sept. 21. Both matches will be played in Dubai. There could be a third possible clash in the final, if both sides make it that far in the tournament.

Bumrah back, Iyer and Jaiswal miss out

Pacer Jasprit Bumrah returns to the T20 squad for the first time since the 2024 World Cup. He played only three tests on the English tour because of fitness and workload management.

Shreyas Iyer, who led Punjab Kings to the 2025 IPL final and scored 604 runs in 17 games, is one of the two big names to miss out. Iyer had played a stellar role in India’s 2025 Champions Trophy win in March.

Yashasvi Jaiswal also missed out – the left-handed opener had scored 411 runs in five tests against England and 559 runs for Rajasthan Royals in the 2025 IPL. However, there was no place for a fourth opening option in the Indian squad after Gill’s inclusion.

“It is unfortunate (to leave Jaiswal out). With what Abhishek Sharma has done over the last year or so with the bat, and he gives us a bowling option as well, one of these guys was always going to miss out," chief selector Ajit Agarkar said. "It’s the same with Iyer – no fault of his, but who will he replace?”

Tilak Varma, Shivam Dube, Hardik Pandya and Rinku Singh will form the middle order for India, leaving Iyer out. Jitesh Sharma is included as the second keeper-batter option after Sanju Samson, but it isn’t clear who will open the innings for India given Gill’s inclusion.

“The captain and the coach will take a call on the best balance for the team," Agarkar said. "Once we get to Dubai, we will have a bit more clarity on the conditions. There are more options available to us – Shubman is in great form, as is Sanju. So we have two good options along with Abhishek.”

Spinners Axar Patel, Kuldeep Yadav and Varun Chakravarthy, along with pacers Bumrah, Harshit Rana and Arshdeep Singh complete the bowling core for India.

Neutral venue

The 2025 Asia Cup is officially hosted by India. Under an Asian Cricket Council decision, the tournament is held in a neutral venue whenever India or Pakistan is the host.

The 2023 Asia Cup (played in ODI format) was split between Pakistan and Sri Lanka, with the latter hosting all Indian games along with the final.

Q: The former president, Juan Orlando Hernández, has been on trial for two weeks in Federal District Court, facing charges that he conspired to import cocaine into the United States. Prosecutors said that he worked with ruthless drug gangs like the Sinaloa Cartel, led by the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzman Loera, better known as El Chapo.

Government witnesses have included a string of former traffickers from Honduras who testified that they bribed Mr. Hernández in return for promises that he would insulate them from investigations and protect them from extradition to the United States.

Dressed in a dark suit with a blue shirt and tie, Mr. Hernández sat up straight during his testimony and sometimes gave long, discursive answers that prompted the judge overseeing the trial to rein him in.

At other times his answers were terse.

“Did you ever receive a bribe from El Chapo?” one of Mr. Hernández’s lawyers asked at one point.

“Never,” Mr. Hernández replied.

He gave the same answer to successive questions about whether he had ever met El Chapo, his traffickers or anyone purporting to be a member of the Sinaloa cartel.

When one of his lawyers asked if he had promised cartels that he would protect them, Mr. Hernández answered: “On the contrary, sir. The problem was that we were going to terminate them.”

Throughout the trial, rows of benches in the courtroom have been filled with Hondurans attending to watch Mr. Hernández face a judicial process of the sort some doubted could have taken place in Honduras. Those who could not find a seat in the courtroom have instead watched the proceedings on a tall screen in an overflow room on a different floor of the courthouse.

During Mr. Hernández’s direct testimony on Tuesday, some in the courtroom gallery were rapt. At times others laughed derisively, and on one occasion a statement by Mr. Hernández was met with a long hiss.

It is almost always considered risky for a criminal defendant to testify because friendly questions from a defense lawyer are typically followed by a pointed cross-examination from prosecutors.

Some defendants decide to testify because they believe they can sway jurors; others may choose to take the stand when they feel that the tide of a trial is going against them and they have little to lose.

While cross-examining Mr. Hernández on Tuesday afternoon, a prosecutor asked him why various accused traffickers whose extradition had been requested by the United States had not been handed over while he was president. Mr. Hernández replied that his administration had referred all extradition requests to the Honduran Supreme Court.

Later, the prosecutor asked Mr. Hernández about a photograph taken during the 2010 World Cup in South Africa that showed him with a man named Miguel Arnulfo Valle Valle, who was a leader of a violent drug gang. Mr. Hernández replied that he believed the picture had been the subject of a debate over whether it was fake or a “photomontage.”

“The person with his arm around you is Arnulfo Valle?” the prosecutor asked.

Mr. Hernández replied: “Sir, I don’t know Mr. Arnulfo Valle.”

During his political career as a member of the right-wing Honduran National Party, Mr. Hernández was seen as adept at accumulating power and willing to use it, sometimes bluntly.

When the Supreme Court threw out laws he had pushed through while serving as president of the Honduran Congress, the Congress simply replaced four justices. Later, the Supreme Court changed rules to allow Mr. Hernández to serve a second term as president of Honduras.

Political opponents claimed that both the presidential contests that Mr. Hernández won, in 2013 and 2017, were marred by fraud. Prosecutors in New York said that he financed both with drug money. Distrust of the 2017 election results led to protests that blocked roads and bridges.

Prosecutors said that Mr. Hernández gave money to a political party colleague who paid gang members to commit violence, and that demonstrators died during confrontations with security forces that followed.

By the time his second term ended, Mr. Hernández was deeply unpopular. His administration had failed to curb crime or create a healthy economy, which led in part to migration from Honduras. His successor as president, Xiomara Castro, accused Mr. Hernández of having turned the country into a “narco-dictatorship.” Thousands of Hondurans celebrated when he was extradited to New York.

On Tuesday, Mr. Hernández portrayed himself as a stalwart partner of U.S. officials in their fight to stem the flow of drugs over the country’s southern border. He said that he had several meetings about that with U.S. officials, including Gen. John Kelly, then the commander of the U.S. Army Southern Command.

“I asked General Kelly to help us in our fight against drug trafficking,” Mr. Hernández said, adding: “The Southern Command helped us set up an elite force that we called the Tigers.”

As Mr. Hernández was being cross-examined, spectators in the overflow room were more animated than those who had watched in the courtroom. At times laughter echoed in the room, including when Mr. Hernández professed puzzlement over the World Cup photo that showed him with Mr. Valle.

After the court session ended, Mr. Hernández buttoned his suit jacket, rose from the witness stand and was led by a federal marshal back to the seat at the defense table that he had occupied since the trial began.

Q: Therefore, the NBS calls for a critical assessment of the tendentious speculations from various sources in the information space about a possible increase of the threat in Europe, including Latvia.

The NBS also calls on the public not to share these messages in order not to support the Russian propaganda machine in its attempts to sow fear about a possible Russian attack on Latvia or another NATO member state.

The NBS also points out that Russia's military failure to prevail and the huge loss of resources in the more than two years of fighting in Ukraine are a sign of its systemic weakness and stagnation at all levels of its command. Moreover, for Russia to attack a NATO member state, a number of preconditions must be met and a specific situation must be created. The NBS therefore draws attention to the fact that such preconditions do not exist for Russian aggression against NATO members.

The NBS reminds that Latvia has been a member of the world's strongest alliance for almost 20 years. An attack on Latvia would mean an attack on all member states, followed by an immediate response from NATO.

Recently, populist speculations about the inability of the NBS to defend the country have been expressed in the Latvian information space by various Latvian and foreign voices. Therefore, the NBS calls on the public to maintain a cool head, not to share or amplify such messages - especially those disseminated by persons who are no longer serving in the armed forces, or who have not been involved in the defence sector at all. By sharing questionable messages, these individuals are unwittingly or knowingly doing a service to Russia's aggressive propaganda messages.

"We, soldiers and servicemen, do not take peace for granted. Like the Lithuanians and Estonians and the soldiers of other NATO member states, we prepare for war every day so that it does not happen. This is our chosen vocation and duty towards Latvia and our responsibility for every resident of our country. Instead of propagating populist posts on social media, we invite everyone to strengthen national security by joining the National Guard, the National Defence Service, or by learning basic military skills in the Volunteer Reservist Course," reads the NBS statement.

In conclusion, the NBS underlines that the security situation in Latvia is as stable and comparable to the security situation in other NATO member states not bordering Russia, such as Spain, France or Italy.

Q: Election body allows ex-president's party to amend applications

The Election Commission on 12 January announced that 1,976 of the over 3,000 application forms, submitted to the commission by the People's National Front (PNF) to register the party, are valid. Commission vice-president Ismail Habeeb said the PNF had submitted 3,370 application forms, which the commission has verified, rejecting 81 forms, and allowing the party to further complete 1,313 forms on issues such as dates and other administrative issues. Former president Abdulla Yameen had resigned from the Progressive Party of Maldives (PPM) and People's National Congress (PNC) coalition right after the party's candidate (President Dr Mohamed Muizzu) was elected president, and commenced efforts to establish his new political party, the PNF. The Election Commission had given the go-ahead for the party to commence work to establish the party on 29 November. Former science minister Mohamed Maleeh Jamal, who was leading the party's membership drive, had at the time said the required 3,000 application forms would be submitted within 24 hours. Following delays till December, he had said the party was delaying the submission until Yameen was freed. Yameen is currently serving an 11-year prison sentence, issued on 25 December 2022, which he is currently serving under house arrest. [Online, Approximate Words: 240]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

Poll panel approves retirement benefits for members

The Election Commission has amended its regulations and approved a retirement package for members. The amendment, published in the government gazette on 28 February, states that an employee, after reaching 55 years of age, has the option to request to retire with benefits, and gives the commission to authority to instruct an employee to retire as well. Retirement benefits include a bulk payment at the outset, based on 15 years of service, as well as 75% of their monthly salaries at the time of retirement paid monthly for life. The regulation also allows for a current employee, who is appointed as a member of the commission, to be eligible for retirement benefits, if they have served the commission for a total of at least 10 years (as an employee and a commission member cumulatively). The retirement packages were formulated and introduced allowing for the five current members to also benefit from the retirement package. Current vice-president Ismail Habeeb's term at the commission will end on 13 March. [Online, Approximate Words: 340]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

Maldives aims to host ITB Berlin fair in 2026

Minister of Tourism Ibrahim Faisal on 12 March announced the government's objective of hosting the 2026 ITB Berlin fair. The minister, speaking to the press on the ITB fair held from 5 to 7 March, said the Maldives is the world's most popular tourist destination, and as such the government is aiming for the objective of hosting the world's biggest tourism fair. He added that the Maldives Marketing and Public Relations Corporation (MMPRC) will be holding discussions with stakeholders to make the necessary preparations and arrangements to do so in 2026. The Maldives had last hosted the ITB fair in 2016. The Maldives was represented at the 2024 fair by 214 delegates from 107 companies. [Online, Approximate Words: 220]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

Parliament approves counting total seats without vacant ones

The Maldivian parliament on 12 March voted against implementing a Supreme Court ruling on the constitutional case, where it stated that the number of seats in parliament must be counted including vacant seats. Opposition Member of Parliament for Villingili constituency Saud Hussain submitted a motion to parliament proposing that vacant seats not be counted in determining the total number of lawmakers in parliament and session quora. The motion was seconded by The Democrats' Member of Parliament Eva Abdulla, and the motion was passed with voted from 25 lawmakers for and two against. Speaker of Parliament Mohamed Aslam had, at the session on 12 March, initially proposed voting on revoking changes to parliament rules of procedure on the issue, in light of the Supreme Court verdict. [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

Court orders incumbent lawmaker to pay decreed debt

The Civil Court on 29 February ordered incumbent Member of Parliament for Dhuvaafaru constituency, Ismail Ahmed, to settled 856,830 rufiyaa ($55,566) in outstanding payments to Ismail Haleel, a sub-contractor. The court, in its ruling, said Ahmed had entered a contract (in 2018) to construct three classrooms in Kandoodhoo School in Thaa Atoll and made a verbal agreement with Haleel to implement the project in 2018. The contract was valued at 1.2m rufiyaa ($84,306), of which Ahmed had paid 425,000 rufiyaa ($27,567). The Civil Court issued the ruling in absentia as Ahmed had failed to appear in court or responded to the court, after accepting the summons. Ahmed is currently campaigning for the upcoming parliament election in his current constituency, on a ticket from opposition Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP). Under the constitution, a decreed debt and failure to pay the debt will result in the lawmaker not meeting the conditions required to be a member of parliament. As such, if Ahmed fails to pay the outstanding within 15 days of the ruling, his seat may be at risk. [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

Lawmaker responds to decreed debt verdict

Member of Parliament or Dhuvaafaru constituency Ismail Ahmed on 12 March filed a case at court requesting that a verdict against him to the outstanding on payments to a sub-contractor, be annulled. In a statement he issued, Ahmed said the Civil Court had previously overseen the same case, ruling in 2020 that there are no outstanding payments from him to Haleel (and as such the same case cannot be filed at the same court – double jeopardy). [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 13 Mar 24

Q: IS published the set of 25 photos in the name of its so-called Mozambique Province branch on 10 March via its channels on Telegram .

The images show militants engaged in a wide range of activities, including performing group prayers, watching videos, feasting together, attending lectures, and preparing and setting off for battle.

They were published a day before the start of Ramadan, which most Muslims marked on 11 March.

Such "daily life" images used to be a staple of IS propaganda in the jihadist group's heyday, and used for recruitment when it controlled large swathes of territory in Syria, Iraq and elsewhere. They became scarce over the years.

The last time the group published such images was in July 2022, depicting the "daily life" of militants in Syria.

The latest Mozambique images suggest that militants in that country now enjoy relative strength and security in areas where they operate.

They compliment the group's recent surge in the north of the country, where it has been claiming a significant number of attacks this year mostly against Christian communities, as well as reaching out to Muslims in the region.

See: Analysis: Islamic State violence surges in northern Mozambique

The images

The latest images show militants in what appears to be a dense forest area. The images' captions do not specify the location where the images were taken, but it is likely to be in the northern Cabo Delgado province, where IS is most active.

Some of the images show about a dozen men performing prayers together. Other images show militants reading the Quran.

One image shows a militant on watch duty, while other photos show dozens of militants "preparing" for battle.

A couple of other photos show militants watching what appears to be a recent video by IS's Afghanistan-focused Khorasan Province branch (ISKP).

Other photos shows militants slaughtering a goat, cooking the meat and eating together.

One set of images depicts a group of masked, armed men listening to what appears to be battle instructions by other men who are standing.

A final couple of photos show dozens of men "heading to fight crusaders".

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 1703 gmt 10 Mar 24

Q: Speaking at the India-Russia Inter-Governmental Commission for Trade, Economic, Scientific, Technological and Cultural Cooperation meeting in Moscow, alongside Russia's First Deputy Prime Minister Denis Manturov, Jaishankar said the trade imbalance has risen to $58.9bn and called for addressing it "urgently", according to a readout by India's Ministry of External Affairs (MEA).

The growing trade imbalance has mainly been attributed to India stepping up oil purchases from Russia in the aftermath of the Ukraine war.

The minister stated that "addressing tariff and non-tariff trade barriers, removing bottlenecks in logistics", promoting connectivity through key corridors, enhancing payment mechanisms, and the "early conclusion" of a Free Trade Agreement (FTA) between India and the countries of the Eurasian region are among key steps which will help the two sides "to address the imbalance and grow our trade".

The terms of reference for the FTA between India and the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU) were finalised during the Moscow meeting on 20 August.

Jaishankar highlighted that the meeting was taking place against "the backdrop of a complex geopolitical situation" and urged that both should move beyond "the beaten track" by diversifying the trade basket.

Separately, addressing the India-Russia Business Forum, the minister urged Russian companies to engage "more intensively" with their Indian counterparts.

"Both the diversification and balancing of trade now urgently mandate more strenuous efforts on our part," he said.

Jaishankar is on a three-day visit to Russia aimed at strengthening what Delhi described as a "time-tested" strategic partnership. He was scheduled to hold talks with his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov on 21 August.
