Q: Neither was hurt, and they continued their visit of Odesa, a strategic port city. It is unclear how close they were to the explosion, and a Ukrainian Army spokeswoman, Natalia Humeniuk, denied that the attack had specifically targeted the state leaders. “This is in no way related to a specific visit,” she said.

Mr. Mitsotakis said at a news conference in Odesa that he and Mr. Zelensky were visiting the city’s port at the time of the assault. “We heard the sound of sirens and explosions that were very close to us,” he said. “We didn’t have time to go to a shelter.”

Dmytro Pletenchuck, a spokesman for the Ukrainian Navy, said that Russia had struck port infrastructure in the city and that five people had been killed. Ms. Humeniuk said Russia had most likely used ballistic missiles.

“You see who we are dealing with,” Mr. Zelensky said. “They don’t care where they strike, whether they are military, civilians, international guests — it doesn’t matter to these people.”

Oleksiy Goncharenko, a Ukrainian lawmaker who was in Odesa at the time of the attack, said it occurred around 10:40 a.m. “I heard explosions, I was very close to the port,” he said in a text message. “It was very loud.”

Russia said that its army had launched “a high-precision missile strike on a hangar in the industrial port area of Odesa were preparations were being made for the combat use of unmanned boats of the Ukrainian Armed Forces.”

Ukraine has frequently used sea drones to target vessels of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet. On Tuesday, it claimed to have sunk a patrol ship off the coast of Russian-occupied Crimea. “This is the third Russian Black Sea Fleet vessel sunk in the past five weeks,” Britain’s military intelligence said.

Odesa, a lifeline for the Ukrainian economy, is home to a vast port infrastructure vital to Ukraine’s Black Sea exports. Many vessels depart from the port to ship grain and other agricultural products across the Black Sea.

But for past six months, Russia has been targeting grain silos and naval infrastructure with drones and missiles. “They are trying to attack and destroy the potential of a country that is at war and is trying to rebuild its economy to support the front,” Ms. Humeniuk said.

The attacks have also caused civilian casualties, either from direct targeting or falling debris. Last week, a drone hit a residential building, killing 12 civilians. It took rescue workers several days to pull the bodies from the rubble, including those of babies and children.

Mr. Zelensky and Mr. Mitsotakis visited the site of last week’s attack on Wednesday to pay tribute to the victims, laying bouquets of flowers at a makeshift memorial in front of the building. They also visited a cathedral badly damaged by a previous Russian missile strike.

The Ukrainian leader said at the news conference that Wednesday’s attack “speaks to the fact that we need to defend ourselves first and foremost.”

Oleksandra Mykolyshyn contributed reporting.

Q: Three thousand observers are set to monitor the upcoming presidential election in Volgograd Region, as reported by GTRK Volgograd TV. The regional public chamber will be responsible for their preparation, as outlined in an agreement signed on 8 February. Public observers will monitor the adherence to election laws at polling stations and cross-check information in media and social networks. The effort involves 26 public organisations and five political parties. A public observation centre will be operated by the public chamber during the voting days from 15 to 17 March. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

Trusted representatives of Leonid Slutsky, the presidential candidate of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia, meet residents of Volgograd Region at his electoral headquarters twice a week. Currently, 10 representatives operate in the region, focusing on listening to people and providing consultations. According to experts, the youth, aged 18 to 35, actively express civic engagement, with inquiries often related to social issues. Older residents inquire about pension matters, housing, communal services, and food prices. Street surveys are also conducted to gather opinions and requests, contributing to a regional database of appeals, with an effectiveness rate of around 40%. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

Political

Russian President Vladimir Putin awarded six residents of Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. According to his decree signed on 5 February, the medals of For Merit to the Fatherland Order 2nd class were conferred to Frolovo mayor Vasily Dankov and Muslim Ganiyev, the senior research associate of the department of the All-Russian Scientific Research Institute of Irrigated Agriculture of the Kostyakov Federal Scientific Centre of Hydrotechnics and Reclamation's branch. The head of the peasant farm enterprise, Vladimir Obyedkov, was awarded the For Work in Agriculture medal. The chairman of the agricultural production cooperative, Pavel Dubrovin, and heads of peasant farm enterprises, Andrei Lippardt and Ruslan Pakhomov, were bestowed with the Honoured Worker of Agriculture titles. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The mayor of the town of Leninsk, Dmitry Smirnov, was removed from his position due to a scandal involving violations in public procurement, the Novosti Volgograda website reported. Following an inspection by the prosecutor's office, which revealed a conflict of interest in public procurement, lawmakers of the urban settlement decided to terminate Smirnov's powers on 8 February. Marina Sasova, the chief specialist of the local administration, will serve as the temporary acting head. (Novosti Volgograda website, 8 Feb 24)

Military

A reconnaissance assault soldier, who died in Ukraine in late November 2023, was laid to rest in Rudnyansky District, the V1 website reported. Vyacheslav Shpilyov, 54, signed a contract with the Russian Defence Ministry on 24 April 2023. (V1.ru website, 5 Feb 23)

Cpl Roman Kondratyuk, 33, who died in "the special operation" zone during shelling on 16 December, was buried in Kamyshinsky District, the V1 website reported. He signed a contract with the Russian Defence Ministry in April 2023. Kondratyuk is survived by his wife, mother and a 10-year-old son. (V1.ru website, 6 Feb 23)

A 56-year-old from Novonikolaevsky District died during "the special military operation," the Vysota 102 news agency reported. Alexander Golokolenov, a contract soldier, was wounded on the front, returned for treatment in Volgograd Region, and went back to the front without waiting for a medical commission. He is survived by his wife, three adult children, and two grandchildren. (Vysota 102 news agency, 7 Feb 24)

Enver Yanmaev, who died in the "special military operation" zone, was buried in the village of Chervlenoye in Svetloyarsky District. (Vysota 102 news agency, 10 Feb 24)

More than 100 drones have been dispatched to the "special military operation" zone from Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. These drones were procured using funds from the regional For Victory support fund, dedicated to assisting servicemen and volunteers. In addition, the region has provided extra technical equipment and construction materials to meet the daily requirements of the fighters. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Volunteers from the Bastion battalion were honoured with distinction badges in Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Parents of participants in "the special military operation" were also presented with the Father of a Soldier medals. Certificates of appreciation were bestowed upon volunteers engaged in rear support, personally delivering humanitarian aid to the zone of "the special military operation." (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The one-time regional compensation payment for individuals involved in "the special military operation" from Volgograd Region has been tripled from 100,000 to 300,000 roubles ($1,000 to $3,300) in 2024. Governor Andrey Bocharov announced this increase at the regional military commissariat assembly point, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Combined with the payment from the Russian Defence Ministry, the total support for regional servicemen fighting in Ukraine now amounts to 500,000 roubles ($5,500). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

A 34-year-old resident of Volgograd was arrested by the regional branches of the FSB and Interior Ministry on charges of supporting Ukraine and inciting violence against Russians on social media. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

Volgograd activists from the We Are For Our People! movement produce 3D-printed items based on the requests of "the special military operation" fighters, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. A group of volunteers purchased six printers for 3D printing, and work facilities were provided by one of the enterprises. They produce parts for quadcopters and plastic devices that help quickly reload weapons under any conditions. Lightweight parts are made from plastic supplied by a local enterprise. Up to 30 kilogrammes of raw materials are used for production each month. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

Large-scale tactical special exercises were conducted at two chemical plants in Volzhsky, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The scenario involved a short circuit in electrical equipment, leading to a fire that damaged containers storing hazardous substances. The exercises included various authorities such as firefighters, gas rescuers, medical personnel, police, and military command. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

Economic

The debt burden on Volgograd Region residents has increased by 1.5 times over the year, the Vysota 102 news agency reported, citing the Volgograd branch of the Russian Central Bank's Southern Main Directorate. In 2023, residents of the region took out loans amounting to 329.4 billion rubles (about $3.6bn), which is 46.5 per cent more than in 2022, but less than the Russian average of 42.9 per cent. The retail lending portfolio in the region grew by 21.7 per cent, reaching 397.1 billion rubles (about $4.3bn) as of 1 January. The increase was mainly due to mortgages, the volume of which increased by nearly 30 per cent over the year, from 148.6 to 193 billion roubles (about $2.1bn). High demand for them continued to be supported by preferential government lending programmes despite the tightening of their issuance conditions. Their peak occurred in the second half of 2023 when people were eager to buy housing as soon as possible, expecting lending conditions to worsen. Consumer loans grew at a slower pace, by 14.9 per cent, and reached 204.1 billion roubles by the end of the last year (about $2.2bn). (Vysota 102 news agency, 5 Feb 24)

Volgograd Region ranks 58th among the country's regions in terms of the average size of bank deposits, amounting to 185.2 thousand roubles (about $2,000) per capita, GTRK Volgograd TV reported, citing a study by RIA Rating. It marked a growth of 28.6 per cent over the year. Within the Southern Federal District, Volgograd Region holds third place after Rostov Region and Krasnodar Territory. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Volgograd ranked seventh among 102 cities in Russia in terms of public transport quality, GTRK Volgograd TV reported, citing a rating by the Simetra company, which excluded Moscow and Saint Petersburg from its assessment. Over the year, Volgograd improved its position by eight spots. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

In 2023, purchase prices for crop products in Volgograd Region decreased by 4.1 per cent, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The purchase price of rye fell by 10.2 per cent, barley by 9.7 per cent, corn by 8.5 per cent, sunflower seeds by 7.5 per cent and cucumbers by five per cent. Additionally, the price of wheat decreased by 10 per cent over the year, with the cost of Grade 3 falling by five per cent, Grade 4 by 10.1 per cent and Grade 5 by 11 per cent. According to the Volgogradstat regional statistics body, Volgograd Region ranks third within the Southern Federal District in terms of the producer price index, trailing behind Rostov Region and annexed Sevastopol. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 5 Feb 24)

Air service between Volgograd and Sochi will be restored from 1 June, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The flights will be operated by the Pobeda low-cost airline. Tickets are already on sale. The flight programme between the two southern regions has been inactive for about 1.5 years, since the fall of 2022. The Volgograd airport is among the few in the Southern Federal District not subject to flight restrictions imposed from 24 February 2022, when the Russian full-scale invasion of Ukraine started. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

The turnover of organisations in Volgograd Region amounted to more than 2.4 trillion rubles (about $26.4 billion) for the year 2023, a nine per cent increase compared to 2022, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The largest share is attributed to the manufacturing industries, with 34.8 per cent, or 850.1 billion roubles (about $9.3 billion). Wholesale and retail trade, together with repairs of motor vehicles and motorcycles, accounted for 791.8 billion rubles (about $8.9 billion). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 6 Feb 24)

In 2024, Volgograd Region is set to fund 529 community projects with a budget allocation of 341 million rubles (about $3.7 million), GTRK Volgograd TV reported on 7 February. These projects, determined by residents through the initiative budgeting programme, predominantly focus on upgrading socially significant infrastructure and creating modern and comfortable public spaces. The selected initiatives include the renovation of educational institutions, rural culture houses, libraries, museums, and addressing issues related to water supply, street lighting, and road infrastructure repairs in specific localities. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

In 2023, 606 kilometres of quality roads were built in Volgograd Region, GTRK Volgograd reported. Several industry projects were implemented within the framework of the Safe Quality Roads national project, including the opening of traffic on four renovated bridges in Novonikolaevsky and Novoanninsky districts, as well as in Volgograd and Volzhsky. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 7 Feb 24)

At least 50,000 jobs are planned to be created in Volgograd Region over the next 10 years. Governor Andrey Bocharov discussed the results of joint efforts to develop the region and strategic tasks for the next decade with representatives of the business community, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. Annually, since 2014, about 180 billion roubles (about $2bn) have been invested in the economy of Volgograd Region, with significant growth in 2022-2023. In 2023, the investment volume amounted to 226.5 billion roubles (about $2.5bn) and 216.5 billion roubles the year before (about $2.4bn). The forecast for 2024 is estimated at 240 billion roubles (about $2.6bn), with the majority of projects related to industry. By the end of 2034, it is planned to implement investment projects in the region totalling 3.4 trillion roubles (about $38bn). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

The gross regional product of Volgograd Region for 2023 is estimated at 1.3 trillion rubles (about $14bn), GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The consolidated budget saw revenues of almost 200 billion roubles (about $2.2bn), which is a 9.5 per cent increase from 2022. Despite external pressure and restrictions, the economy of the region continues to show stable development across various sectors, governor Andrey Bocharov said at a meeting with representatives of businesses. He added that "enterprises and organisations of the real sector have largely adapted to modern conditions" thanks to overall cooperation, implementation of national and regional projects, modernisation of production and skilled personnel. According to him, an important task is to grow the gross regional product by almost 2.5 times, ensure an accumulated investment volume of at least 3.4 trillion rubles over a decade and increase the income of the regional budget to 300 billion rubles (about $3.3bn). (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 8 Feb 24)

In 2023, Volgograd Region residents spent 183.8 billion rubles (about $2bn) on various services, which is 2.3 per cent more than in 2022, GTRK Volgograd TV reported. The largest share was spent on utility services - 20.5 per cent. Transport services accounted for another 15.3 per cent. Household and telecommunication services made up 13.9 per cent and 13.1 per cent, respectively. The share of medical services was 10.2 per cent, while education system services accounted for 7.1 per cent. (Vesti-Volgograd, GTRK Volgograd TV, 9 Feb 24)

HEALTH

In Volgograd, there is a severe shortage of imported drugs for treating pneumonia in children, notably the children's antibiotic Klacid, V1.ru reported on 5 February. Pharmacies in the city, including the Volgopharm chain, have confirmed a critical scarcity of this medication manufactured in Italy due to disrupted logistics. The report notes that this shortage compounds previous issues with medication availability in late 2023, especially impacting imported children's antibiotics. (V1.ru website, Volgograd, 05 Feb 24)

Q: Many Iranian newspapers reacted this morning to the appointment of former parliament Speaker and veteran politician Ali Larijani as the secretary of the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC), Iran's top security body.

Larijani's appointment by President Massoud Pezeshkian, which had been speculated about for a week, followed the creation of a new Defence Council under the SNSC aimed at centralising strategic military decision-making.

Larijani previously held the same top security position from 2005 to 2007 and was parliamentary speaker from 2008 to 2020. He also registered his candidacy in the 2021 and 2024 presidential elections, but was disqualified by the hardline vetting body, the Guardian Council.

The state broadcaster-run daily Jaam-e Jam newspaper said "With Larijani's appointment and the formation of the Defence Council, Iran has unveiled a new security and defence arrangement."

Conservative daily Farhikhtegan said "Larijani's return to the SNSC after 20 years signals a reconstruction of national affairs with a centrist approach".

The paper in a separate op-ed said "Larijani 3.0 must rebuild national unity from a centrist stance - neither the hardliner of the past nor the reformist ally of the Rouhani era".

The reformist Sazandegi said Larijani's return could mean "a shift from maximalist resistance to greater rationality in security policymaking".

On X, Larijani's appointment was either welcomed or tacitly accepted by users from across the political spectrum.

Some users said the appointment signified changes in strategies of Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, echoing recent speculation and chatter on upcoming senior staffing changes.

Others highlighted his nonpartisan nature and perceived "moderate approach", expecting a "positive change" in the top security body.

Some users described Larijani as a critic of hardliners, saying that a shift towards a more moderate approach was desperately needed in the current situation.

Meanwhile, some hardline figures sought to warn Larijani that he must adhere to Iran's conservative policies, especially in foreign policy especially towards the US and Trump's mounting pressure on Iran.

Hardline MP Amir Hossein Sabeti suggested Larijani was appointed to compensate for Pezeshkian's weaknesses.

Public offices closed in most provinces amid heat, energy crisis

Public offices in more Iranian provinces will be closed today. According to some outlets, 28 out of Iran's 31 provinces are affected.

State TV reported the closures in their morning bulletins today, but named only 13 provinces affected by the shutdowns, while state media cited "over 20" provinces. The reports and decisions on closures of new provinces were being released gradually until last night.

The shutdowns, aimed at saving electricity and water, come amid recurring blackouts and concerns over unprecedentedly bad water shortages this summer. Although Iran has been experiencing energy and water shortages for several years, the situation has significantly worsened this year.

State media has noted that essential service providers such as hospitals and select bank branches remain open during the closures in all affected provinces.

Iran executes alleged 'Mossad spy', 'IS terrorist'

The Iranian judiciary announced this morning that it had carried out the execution of an alleged Mossad spy and an "Islamic State [IS] terrorist".

In two separate reports, the judiciary-run Mizan News Agency described the individuals as "an operative of the Mossad spy-terror network who had engaged in espionage", named Roozbeh Vadi, and a "member of Daesh [IS]" who "intended to carry out terrorist operations", named Mehdi Asgharzadeh.

Mizan said Vadi was "employed in one of the country's key and sensitive institutions, and given his level of access, he had become an attractive target" for foreign intelligence. The report said he travelled to Vienna and met Mossad officers on five occasions.

Mizan also added that Vadi had provided Mossad with information about one of the Iranian nuclear scientists assassinated during the 12-day military campaign by Israel, which included targeting of top commanders and nuclear scientists.

On the case of the alleged IS member, Mizan said a "terrorist cell's safehouse was identified before any attack could take place" and that security forces "killed four terrorists in an armed clash" while raiding the house, while Asgharzadeh managed to flee and was later arrested.

Q: - The state-owned Sudan TV dedicated most of its 19:00 GMT news bulletin on 12 March to the recapture of its headquarters by the army from the Rapid Support Forces paramilitary group

- The TV said the army received much commendation in the country for “liberating” the state broadcaster headquarters

Full story

The state-owned Sudan TV channel dedicated most of its 19:00 GMT news bulletin on 12 March to the recapture of its headquarters by the regular army after weeks of fierce fighting with the rival Rapid Support Forces (RSF) paramilitary group.

The seizure of the Sudan Radio and Television Corporation (SRTC) headquarters by the army marked a significant setback for the RSF as the paramilitary group has been controlling the premises since its war with the army began in April 2023.

Sudan TV has been airing clips of army troops inside the television and radio headquarters in Omdurman, hours after the military announced the takeover.

The TV said in its 19:00 GMT bulletin on 12 March that the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) has received much commendation in the country for “liberating” the state broadcaster headquarters.

It said the armed forces, other security agents and volunteer fighters deserve recognition for the liberation of the TV headquarters in Omdurman.

 "This institution serves as the national voice and embodies the people's memory and historical heritage, reflecting their culture," the TV said.

Sudan TV showed the commander-in-chief of the armed forces, Lt Gen Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, arriving in Omdurman to congratulate the army for the victory. 

The TV also broadcast a statement by the chief of staff of the Sudan army, Lt Gen Mohammed Osman al-Hussein, flaunting the liberation of the TV premises and congratulating the army for the victory.

Several ministries have issued statements “emphasising the significance of this victory as a step in the ongoing efforts to free the country from the grip of RSF rebellion”, Sudan TV said.

The television prominently broadcast statements by the governors of states controlled by the army sending congratulatory messages over the recapture of the TV premises in Omdurman. These include the Northern, Kassala, Qadaref, South Kordofan, North Kordofan, West Kordofan, Blue Nile and White Nile states.

It said the residents of some of those states who spoke to Sudan TV “expressed their joy at the liberation” of the TV premises.

Sudan TV has been operating from the eastern city of Port Sudan, which has become the government base after the conflict began.

It is worth noting that RSF has not used the state broadcaster headquarters in Omdurman for broadcasting despite having controlled it for more than ten months. It instead turned the premises into "a military base" according to local media.

Q: “Russia’s new bloody terror in Europe is contributing to the growth of instability and threats around the world. However, we in Lithuania are calm because we know that we will never be alone again,” said President Gitanas Nauseda, standing near the runway where the first NATO jets landed back in 2004. “We will always have a strong, supportive Alliance family by our side, and we will face any challenges together.”

Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, and Slovenia joined NATO on March 29 in 2004, bringing the total membership of the Alliance to 26. The seven nations started accession negotiations soon after the collapse of the Soviet Union and eventually were invited to join at the Prague Summit in November 2002. Another group of former Soviet satellites including Poland and the Czech Republic had been admitted several years earlier.

Since joining the alliance, these countries often warned about the threat of Russia, using their national trauma of Soviet occupation as proof of credibility. While Western nations often dismissed their sometimes hawkish attitude, Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine is seen as a vindication of those fears. They have given some of the most robust responses, helping Ukraine with equipment and money, and pushing for even greater sanctions on Russia.

Most of the former Soviet Republics that joined NATO at the turn of the millennium spend more than the required 2% of gross domestic product on defense. When Romania’s President Klaus Iohannis announced his bid earlier this month to become the next leader of the alliance, he emphasized the threat from Russia and said the alliance needs a “renewal of perspectives” that Eastern Europe could provide.

“Russia is proving to be a serious and long-term threat to our continent, to our Euro-Atlantic security,” the 65-year-old said when he announced his bid. “NATO’s borders become of paramount importance, and the strengthening of the eastern flank ... will remain a long-term priority.”

The seven countries are marking the anniversary with solemn events and shows of force, but also some levity, with open-air concerts and exhibitions.

“Twenty years ago the Bulgarian people made the right choice for our country to join NATO,” the country’s defense chief Adm. Emil Eftimov said. “Given today’s security situation, this is the most appropriate decision we have made in our recent history.”

NATO was established in the aftermath of World War II.

___

Associated Press writers Stephen McGrath in Sighisoara, Romania, and Veselin Toshkov in Sofia, Bulgaria contributed to this report.

Q: The voting coincides with International Women’s Day and could be another milestone in a transformative few decades during which Ireland has reshaped its Constitution in ways that reflect the country’s more secular and liberal modern identity.

If passed, the amendments would provide the latest updates to the Constitution, a document originally written in line with the values of the Roman Catholic Church and ratified in 1937, when religion and social conservatism dominated society.

What exactly is the Irish public voting on?

Voters will be asked to consider two separate questions.

The first asks whether the public is in favor of amending Article 41 of the Constitution to provide for a wider concept of family.

At present, the Constitution says: “The state recognizes the family as the natural primary and fundamental unit group of society, and as a moral institution possessing inalienable and imprescriptible rights, antecedent and superior to all positive law.”

It adds: “The state pledges itself to guard with special care the institution of marriage, on which the family is founded, and to protect it against attack.”

The new language would recognize a family, “whether founded on marriage or on other durable relationships” as the fundamental unit of society. The words “on which the family is founded” would be removed from the clause about the state’s responsibility for guarding the institution of marriage.

The second question is about Article 41.2 of the Constitution, which currently says that the state “recognizes that by her life within the home, woman gives to the state a support without which the common good cannot be achieved” and that the state will “endeavor to ensure that mothers shall not be obliged by economic necessity to engage in labor to the neglect of their duties in the home.”

If voters choose in favor, the reference to the role of women in the home would be removed. A new Article, 42B, would recognize and protect all family caregivers, saying: “The state recognizes that the provision of care, by members of a family to one another by reason of the bonds that exist among them, gives to society a support without which the common good cannot be achieved, and shall strive to support such provision.”

The amendments would be another sign of a changing country.

The Irish Constitution was written at a time when the influence of the Roman Catholic Church was immense, and language that reflected the church’s social teachings was woven into the national document. It defined women in terms of their role as wives and mothers, and outlined their duties in the home.

The proposed changes would be another signal of Ireland’s move away from being a conservative state rooted in Catholic values — particularly around the role of women. That transformation has happened rapidly. At the start of the 1990s, divorce and gay marriage were illegal, and abortion was outlawed in nearly all cases.

In 1995, Ireland voted to end its ban on divorce, with a later referendum in 2019 further liberalizing divorce laws. In 2015, the country voted to legalize same-sex marriage, and, in 2018, to repeal the amendment that prohibited abortion.

What do those who support the propositions say?

Recent polling by The Irish Times has indicated that a majority of voters intends to approve both proposals. Orla O’Connor, director of the National Women’s Council of Ireland, a charity that promotes women’s rights and equality, said in a statement that the changes were a “chance to remove sexist language and limits on women from our Constitution.”

Voting in favor, she said, “will be a long step away from this dark past and a small step toward recognizing the importance of care and the care roles of both women and men.”

She added: “We encourage all voters to really think: Do we want our young women and girls growing up in an Ireland where the Constitution still tells them that their primary place, indeed their ‘life,’ is in the home?” And that they have ‘duties’ and the boys and men don’t?”

Mary McAleese, a former president of Ireland, has campaigned in favor of the proposals. She said she thought that the changes “will reflect the overwhelming impulse for equality and inclusivity that is a hallmark of modern Ireland.”

All of the country’s major political parties have also called for voters to approve the overhaul. Leo Varadkar, Ireland’s prime minister, speaking to reporters while he was campaigning in Dublin this week, urged the public to vote in favor of both proposals.

“If there is a yes vote, we will be saying as a society that all families are equal and the marital status of parents shouldn’t affect that,” he said, referring to the family question. Regarding the second question, about the role of women, he added: “If there is a no vote, we will have very outdated language in our Constitution that will be there for the foreseeable future. I think that would be really unfortunate.”

What about those opposed?

Catholic bishops in Ireland issued a statement last month saying they believed that the proposed change to the family clause would “lead to a weakening of the incentive for young people to marry.”

They also expressed concern about the removal of the clause about women, saying, “It would have the effect of abolishing all reference to motherhood in the Constitution and leave unacknowledged the particular and incalculable societal contribution that mothers in the home have made and continue to make in Ireland.”

Other critics have argued that the proposed language changes do not go far enough, particularly around the provisions for caregivers, while some have said that the new language is problematic. Free Legal Advice Centres, an independent human rights and equality body, said in a statement that it supported the change to in the first question, the definition of family, but rejected the wording in the second, about caregivers.

The proposed language intended to replace the reference to a women’s duties in the home “endorses a status quo where women undertake the bulk of unpaid care work and places no obligation whatsoever on the state to redress this gender imbalance — rendering it an implicitly sexist amendment,” the group said.

Mr. Varadkar, however, said that those who criticized the measures as not going far enough were missing the point.

“I would very much see these referendums as further progress toward modernizing our Constitution, and incremental change in the right direction,” he said.
A:

The locations mentioned in the article are:

*   Ireland
*   Dublin

Q: ''When people ask us whether it is OK for the United States to abandon Ukraine, the answer is no, because the world is operating not in a black-and-white way, or if you only look at one theater at a time,'' he said. ''The world is interconnected.''

If Russia is able to occupy more of Ukraine and claim victory, he added, ''it would be seen as a victory of authoritarian states because Russia, China, North Korea and Iran, they are now linked together.''

Mr. Wu's comments, made in a wide-ranging hourlong interview in Taipei, come as the Biden administration tries to get Congress to pass a supplemental funding package that would give $60 billion of aid to Ukraine.

Many House Republicans are staunchly opposed to giving more aid to Ukraine, adopting the ''America First'' posture embraced by former President Donald J. Trump, a pro-Russia candidate who has pressed them to reject the package. For months they claimed they would be willing to consider providing more assistance for Kyiv if the Biden administration imposed severe immigration restrictions at the United States border with Mexico. But at Mr. Trump's urging, they balked at a funding package that would have done that, calling the border measures too weak.

The package also includes $8 billion of aid to counter China in the Asia-Pacific region, $1.9 billion of which would refill stocks of U.S. weapons sent to Taiwan. And it includes $14.1 billion of military aid to Israel.

Some Republican lawmakers contend that China is a bigger threat than Russia and that the funding proposed for Ukraine should go toward countering China. But other Republican officials in Congress and many Democrats make the same argument as Mr. Wu: that Taiwan's security is linked to that of Ukraine, because China will see weakness on the part of the United States -- and a greater chance of success in a potential invasion of Taiwan -- if Ukraine is defeated.

Chinese leaders have said for decades that Taiwan, a de facto independent island, must be brought under the rule of the Communist Party, by force if necessary. Xi Jinping, China's leader, has continued to promote that position.

The U.S. and Taiwanese governments have been trying to deter China from notions of invading Taiwan, including through military buildup in the region and bolstering alliances with other democratic nations.

If the United States abandons Ukraine, Mr. Wu said, China will ''take it as a hint'' that if it can keep up sustained action against Taiwan, ''the United States is going to back off, the United States and its allies are going to back off.'' The thinking among Chinese officials would be this, he said: ''OK, since Russia could do that, we can do that as well.''

''So the U.S. determination in providing support to those countries suffering from authoritarian aggression, it is very important,'' Mr. Wu said.

After U.S. troops withdrew from Afghanistan in 2021, China pushed propaganda through traditional state-run media and social media that ''the U.S. commitment to anything is not firm,'' Mr. Wu said. ''We suffered from a huge wave of cognitive warfare.''

China has also spread disinformation stressing Russian narratives of the war, Mr. Wu said, including the idea that the expansion of NATO forced President Vladimir V. Putin to attack Ukraine, and that the United States is ultimately not committed to supporting Ukraine.

On the eve of Russia's invasion in February 2022, Mr. Putin visited Mr. Xi in Beijing, and their two governments announced a ''no limits'' partnership.

Mr. Wu said some Central and Eastern European nations seeking to forge anti-authoritarian partnerships had strengthened their relations with Taiwan during the war.

His comments on the need for the United States to keep supporting Taiwan echo those of other senior Taiwanese officials. In May 2023, Bi-khim Hsiao, then Taiwan's de facto ambassador to the United States and now the incoming vice president, made similar arguments to reporters in Washington.

And in February, Representative Raja Krishnamoorthi, Democrat of Illinois, said during a visit of American lawmakers to Taiwan that the current president, Tsai Ing-wen, and the president-elect, Lai Ching-te, made clear to the lawmakers that ''if for some reason the Ukrainians do not prevail, that will only encourage hostilities against Taiwan.''

Tuskayev said that new programmes should be drawn up taking into account sectors which are the most important for the republic’s economy. The regional minister of agriculture, Alan Kusrayev, said in 2023 that more than 2.2bn roubles (around $23.75m at the current exchange rate) had been used to implement a state programme for developing the agricultural sector and regulating markets of agricultural products, raw materials and foodstuffs. Q: Investigators charged Febrio De-Zoysa, 19, a student who also lived in the home, with six counts of first-degree murder and one count of attempted murder. He was arrested shortly after the police received two emergency calls around 11 p.m. Wednesday requesting they come to the home, which is in a residential neighborhood, police officers said.

Ottawa’s police chief, Eric Stubbs, said at a news conference that the stabbings were the largest mass killing in the city, Canada’s capital, in at least three decades.

“I want to emphasize this was a senseless act of violence perpetrated on purely innocent people,” Chief Stubbs said. “I know our whole community is shocked and mourning this event.”

The victims were identified as Darshani Banbaranayake Gama Walwwe Darshani Dilanthika Ekanyake, 35, the mother of the four children; Inuka Wickramasinghe, a 7-year-old boy; Ashwini Wickramasinghe, a 4-year-old girl; Rinyana Wickramasinghe, a 2-year-old girl; and Kelly Wickramasinghe, a 2-month-old girl.

The children’s father and Ms. Ekanyake’s husband, identified as Dhanushka Wickramasinghe in court documents, was seriously injured in the attack and was in stable condition at an area hospital.

Bhante Suneetha, a monk at the The Hilda Jayewardenaramaya Buddhist Monastery, where the family were active members, said that he spoke by phone on Thursday with Mr. Wickramasinghe, who he said is being hospitalized for slash wounds to his eyes and one of his hands.

Mr. Wickramasinghe told the monk that he arrived home from work on Wednesday night and was attacked when he opened the door, Mr. Suneetha said. Mr. Wickramasinghe was able to subdue his attacker before he discovered the other victims, he said.

Police officers said Mr. Wickramasinghe was seen on the street shouting for someone to call 911.

The sixth person killed, Amarakoonmubiayansela Ge Gamini Amarakoon, 40, was an acquaintance who had recently arrived from Sri Lanka and was living with the family. Mr. Suneetha said that he leaves a wife and two young children in Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka.

The police said they believed the victims were attacked with “an edged weapon” but did not provide any more details.

According to Mr. Suneetha, Mr. Wickramasinghe arrived on his own in Canada as a student in 2020 and the rest of the family followed about a year ago. After his graduation from college, Mr. Wickramasinghe worked in a restaurant before starting his own cleaning business.

The family, Mr. Suneetha said, came to Canada with so many “dreams and plans.”

“That is why they brought their kids here,” he said.

While he was in school, Mr. Wickramasinghe lived in another Sri Lankan family’s home. Mr. De-Zoysa also boarded there, according to Mr. Suneetha. After that arrangement fell apart, Mr. Wickramasinghe invited Mr. De-Zoysa to live in the basement of his family’s home.

Mr. Suneetha said the family recently celebrated Mr. De-Zoysa’s 19th birthday.

The Wickramasinghe family regularly helped organize events at the temple, and Inuka, the 7-year-old, began his studies in meditation and Buddhism a week ago, Mr. Suneetha said.

Members of the temple were meeting on Wednesday to work out plans for the funerals and to support Mr. Wickramasinghe, as well as the family of Mr. Amarakoon.

Two police SUVs remained parked at the home nearly a full day after the killings. The police chief said it would take several days to process the scene.

Shanti Ramesh, a neighbor, said she saw about 15 police cruisers rush to the home on Wednesday night.

Ms. Ramesh watched as investigators began rolling out yellow crime-scene tape in front of the home. She went to bed thinking the scene would be cleared up overnight.

“But when I saw the news in the morning, it was a shock that such a big tragedy happened in our city and just across my house,” she said, adding that she did not know the family who lived in the home.

Mass killings are rare in Canada, where the homicide rate in 2022 was about 2.3 killings per 100,000 people, about one-third of the rate in the United States that year.

There were 874 murders in Canada in 2022, according to the latest data from the census agency. They represented an 8 percent rise in the country’s homicide rate and the fourth year of consecutive increases.

Mark Sutcliffe, the mayor of Ottawa, offered his condolences.

“We are fortunate to live in a safe city where these events are extremely rare,” he said at a news conference on Thursday afternoon. “Everyone, understandably, will react to this news today and feel less safe and secure.”

About 100 people gathered at a gazebo on the edge of Palmadeo Park, just two blocks from the crime scene, for a memorial vigil on Thursday evening. Some stayed for a while; others stopped only to leave teddy bears, letters or bouquets of flowers.

“They were so sweet, they were caring, they were kind. It was honestly very devastating,” Dayna Craigie, a former educational assistant at the children’s school, said. “I’m remembering them as innocent children who should not have had their lives taken away from them.”

Neela Singh looked on with her two children, ages 4 and 11. They went to school with the victims, she said. Through tears, Ms. Singh described that afternoon’s school pickup as somber.

“There were so many people around, yet no sound until the teacher came out,” she said.

After the peak of the coronavirus pandemic, the temple began holding special counseling and mediation sessions for students from Sri Lanka who, Mr. Suneetha said, seemed to be under ever-increasing stress.

“After the pandemic, the society here in Canada is not so well,” he said.

Recovery, Mr. Suneetha added, will take time for the temple’s 120 members. The temple is a hub for many members of the Sri Lankan community, including several hundred people who are not members of the temple, he said.

“We will definitely need help from the society,” Mr. Suneetha said. “Not just from the Sri Lankan community, but the whole community.”

Q: The organizers say they’re putting the games on a climate diet. These Olympics, they say, will generate no more than half the greenhouse gas emissions of recent Olympics. That means tightening the belt on everything that produces planet-warming emissions: electricity, food, buildings, and transportation, including the jet fuel that athletes and fans burn traveling the world to get there.

An event that attracts 10,500 athletes and an estimated 15 million spectators is, by definition, going to have an environmental toll. And that has led those who love the games but hate the pollution to suggest that the Olympics should be scattered around the world, in existing facilities, to eliminate the need for so much new construction and air travel. That’s why Paris is being watched so closely.

It is making more space for bikes and less for cars. It’s doing away with huge, diesel-powered generators, a fixture of big sporting events. It’s planning guest menus that are less polluting to grow and cook than typical French fare: more plants, less steak au poivre. Solar panels will float, temporarily, on the Seine.

But the organizers’ most significant act may be what they are not doing: They aren’t building. At least, not as much.

Instead of building new showpieces for the games (which generates lots of greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing of concrete and steel), the Paris Olympics are repurposing many of the city’s existing attractions, including the Grand Palais, the plaza known as the Concorde and even a swimming pool built for the 1924 Paris Olympics.

It’s not without controversy.

One notable emissions-reduction effort, a decision to forego conventional air-conditioning at the athletes’ village, has raised concerns. Instead, the buildings will rely on a cooling system that uses water pulled from underground. Several Olympic teams, are considering bringing their own air-conditioners.

Still the hope is that experiments like these will offer a template for other Olympics in the future, and other cities worldwide. The few new buildings that are being built, including the athletes’ housing, as well as a swimming complex and an arena, are using less cement and more wood. They have solar panels and greenery on their roofs.

The new buildings are also meant to have a life far beyond the Olympics. They’re designed to be used by local residents for decades to come and, the leaders of the Paris 2024 organizing committee say, revitalize the city’s suburbs. “We set for ourselves ambitions that have never been set for any event before, let alone have this scale,” said Georgina Grenon, who is in charge of the games’ environmental efforts.

Critics counter that, while much of what Paris is doing is commendable, particularly the limits on new construction, to truly address the climate crisis requires more than paring back emissions here and there. “We need to fundamentally rethink these huge mega events,” said Cesar Dugast, co-founder of a climate analysis group called Eclaircies. “Instead of concentrating all the events in a single city, it could be envisaged to distribute them around the world.”

‘It’s a big test’

There’s a more immediate risk facing the Olympics: climate change itself. Rising global temperatures are making Paris summers dangerously hot. That has heightened concerns about how to protect athletes and fans in late July and August.

City officials say they have planted thousands of trees in recent years to temper summer heat. They are erecting misting towers to spray the air. The search is on for wide umbrellas under which fans can wait. “We have solutions. We are preparing,” said Dan Lert, the deputy mayor in charge of preparing the city for heat. “It’s a big test.”

One major thing that sets the Paris games apart from previous Olympics is that it has imposed a limit on the total emissions it will produce. The target: Generate no more than half the greenhouse gas emissions of the 2012 Olympics, which were held in London.

London was chosen as a benchmark because the organizers there also sought to reduce emissions, and they measured them. Estimates like these are based on standard measures of, for instance, how much carbon dioxide is produced by the amount of cement used in new buildings.

The Paris organizers say they will offset those emissions by purchasing “carbon credits” to help fund emissions-reducing projects worldwide. The games organizers have not said what projects the games will fund and at what price. In any case, the market for carbon credits can be murky, with some projects not delivering on their promise.

Refashioning a historic city

What Paris is doing shows what can be done to remake an old city for a new global climate. It also shows what the limits are.

The Place de la Concorde, an 18th century plaza where guillotines were once erected during the French Revolution, this summer will be home to Olympic events like skateboarding.

The plaza is also now home to an unassuming metal box designed to spur an electricity revolution. It contains a high-powered electrical outlet connected to the national grid, enabling every big event on the plaza to throw off the shackles of diesel.

Diesel generators are the dirty secret of sports events. Typically they are trucked in to provide a stable source of power.

The Paris games have also cut a special deal with the electric utility stipulating that there be enough wind and solar energy in the grid to produce all the energy that the games consume.

When it comes to emissions, transportation is another headache. Paris has already been limiting space for cars and making space for bikes, and it’s using the games to accelerate that shift.

But the Olympics, with its huge crowds, threatens trouble for how Parisians get around their city, with many making plans to flee on vacation.

Pierre Rabadan, a former pro rugby player who is now Paris’ deputy mayor for sports, lifted his shoulders against a wind and walked briskly out of the tram stop in front of the city’s new basketball arena, at the top of Rue de la Chapelle. He pointed to an almost finished bike lane along the road, carved out of what had been a wide boulevard devoted to automobiles.

Since the election of Anne Hidalgo as mayor in 2014, Paris has added some 600 kilometers of bike lanes. Around 10 percent have been dubbed Olympistes, a play on “piste,” the French word for track.

“The problem is we built the city around cars,” Mr. Rabadan said.

Another problem is that the city’s metro system is bursting at the seams. Trains are already crowded, and workers are rushing to complete new extensions of two lines in time to serve the games.

To make room for Olympics visitors, the city has urged people to stay off the trains or work from home.

Tarzan and the old pool

Key to the organizers’ climate strategy is to build as little as possible, which is why it is tapping into a leftover from the 1924 Paris Olympics: the Georges Vallerey swimming pool.

It’s getting a new air filtration system, as well as a new roof that lets in light but keeps out heat and cold. Old wood roof beams have been repurposed as countertops. The wooden bleachers, installed at least 40 years ago, remain. Sturdy stucco walls reveal the pool’s age.

“We need not trash everything or destroy everything and put it in the bin,” said Mr. Rabadan.

The pool holds history. It is where Johnny Weissmuller, an American swimmer, won a gold medal in 1924. He went on to play Tarzan in a string of Hollywood movies, Mr. Rabadan is keen to point out.

Roughly 95 percent of the venues to be used in the 2024 games are old buildings or temporary structures. For example, several temporary pools will be built for the games, then taken apart and re-installed in communities that have a dearth of public pools.

‘A laboratory’

The Olympics, Ms. Grenon said, offer “a laboratory,” particularly when it comes to the buildings designed from scratch.

A new aquatic center, on the edge of a highway in the northern suburb of Saint-Denis, is a showpiece of Douglas fir and pine. Its 5,000 square meter roof curves like a wave: The architects designed it that way to shrink the size of the building, reducing the energy needed to heat the space.

The pool is 5 meters deep only where necessary to have greater depth for diving, and shallower where it’s not. That too saves water and energy it takes to heat the water. Some of that heat will come from a nearby data center. The venue’s 5,000 seats are made from recycled plastic.

The goal, said Cécilia Gross, one of the architects, was “to do better with less.”

Rising nearby is the biggest new Olympics project: the 128-acre Athletes Village complex that is to morph into a mixed neighborhood for 6,000 residents afterward. Its builders say its emissions are at least 30 percent less than a conventional project of its size.

Timber has a starring role here, too. The village is a cluster of mostly wood-frame buildings.

While timber has its own environmental costs depending on how it’s grown, it is considered far more sustainable than concrete.

In the village, a small patch of sidewalk is paved with oyster shells that can be watered from an underground reservoir and cool the sidewalk on hot days. One experimental building is to recycle all its water. To cool the grounds, 9,000 trees have been planted, including local varieties like oaks and elms that can survive in a hotter future.

Then there’s the unconventional air conditioning.

A network of pipes, using water cooled by first being sent underground, will cool the interiors of the buildings in a technology known as a geo-exchange system. In New York City, St. Patrick’s Cathedral uses something similar, but using air instead of water. A smattering of U.S. universities are also switching to geoexchange.

Along with shade trees, insulation and a breeze from the river, the builders say indoor temperatures can be kept cool enough for the Paris summers of the future. However, the games organizers say, Olympic teams are still free to bring their own air conditioners.

The United States, Canada and Norway said they would. Australia and Ireland have too, according to press reports. The mayor, Ms. Hidalgo, in an interview with Reuters, urged teams to “trust the science.”

Léontine Gallois contributed reporting from Paris.
A:

Q: Zulfiqar spoke with former caretaker minister Zubair Jamali and asked him to comment on the recent incident of the martyrdom of military officers. Jamali said it is a very gloomy event for a family to receive the dead body of their young son. He noted a lieutenant colonel, captain and five soldiers have been martyred, and they have sacrificed their lives for the country. He remarked such incidents prove to be a "binding force" for the country and people need to realise that if they are living safely in their villages and cities, it is "at the cost of soldiers who are fighting against terrorism on borders and within the country". He added people should be thankful to the martyrs and their families for their sacrifice.

Senior journalist Saleem Shahid said it was a very sad incident, but it should be noted that the officers and soldiers fought against "terrorists" and killed six of them before embracing martyrdom. He noted incidents of terrorism have increased recently. He was of the view that such incidents cannot be planned and executed by a small group and large-scale resources are behind them which are only available to a state. He claimed due to this, some state is behind these incidents and is funding such elements.

Zulfiqar noted President Asif Ali Zardari expressed grief over martyrdom of the military personnel and expressed a firm resolve that "revenge" would be taken for the killing. He asked Mir Saadat Baloch, pro-vice chancellor of the Panjgur University, to comment on the same. Baloch paid tributes to the martyred soldiers and said Zardari's reaction to the incident is "understandable" because his family has also been a victim (his wife and former prime minister Benazir Bhutto was killed in an attack).

Commenting on the alleged social media campaign ridiculing the martyrs, Jamali insisted elements involved in "insulting propaganda" should be "gripped with a hard fist". He said the martyrs have offered the ultimate sacrifice by laying down their lives, so the government and civil society should "thrash" such elements.

Shahid said the propaganda insulting martyrs is "highly deplorable" and such comments are very painful for their families. He added people should realise that "their existence is linked to the existence of the country" and being "country-less" is a huge tragedy. He insisted the government should take serious action against such people.

Baloch condemned those targeting martyrs with malicious campaigns and said a "strategy" should be devised, not only against those who are active on social media, but also against those who are encouraging them. He recalled a foreign institution had conducted a survey before elections to assess whether people's confidence in the military had declined. He noted according to the results of the survey, "89 per cent of the youth all over Pakistan expressed confidence in the military". He agreed that action must be taken against those involved in propaganda.

Commenting on a recent meeting between Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif, Jamali said it is a "positive gesture" as everyone needs to work jointly for the country. Shahid commented coordination among different institutions is necessary for improving the economy. He noted the caretaker government took important steps to solve economic issues which should be taken forward by the new government. He said opposition parties should not create hurdles in the working of the new government. Baloch remarked people need to rise above party politics in the larger interest of the country.

Zulfiqar said Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif met a young student from Balochistan on 17 March. He noted Sharif had met the student in 2022 while visiting flood-hit areas and had helped the youth enrol in a reputable college. Jamali appreciated the prime minister's action and urged him to establish a network of quality schools in Balochistan, like he did in Punjab under his government. Baloch remarked it is a "welcome message" from the prime minister which would encourage students to focus more on their education.

Q: Most of those identified so far appeared to be in their 40s, and many had traveled from other parts of the country to attend the concert where Piknik, a Russian rock band formed in the late 1970s, was slated to perform on Friday night.

Alexander Baklemyshev, 51, had long dreamed about seeing the band, his son told local media, and had traveled solo from his home city of Satka, some 1,000 miles east of Moscow, for the concert.

His son, Maksim, told the Russian news outlet MSK1 that his father had sent him a video of the concert hall before the attack. That was the last he heard from his father.

“There was no last conversation,” his son said. “All that was left is the video, and nothing more.”

Irina Okisheva and her husband, Pavel Okishev, also traveled hundreds of miles to attend the concert — making their way from Kirov, northeast of Moscow. Mr. Okishev had received the tickets as an early birthday present. He was set to turn 35 next week, the Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper reported. Both he and his wife died in the attack, the paper reported.

“Very painful and scary,” Ms. Okisheva’s colleagues wrote on a social media page for a photo studio where she worked. “The whole studio team is horrified by what happened.”

Anastasiya Volkova lost both of her parents in the attack. She told 5 TV that she had missed a call from her mother on Friday night at around the time of the attack. When she called back, there was no response, Ms. Volkova said.

“I couldn’t answer the phone. I didn’t hear the call,” Ms. Volkova told the broadcaster, adding that her mother had been “really looking forward to this concert.”

As the death toll climbed to 133 people, the Moscow region’s health care ministry published a preliminary list of victims. It had 41 names; Andrey Rudnitsky was one of them.

A forward in an amateur hockey league, he turned 39 years old last week, according to his page on the league’s website. Mr. Rudnitsky’s teammates told Pro Gorod, a local news website, that he had moved to Moscow last year from Yaroslavl but planned to return home to play there. Mr. Rudnitsky had two children.

Ekaterina Novoselova, 42, was also on the list. Ms. Novoselova won a beauty pageant in 2001 in her home city of Tver, 110 miles northwest of Moscow, one of the pageant organizer’s told the local news outlet TIA. It reported that she had moved to Moscow to work as a lawyer and is survived by her husband and two children.

Some people appeared to have been named by mistake. Yevgeniya Ryumina, 38, told Komsomolskaya Pravda that she had fled the concert hall to safety. But she had lost her ID, Ms. Ryumina said, suggesting that might have led to the confusion.

Q: Ex-speaker continues to be lawmaker despite being abroad

Former speaker of parliament and Member for Machchangolhu Medhu constituency, Mohamed Nasheed, has spent over a month abroad, while being a lawmaker. Nasheed, who had been speaker during a large part of the current parliament term, had resigned after the Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP) submitted two no-confidence motions against him. On 12 December 2023, Nasheed announced that he was stepping away from politics and moved to Ghana on 30 January, where he has taken on the role of Secretary General of the Climate Vulnerability Forum (CVF). He has, however, still not resigned from him parliament seat. The President of The Democrats, of which Nasheed is a member, Hassan Latheef, when questioned on the matter, said Nasheed had issued a statement prior to moving to Ghana, and as such he had no role in the matter in his capacity as party president. The parliament secretariat on 31 January had said Nasheed had not informed the secretariat of his move to Ghana, that he had not taken leave, and would continue to receive the salary and benefits as a representative of the parliament for the three months remaining in his term. [Online, Approximate Words: 350]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

President pledges to allocate tax revenue to local councils

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu on 7 March announced that a certain percentage of revenue collected by the Maldives Inland Revenue Authority (MIRA) will be allocated to local councils. At a meeting he held with residents of Keyodhoo in Vaavu Atoll, the president said amendments will be brought to tax laws to implement the said change, which will allow councils to provide services in the islands using these funds. In addition, he also announced that changes will be made to the Goods and Services Act and the Tourism Act, to allocate a certain percentage of GST collected from guesthouses in the islands to the island council. The president said these changes will need to be made through the parliament and appealed to the public on the need for a parliament that extends cooperation to the government (parliament elections are scheduled for 21 April and the opposition currently holds a majority). [Online, Approximate Words: 250]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

Government to reduce raw fish exports to zero

Minister of Fisheries and Ocean Resources Ahmed Shiyam on 7 March, at a press conference held to share progress on the government's 100-day pledges for the sector, said the government's objective is to reduce the export of raw fish from the country to zero. Shiyam highlighted that the addition of value will increase revenue for the sector, noting that 75% of current fish exports is as raw material. The previous Solih administration had also said the fisheries sector can only be diversified and value increased by reducing the exports of raw fish, and instead add value in the country prior to export. Efforts were also made during that administration to increase processing capacity and extend cold storage facilities, although none of these efforts came to fruition. [Online, Approximate Words: 230]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

Minister sets new deadline for payments to fishermen

Minister of Fisheries and Ocean Resources Ahmed Shiyam on 7 March announced that 280m rufiyaa ($18.2m) remains outstanding to fishermen for fish purchases and, despite a previous deadline to pay the outstanding by 5 March, 50m rufiyaa ($3.2m) will be issued on 5 March. At a press conference held by the ministry, he reiterated that the backlog will be cleared by the beginning of Ramadan (10 March). Fishermen had protested at the government fish purchase and processing facility due to delays in payments due to them. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

President concludes tour of three atolls

President Muizzu on 7 March returned to capital after concluding his tour of Dhaalu, Meemu, and Vaavu Atolls. The tour is part of a series of visits the president has embarked on with the objective of visiting all atolls across the country and meeting with all local councils during the year. The president has to date met with 145 councils across the country. Muizzu has announced that a similar visit to all islands will be made in 2026. The president meets with the local councils, women's development committees, and residents of the islands during his visits. [Online, Approximate Words: 250]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

Parliament condemns minister's statements

The Maldivian parliament on 7 March issued a statement condemning statements by the Minister of Cities, Local Government and Public Works, Adam Shareef. Shareef, at a meeting held by President Muizzu with residents of Dhiggaru island in Meemu Atoll, had said that Muizzu faced challenges in implementing his vision and policies because of the parliament and intimated that he was controlling the urge to physically assault lawmakers. The parliament, in its statement, said the minister's statements may encourage violence against lawmakers and that such statements are not befitting of a person in such a position. It also called on the government to extend its cooperation on efforts to ensure the safety and security of lawmakers. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 8 Mar 24

Q: Because the defendants want to pursue an appeal now, ahead of any trial, Georgia law requires them to get permission from the presiding judge, Scott McAfee of Fulton Superior Court. Even if Judge McAfee allows an appeal to go forward, the Georgia Court of Appeals would have to agree to take the case.

The judge’s ruling last Friday followed weeks of public hearings delving into a romantic relationship between Ms. Willis, the Fulton County district attorney, and Nathan J. Wade, the lawyer she hired to run the Trump case. The defendants had argued that the relationship created an untenable conflict of interest for Ms. Willis.

Judge McAfee disagreed, but found that it had raised “a significant appearance of impropriety” that could be addressed by Mr. Wade withdrawing from the case.

In their filing on Monday, the defendants said that Mr. Wade’s resignation was “insufficient to cure the appearance of impropriety the court has determined exists.” If an appeal is not allowed now, they wrote, any eventual convictions could be subject to retrial if the judge’s decision is overturned later.

“The court’s order is ripe for pretrial appellate review,” Steven H. Sadow, Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer in Georgia, said in a statement.

Ms. Willis’s office had no immediate comment. Neither she nor Mr. Wade have spoken publicly since the ruling, beyond releasing his resignation letter and her response to it. This weekend, the NBC show “Meet the Press” announced that Mr. Wade had agreed to come on the Sunday morning program for an interview. But hours later, it said that Mr. Wade had backed out.

The defendants’ motion on Monday also noted a speech that Ms. Willis gave at a church in Atlanta on Jan. 14, in which she suggested that criticism of her and Mr. Wade was prompted by racism. Mr. Sadow had argued that the speech itself was grounds for disqualifying Ms. Willis.

Judge McAfee, in his ruling last Friday, said that the speech was “legally improper,” but also that there was not enough legal precedent in Georgia to guide him on whether he should disqualify Ms. Willis for it.

In seeking the judge’s permission to pursue an appeal, the defendants argued that this lack of precedent was another reason for the appellate court to weigh in.

Mr. Trump and 14 others are charged with racketeering and a number of other crimes related to accusations that they conspired to overturn the former president’s 2020 election loss in the state. Four other defendants have already pleaded guilty.

Shortly after the indictments last summer, Ms. Willis asked for a trial to start this August. But the odds are low that it will happen that soon.

Q: Officials condemn Israeli 'siege' of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza

Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Nasser Kanani yesterday condemned a week of an Israeli "siege" of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza, saying that Israel was adding "another shameful page to its disastrous history and dark list of crimes".

International-facing English-language Press TV highlighted reports that Israeli troops were "raping Palestinian women before killing them" at the hospital.

See: Briefing: Anger online after Palestinian said Israel forces raped Gaza women

Kanani repeated these claims in his statement, calling on the international community to take "effective and decisive steps" to set up an international investigative group to "reveal the volume of the war crimes" of Israel at the hospital.

Israel says that it has killed more than 170 gunmen at the hospital in an extensive raid, while Kanani stressed that 170 "patients, medical staff and displaced Palestinians" were killed in Israel's "horrific crimes".

Yesterday, Iran's Foreign Minister Hossein Amir-Abdollahian discussed the Gaza war with his Omani counterpart Badr al-Busaidi, condemning Israel's "barbaric and inhumane actions" at Al-Shifa Hospital.

Somalia releases 33 Iranian fishermen and sailors detained last year

Iranian broadcast media reported this morning that Somalia had released 33 Iranian fishermen and sailors detained for illegal fishing in last summer.

Ali Gholampour, Iran's ambassador to Kenya and Somalia, said yesterday that the release of the fishermen could pave the way for restoring ties between Mogadishu and Tehran.

Somalia cut diplomatic ties with Iran in 2016 after accusing Tehran of trying to destabilise the Horn of Africa nation.

Iranians online criticise 'merciful dealing' call for cleric in land-grabbing scandal

Anti-establishment Iranians online have criticised a call by the conservative Hamshahri newspaper to "treat with religious mercy" the case of senior cleric Hojjat ol-Eslam Kazem Seddiqi who has recently been at the centre of an illegal land seizure scandal.

See: Briefing: Allegations of land grabbing by senior cleric stir controversy in Iran

Users wondered why the "merciful approach" was not exercised in regard with ordinary citizens and critics of the establishment.

"Religious mercy-based dealing for insiders, decisive dealing with outsiders," one user said sarcastically in a post on X (formerly Twitter).

Some asked why protesters were executed for petty crimes such as "setting fire to dustbins" during the 2022 nationwide protests rather than being granted such "merciful treatment". Charges against Mohsen Shekari, who was the first protester executed in relation to the 2022 unrest, included blocking a street and setting fire to a dustbin alongside wounding a security force officer.

They circulated photos of the protesters executed or killed, as well as other cases of police crackdown and political prisoners, under the hashtag "merciful dealing".

See also

Briefing: Rouhani, Zarif reveal new details on Iran's 2020 attack on US base

Source: BBC Monitoring 25 Mar 24
