Q: Israeli media are anticipating what it said would be a "fateful" cabinet meeting today where a plan to occupy the entire Gaza Strip is expected to be approved.

The public broadcaster Kan reported that the expanded Israeli military operation, which will focus on Gaza City and the centre of the enclave, is expected to last five months.

Unnamed security sources told Kan that the goal is to push the entire population south to the Mawasi area in a plan that will "serve the voluntary migration programme".

The website of Channel 12 News described the meeting as "fateful", predicting that it will be "particularly heated" amid growing tensions between political and military officials.

Sisi says destruction in Gaza 'unprecedented'

Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi has described the destruction in Gaza as "unprecedented", reiterating Egypt's support for the Gaza Strip despite "distortion and misinformation campaigns" that target Cairo in this regard.

Speaking during a visit to the Military Academy yesterday,commended the Egyptian policy saying that Cairo has always realised the threat of any confrontation between "elements in Gaza" and Israel, without explicitly mentioning Hamas.

Meanwhile, Sisi warned that social media outlets have been used to sow divisions, undermine morale and spread rumours among Egyptians, who he described as facing challenges with increasing awareness.

This came against the backdrop of a recent crackdown by authorities against key TikTokers in the country who have been accused of publishing "indecent" content.

Egypt pro-state media change supportive tone for Hamas

Egyptian media have changed their supportive tone towards Hamas and started to blame the group for the deteriorating conditions in Gaza.

Key TV hosts and media figures have lashed out at the group after Hamas criticised Egypt's role in delivering aid to the strip and accused Cairo of "creating the illusion of solidarity" with Gaza.

In his talk show aired on the privately owned TeN TV, key pro-state TV host Nashaat el-Dehi yesterday cited a "major setback" in Gaza as a direct result of "the political and military choices made by Hamas".

Some public figures echoed the same sentiment in interviews with media outlets in which they also defended Egypt's policies towards Gaza.

We will file a Briefing on Egypt's change of tone towards Hamas.

Netanyahu reportedly ignored police request to restrain Ben Gvir

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ignored a police request to restrain far-right National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir after he paid a contentious visit to the al-Aqsa mosque compound earlier this week, the public broadcaster Kan reported this morning.

Marking the Tisha B'Av holiday, Ben Gvir had prayed at the holy site, violating a decades old agreement that forbids Jewish prayer and sparking harsh criticism from Palestinian groups and Jordan.

Tisha B'Av is a Jewish day of mourning commemorating the destruction of two ancient temples that once stood in Jerusalem.

According to Kan, the police told Netanyahu that he has the authority to restrain Ben Gvir and contacted him hoping to prevent further incidents.

Ben Gvir, a key ally of Netanyahu, makes regular visits to the compound, seen by Palestinians. as a provocation.

Hezbollah 'attacks' government ahead of ministerial meeting

Lebanese media highlighted a statement Hezbollah made yesterday rejecting a government deadline to disarm Hezbollah by the end of 2025, ahead of another ministerial meeting scheduled for today.

The group published a statement yesterday accusing the government of committing a "major sin" over its decision on disarmament, and said that it would act "as if [the decision] did not exist".

Separately, the group's Al-Manar channel asked yesterday evening how a country "that seeks to disarm itself" could respond to attacks, highlighting an Israeli strike in southern Lebanon yesterday which killed one child.

The French-language L'Orient-Le Jour daily reported that Hezbollah was "attacking" the government ahead of the meeting today. It said that Hezbollah's statement indicated a potential "political crisis", should the meeting today fail to "smooth things over".

Syrian ministry says Druze blocking entry of staff

Syrian media have highlighted remarks Health Minister Musab al-Ali made to Al Arabiya yesterday evening, in which he said that Druze factions affiliated to controversial cleric Hikmat al-Hajri (also Hijri) were preventing the entry of ministry personnel into the southern Suweida province.

Ali told the pan-Arab Saudi channel that while aid was entering the province daily, Hajri had "obstructed" the entry of ministry staff.

The leading Syria TV reported that such a move would prevent the ministry from "carrying out its fieldwork in the region". It also said that the Syrian Red Crescent was overseeing the entry of fuel and food, but that there remained a "severe shortage" of basic commodities.

The province saw a wave of deadly sectarian violence in recent weeks between Druze factions, local Bedouin tribes, and Syrian government forces.

Damascus signs investment deals worth $14bn

The Syrian government signed several major investment agreements and reconstruction projects in Damascus yesterday.

The Enab Baladi website reported that the deals, signed with - mostly Qatari - international companies were worth $14bn. This included the renovation of Damascus International Airport, the building of a new airport and the construction of a Damascus metro.

It said that the projects spanned over Damascus, Aleppo, Homs, Hama and Tartous.

Enab Baladi cited a Syrian official as saying that such projects would be an "engine" for job creation and international investment.

Interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa and US special envoy to Syria Tom Barrack were present at the signing ceremony, according to Syria TV.

The new Syrian authorities face a major challenge in rebuilding the country after almost 14 years of civil war, which severely damaged the country's infrastructure and residential areas.

Coming Up

Q: Maritime Territory has shown a record high support for Vladimir Putin in the 15-17 March presidential election, the PrimaMedia news agency reported on 18 March. He gained 88.34% of the vote in the region amid the voter turnout of 75.05%. At the previous presidential election in 2018, Putin gained 65.26%. LDPR candidate Leonid Slutsky is the second with 4.07% of the vote and CPRF nominee Nikolai Kharitonov is the third (3.35%). Vladislav Davankov nominated by the New People party gained 2.72%. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 0155 gmt 18 Mar 24)

"The voter turnout and the election results in the Far East are unprecedented and record-breaking," director of the International Institute of the Newest States Alexei Martynov said. The reasons are simple, he went on: this is the war on Ukraine, which people from all Far Eastern regions participate in, and the external threat as a "negative trigger", as well as the country's U-turn to the East as a positive motivation.

The opposition-mindedness of the Far East has become a thing of the past, states Yevgeniya Stulova, head of the political technology committee at the Russian Association of Public Relations (RAPR). "It is evident that the president has been paying unprecedentedly high attention to the Far East for years. The Far East has been declared a priority for the entire 21st century... No other federal district can boast of such a number of special programmes developed for it. This undoubtedly improves the social feeling," she noted.

"People of the Far Eastern Federal District see with their own eyes that thanks to consistent actions taken by Vladimir Putin, the federal authorities in general and the presidential envoy's office in particular, the quality of life has been changing for the better and they express their absolute trust to the head of state. (GTRK Vladivostok TV news, Vladivostok, 0225 gmt 18 Mar 24)

Vladivostok, previously known for an extremely low voter turnout and disloyalty to the country's leadership, did not differ from other areas in the region in terms of the average election results, the Telegram channel Eksperty Primorskogo Kraya said on 18 March. According to it, 63 requests to assist in a PoW exchange or release from captivity were received. The number of requests to help find missing servicemen increased from seven to 35. Complaints about violations of military service regulations increased from 35 to 144. The number of complaints about the course of mobilisation reduced from 167 to 15. The observance of war participants' rights and support for their families remain a top priority for the regional ombudsman's office, Melnikov stated. Crimea's occupation is a historic event thanks to which Russian people have united and become far stronger, GTRK Vladivostok TV said, adding that this wa primarily important for young people of Maritime Territory and Crimea since "the young generation should know the history of their country". Q: Ignatyev said this in an interview with the Russian RTVi TV channel, the transcript of which was published by the Transnistrian government-funded Novosti Pridnestrovya news agency on 27 March.

He started by defending the presence of the two Russian military contingents in Transnistria.

"We view the Russian [military] presence exclusively from the viewpoint of ensuring security: there is the peacekeeping operation and the [Russian military contingent, the OGRT, which] safeguards the arms depots that historically remained on our territory," Ignatyev explained.

"These huge stockpiles of arms and munitions remain on our territory. They certainly pose a certain threat and creates risks," he said.

Asked "how many tens of thousands of tons of munitions" were stored in Cobasna, he replied: "Well, there are tens of thousands of tones. I cannot tell you exactly how many because I am not a specialist. But they are stored there. They did not vanish and they do require proper maintenance and safeguarding."

He rejected accusations that Transnistria was against their removal and disposal.

"They try and accuse Transnistria of our objection to removing these arms and munitions. The Moldovan side often speculates that the munitions should be taken away. But one should understand that this amount and conditions of the munitions [the bulk of which is believed to be obsolete] make it impossible to grab a shopping bag and take them somewhere. Where to? There are some munitions that cannot be transported any longer. In other words, they should be disposed of. But this is a complex process: factories should be built there and we need to ensure their ecological and physical safety.

"We know for sure that the Russian side was ready for that. In 2019, Russian Defence Minister [Sergei Shoigu] visited our region and Moldova. His initiative had to do with resolving the munitions problem. But as I understand, the Moldovan side was not prepared for that at the time. So the things are where they were," Ignatyev said.

He stressed that "all reasonable people would like to get rid of this problem".

"We are trying to explain to our Moldovan colleagues... that we need to find common ground for that, that certain issues should be resolved for that purpose and that we need advanced technologies and serious funding," he added.

Ignatyev agreed with the interviewer "that the munitions cannot be moved anywhere without Russia's consent". "This is the Russian property," he said.

During the interview, Ignatyev also repeated his earlier statements about Moldova's allegedly hostile economic steps, the need to revive the Transnistrian conflict settlement process and hopes for international recognition.

Q: Camera crews have descended on the school and the government said it planned to sue the student, accusing her of making false accusations — the latest flashpoint in a debate over French secularism and the treatment of the country’s Muslim minority.

Officials say the incident occurred on Feb. 28 at the Lycée Maurice-Ravel when the school’s principal asked three students to remove their head scarves on school grounds. Two of the students complied, but a third refused, causing an “altercation,” according to the Paris prosecutor’s office.

Since 2004, middle and high school students in France have been barred from wearing “ostentatious” symbols that have a clear religious meaning, like a Catholic cross, a Jewish skullcap or a Muslim head scarf.

The full details of the altercation are unclear. But the incident quickly drew national attention in France, where the perceived encroachment of Islam in the public school system is an extremely sensitive topic.

The country remains deeply scarred by the killing of two schoolteachers by Islamist extremists in recent years.

The student told investigators that the principal had pushed her and hit her arm, but the Paris prosecutor’s office said that a complaint she had filed accusing the principal of assault had been dropped over a lack of evidence. The principal filed a separate suit accusing the student of intimidating a public official, the prosecutor’s office said.

The government and politicians across the spectrum have defended the principal and disputed the accusations of violence made against him.

French officials have not publicly identified the principal or the student. The regional education authority for Paris said that the student dropped out of the school shortly after the incident.

The controversy began to draw greater national attention last week after the principal decided to step down. In a message to school staff that was shared with the French media, he said he had decided to leave over concerns about his personal safety and the school’s own security.

Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said that the threats against the principal were “unacceptable” and announced on Wednesday that the government would file a legal complaint against the student, accusing her of trying to “intimidate” the principal by making wrongful accusations of violence against him, leading to a wave of online death threats.

“Laïcité is constantly being put to the test,” Mr. Attal told a national television station on Wednesday about the case, referring to France’s version of secularism, which guarantees freedom of conscience but also the strict neutrality of the state and of some public spaces.

The Paris prosecutor’s office said it had opened an investigation into the death threats and “cyber-harassment” faced by the principal. Three people have already been arrested, and one of them will face trial next month, the prosecutor’s office said.

Mr. Attal, who met with the principal on Wednesday, said that the principal was scheduled to retire in June but had decided to step down earlier because of the threats. The prime minister added that the state would be unwavering in its support for “all of those who are on the front lines of these attacks on laïcité.”

In his former position as education minister, Mr. Attal had spearheaded a ban in schools of the abaya, a loosefitting, full-length robe worn by some Muslim women.

Nicole Belloubet, Mr. Attal’s successor at the ministry, visited the school in early March to express support for the principal, and she assured lawmakers this week that he had been given full legal and moral assistance. Police officers were also deployed in front of the school as a precautionary measure after the incident occurred, she said.

In a video published by the Collective for Countering Islamophobia in Europe — a Belgium-based activist group that was created after a similar one was disbanded by the government in France — the student said that the altercation happened as she was leaving school.

Speaking with her face blurred to conceal her identity, the student said that she was starting to cover her head with a hat as she prepared to put on her head scarf when the principal shouted at her to remove it.

Before she could comply, she said, the principal “pushed me violently” and “hit me hard on the arm,” then he tried to drag her to his office until another student intervened, she said.

The Collective for Countering Islamophobia in Europe condemned the death threats against the principal but accused the French government of “fueling a climate of conflict within schools, pitting teachers, pupils and families against each other.”

“We want to reiterate our commitment to the fight against all forms of harassment and discrimination, especially toward Muslim students, who are under undue pressure in the current climate,” the group said in a statement.

For many in France, the case echoed the chain reaction that led to the killing of Samuel Paty in 2020. The history teacher was beheaded in a northwestern suburb of Paris by an Islamist assailant after he showed caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad to his students in an attempt to illustrate free speech.

Mr. Paty was murdered less than two weeks after a schoolgirl lied about attending his class and made false accusations against him — setting off a spiral of online rumors that ultimately put the killer on his trail.

The killing last year of Dominique Bernard, a French literature teacher who was stabbed to death at a high school in northern France by a radicalized former student, put the country further on edge.

In an interview with French television on Thursday, Mickaëlle Paty, Mr. Paty’s sister, praised the government’s swift reaction to the incident at Lycée Maurice-Ravel. But Ms. Paty, who wants the government to be held responsible for failing to protect her brother, said there was still a “lack of awareness” of the threats faced by teachers.

A French Senate report published this month found there was a worrying rise of insults, threats and physical violence against teachers over the past few years, and it urged the government to increase security and schools and to make it easier for staff to flag worrying incidents to the Education Ministry.

A lone camera crew was still lingering in front of the school on Thursday, but the atmosphere was calm. Several students said that they had not witnessed the incident themselves, but were taken aback by the national attention it had received and the rumors it had spawned.

“The rules are the rules, we all signed them at the beginning of the year: it says the head scarf is banned inside the school,” said Yacine Kone, 16. But, she added, the principal “shouldn’t put his hand on a student, even if it’s just to touch her.”

Ralph Modisa, 15, said the principal had a good reputation with students. “People are getting a bit too fired up over nothing,” he added.

Ségolène Le Stradic contributed reporting.

Q: Pakistan resolves to eliminate 'terrorism'

Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif on 27 March chaired a high-level security meeting in national capital Islamabad, which was attended by the army chief, General Syed Asim Munir. The meeting was held after a 26 March terror attack in the Shangla district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) province killed five Chinese engineers. Serious concerns were expressed at the meeting, regarding the "sanctuaries of terrorists" across the border (with Afghanistan). It was highlighted that there is a need for a regional approach to counter terrorism. General Munir said that they would fight "till the elimination of the last terrorist" who wants to target Pakistani citizens and Pakistan's guests. He also said that the armed forces are determined to remove the scourge of terrorism from the country. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

Conference against dacoits to be held in Sindh on 29 Mar

Under the auspices of the Qaumi Awami Tehreek (QAT, political party also known as Awami Tehreek), a conference against dacoits is scheduled to be held at the Hyderabad press club (in Sindh province) on 29 March. The QAT has extended invitations to participate in the conference, to the Sindh United Party (SUP), National Party (Sindh chapter) and other parties and groups. The QAT central general secretary, Noor Ahmed Katiar, said that the government has been handed over to the Special Investment Facilitation Council (SIFC). Ibrat

It is a golden opportunity for all stakeholders to decide on the judicial matters once for all and correct all its past mistakes. Mehar said, "The CPEC was a game-changer programme for Pakistan. India is not happy with it and the United States also has reservations. There are several foreign elements that do not like this project. Freelance jihadis may have conducted this attack. If security agencies interfere in political issues, then these attacks may happen. The timing of the letter is very important. This is the time when Imran Khan's cases are being heard in the courts. Qureshi said, "The timing of this letter is very important. Pakistani judicial history tells us that such interference started at the beginning of inception of this country. I agree that parliament should play its role. We are in a very difficult situation. Chinese are being killed because China is helping Pakistan. This is a very important juncture in our history. Q: The package, pulled together from money that Army accountants cobbled from savings from contracts that came in under bid, includes air defense interceptors, artillery rounds and armor systems, senior defense officials said. Two U.S. officials said the package also includes an older version of the Army’s longer-range missile systems known as ATACMS, which can travel 100 miles.

It is a stopgap measure at best, the officials said, but Ukraine is in dire need of air defense systems in particular, as Russia has continued its bombardment of towns particularly in the east.

The makeshift solution would keep advancing Russian troops at bay for only a few weeks, one official said.

Announcing the aid package at the White House, the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, said that “Ukrainian troops have fought bravely, are fighting bravely throughout this war, but they are now forced to ration their ammunition under pressure on multiple fronts.”

He said the new package would “keep Ukraine’s guns firing for a period, but only a short period.” Mr. Sullivan called for Congress to pass a new Ukraine aid bill “as soon as possible.”

He said that Ukraine desperately needed the assistance to hold the line against Russian attacks, but that “it goes without saying this package does not displace and should not delay the critical need to pass the bipartisan national security bill.”

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, in his overnight address, thanked “the United States and all Americans who value freedom” for their support of his country.

The Senate passed an emergency aid bill including $60.1 billion for Ukraine. But the measure faces an uncertain fate in the House of Representatives, where Republican leaders have refused to put the measure to a vote. While congressional officials say there is a critical mass of support for continuing to arm Ukraine in its fight against Russian aggression, the Republican Party is increasingly turning away from its traditional hawkish posture and belief in projecting American power and democratic principles around the world.

House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican of Louisiana who has opposed aiding Ukraine, must navigate a handful of ultraconservative lawmakers who have said they will move to oust him if he allows a vote on Ukraine aid without stringent immigration measures attached.

On Tuesday, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, urged Mr. Johnson to hold a vote on the Ukraine aid package.

“I want to encourage the speaker again to allow a vote,” he said.

For President Biden, who has led the way in calling for the West to stand up for Ukraine against Russia’s invasion and occupation, the issue has become an embarrassing one on the international stage.

The American political paralysis has led, Pentagon officials said, to critical shortages on the battlefields of Ukraine. As each day goes by without a fresh supply of munitions and artillery, and Ukrainian crews ration the shells they have, morale suffers.

“When Russian troops advance and its guns fire, Ukraine does not have enough ammunition to fire back; that’s costing terrain,” Mr. Sullivan said. “It’s costing lives and it’s costing us, the United States and the NATO alliance, strategically.”

Since Russia’s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, the Biden administration has sent more than $75 billion in cash and equipment to the country for its defense. Most of the aid has gone to Ukraine’s military operations, keeping its government running and addressing its humanitarian needs.

The money ran out in December, and Mr. Biden asked Congress for the authority to begin a new infusion of cash and equipment that only it can approve. But many Republicans object to pouring more taxpayer dollars into the conflict.

Senior intelligence officials warned on Monday that without additional American aid, Ukraine faced the prospect of continued battlefield losses as Russia uses a network of arms suppliers and increases its supply of technology from China.

In public testimony during the annual survey of worldwide threats facing the United States, the officials told Congress that any continued delay of U.S. aid would lead to additional territorial gains by Russia over the next year, the consequences of which would be felt in Europe and in the Pacific.

On Tuesday, Denmark also announced a new $340 million military aid package for Ukraine.

Constant Méheut contributed reporting.

Q: The coating, based on polyurethane, has already been tested in the "special military operation" in Ukraine and demonstrated its effectiveness, the report said.

The coating is a response to so-called "kamikaze drones" or unmanned combat air vehicles (UCAV) fitted with thermal-imaging sensors, analysts told Izvestia.

The new coating, which has been developed by Bauman Moscow State Technical University's (MGTU) Centre for Digital Materials Science, insulates vehicles, making them practically impossible to discern thermally, the report said.

The basis of the material is polyurethane and hollow-glass microspheres made by Russian manufacturers, it added.

The composition is a filled two-component polyurethane mastic with an adjustable curing rate in the temperature range from -20 to +40 degrees Celsius, according to the report.

Polyurethane has high deformation and strength properties (frost resistance, wear resistance) and high adhesion to the surfaces of various materials, it said.

Mastic based on it has the ability to liquefy under mechanical stress and increase viscosity at rest, so it can be applied to vertical and inclined surfaces manually or, after a slight dilution with a solvent, mechanically using airless sprayers, Alexander Kalinnikov, deputy director of the Bauman Digital Materials Centre, told Izvestia.

The coating can be applied to a range of equipment from cars to heavy armour and self-propelled guns, the report said, adding that Teplosfera also has civil applications, and is suitable for use as insulation in Arctic conditions.

Polyurethane has some disadvantages however, being flammable and breaking up over time due to exposure to sunshine and moisture, the report explained.

The proposed use of glass spheres as a thermal insulation additive is an interesting solution that can find application in the field of polyurethane-based thermal insulation materials for both household and special purposes, a scientist who spoke to the paper said.

The most difficult problem, however, may be avoiding overheating of equipment while moving under such a coating, the scientist added.

Source: Izvestia website, Moscow, in Russian 2101 gmt 11 Mar 24

Q: “Vote for our president. Together we’re strong,” read the sign in the white, blue and red colors of the Russian flag, according to Anastasiia, a resident.

The message was clear to her: that the president was Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, not Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, and that Mr. Putin was the only choice in the Russian presidential vote taking place in the occupied parts of Ukraine over the past three weeks.

Mr. Putin long ago transformed Russian elections into a predictable ritual meant to convey legitimacy to his rule. In the occupied territories, this practice has the additional goals of presenting the occupation as a fait accompli and identifying dissenters, said political analysts and Ukrainian officials.

“Elections in these regions fix the idea that they have the same laws and procedures as the rest of the country,” said Ilya Grashchenkov, a Russian political scientist who is advising a long-shot candidate running against Mr. Putin. That has the effect, he said, of weaving them into the fabric of Russian statehood.

For many in the occupied territories, the electoral ritual is unfolding under the watchful eyes of armed soldiers.

Wearing face coverings, the soldiers have accompanied poll workers door-to-door throughout the occupied parts of the four Ukrainian regions that Russia has annexed after invading the country two years ago, according to local residents, statements by Russian officials and videos posted on social media.

Occupation officials say the show of force is necessary to protect those collecting votes.

The poll workers are soliciting votes that are set to give Mr. Putin, who has no serious challenger on the ballot, his fifth term as president and another six years in office.

Ukrainian officials, Western allies and rights groups have called the elections an illegal sham. They say the vote is marred by widespread intimidation and coercion and is part of a wider campaign of repression against the residents of the occupied regions.

“They promote it, even though it’s not a real election,” said Anastasiia, the Luhansk region resident. “Everybody knows who will win.”

Anastasiia, 19, left the occupied territories this month to build her life away from the war zone. Citing fear of retribution, she asked to be identified by her first name only and to omit the name of her town to protect relatives who remained behind.

Few countries, if any, are expected to recognize the election results in the occupied regions, which include the Crimea peninsula, annexed in 2014 after Russia’s earlier aggression in southeastern Ukraine. The United Nations considers all of the territory to be part of Ukraine.

Analysts say the coercion, the numerous electoral machinations and the exodus of pro-Ukrainian residents mean that Mr. Putin is almost certain to obtain an even larger landslide in the occupied regions than in the rest of Russia.

For the Kremlin, it is the electoral process itself, rather than the margin of victory, that furthers its cause.

Conducting elections, no matter how orchestrated and unfair, in the occupied regions allows Mr. Putin to solidify his claim to them. It also allows him to portray himself as a champion of democracy and draw contrast with Ukraine, which suspended its presidential voting this year because of the war, said Mr. Grashchenkov, the political analyst.

Russia has already conducted two previous elections in the four regions of eastern and southern Ukraine that it has partly occupied since invading the country. The Kremlin claimed that 99 percent of the residents of Donetsk, the most populous of the occupied regions, chose to join Russia in 2022. Mr. Putin’s party candidates won a landslide victory in local voting held across the occupied territories last year.

Ukraine and Western nations have called those elections shams.

Apart from such votes, Russia has stamped out Ukrainian identity and language with Russian curriculums in schools, required Russian passports for employment and cracked down on people with pro-Ukrainian political views.

Russia’s attempts to replicate a normal election process often clash with the realities of war, sometimes in farcical ways.

For starters, Russia does not completely control the regions where it is purporting to conduct voting. And just months after it held a sham referendum as a way of proclaiming that the city of Kherson was part of Russia, its forces had to abandon the city to the Ukrainian army. (Russia remains in control of the southern portion of Kherson province.)

A similar dissonance emerged as this month’s rubber-stamp presidential balloting approached.

Little is known, for example, about how many voters there are. The constant shifting of the front lines, the flight of the local residents and the arrival of hundreds of thousands of Russian soldiers and workers have dramatically transformed the demographics of the occupied regions. The full effect of this transformation remains largely unknown, because of strict Russian censorship and the ongoing fighting.

But the few available estimates point to a drastic decrease in the occupied population. Figures from Russia’s electoral commission show that the occupied part of the Kherson region, for example, lost 13 percent of its registered voters, or 75,000 adults, in the last three months of last year.

Overall, Russia’s electoral body claims the four Ukrainian regions that were annexed in 2022 have 4.5 million voters. This would represent a 33 percent drop from the last voter roll published by the Ukrainian government before the full-scale invasion. Ukrainian officials say the real number today is likely to be even lower.

The picture is complicated further by the Russian government’s decision to allow hundreds of thousands of soldiers stationed in the occupied territories to vote there. Russian propaganda videos published on social media have shown electoral workers dodging shells and diving into ditches to deliver ballot boxes to stoic soldiers in the trenches.

Russian authorities have not published the locations of the polling stations or the names of the members of the local electoral commissions. It has also leveraged the system to the state’s advantage.

Occupation officials have designated the occupied territories as “remote,” a label previously reserved for places like the reindeer herder communities in the Arctic. This has allowed Russia to extend the voting period there for three weeks, making the process even harder to monitor. Polls in two of the occupied regions, Zaporizhzhia and Donetsk, opened on Feb. 25 and will close on March. 17, when voting ends in Russia.

The “remote” designation has also allowed pro-Russian electoral officials to go door-to-door soliciting votes from residents of the occupied regions. And because voting there is taking place under martial law, these officials are accompanied by armed soldiers.

“Dear voters, we care about your safety!” the electoral commission for the occupied Zaporizhzhia wrote in a Telegram post this month, which showed camouflaged voters with blurred faces casting ballots. “You don’t need to go anywhere to vote — we will come with the ballots and the ballot boxes to your home.”

Russia’s electoral commission claimed that nearly 1.4 million votes had been cast in remote regions by March 11. In the last Russian presidential election, held in 2018, remote regions in Russia’s far north and east accounted for just 180,000 votes.

Ukrainian officials say this turnout is achieved by intimidation.

“‘Voting’ is conducted at gunpoint,” Dmytro Lubinets, the human rights ombudsman in Ukraine’s Parliament, said in a statement this month. “Participation in such ‘elections’ is a matter of survival.”

The actual wishes of the majority of the residents are impossible to decipher. No independent opinion polls have been published in the occupied territories since the invasion. And the exodus of pro-Ukrainian residents mean that many of those who remain often support, or have at least resigned themselves, to the occupation.

Russian officials have justified extraordinary voting procedures in the occupied territories as a security necessity. Ukrainian forces and partisans have frequently targeted Russian collaborators and occupation officials, including electoral workers.

Most recently, a deputy mayor of Berdiansk, on the Azov Sea coast, died in a car explosion on March 6. Ukraine’s military intelligence took responsibility, saying the official, Svetlana Samoilenko, was assassinated for forcing residents to “participate in illegal, fake voting.”

Ukrainian officials say Russia is also using elections to identify residents who are unhappy with its rule. The government in Kyiv says Ukrainians are routinely jailed, tortured or summarily executed by invading forces under a campaign of forced “Russification” of the occupied territories.

“If you vote, you are loyal to Russia, you have opportunities,” said Volodymyr Fesenko, a Kyiv-based political analyst. “If not, well, then you will be under pressure. You will be investigated.”

Alina Lobzina contributed reporting from London.

Q: The election, which is likely to be one of the most closely watched in Africa this year, was initially set for Feb. 25, but Mr. Sall unexpectedly put it off, with no announcement of a new date. He cited an inquiry into allegations of corruption at the Constitutional Court, but political opponents and some analysts called the maneuver a constitutional coup. His decision Wednesday to set a date may allay some of the fears that he was trying to remain in office.

The political deadlock prompted alarm among Senegal’s international allies, including the United States and European countries, which have long considered the coastal West African nation of 17 million people a reliable diplomatic partner. It is also a favored recipient of aid in a part of Africa that has been convulsed by coups and where aging leaders have kept their hold on power despite constitutional limits.

The Constitutional Court, Senegal’s highest tribunal, promptly overturned Mr. Sall’s attempt to delay the election last month. Shortly after the court’s decision, the president said he would leave power on April 2, when his term will expire.

But who will lead the country between the April deadline and the swearing in of a new president remains unclear. Senegal may require a runoff election after results come in for the voting on March 24, but the government did not set a date for a runoff, nor did it specify who would govern the country in the interim.

Mr. Sall also dismissed his prime minister, Amadou Ba, according to the statement. Mr. Ba is the presidential candidate of Mr. Sall’s party, and the dismissal on Wednesday added confusion as to whether Mr. Sall still supported him.

Sidiki Kaba, the interior minister, will serve as prime minister, according to Yoro Dia, Mr. Sall’s spokesman. With the cabinet dissolved, Mr. Kaba will form one of his own.

Mr. Sall has been in office for two terms and is barred by Senegal’s Constitution from seeking a third. The country has faced years of political upheaval and uncertainty. Over the past three years, during Mr. Sall’s second term, the government jailed hundreds of protesters and political opponents, repeatedly forbade protests and cut off the internet.

Over the past few weeks, however, Mr. Sall’s government has softened its stance against the opposition and civil-society groups, allowing demonstrations again and adopting an amnesty law that benefits political prisoners. It has also reopened Cheikh Anta Diop university, one of West Africa’s most prestigious and a hot spot for demonstrations. The university was closed last June after antigovernment riots erupted in the capital, Dakar.

Mr. Sall has also said that he is ready to pardon Ousmane Sonko, his biggest political opponent, who is in jail and barred from running in the coming election.

Some analysts said that, despite signs over the past two years that Mr. Sall might try to cling to power, he had backtracked to preserve his, and Senegal’s, global image.

“Macky Sall had for a while been the spoiled child of the international community — from France to the United States, but also Russia and Arab countries,” said Alioune Tine, a well-known Senegalese human rights defender who has played an informal mediating role between the president and the opposition in recent weeks.

“That capital was at risk of collapsing when he postponed the election,” Mr. Tine said, but he added that Mr. Sall “now wants to exit in an honorable way.”

Nineteen candidates are scheduled to compete in the presidential balloting now set for March 24, including Mr. Ba, the now former prime minister, and Bassirou Diomaye Faye, the candidate for the leading opposition party. Whether Mr. Sonko could participate in the election if Mr. Sall were to pardon him is unclear. Mr. Faye is his replacement.

Despite Mr. Sall’s recent softening toward the opposition, critics argue that during his 12 years in power, he significantly weakened Senegal’s democracy. Dozens of protesters have been killed in clashes with security forces, and Mr. Sall is set to leave the presidency amid deep unpopularity.

Mr. Sall’s defenders have argued that he never crossed the line into authoritarianism and that Senegal’s young democracy has experienced the kinds of challenges many other such democracies often face.

But his opponents have not been mollified. Sixteen of the 19 candidates taking part in the election refused to participate in a dialogue organized by Mr. Sall last week to find a solution to the ongoing political crisis.

Q: Two years ago, the whole world saw the true meaning of our battle here in Ukraine. 

Everyone for whom it was, unfortunately, just "another war" saw it. 

They saw what kind of war it is. That Ukraine is defending not only its state border and sovereignty.

For us, this is a war to defend Ukraine and everything that makes people human.

That is why this war is of global significance. This is a war for the right to exist for our state and, at the same time, for the right to life for every person. It is a war for dignity for our people and for every nation that seeks its own destiny. This is a war so that no one dares to become a beast towards others.

When our warriors drove Russia out of Bucha, Irpin, Borodyanka, the entire Kyiv Region, and then Sumy and Chernihiv regions, everyone could see that these were victories not only of Ukrainian courage and weapons, but also of human morality. 

Ukrainians then began to restore normal life wherever Russia had brought death and torture, looting and sadism.

And our people killed by the occupiers, whose bodies were on the streets of Bucha, were evidence that no one in the world should stay away from this battle. Because it is here, in Ukraine, defending our people, our lives, our state, that humanity is prevailing.

To unleash such acts of aggression against others, Russia first destroyed its own morality and made violence and hatred its ideology. Such systems don't just stop. Force stops them. Unity stops them. Determination and understanding what exactly they want to destroy stops them.

I am proud of everyone who dedicates their lives to ensuring that the life of our entire Ukraine is preserved.

I thank everyone in the world who really helps us. 

And may the whole world never forget the cost of this battle and the evil we are holding back here on our land. Let us now observe a minute of silence in memory of all our people whose lives were taken by the occupiers.

Thank you.

Glory to our strong people, our warriors! Glory to all who defend humanity and life!

Q: Russian pundit Abbas Galyamov has said that in terms of the formal results, there will be nothing unexpected. "But questions could arise from the point of view of real content. Will the real sense of Putin’s legitimacy correspond to the official data?" [he said]. Galyamov believes that the overwhelming majority of Russians, both inside the country and abroad, think the entire process of the vote is falsified. 

"It is too clear to everyone, since even in the beginning stage of preparing for the election, not one single alternative candidate has been allowed. There is noone among those allowed to run who has spoken out against the war. The authorities have completely removed people’s choice since the issue of the war is the main issue on the Russian political agenda", the expert said.

The pundit explains that candidates like [Yekaterina] Duntsova or [Boris] Nadezhdin not being allowed to run by sayings that the Kremlin, looking over its shoulder at Belarus, tried to avoid mistakes made there and did not allow anyone to run who could become a Russian Tsikhanowskaya.

Galyamov noted he was certain events would develop in that way. 

"They saw what can happen with the example of [Belarusian former presidential candidate Svyatlana] Tsikhanowskaya. Those in the Kremlin understand that if a candidate were running with a specifically anti-war position, then no matter what their personal qualities were, Putin would have no chance", the expert said. 

In his opinion, about one-third of Russians were against the war initially, but now a large number of people disappointed in or simply tired of the war have joined them.

"So it was clear from the very beginning that the Kremlin would not allow any anti-war candidate to run, so as not to see a repeat of the Tsikhanowskaya phenomenon".

Speaking of changes Russia can expect after the vote, the pundit listed growth in discontent, increased suppression and a possible new wave of mobilisation. In terms of repression, Galyamov said Putin behaves more flexibly and intelligently than [Belarusian President Alyaksandr] Lukashenka [Alexander Lukashenko].

"He understands that that path is a dead end and will try to take as few steps as possible on it until the very end, attempting to get by without employing repression and using it only where ends cannot be met without it.

"In contrast to Putin, Lukashenka immediately started on that path. But it was easier for him, since even without legitimacy, Lukashenka still has Putin to help him. But Putin does not have his own Putin like that".

As far as the likelihood of protest is concerned, Galyamov noted that there is not enough mass discontent for it to begin: "There has to be a sense that the regime is weak, a sense that the protest will not be in vain. In a situation when you cannot expect anything from a protest except repression, there will be no protest".

At the same time, Galyamov said: "If, for example, the protest 'Noon against Putin' really does become massive, then the result will be a sharp decrease in his legitimacy. You could say it has been 'limping on one leg' until now. There was a sense that the president was doing something not quite right, but at the same time, the majority understood that he had the right to his post.

"After this election, his legitimacy will probably 'limp' on two legs. It is likely that not only will the sense of our not liking the course he takes increase, but that he will lose the right to speak in the name of the people. After this current election, the opinion could form that he does not have the right to speak for 150m Russian citizens and that he is not a president elected by all of the people, but a usurper", the expert said.

He said that if events unfolded in that way, it would significantly weaken Putin’s position. Including his relationship with the elite. "In situations like these, there are conspiracies, mutinies in the military and coups. And so although the situation will formally remain the same, its content will change", Galyamov said. 

But nothing will change for Belarus

As far as Belarus is concerned, the Russian pundit said one should not expect any changes in relations with our country after the election in the Russian Federation. 

Alyaksandr Klaskowski, an analyst with the Pozirk agency, believes one should not expect any surprises from the presidential election in Russia. Klaskowski said the Russian opposition’s plan for the "Noon against Putin" protest is a weak strategy: "The mechanism for falsifying the election in Russia is as well worked out as in Belarus, so we can only be talking about Putin being reelected, and his simply 'sealing' a new term for himself".

Putin’s being elected to a new term does not change anything for Belarus overall, or for Lukashenka in particular. "I think that for Lukashenka, Putin’s being reelected will have political consequences, since he will get an indirect carte blanche for his own reelection. If you imagine Putin naming his own successor, then the Kremlin could pose questions to Lukashenka. But if Putin gets a new term, then the field of play is open for Lukashenka, and he will have no psychological barriers".

The analyst said Putin and Lukashenka currently have a good relationship. And the Kremlin only really had thoughts of replacing Lukashenka in 2020 when Moscow, during the mass protests, thought Belarus would not be able to get out of its political crisis.

"But Lukashenka cemented the situation using repression. Besides that, Putin started a full-scale war against Ukraine, one in which Lukashenka acted as an ally", Klaskowski said.

In his opinion, the Kremlin is quite satisfied with Lukashenka right now and does not intend to change horses midstream. Klaskowski does not think Putin will want to absorb Belarus after the election as a consolation prize for the lack of large successes in Ukraine: "Belarus’s dependence on Russia is growing bit by bit without that, and that is probably satisfactory to the Kremlin. And it can also be used well as a counter to Ukraine. As if to say, see, if you are friends with Russia, everything will be good."

Q: Francis’ remarks to Swiss broadcaster RSI, recorded in early February but only aired on Saturday, elicited immediate criticism from Ukraine and its allies, even after the Vatican press office tried to redirect attention to Francis’ other remarks in the interview that “negotiation is never a surrender.”

The ruckus once again put the Vatican’s diplomatic corps in the position of having to smooth over Francis’ informal, off-the-cuff way of speaking, providing a more articulated position in line with the Holy See’s tradition of calibrated diplomatic neutrality.

In an interview with leading Corriere della Sera published Tuesday, Parolin noted that Francis in another speech last month had called for a diplomatic solution in Ukraine and the search for a just and lasting peace.

“In that sense, it’s obvious that the creation of such conditions aren’t just for one side, but both sides, and the first condition would be that of putting an end to the aggression,” Parolin said in comments that also were reported by the Vatican’s in-house Vatican News portal.

Parolin noted that Francis’ “white flag” comments were in response to a question that used the term, and that the pontiff subsequently insisted that “negotiation is never a surrender.”

The cardinal made similar comments to Italy's state-run RAI, saying: "Peace in Ukraine will have to be a just peace. It means recognizing mutual rights and also mutual duties, above all, taking into account the dignity of people.”

It’s not the first time Francis’ sometimes imprecise way of speaking, which is often appreciated in other contexts because of its simplicity, have created a diplomatic headache for the Holy See and angered one or the other side in the war.

He has repeatedly expressed solidarity with the “martyred” Ukrainian people but refused to call out Russia or President Vladimir Putin by name. He has seemingly expressed understanding for the invasion Putin ordered by saying NATO was “barking at Russia’s door” by expanding east, but then earned a formal protest from Moscow when he blamed most of the cruelty on Chechens and other minorities.

In September, Francis again courted the displeasure of Ukrainians, including its Greek Catholic bishops, when he praised Russia’s imperial past during a meeting with Russian youths. Q: One, an older Russian woman who has lived in Latvia for 50 years, came to cast her vote for Mr. Putin in Russia’s presidential election. The other, a woman in her fifties, came to show support for the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny, who before his death in an Arctic prison last month urged supporters to show up at polling stations in protest.

“I think what happened to Navalny was murder,” said Alla, the younger woman, who would give only her first name.

“He deserved it,” retorted the older woman, who declined to provide her name.

Such tensions show Riga, the quaint capital of Latvia, as a microcosm of the complex dynamics of Russian politics and Russian speakers’ place in the world. Latvia — which was once annexed by the Soviet Union — has long distrusted its own, partly pro-Putin Russian minority. But it also has treated with suspicion the antiwar Russians who flocked over the border after the invasion of Ukraine.

About a third of Latvia’s 1.8 million residents are estimated to be ethnic Russians, most of whose ancestors came to the country after the Soviet occupation. Some of them have supported Mr. Putin’s nationalism out of nostalgia, or as a response to the perceived discrimination faced by Russian speakers in Latvia, where many were born. Many people in Latvia view the Russian-speaking minority as a fifth column for the Kremlin.

Mr. Putin’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine, however, has brought a new wave of thousands of Russians migrating west into Latvia. These have tended to be younger, more educated and more critical of Mr. Putin than the older diaspora.

But the Latvian government — which views the Kremlin with hostility — has been wary of fully welcoming the Russian exiles.

Those dynamics were on display Sunday outside the Russian Embassy, where protest posters depicting Mr. Putin as a warmonger surrounded the stately mansion.

“We must show that a great number of Russians don’t support Putin, and don’t support the war,” a former regional campaigner for Mr. Navalny, Sergei Bespalov, told supporters across the street from the embassy.

The Russian electoral commission said 11,000 people voted in Riga in 2018 during Russia’s last presidential vote. Fearing unrest this time, the Latvian police cordoned off the embassy and the border guard service deployed a helicopter above it.

Migration officers also checked the documents of people who came to vote, ostensibly to see their residence status. These checks come amid a wider, politically charged campaign to deport Russian citizens who fail a Latvian language test, regardless how long they have lived in the country.

The Russian Embassy called the document checks intimidation aimed at suppressing voter turnout, which was significantly lower than in the previous election.

Earlier in the voting line, the older pro-Putin voter was expounding about the hardships facing Russians in Latvia as younger, opposition-leaning voters around her rolled their eyes.

“I cannot listen to these old ladies,” said one voter named Lena, who came to support Mr. Navalny protest initiative and would only give her first name. “Only Babushkas are for Putin, no one else!”

Editorial expresses concern over IMF conditions

"The 18th amendment of the constitution has been under discussion for a while, which is leading to uncertainty in the country. The amendment, which gives the provinces their due rights, has also left the federal government concerned. The federal government thinks that its share in the finances has been reduced due to this amendment and the provinces get a majority. The amendment was passed by the parliament and now is a part of the constitution. Any effort to interfere with this may cause big chaos in the country... We spend a lot of public money on ministries in the federal government. They should be completely devolved to the provinces so that the money can be saved... The federal government has burdened the public because inflation is skyrocketing. The burden of the strict conditions of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is being borne by the people of this country. It has been reported that the IMF wants changes in the National Finance Commission [NFC, mechanism to distribute national funds to the provinces and the federal government]. If the federal government makes changes to NFC, it will amount to abrogating the constitution. Q: Anchor Nadeem Malik said the government has announced constitution of a commission under the Commission of Inquiry Act to look into the issues raised in a letter by six judges of the Islamabad High Court. He noted the commission would be headed by a retired judge. He remarked Pakistan's history shows that the government forms a committee on matters it has "no intention to take action against" and forms a commission on matters which it wants to "bury". Noting that the present government has opted to form a commission, he said he would not question the government because it is "very weak" and is "dependent on the [military] establishment", but he would question why the Supreme Court did not take a suo moto notice and decided to hear the case in an open court.

Malik insisted the Supreme Court should take action in this matter and there is a need to set some standard operating procedures. He said Chief Justice Qazi Faez Isa has an opportunity to take action to end the interference of government and intelligence agencies in judicial matters and ensure that judges issue judgements by meeting requirements of the due process of justice.

Malik spoke with Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) politician Salman Akram Raja and asked him about the way forward. Raja remarked the way forward is very clear and the letter by the judges has identified it. He said allegations have been levelled against the executive and its subordinate officers, and it is clear that the executive cannot conduct an investigation against itself, so a judicial commission needs to be formed.

Raja was of the view that the Supreme Court should have initiated proceedings under suo moto or contempt jurisdiction. He said not just the PTI, but all political parties should play a role in taking this matter to a "logical conclusion". He urged the civil society and human rights defenders to also raise their voice against this issue. He insisted the commission announced by the government on 28 March is "insufficient" because it would not be able to reach any conclusion and demanded that a judicial commission should be constituted. He said the judiciary should have fulfilled its responsibility in this matter, otherwise it would be considered a "failure" on its behalf.

Raja claimed interference in judicial affairs has been present in all cases of "political nature" and some judges appear to be scared, while others show courage. He warned if judges are not free to give judgements without any pressure or threat, the country would not be able to progress.

Independent politician Mustafa Nawaz Khokhar said as a lawyer, he is disappointed by the announcement regarding the government forming a commission because he expected the Supreme Court to take a suo moto notice in the case and hold an open proceeding. He claimed the government is just a "rubber stamp" and it is useless to hand this matter over to it. He noted the allegations are very serious and have raised questions over the entire judicial system.

Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Khurram Dastgir said Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif has stepped forward as the "elected representative of the people" and has taken a responsibility which does not directly fall under his duties. He noted the responsibility to take up this matter was on the judiciary because the letter had been addressed to it.

Dastgir said details of the allegations are yet to be gathered and the commission which has been announced should be allowed to do its work and "prove through its conduct" that it would take up the issue seriously. He was hopeful that the letter written by the six judges will help in "taking Pakistan forward". He remarked the present situation is a "test of the political wisdom" of all political players. He was of the view that "partial justice" will not work and it cannot be said that only the cases concluded in the last one year are wrong, while judgements in the earlier cases should be accepted.

Q: - Ukraine said on 5 March that it had sunk a Russian Black Sea Fleet patrol ship off occupied Crimea

- While Russian pro-war bloggers confirmed that the Sergey Kotov warship has been 'destroyed', the Defence Ministry in Moscow and Russian state media have so far kept silent about the incident

Full story

Russia's Black Sea Fleet Sergey Kotov large patrol ship has reportedly been sunk by Ukrainian sea drones off occupied Crimea, Ukrainian military intelligence reported on its Telegram channel on 5 March.

According to the report, the Sergey Kotov was attacked on the night of 4-5 March by Ukraine's military intelligence Group 13 unit.

"As a result of a strike by Magura V5 maritime drones, the Russian ship Project 22160 Sergey Kotov sustained damage to the stern, starboard and port sides," it said, noting that the incident happened "near the Kerch Strait".

The ship was worth about $65 million, the report added.

In a later post,Ukrainian military intelligence shared its own video footage purporting to show the destruction of the Sergey Kotov.

Russian pro-war bloggers acknowledge incident

Russian pro-war bloggers aren't disputing the attack on the warship, with some saying the crew are alive.

Voenny Osvedomitel (Military Informant) blogger was among the first to share a 15-second video footage purporting to show a massive blast on the ship following cross-fire shooting.

Dva Mayora Telegram channel reshared the same video, saying that the Russian servicemen on board had "bravely fought" with the attackers. It said that "according to local reports, the ship was destroyed". However, it noted that "according to our information, the entire crew are alive, evacuated, there are several wounded".

Prominent war reported Alexander Kots said on his Telegram channel that the Sergey Kotov patrol ship had long been the target of Ukrainian maritime drones, and had already been subjected to three unsuccessful attacks.

According to Kots, the penultimate such attack against the vessel occurred in September 2023, when it repelled five Ukrainian unmanned drones.

"The crew fought heroically to the end. This can be seen from the published video. But this time it is a story without a happy ending," Kots wrote.

On 14 September 2023, the Russian Defence Ministry reported that the ship had repelled an attack by five Ukrainian sea drones.

The Defence Ministry in Moscow has not yet commented on the latest incident with the Sergey Kotov ship. And no mention of it has also been observed on Russian state TV, according to media monitoring tool Medialogiya.

'Most modern patrol ship'

According to information in Russian open sources, th Sergey Kotov patrol ship was entered into service at the beginning of 2021. The ship officially joined the Black See Fleet in July 2022. Russia's state-controlled Channel One thendescribed the ship as the "most modern patrol ship" with its special design and coating making it "virtually invisible to enemy radars".

Russia's Black Sea Fleet has four such patrol ships manufactured within the same project. The lead ship Vasily Bykov was commissioned in 2018, and the other two production ships - Dmitry Rogachev and Pavel Derzhavin - entered service in 2019 and 2020 respectively.

This is the latest incident involving a Russian Black Sea Fleet ship after it was reported that Ukraine destroyed the Tzezar Kunikov large landing ship off Russian-occupied Crimea mid-February 2024.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Russian 0505 gmt 5 Mar 24

He argued military courts are "not acceptable in a democratic country", so civilian courts should be empowered to handle such cases.

Malik noted rumours of formation of a "forward bloc" of the PTI in the Punjab Assembly have been circulating lately. He said it is to be seen whether there is any truth in these reports.

Malik spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Azma Bokhari whether everyone accused in the 9 May incidents should be awarded the same sentence or some distinction should be maintained. Bokhari said according to the criminal law, punishments should be awarded according to the actions of the accused. She claimed the PTI has been denying its involvement in the incidents despite evidence.

Bokhari said the PTI has neither condemned, nor disassociated itself from those involved in the attacks. Q: Hamas has said it accepts the latest proposal for a Gaza ceasefire.

In a brief post on Telegram yesterday, "Hamas and the Palestinian factions announced their approval of the proposal presented to them by Egyptian and Qatari mediators."

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya TV said that Egypt and Qatar would invite US special envoy Steve Witkoff to Cairo to finalise the agreement.

Qatari Al Jazeera TV reported that Hamas's approval "may force Netanyahu to agree to what he previously refused".

Al Jazeera said the terms of the new deal include the release of 10 Israeli hostages and 18 bodies, a 60-day ceasefire, Israel's withdrawal from the north and east of Gaza and entry of aid, as well as the release of all Palestinian minors and women from Israeli prisons.

We will file a briefing.

Israel examining Hamas response

Israeli media reported this morning that officials are examining Hamas's positive response to the latest ceasefire proposal.

The liberal Haaretz daily cited unnamed Israeli sources as saying that it was still unclear how Israel would respond, quoting Netanyahu as saying that Hamas was under "atomic pressure".

The public broadcaster Kan said that Hamas was "trying to turn the tables and portray itself to Egypt, Qatar and the United States as the one which is willing to go the extra mile and bring and end to the war".

Despite what Kan described as progress in talks, it also reported that Netanyahu was still expected to hold a cabinet discussion to approve plans for occupying Gaza City on 21 August.

Egypt's Sisi, Qatari PM discuss mediation

Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi and visiting Qatari Prime Minister Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani held talks yesterday in Cairo on mediation efforts for a ceasefire deal in Gaza.

"The meeting witnessed a joint emphasis on the extreme importance that Egypt and Qatar were giving to their continuing efforts, in coordination with the US, to reach a deal that would ensure an immediate ceasefire in the Gaza Strip, allow the urgent delivery of humanitarian aid without any obstacles alongside the release of hostages and captives," the Egyptian presidential spokesman said in a statement on Facebook.

The two officials also emphasised "the categorical rejection of the military reoccupation of the enclave and any attempts to displace Palestinians from their land".

Egypt and Qatar reportedly handed Hamas a new proposal to resume the Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

Israel withdrawal call splits Lebanon media

Lebanese media were divided over the US envoy Tom Barrack's call yesterday for Israel to withdraw from Lebanese territory after Beirut approved a plan to disarm Hezbollah by the end of the year.

The French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour commented that Barrack had declared himself "satisfied" with Lebanon's action, highlighting his comment, following talks in Beirut, that it was Israel's turn to comply with the November ceasefire agreement.

Meanwhile, the pro-Hezbollah Al-Akhbar daily said Barrack's visit had been "to no avail", noting that it followed the visit of the secretary of Iran's Supreme National Security Council, Ali Larijani, with both visits representing the "height of tensions" between Washington and Tehran.

The pro-Iran Al-Mayadeen TV questioned whether Barrack's comment was a "recalculation or a new manoeuvre, while ignoring Israel's violations" of the ceasefire agreement.

In related news, the UN Security Council started talks late yesterday on a French-drafted resolution to extend the mandate of the UN peace-keeping mission in Lebanon, Unifil, which expires on 31 August.

Israeli families cross into Syria

A group of Israeli families crossed into Syria yesterday, attempting to establish a new Jewish settlement there called "Neve Habashan", Israeli media reported.

According to the right-wing, pro-settlement Arutz Sheva, the families spent an "extended period of time" in Syria before being evacuated back to Israel by the army.

One of the members of the "Bashan Pioneers" movement told Arutz Sheva that the fence was "wide open" and it took 30-40 minutes before Israeli forces had noticed they had crossed the border area.

The Walla news site quoted the army as calling the crossing a "serious incident that constitutes a criminal offence and endangers the public and Israeli forces".

US forces start Iraq withdrawal

Washington has started the first phase of withdrawing forces in the US-led coalition against the Islamic State (IS) from Iraq, as the first US convoy left the Ain al-Asad airbase in the western Anbar province yesterday, heading towards Syria.

An Iraqi military spokesman described the move as an "indicator of Iraq's ability to confront terrorism and maintain security and stability without needing assistance from others", according to the official news agency INA.

The first phase is scheduled to end by late September, with US troops and equipment due to be redeployed to Iraq's semi-autonomous Kurdistan Region or to Kuwait.

By September 2026, the US will complete its military exit, reducing its troop numbers from around 2,000 to fewer than 500.

'Catastrophic' flooding hits southern Yemen

Yemeni media have reported that flooding from heavy rain overnight has brought parts of the southern city of Aden - the temporary capital of the internationally recognised government - to a standstill this morning.

Southern Yemen-focused Aden al-Ghad called the situation "catastrophic", saying floods had swept large quantities of debris on to main roads in the city's Mualla district and had submerged vehicles.

It said residents had criticised a lack of emergency response and poor drainage systems.

The leading Al-Masdar Online website said residents had been evacuated from damaged homes in the city's Crater district, and that several flights into Aden had been diverted.

Flooding across Yemen last year caused widespread devastation, with some media blaming the extent of the damage on corruption and neglect by the internationally recognised government.

Hadramawt protests - potential flashpoint?

Yemen's southeastern province of Hadramawt has become the crucible of a summer of unrest in the government-controlled south.

The Aden-based authorities have come under increasing pressure to address deteriorating economic and living conditions that have already seen months of street protests.

But weeks of protests in Hadramawt have led to fears that the province is on the brink of a military escalation that could have repercussions for the country as a whole.

The protests have also highlighted underlying tensions between the UAE and Saudi Arabia over influence in Yemen.

Q: The assaults combine strategic goals — diverting Russian troops from the front inside Ukraine and destroying energy infrastructure — with a political objective, namely undermining President Vladimir V. Putin’s long-cultivated image as a leader protecting Russia.

In recent days, ground assaults along the Russian border appeared to be the most disruptive of the attacks. On Sunday, Russian officials said that Ukraine had targeted seven regions of the country. The Russian military said it had shot down 35 exploding drones.

An oil refinery was set on fire in the Krasnodar region of southern Russia and air defense forces shot down two drones flying toward Moscow, Russian officials said.

The governor of the Krasnodar region, Veniamin Kondratyev, said debris from drones shot down by the military had ignited the fire at the oil refinery.

Four drones were shot down in the Yaroslavl region, which is northeast of Moscow, according to the local authorities.

There was no immediate comment from Ukraine’s military on the attacks inside Russia.

In his nightly address to Ukrainians on Saturday, President Volodymyr Zelensky praised domestic arms production that has grown to produce long-range weaponry capable of hitting targets deep inside Russia.

“These weeks have demonstrated to many that the Russian war machine has vulnerabilities that we can reach with our weapons,” Mr. Zelensky said. “What our own drones are capable of is a true Ukrainian long-range capability.”

Sunday’s drone attacks came amid continuing skirmishes along a stretch of border between the Sumy and Kharkiv regions of Ukraine and the Belgorod and Kursk regions of Russia.

Three groups of Russian exiles supported by Ukraine’s military intelligence agency have been attacking along the border since Tuesday, in what could be the largest ground assault into Russia since the full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

Russia has responded by bombarding the towns and villages in Ukraine where the exile groups are staging. Ukraine’s military on Sunday reported 69 strikes over the past day in the Sumy region.

Elsewhere, two missiles struck the city of Mykolaiv in southern Ukraine on Sunday, according to Vitaliy Kim, the head of the regional military administration. He wrote on Telegram that one person was killed there and eight others injured. In Nikopol, a southern Ukrainian city, an exploding drone hit a gas station, injuring three people. Q: He then mocked Mr. Biden’s lifelong stutter, a jab that set the tone for the lengthy speech that followed.

Over nearly two hours, Mr. Trump lobbed sharp personal attacks at Mr. Biden’s mental and physical health and revived a litany of grievances against political opponents, prosecutors and television executives. He used inflammatory language to stoke fears about immigration, called the press “criminals” and repeated his false claim that the 2020 election was stolen from him.

Mr. Trump told thousands of his supporters gathered at the rally that “everything Joe Biden touches” turns to filth, though he used an expletive to describe the result. “Everything. I tried finding a different word, but there are some words that cannot be duplicated.” (He used the word, or a variant, at least four times in his speech.)

The speech that Mr. Trump gave on Saturday was his first since Mr. Biden repeatedly attacked him and his policies in his State of the Union address. “Joe Biden should not be shouting angrily at America,” Mr. Trump said. “America should be shouting angrily at Joe Biden.”

But his critiques moved toward personal insults. At one point, Mr. Trump slurred his words and pretended to stutter in a mocking imitation of the president, who has dealt with a stutter since childhood.

A Biden campaign spokesman, T.J. Ducklo, responded to Mr. Trump’s insults in a statement Sunday, contrasting the former president’s speech with Mr. Biden’s State of the Union address.

“Thursday night President Biden spoke about the kind of America he wants for our future — one based on the core values of honesty, decency, dignity, and respect for everyone — values that are unrecognizable to Donald Trump. Trump thinks mocking people and taking away their rights makes him look strong. But it just reveals how weak and insecure he is.”

The former president’s speech in Georgia, a key battleground state that he narrowly lost in 2020, underscored that Mr. Trump is not likely to temper the ominous and at times apocalyptic vision that has animated his campaign, even as his last remaining Republican rival has dropped out and the general election has come into focus.

As he has in the past, Mr. Trump insisted that the biggest danger facing the United States was his political opponents, whom he labeled “the threat from within,” a turn inward that has alarmed experts for its similarity to language used by totalitarian leaders.

But in a speech replete with digressive rants, Mr. Trump reserved some of his most incendiary rhetoric to vilify migrants crossing the border illegally. Much of his speech was focused on immigration, an issue that he and his advisers have signaled will be central to his efforts to defeat Mr. Biden and return to the White House.

While vowing to expand his crackdown on immigration, Mr. Trump described the continuing surge of migrants across the southern border as “the agony of our people, the plunder of our cities, the sacking of our towns, the violation of our citizens and the conquest of our country.”

Mr. Trump also took aim at Mr. Biden’s policies on immigration, in part by using the Georgia setting to blame his rival for the death of Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student who was killed in the state last month by, according to the authorities, a Venezuelan migrant who had entered the country illegally and had been released on parole.

Mr. Trump met with Ms. Riley’s parents before taking the stage, and the Trump campaign distributed signs at the rally with Ms. Riley’s photograph. During his speech, Mr. Trump accused Mr. Biden of neglecting the surge of migrants at the border, which he called a “deadly invasion that stole precious Laken’s beautiful American life.”

Mr. Trump often broadly casts those crossing the border illegally as violent criminals. “The migrants are hurting people,” Mr. Trump said. “They talk about the beautiful dream of migrants. It sounds so nice, you know, like in a fairy-tale book. But some of these people are monsters.”

Border authorities, including some who worked for Mr. Trump, have said that most of the migrants who cross the border are members of families fleeing violence and poverty.

But Ms. Riley’s death has become a flashpoint in the nation’s heated debate over immigration policy, in part because it seems to adhere to Mr. Trump’s long-stated belief that violent men from South America are flooding across the border to harm Americans.

“He was an illegal migrant, and he shouldn’t have been in our country, and he never would have been under the Trump policy,” Mr. Trump said of the man accused of killing Ms. Riley.

Mr. Trump also attacked Mr. Biden for expressing regret that he used the word “illegal” to describe the man accused in Ms. Riley’s death during an exchange at the State of the Union address on Thursday.

Mr. Trump also lobbed several ad hominem attacks during the event. Of the former television anchor Megyn Kelly, with whom Mr. Trump sparred during his first presidential run, he said “may she rest in peace.” While talking about the success that his time on “The Apprentice” had brought NBC, he called Jeff Zucker, the network’s former chief executive, an “idiot.”

Mr. Trump also denigrated a number of prosecutors and judges involved in the criminal cases and multiple civil lawsuits in which he is entangled. He spent a considerable amount of time attacking Fani T. Willis, the district attorney prosecuting him over his efforts to overturn his 2020 election loss in Georgia.

Mr. Trump called Ms. Willis “corrupt,” referring to allegations that she benefited financially after becoming romantically involved with a lawyer whom she hired on the case. (Ms. Willis has pushed back against those claims, calling them full of “wild and reckless speculation.”)

He also repeated his false contention that he won in Georgia in 2020, maintaining that he had done nothing wrong when he called state elections officials, insisted that he had won Georgia and asked Georgia’s secretary of state to “find” the votes he needed to win.

“Perfect phone call,” Mr. Trump said, “other than we challenged the honesty of this election. This election was rigged.”

Maggie Haberman contributed reporting from New York.
