Q: The Ukrainian Air Force said that air defense systems had intercepted all 31 of the Russian missiles that targeted Kyiv. Still, debris from the downed missiles fell in various parts of the city, causing the injuries and damage. No deaths have been reported so far.

“Such terror continues every day and night,” President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said in a social media post that included a video of firefighters dousing burning buildings with water.

The attack began in the early morning with loud blasts jolting residents awake around 5 a.m. as air defense systems went into action. Many people rushed to take shelter in subway stations. Several orange fireballs lit up the sky, apparently the result of missile interceptions.

Air-raid alerts ended at 6:10 a.m. just as sun rose, revealing the damage.

Vitali Klitschko, Kyiv’s mayor, said on Telegram that missile debris had caused fires in at least three residential buildings and in parking lots. He said emergency responders had been deployed to help victims. Four people were hospitalized, the city’s military administration said.

Photos of the aftermath of the attack released by Oleksiy Kuleba, the deputy head of Ukraine’s presidential office, and the local authorities showed burned-out cars in front of a building with a facade blackened by fire, a large hole at the foot of a pink building with all of its windows shattered, and a destroyed house on charred ground.

In the Podilskyi district, which is home to industrial facilities that Russia has targeted in the past, a plume of black smoke was rising early in the morning, suggesting a hit. Mr. Klitschko said a fire had broken out at a power substation in the area.

In the past, the targets of Russian air assaults have sometimes been unclear, and Ukrainian officials rarely confirm strikes on strategic industrial and military targets.

On Thursday, however, an official from Ukraine’s military intelligence services said most of the missiles had targeted the agency’s offices in the capital, but had been shot down before reaching their destination. The official spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive matters, and his claim could not be independently verified.

The assault Thursday came at a difficult time for Ukraine’s military, with Russian forces pressing ahead with ground attacks at several locations along the front line of more than 600 miles.

Faced with a shortfall of troops and ammunition, Ukraine has struggled to contain Russian assaults in its east and south. Ukrainian officials have vowed to launch a counteroffensive this year, but experts say the military has yet to receive the kinds of weapons that would let it regain the initiative on the battlefield, with American aid held up in Congress.

On Wednesday, Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, made an unannounced trip to Kyiv in an effort to show the White House’s continued commitment to Ukraine’s defense. He urged Republican lawmakers to pass the stalled package of billions of dollars in aid.

“It has already taken too long,” Mr. Sullivan told reporters in a briefing at Ukraine’s presidential office. “And I know that — you know that.”

Thursday’s attack on Kyiv echoed a strategy used by Russia during air assaults in late December that consisted of overwhelming Ukraine’s air defenses with multiple launches of various types of missiles, including ballistic and hypersonic ones.

Russia has launched relatively few large-scale missile attacks in recent months, despite a capacity to produce more than 115 long-range missiles per month, according to Ukrainian officials.

Mr. Zelensky said on Thursday that Ukraine urgently needed more air defense systems from Western allies. He pointed to recent missile attacks on the cities of Kharkiv, Odesa and Kherson that claimed many lives.

“We need the support of our partners,” Mr. Zelensky said. “We must prove that terror is always the loser.”

Oleksandra Mykolyshyn and Maria Varenikova contributed reporting.

Q: Mr. Varadkar’s decision, which he attributed to both “personal and political” reasons, was unexpected, with some members of his government given only a few hours’ notice of his plans.

A medical doctor and former health minister, Mr. Varadkar first became taoiseach, or prime minister, in 2017, at a time when his Fine Gael party was still one of the country’s two dominant parties, a position it had enjoyed nearly uninterrupted since the founding of the Irish state.

During his years in office, though, public opinion shifted, and as Fine Gael’s popularity dipped, his departure seemed inevitable, experts said. Now, as Ireland grapples with what comes next for its government, here’s what to know.

Who might be Ireland’s next leader?

Despite calls from the opposition for a general election, Mr. Varadkar’s resignation does not mean an end to the current government.

Fine Gael, a center-right party, currently governs in coalition with two other parties, Fianna Fáil, its longtime rival, and the Green Party. Under the terms of their power-sharing arrangement, it is up to Fine Gael to appoint a new leader, who will then become the prime minister.

Because of the surprise nature of Mr. Varadkar’s announcement, there was no immediate successor waiting in the wings, leading to an initial rush of speculation about who might fill his position.

By Thursday evening, though, it appeared that Simon Harris, the minister for education, might be vying for the role uncontested. For years he has spoken of his desire to one day lead the party, and on Thursday evening he confirmed to the national broadcaster RTÉ, “I want to be the next leader of Fine Gael,” adding, “If given the opportunity, I will give this my all.”

Mr. Harris, who is 37, will become the youngest-ever taoiseach if he does become the party’s leader, edging out Mr. Varadkar, who initially took up the leadership role at 38. So far, it appears that other members of the party are rallying around him.

Other potential contenders included party stalwarts like Paschal Donohoe, the minister for public expenditure and reform, and Heather Humphreys, the minister for social protection. Both are longtime Fine Gael lawmakers, but in the past 24 hours both have said they have no intention of putting themselves forward.

How long until the new leader is announced?

In his resignation speech, Mr. Varadkar laid out an aspirational timeline for Fine Gael to appoint a new leader, saying that he wanted a successor to be elected before the party’s annual conference on April 6. That person would then become prime minister when parliament resumed on April 9, after an Easter break.

The process to get there, though, could become complicated if more than one lawmaker contests the election.

One reason for the urgency to choose a new leader is that Ireland will hold local and European elections in June.

In addition, Ireland’s Dáil, the popularly elected lower house of parliament, has a maximum term of five years, so a national election must be held before March 22, 2025. That means that whoever replaces Mr. Varadkar will serve as taoiseach for less than a year before an election is called.

What does this mean for Irish politics?

Mr. Varadkar, the young, gay son of an Irish mother and an Indian father, once seemed like an emblem of a new, more energetic and inclusive Ireland. Now, he is the face of an increasingly unpopular establishment.

His resignation follows years of waning support for the long-dominant parties, Fine Gael, which dropped to the third most popular in the country’s last general election in 2020, and Fianna Fáil. It crystallizes the perception that Irish politics is in a moment of flux and uncertainty.

Meanwhile, Sinn Féin, once the political branch of the I.R.A., rose from its position as a fringe player to win the most votes in the last election. No party came close to a majority, forcing the formation of a coalition.

All of the major parties are fighting political headwinds, as Ireland faces a number of domestic challenges. A severe housing shortage — caused partly by the failure of successive governments to invest in affordable housing — and a cost-of-living crisis have created widespread frustration with the political establishment.

With the number of asylum seekers arriving in the country rising sharply, the government has had to contend with an anti-immigration backlash driven in part by far-right rhetoric online. That has increasingly spilled over into violence, with arsonists targeting planned housing for asylum seekers and a violent riot in Dublin late last year that drew international attention.

Concerns about immigration seem to be benefiting independent candidates. Even Sinn Féin, still the most popular party in the polls, has seen its support fall. And with a general election on the horizon, the country’s leading politicians must now grapple with how to address a deeply divisive issue without inflaming it further.
A:

*   Ireland
*   Dublin

Q: At a hearing on Wednesday before a special committee of the State Senate, which recently began investigating Ms. Willis, the defense lawyer leading the disqualification effort testified that Ms. Willis had once taken a large sum of money from her political campaign for her personal use.

The senator presiding over the hearing, Bill Cowsert, a Republican, was taken aback by the allegation. “I think all of us up here that have campaigns know that you can’t take campaign funds for personal use, right?” he asked.

The defense lawyer, Ashleigh Merchant, told Mr. Cowsert that she was “not well versed in that area of law, but that is my understanding.” He replied, “It’s pretty black and white.”

There is no evidence to back up the allegation. In fact, Ms. Willis lent her first campaign nearly $50,000, drawn from a retirement account, and was paid back only a fraction of that, according to her office, campaign finance records and her past remarks.

But the incident reflected that even if Ms. Willis survives the effort to disqualify her, she would face tough inquiries by Georgia Republicans that could perpetuate questions about her character and uncertainty around the Trump case for months to come.

Seven months have passed since Ms. Willis brought the racketeering case against Mr. Trump and 18 of his allies, charging them with conspiring to overturn his 2020 election loss in Georgia. Four of the defendants have already pleaded guilty, and Ms. Willis at one point told the judge, Scott McAfee of Fulton County Superior Court, that she was aiming for a trial to start in August.

But the case was upended in January after Ms. Merchant revealed in a court filing that Ms. Willis had a romantic relationship with Nathan Wade, the lawyer she hired in November 2021 to manage the Trump case.

Ms. Merchant represents Michael Roman, a defendant and former Trump campaign official. She and other defense lawyers have said that Ms. Willis engaged in “self-dealing,” because she took a number of vacations with Mr. Wade after hiring him while using public funds to pay him more than $650,000 to date.

The filing forced Ms. Willis to publicly acknowledge that she and Mr. Wade had pursued a romance. And the allegations were concerning enough that Judge McAfee held a series of public hearings over the last few weeks to determine whether the relationship had created a disqualifying conflict of interest. The judge has said that he will decide by next week.

Legal experts have pointed out that Ms. Willis could have avoided this particular controversy had she not had a romantic relationship with someone who worked for her.

Ms. Merchant testified on Wednesday that if Ms. Willis had gone to the county and said, “I’m having an affair with this man, but he is brilliant and he would be an amazing prosecutor on this election interference case,” then “we wouldn’t be here,” because the hiring, Ms. Merchant later added, “wouldn’t have been approved.”

The Senate investigation is one of several springing up around Ms. Willis. Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio, a Trump ally and the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, has used the conflict-of-interest allegations to seek more records as part of the committee’s ongoing investigation of the district attorney’s office. Georgia Republicans are in the process of empowering a prosecutorial oversight commission that is also expected to review the matter.

The Republican-controlled Senate created its special committee to investigate Ms. Willis soon after the motion was filed to disqualify her. The committee has no power to punish the district attorney. But with the power to issue subpoenas, it can embarrass her.

That could help Mr. Trump as he seeks to win Georgia in the presidential election. Negative headlines about Ms. Willis generated by the committee’s work could also influence potential jurors if the Trump case ends up going to trial.

During the Senate hearing on Wednesday, Ms. Merchant said that Ms. Willis recently testified that she had used a large amount of money from her failed 2018 campaign for a local judgeship to reimburse Mr. Wade for expenses from their vacations.

Ms. Merchant said that Ms. Willis testified “that the majority of the cash she had on hand was from her campaign,” and that it was “a loan she had given herself from the campaign.”

“She was very clear about that,” Ms. Merchant added.

In fact, Ms. Willis’s testimony on Feb. 15 was not clear. She said: “When I ran for judge I took $50,000 of my personal money out of my retirement and that money ended up being lost.”

Later in her testimony, when she was pressed further about how she had repaid Mr. Wade, she said that she had taken “a large amount of money on my first campaign,” and that she had “kept some of the cash of that.” Neither the judge nor defense lawyers asked at the time what exactly she meant.

Campaign finance records from Ms. Willis’s judicial campaign show loans of $49,000, and that the campaign reimbursed her roughly $8,500 in 2018.

After the Senate hearing, a spokesman for Ms. Willis’s office said Ms. Merchant had “misstated the D.A.’s testimony.” The spokesman, Jeff DiSantis, said Ms. Willis “testified that she took money out of her retirement to fund her unsuccessful 2018 campaign for Superior Court judge.”

“She did not testify that she took money out of her campaign for herself, other than the repayment of the loan that is detailed in her campaign report,” he added.

Ms. Merchant, in an email, said that her testimony “was based on Ms. Willis’s statements under oath.”

The Senate committee is planning to meet again in the next few weeks.
A:

Q: Iran warns cooperation with IAEA could halt if E3 triggers 'snapback' mechanism

Iran yesterday warned it may halt cooperation with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) if the E3 (UK, France, Germany) triggers the "snapback" mechanism to reinstate UN sanctions.

Deputy Foreign Minister Kazem Gharibabadi said such a move would undermine diplomacy and prompt a "special measure" from Tehran. The warning comes as IAEA inspectors arrived in Iran to oversee refuelling at the Bushehr plant, an activity conducted under a separate Iran-Russia agreement.

Citing its diplomatic sources, Reuters reported that the snapback process is likely to be initiated today.

Gharibabadi said that if the snapback is activated, "Iran will take a special measure and issue a warning and notification to the UN Security Council. Moreover, such a step would seriously impact our cooperation with the IAEA, which could potentially be suspended."

Separately, Alaeddin Boroujerdi, a hardline lawmaker and member of parliament's National Security and Foreign Policy Committee, said in a TV interview that Iran "will use all the tools" at its disposal if the snapback is activated and that if Iran is not prevented from exporting its oil, "something will definitely happen that other oil is not exported either".

FM meets MPs to talk IAEA cooperation, 'snapback'

Separately, Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi met with the parliament's National Security and Foreign Policy Committee to discuss nuclear talks with the E3 and the snapback mechanism.

He later told reporters that no new cooperation text with the IAEA has been finalised and that the recent entry of IAEA inspectors was solely for the Bushehr plant refuelling, authorised by Iran's Supreme National Security Council.

JAAM-E JAM

Papers discuss IAEA presence in Iran

Iranian dailies today discussed the presence of IAEA inspectors in Iran and apparent dissent by hardline MPs over the matter.

Hardline Javan daily warned the inspectors' return "without any guarantees" against further attacks strengthens the view that the IAEA is using Bushehr as a "foot in the door" for a wider return.

Ultraconservative Keyhan daily condemned the inspectors' return as a "suspicious presence" and a "costly error". It said that the IAEA has become an "intelligence arm of the West" and that any official circumventing parliament's law to allow access would be "responsible to the Iranian people".

Conservative Farhikhtegan newspaper noted that while the SNSC's approval made it legal, MPs retain the right to demand reports on whether the conditions for cooperation have been met. But it framed the issue as political rather than technical, insisting that the hardline MPs knew of the visit beforehand.

Online concern as rial value drops

Iranian online users have been discussing a sharp fall in the value of Iran's currency, the rial.

One US dollar was traded for the price of 1,000,500 rials on the open market yesterday, marking at least a 10% drop in the rial's value since the beginning of this week. Concerns about the activation of the snapback mechanism and the return of the UN Security Council sanctions against Iran are said to be the main factor behind the jump.

The Iranian Chamber of Commerce predicted that in an optimistic scenario, the dollar price could be 1,150,000 and in a pessimistic scenario the dollar price could increase to 1,650,000 rials and inflation could reach 90% by the end of 2025.

The conservative Siasat-e Rouz daily said the Chamber of Commerce has "painted a bleak picture of the future of the economy, but experts believe that such scenarios are more inflammatory than realistic".

A user by publishing the Iranian Chamber of Commerce prediction chart on X said: "Previously, a 20% increase per year was scary, but now 20% increase per month has become optimistic for us".

"When people are getting crushed by the dollar's price, blaming the trigger is just an escape from reality," another user said.

One user asked, "How long should we tolerate this?" Noting sanctions, war, electricity outages and the dollar price, the user asked if people have a "right to protest without being called seditionist".

2005 Al-Atta confirmed that all necessary arrangements have been made to eradicate the Rapid Support Force and restore order in Gezira State and Khartoum State. He reassured the Sudanese populace that the armed forces are in control of the situation as they advance towards the western states.

2007 Lt Gen  Yasser al-Atta, also met with the collective leadership of the 17th Infantry Division in Singa, alongside the Sennar Air Defense and state government officials. 

2009 Lt Gen  Yasser al-Atta, conducted an inspection of the 18th Infantry Division in White Nile state. He met with the State Security Committee, chaired by Police Brigadier Saif al-Din Ahmed, where detailed reports were reviewed to ensure effective coordination among all security agencies. The meeting yielded directives to enhance state’s security measures.

2011 Culture and information minister Graham Abdulqadir met with the acting Indian Ambassador to Sudan Mr. Joshi Jesse, Consul Anil Kumar, and the Indian delegation in Port Sudan. They discussed India's assistance in rehabilitating the Sudanese Broadcasting Corporation in Omdurman after it was recaptured from the RSF militia. They agreed to provide a detailed study on the rehabilitation needs as requested by the India.

2012 Minister of Higher Education and Scientific Research, Prof. Mohamed Hassan Zahab, commended certain university administrations for their efforts in creating conducive academic environments and ensuring stability. During a meeting with university directors in Port Sudan, he reaffirmed the ministry's commitment to supporting all university programs to maintain academic stability amid ongoing activities. Zahab also expressed readiness to assist universities affected by conflict.

2014 Health Minister of Khartoum State attended the inauguration of Bar Al-Walidain Hospital in Khartoum's 21st neighborhood, alongside governor Ahmed Osman Hamza and health officials. The minister praised the hospital's opening amid wartime challenges, emphasizing its significance for the community. Governor Hamza also commended the Federal Health Ministry for its support in improving healthcare services across the region. Video report.

2019 A tour conducted by Khartoum governor Ahmed Osman Hamza and federal health minister Haitham Mohamed Ibrahim, along with their accompanying delegation, unveiled extensive vandalism at government hospitals in Omdurman locality. Video report.

2023 Governor Ahmed Osman Hamza of Khartoum State officially opened a branch of Khartoum Bank in the Seventh Revolution neighborhood, marking the resumption of banking operations in Khartoum. The Federal Health Minister, present at the event, hailed the move as a positive sign amid the armed forces' victories, underscoring the region's restored security. Video report.

2027 Governor Ahmed Osman Hamza of Khartoum State assessed the traffic police's performance in the first quarter of 2024, particularly focusing on vehicle licensing and citizen transactions with the traffic department in safe areas. This occurred during his leadership of a meeting with director of Khartoum State Traffic, Maj Gen Ahmed Ali Al-Khalifa, and director of roads and bridges authority, Mukhtar Saber. The governor instructed the authorities to streamline traffic services and deploy traffic forces in liberated areas.

2028 The sixth infantry division in El Fasher city in North Darfur commemorated the successes of the armed forces and the liberation of the Sudanese Broadcasting Corporation buildings in Omdurman from the Rapid Support Forces.

2029 The governor of Gezira State, Taher Ibrahim Al Khair, highlighted the ongoing provision of exceptional healthcare services despite the country's challenging circumstances. He made these remarks at the inauguration of the Health Insurance Center in the 24th locality of Al Qurashi, a significant addition to the state's healthcare sector. The governor, accompanied by the director of the national intelligence agency, brigadier Imad Al-Din Sayed Ahmed, emphasized the center's role in delivering essential services to its beneficiaries as part of the comprehensive health insurance coverage expansion.

2029 The acting governor of North Darfur state, Hafiz Bakheet Mohamed, presided over a meeting of the state government's cabinet ministers. The meeting included discussed reports from various service ministries. The president of the supreme council for culture and media, Khalid Yousef Abdel Rahim, emphasized the council's briefing on agricultural activities and early preparations for the upcoming season, including livestock surveys. The meeting underscored the significance of agricultural seasons and the need for timely preparations.

2031 Acting governor Mohammed Musa Abdul Rahman of Kassala State witnessed the signing of a partnership agreement between the government and the private sector. The agreement, between the Ministry of Finance and Labor of Kassala State and the United Tuteel Projects Company, aims to rehabilitate and operate the Kassala Printing and Publishing Authority. The governor emphasized the project's significance in revitalizing the printing press to accommodate various publications.

2033 The acting governor of Kassala State, Mohammed Musa Abdul Rahman, chaired a collaborative meeting with the Ministry of Production and Economic Resources and the Executive Unit for Taming the Qash River. The meeting brought together representatives from the Federal Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, focusing on excavation and irrigation activities. Discussions centered on the progress of taming the Qash River and ensuring groundwater recharge to provide drinking water for both humans and animals.

2035 The Najashi Charitable Organization, in partnership with the Islamic Education Association of Bahrain, launched the Iftar and Ramadan food basket project at the Arous Al Ramal displacement center in El Obeid City in North Kordofan State. The initiative aims to assist those affected by the war, providing essential support to vulnerable families. Director Salah Hamdou highlighted the program's coverage of all refugee centers, praising the exceptional partnership with the Islamic Education Association of Bahrain.

2038 The acting governor of North Kordofan State, Abd Al-Khaliq Abd Al-Latif, addressed the opening session of the first training course for journalists titled "Journalists' Safety in Conflict Zones." The course, organized by the Press Committee of the High Committee for Mobilization and Preparedness, aims to enhance journalists' safety and bolster the media's role in supporting the populace, popular resistance efforts, and supporting the armed forces.

2041 End of bulletin 

Source: Sudan TV, Omdurman, in Arabic 1900 GMT 19 Mar 24

Q: This year’s address will be different. Ukraine’s first lady, Olena Zelenska, declined an invitation, citing a scheduling conflict. Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of the Russian opposition leader who died in a Russian prison last month, Aleksei A. Navalny, was also invited but is unable to attend.

And it is unclear how many lawmakers will be waving Ukrainian flags this year, as the initial outrage that welled after Mr. Putin’s invasion has given way to the partisan squabbling and gridlock that now characterize politics in the United States.

Mr. Biden’s latest aid package proposal — $60.1 billion for badly needed artillery ammunition, air defense interceptors and other weapons — remains stalled in Congress, already undermining the fight on the ground in Ukraine, where American officials say more than 500,000 have been killed and injured between the two sides.

Mr. Putin’s military was forced to abandon its drive to Kyiv, the capital, on April 2, 2022, thanks to stiff Ukrainian resistance helped by real-time intelligence provided by the United States and NATO allies, not to mention poor logistics and tactical decision-making on the Russian part. But Russia decimated many cities and towns in the east and established a “land bridge” connecting the mainland with Crimea, the peninsula that Mr. Putin illegally seized in 2014. And two years on, depleted Ukrainian forces are still trying to hold off advancing Russian troops in the east.

Mr. Biden will certainly exhort Congress to move forward on the aid package in his speech, administration officials said. But some contingency planning is also underway.

The administration is trying to cobble together a stopgap package of artillery ammunition and air defense interceptors, paid for with money from Army contracts that came in under bid, U.S. officials said. That measure, which could also include some longer-range guided missiles known as ATACMs, was unlikely to be ready in time to announce during Mr. Biden’s remarks on Thursday, they added.

But at best, the makeshift solution would only keep advancing Russian troops at bay for a few weeks.

Mr. Biden will be able to point to at least one success that has resulted from Mr. Putin’s invasion: One person who accepted the White House invitation is the Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson of Sweden, which became NATO’s newest member just a few hours before Mr. Biden’s speech was scheduled to begin.

Sweden along with Finland decided to apply to join NATO shortly after the invasion began, expanding the alliance that has so bedeviled Mr. Putin.

Q: Lava fountains burst out of the ground, and a nearly two-mile-long fissure opened up on the Reykjanes Peninsula around 8:30 p.m., the Icelandic Meteorological Office said. The eruption occurred near the town of Grindavik, the Svartsengi Power Plant and the Blue Lagoon, one of Iceland’s most famous tourist attractions.

The meteorological office said that it had received indications of a possible eruption only about 40 minutes before it happened. The office sent out its first warning moments before the eruption began.

The Blue Lagoon and Grindavik were evacuated shortly after the eruption, according to RUV, the national broadcaster. Grindavik has a population of about 4,000, but few residents were in the town at the time. About 700 visitors were staying at the Blue Lagoon.

On Sunday morning, Hjordis Gudmundsdottir, a spokeswoman for the Department of Civil Protection and Emergency Management, told reporters that the biggest risk was to two pipes that carried hot water from the geothermal Svartsengi Power Plant to homes on the peninsula.

Shortly after midnight, lava flowed over a road toward a water distribution pipe from the power plant, according to an update from the Icelandic Meteorological Office at 1 p.m. local time.

The lava has not moved much since Sunday morning, and it was about 200 meters from the pipe. Response workers were monitoring the speed of the lava, which has been “slow and steady since this morning,” the office said.

The eruption was most likely the biggest of the seven that have occurred across the Reykjanes Peninsula since 2021, including four since December, the civil protection agency said in a statement. Before that, the peninsula had laid dormant for 800 years.

Meteorologists have expressed concerns that if the lava continues at the same rate, it could flow into the North Atlantic. Contact between lava and water can create small explosions and dangerous gases.

Q: The announcement by the West African nation's military junta on Saturday came after meetings last week with a delegation from Washington and the top U.S. commander for Africa, Gen. Michael E. Langley. The move is in keeping with a recent pattern by countries in the Sahel region, an arid area south of the Sahara, of breaking ties with Western countries. Increasingly, they are partnering with Russia instead.

American officials also voiced alarm in the meetings about several other issues, including whether Niger's military government was nearing a deal to give Iran access to Niger's vast uranium reserves, a concern that was reported earlier by The Wall Street Journal.

Niger's rejection of military ties with the United States follows the withdrawal from Niger of troops from France, the former colonial power that, for the past decade, has led foreign counterterrorism efforts against jihadist groups in West Africa, but which has lately been perceived as a pariah in the region.

''The American presence in the territory of the Republic of Niger is illegal,'' Niger's military spokesman, Col. Amadou Abdramane, said on national television. He added that the U.S. military presence ''violates all the constitutional and democratic rules, which would require the sovereign people -- notably through its elected officials -- to be consulted on the installation of a foreign army on its territory.''

Matthew Miller, the chief State Department spokesman, said it was in touch with the ruling military junta, known as the National Council for the Safeguard of the Homeland, or CNSP, about the move.

''We are aware of the statement from the CNSP in Niger, which follows frank discussions at senior levels in Niamey this week about our concerns with the CNSP's trajectory,'' he said in a message on X, formerly Twitter.

Many of the Americans posted to Niger are stationed at U.S. Air Base 201, a six-year-old, $110 million installation in the country's desert north. But since the military coup that ousted President Mohamed Bazoum and installed the junta last July, the troops there have been inactive, with most of their drones grounded.

Because of the coup, the United States had to suspend security operations and development aid to Niger.

Mr. Bazoum, the country's elected president, is still under arrest, eight months after he was ousted. But the United States had wanted to maintain its partnership with the country.

A senior U.S. military official said on Sunday there had been no immediate changes to the status of about 1,000 American military personnel stationed in the country. The Pentagon has continued to conduct surveillance drone flights from Air Base 201 to protect U.S. troops and alert the Nigerien authorities if the flights detected an imminent terrorist threat.

''The canceling of the security agreement is not quite a direct expulsion of the American military presence, as happened with the French,'' said Hannah Rae Armstrong, an analyst focused on peace and security in the Sahel. ''It's more likely an aggressive negotiation tactic to extract more benefits from cooperating with the Americans.''

In Niger, the decision was couched in terms of ''sovereignty'' -- rhetoric meant to resonate with the public.

''The goal of American policy is not to help fight armed groups, but to maintain control and counter the growing influence in the region of countries such as Russia, China and Turkey,'' Abdoulaye Sissoko, a Nigerien columnist, wrote on a popular Nigerien news site. ''There is no public evidence that American bases in Niger have proven useful.''

American officials say they have tried for months to prevent a formal break in relations with Niger's junta.

The new U.S. ambassador to Niger, Kathleen FitzGibbon, one of Washington's top Africa specialists, has held regular discussions with the junta since taking office at the beginning of the year.

In a trip to Niger in December, Molly Phee, an assistant secretary of state for African Affairs, said the United States intended to resume security and development cooperation with Niger, even as she called for a swift transition to civilian rule and the release of Mr. Bazoum.

But the Pentagon has been planning for the worst-case contingencies if the talks failed. The Defense Department has been discussing establishing new drone bases with several coastal West African countries as backups to the base in Niger, which is landlocked. Talks are still in the early stages, military officials said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to discuss operational matters.

J. Peter Pham, a former special U.S. envoy to the Sahel, said Washington will ''have to wait and see'' how Niger will implement the new approach.

''The potential fallout goes beyond the not insignificant damage to counterterrorism and intelligence efforts that loss of access to the bases in Niger entail,'' Mr. Pham said, ''but to the broader damage to America's standing on the continent.''

The Biden administration formally acknowledged last October what most countries had declared months previously: that the military takeover in Niger last July was a coup.

Biden administration officials had sidestepped that declaration for weeks because the word ''coup'' has major policy implications. Congress has mandated that the United States must halt all economic and military aid to any government installed by a military coup until democracy is restored.

But the administration finally concluded that efforts to restore Niger's democratically elected government to power had failed and that aid that had not already been restricted would be cut off. State Department officials said nearly $200 million in aid that was temporarily paused in August would be suspended. About $442 million in trade and agricultural assistance will also be suspended.

In Washington, the Biden administration had been holding out increasingly dim hopes that the military junta would reverse its takeover and agree to restore a democratically elected government.

The junta's announcement is part of a major change in dynamic between the country and its erstwhile Western partners.

''It reflects a real shift in the balance of power,'' Ms. Armstrong said. ''Over the past decade, Niger has repeatedly pleaded for security assistance and aid. Now it's the U.S. that finds itself in a position of being asked to beg to keep forces and bases in the country.''

The entire military approach in the Sahel needs to be reformed, said El Hadj Djitteye, director of the Timbuktu Center for Strategic Studies on the Sahel, a Mali-based think tank.

''Western governments including the United States and France have failed to work closely with African governments and civilian populations in economic and military development,'' Mr. Djitteye said. This, he said, has fed the widely held perception that their presence in the region is an extension of ''the old colonial pattern which puts colonial interests first and African interests a distant second.''

"Recent deaths in some parts of Balochistan and India-held Kashmir [Indian-administered Kashmir] due to heavy rains and landslides serve as a stark reminder to the new government in the wake of Pakistan's growing vulnerability to climate change," said the editorial on 11 March.

"While major cities like Karachi and other urban areas remained safe from untimely rains, heavy rains and unseasonal snowfall in Balochistan and northern areas showcase a concerning picture, and perhaps warn the people about upcoming times," it warned.

"Memories of last year's floods, which impacted over 30 million people, are still fresh. Pakistan, already categorised as one of the countries most susceptible to climate change, faces a heightened threat. The time for complacency is over," it emphasised. 

Listing possible actions, the editorial said that "firstly, institutions responsible for disaster management, including disaster management authorities and irrigation departments, must begin immediate preparedness efforts."

"Secondly, raising public awareness is crucial. Educating the public on flood safety measures, early warning systems, and evacuation procedures will empower them to respond effectively in case of emergencies. Thirdly, long-term climate change mitigation strategies cannot be ignored," it added.

"Fourthly, international cooperation is paramount. The government must actively participate in global climate change dialogues and seek assistance in mitigation efforts and adaptation strategies," it further said.

Reiterating the call for action, the paper said that "it is time to act. We can choose to ignore the warning signs and face the consequences, or we can act collectively, embracing proactive solutions." 

See also: Pakistani daily urges development of 'comprehensive' climate adaptation policy

Source: Daily Times website, Lahore, in English 0000 GMT 11 Mar 24

*   Balochistan

Q: On an election-themed night on Russia’s three main TV channels on 17 March, host Irada Zeynalova of NTV’s Itogi Nedeli (Results of the Week) spoke of “links in the same chain” (both “our elections”, “regarded in the West as a vote in support of the course that has been taken”, and those to come in the US and the EU). This, she said, is about “reformatting the world order”. Everything is viewed “through the same prism of the Ukrainian conflict by everyone”.

“That is to say, the entire system of global relations is now being tested. Everyone understands that in the end the world will definitely become different, a new alliance will be formed, new rules, a new order will begin to work. And that the international institutions that were created after World War II no longer work, or the treaties that everyone voluntarily promised to observe, precisely because they no longer solve the problems that emerge, and their opinion is appealed to only when it is convenient for politicians,” as per Zeynalova’s seemingly abstract commentary at the top of the news.

In the meantime, it was tonight’s news reviews that were reformatted as Vladimir Putin claimed his fifth term as Russia’s president. On NTV, Itogi Nedeli made an earlier start than usual, at 1850 Moscow time (1550 gmt), against its usual start time of 1900 (all Moscow time henceforth). Rossiya 1 brought forward its Vesti Nedeli (News of the Week), with Dmitry Kiselyov, by an hour, to start at 1900 rather than its usual 2000. At an hour and 55 minutes, the programme was shorter than usual, to make way for a version of election coverage in the form of an unscheduled Vesti bulletin for the next two hours.

Channel One’s “special” Vremya (Time) edition started at its usual time of 2100 but it extended its bulletin late into the night to include the latest speeches by Vladimir Putin, which took the programme into four-hour territory. Its veteran host Yekaterina Andreyeva was at the helm, not always smoothly, throughout the programme.

Early, pre-exit poll coverage

NTV’s Itogi Nedeli and Rossiya 1’s Vesti Nedeli were aired well before exit poll data was officially announced at 2100, which gave Putin a landslide share of 87% of the vote. Accordingly, their reports were confined to heavy hints from voters about the kind of candidate they would like to lead Russia in the next six years. “We need someone who will lead our country for the next six years. Someone who is decisive, who is courageous and who will bring us to victory,” a man captioned as ex-navy told NTV. 

The discourse claimed a high turnout and emphasised the importance of the vote as a manifestation of unity and consolidation in the face of external pressure and hostility. This was Dmitry Kiselyov of Vesti Nedeli, for example: “We need to understand the nature of such high civic activity. This, now, is a special election. In effect, it is a wartime one, as both missile salvoes and drone swarms head in our direction every day in the hope that they can disrupt the electoral process through intimidation. However, exactly the opposite has happened. People rallied and even those who had not done so before went to vote. Such a high turnout is the answer to all attempts to interfere with the election.”

The vox pop in the reports was monotone, not to say apparently scripted, as voters, to camera, expressed their sentiment in near-identical terms. Some recalled the hardship of the 1990s and by contrast invoked what they described as the many changes for the better in their lives now. Others professed their pride in Russia, apparently the envy of the world. Separately, voters in Russia’s “new regions” (such as Donbas and other occupied Ukraine) were given the floor to say they were happy to be back with Russia again.

Separate reports were fashioned to describe the vote in Russia’s border Belgorod Region, where voters were unafraid to be active even though it has been under continuous attack from Ukraine, as the story ran.

“The fact is that Russia has a very transparent and democratic electoral system, as international public observers note,” according to Rossiya 1’s summary of the state of affairs. 

Ukraine’s ‘terrorist tactics’

In the context of Belgorod and more generally, Ukraine was described as either a terrorist or Nazi “regime”, or both. On Rossiya 1’s Vesti Nedeli, Kiselyov used the slur “Bandera Nazi regime” repeatedly and pointedly throughout his programme. A start on this usage was made as Kiselyov looked back to his interview with Putin at the start of last week, to which he returned again and again during his programme. “It is important to realise the historical inevitability of the battle with the Bandera Nazi regime, which, with the support of the West, has encroached not only on its own Russians [in Ukraine], but also on Russia itself. And the Russians are today the largest divided nation in the world,” Kiselyov said. “If we abandon these people today, then tomorrow our losses may increase many times over, and our children will not have a future, because we will feel insecure. We will be a third or fourth class nation. No one will take us into account if we cannot protect ourselves. And the consequences could be catastrophic for Russian statehood,” Putin told Kiselyov. “The West also understands that for Russia this is a matter of life and death. They dream about the death of Russia. Hence all these insane quantities of weapons and money provided to the Bandera Nazi regime. They have even begun to discuss sending troops. Maybe we should also take an unconventional step and ask to send North Korean troops to help us? After all, the friendly DPRK has an army of more than two million, and we once helped North Korea a lot in the battle with America. Putin’s response was that on the one hand, he did not obviously rule out such a turn, but at the same time, there is no need to turn to North Korea now. We can handle it ourselves,” Kiselyov said. “But a categorical no was the response to the question whether it ever occurred to us, during difficult moments for the front last year, to use tactical nuclear weapons,” Kiselyov added.

As elsewhere, Channel One described what it framed as “attempted breakthroughs”, that is to say incursions into Russia from Ukraine by hostile forces, as an attempt to destabilise Russia during the presidential election. “Carried out by elite Ukrainian special forces along with foreign mercenaries, with armour and artillery support”, they were repelled. “As a result, hundreds of militants are dead, dozens of pieces of equipment destroyed, but the Russian border is still securely locked,” according to Channel One’s Yekaterina Andreyeva’s summary. “After this rout, the adversary switched to its usual terrorist tactics as it launched strikes against peaceful neighbourhoods, including with drones stuffed full of explosives,” it added.

Channel One went on to liken Ukraine to Nazi Germany, branding Kyiv “a Nazi regime” and “direct successor to Hitler's”, complete with a campaign of “mass terror”.

Over on NTV, the Belgorod raid was framed as an attempt at distraction amid bad news from the battlefield. “Militants have been trying to get into the Kursk region and Belgorod region like cockroaches since Tuesday. Ever since then, action has been taken to crush them like bedbugs,” the report remarked.

Escalation, nuclear again

As NTV’s Zeynalova continued to ponder the issue of escalation, she invoked US diplomat George F. Kennan’s 1997 op-ed as an argument against Nato’s expansion (“A Fateful Error”). This, she said, is “hybrid war, in which any methods are being used”, complete with “fakes” and “discussions about nuclear use” and “statements about an imminent retaliatory offensive”; all “a game of escalation according to Kennan’s logic of an escalation ladder”. She went on to quote an unspecified essay in Responsible Statecraft, with the apparent suggestion that it was time for the West to push Ukraine towards negotiations. What with US President Joe Biden’s new Iran sanctions waiver and Nato Deputy Secretary General Mircea Geoana‘s reported remarks about the years of tense relations with Russia to come, Zeynalova said, there is a chance for de-escalation. 

“Compared to statements about our strategic defeat, this may already mean something simple - there is a chance over the years to move away from the dangerous threshold with talk of nuclear use. If we use it, we will have a chance to find reasons to build new relationships. But, as Putin says, it takes two to tango,” Zeynalova said.

Here, on NTV, as on the other two channels, Putin’s assurances, in his interview with Kiselyov, that Russia is willing to negotiate about Ukraine provided Russia is given security guarantees were televised. 

Putin’s latest nuclear rhetoric, also in his interview with Kiselyov, also made an appearance, in which he said Russia was ready for nuclear war “from a military-technical point of view”. But other than a long extract from Putin himself televised on Vesti Nedeli, it was not especially dwelt on in any of the commentary. If anything, it seemed to be purposely played down. The phrase “from a military-technical point of view” was present in Kiselyov’s account of this point from his interview with Putin, but the words “[ready] for nuclear war” contained in the question’s wording were absent, replaced as they were with Kiselyov’s comment that this appertained to the status of Russia’s strategic missile forces. Over on NTV, meanwhile, these words were omitted altogether, its relevant commentary confined to what Putin said about the newness of Russia’s nuclear triad, even though elsewhere in its commentary, rebuttal appeared mixed with satisfaction at the effect of Putin’s latest nuclear outburst.

“American propaganda assigns the role of the first strike to Vladimir Putin. Therefore, everything he said in the interview about the possibility of using nuclear weapons became a real bomb shell, even though the Americans themselves were not uninvolved in whipping up this hysteria. CNN reported last week that Russia was planning a nuclear strike on Ukraine at the end of 2022 and that the United States itself was carefully preparing for the consequences. A little earlier, meanwhile, the United States convinced the whole world that Russia was about to use nuclear weapons in space,” NTV’s story ran.

More Macron, ‘mercenaries’

As over the previous couple of weeks, Russian TV’s news reviews continued to be preoccupied with French President Emmanuel Macron’s series of pronouncements on Russia’s war in Ukraine. There was extensive anti-Macron content especially on Rossiya 1 and NTV, plus a segment on Channel One.

Rossiya 1 was especially strident in its anti-Macron commentary. In his dispatch, inter alia, its Europe correspondent Mikhail Antonov described France’s ministerial duo of PM Gabriel Attal and Foreign Minister Stephane Sejourne as “the homosexual pair, Attal and Sejourne, completely controlled” by Macron (the word “homosexual” present in the broadcast version but mysteriously absent from media monitoring service Medialogia’s text transcript).

Apparent contrast was served up with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s caution, with his refusal to supply Ukraine with the Taurus long-range cruise missile. Nevertheless, the channels felt it necessary to amplify warnings against such an eventuality. Further claims of a Nato split on support for Ukraine provided an accompaniment.

In the same report, incongruously (given Russia’s actions), Antonov asserted that any Taurus supplies to Ukraine would amount to an act of “aggression against a foreign state”, any such German involvement also “prohibited” by its constitution.

On Channel One, it invoked a 2022 “Ukrainian propaganda” production, its gist “to frighten the Germans with computer simulation of an ostensible missile attack on the centre of Berlin” (cue part of the montage where a member of the public in front of the Brandenburg Gate ducks in fear as an object like a missile streaks low over her). The question the report went on to pose was: “What if Kyiv strikes Russian targets but the Germans get hit [in retaliation]?”

Over on NTV, meanwhile, it discerned Macron’s attempt to walk back on some of his statements as he met Scholz and Polish PM Donald Tusk. “Perhaps to backtrack, on Friday in Germany, at a meeting with Scholz and Tusk, who had returned from Washington, Macron said that the [three] were not parties to the conflict and would never initiate escalation. Although Macron tried to present the alliance of the three countries as a single fist to fight Russia, there has been no talk of unity for a long time,” it said.

All this was combined with discourse about what was framed in unison as the use of “foreign mercenaries” by Ukraine, on the back of the Russian Defence Ministry’s claims. The reports’ usage was “soldiers of misfortune”, to convey the message of the inevitable fate that awaits them – death at the hands of the Russian military.

Source: BBC Monitoring in English 1600 GMT 17 Mar 24

Q: The new information comes from Cindi Lee Yeager, a deputy district attorney in neighboring Cobb County, Ga., whom the defense lawyers said they spoke to on Friday about conversations she has had with Mr. Bradley.

At issue is a key matter in the disqualification effort: the timing of the romantic relationship that developed between Fani T. Willis, who as the Fulton County district attorney is leading the prosecution of Mr. Trump, and Nathan Wade, the Atlanta-area lawyer she hired to manage the case.

Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade have said that a romance developed between them after she hired him in November 2021. But the defense lawyers have tried to prove the romantic relationship started earlier.

If they are correct that Ms. Willis hired a boyfriend for a lucrative, high-profile job, it might bolster their argument that she engaged in “self-dealing” when she took a number of vacations with Mr. Wade, and thus created a conflict of interest that should result in her removal from the case.

Defense lawyers thought that Mr. Bradley, a former law partner of Mr. Wade who also served for a time as Mr. Wade’s divorce lawyer, might offer some clarity as to when the romance began. But that did not happen. In a text exchange in January, he told one of the defense lawyers in the case that he “absolutely” thought the romance began before Ms. Willis hired Mr. Wade.

But when called to the stand last week, Mr. Bradley said that he had been “speculating.”

In a filing on Monday, lawyers for David J. Shafer, a co-defendant in the case, said that they had spoken to Ms. Yeager, who said that Mr. Bradley had told her the prosecutors’ relationship began before Mr. Wade went to work for Ms. Willis.

The filing stated that according to Ms. Yeager, Mr. Bradley told her that “Mr. Wade had definitively begun a romantic relationship with Ms. Willis during the time that Ms. Willis was running for district attorney in 2019 through 2020.”

According to the filing, Ms. Yeager said she also overheard Ms. Willis call Mr. Bradley last September, prompted by a news article that mentioned how much her office was paying Mr. Wade and his law partners. (Mr. Bradley’s work for the office was not related to the Trump case.)

“They are coming after us,” Ms. Willis told Mr. Bradley during the call, according to the account offered by Ms. Yeager that is described in the defense filing. “You don’t need to talk to them about anything about us.”

The context of Ms. Willis’ alleged call to Mr. Bradley is not clear; In any case, it would have taken place before the disqualification effort began in January and before it was known that Mr. Bradley would be subpoenaed to testify.

On the stand last month, Mr. Bradley testified that he “did not personally know” Ms. Willis. “My interaction with Ms. Willis was never where I would pick up the phone and talk to her,” he said.

Also unclear is what impact, if any, Ms. Yeager’s statement could have on a judge’s decision whether to disqualify the prosecutors. The judge, Scott McAfee of Fulton County Superior Court, has already wrapped up testimony on the disqualification question; on Friday, he said he would rule on the matter within two weeks.

In their filing on Monday, Mr. Shafer’s lawyers asked the judge to allow them to put Ms. Yeager on the stand “in the event that the court reopens the hearing to receive additional evidence.” They noted that Mr. Trump and Ms. Willis’s office have also asked the judge to allow for additional testimony.

At a hearing on Friday, Judge McAfee heard final legal arguments from both sides but said that he could hold another hearing if evidence emerged to require it.

A lawyer for Mr. Bradley did not return calls seeking comment. Ms. Yeager, who has run for local office previously as a Republican — but says she currently considers herself a Democrat — declined to comment on the filing on Monday. A spokesman for the district attorney’s office did not comment on Monday, but Ms. Willis and her office have described the disqualification effort as legally baseless and an effort to generate salacious headlines.

If successful, the effort to remove Ms. Willis would throw the criminal case against Mr. Trump into turmoil, forcing a state agency to find another prosecutor to take it on. A new prosecutor could move to keep, modify or drop the case against Mr. Trump, who was indicted in August with 18 allies on charges of conspiring to overturn the former president’s 2020 election loss in Georgia.

Since then, four defendants have pleaded guilty.

Q: In updates about the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the channels said Russian forces had taken yet another village in Donbass and destroyed more Western equipment.

Newly elected UK MP George Galloway and US TV personality Tucker Carlson were shown parroting the Kremlin's propaganda narratives on Ukraine, while Russian Duma speaker Vyacheslav Volodin appeared to threaten Germany over possible deliveries of Taurus missiles to Kyiv.

In a lengthy Rossiya 1 report about Putin meeting the next generation of Russian managerial talent, the president was shown casually admitting that Russian oil production is falling and Russia is at risk of losing its traditional markets. Another Rossiya 1 report said that despite "external pressure", the Russian economy is showing a strong and accelerating growth.

Incursion from Ukraine

All three channels led with what they described as an attempted but unsuccessful cross-border raid into Russia's Belgorod and Kursk regions by Ukrainian "terrorists" and "saboteurs".

The attempt was a "complete failure" and the "Ukrainian terrorist formations" were not allowed to cross into Russia, losing hundreds of men, seven tanks and several armoured vehicles, including US-supplied Bradley IFVs, state-controlled Channel One told its viewers.

Footage of damaged or destroyed armoured vehicles was shown to corroborate these claims, but it is not immediately clear where or when that footage was recorded.

Ukrainian claims that anti-Kremlin paramilitary groups manned by Russian nationals had turned Russian border guards to flight and seized a village in Kursk Region were dismissed as enemy propaganda.

"While Ukrainian tanks were burning, Kyiv propagandists were posting videos supposedly showing terrorists crossing the Russian border, but what the videos actually showed were ordinary passers-by," Channel One said.

It also showed what it said was footage from the Russian villages which the anti-Kremlin paramilitaries had earlier claimed to have seized. The footage shows that the Russian military are fully in control of both villages and there is no sign of any fighting there, Channel One's presenter said.

Another Ukrainian village seized, Galloway and Carlson parrot Kremlin propaganda

In other Ukraine-related news, the three channels relayed the Russian MoD's report that Russian forces had seized the Donbas village of Nevelske, continued to make steady advances on other stretches of the front, and destroyed valuable Western equipment, including another Himars MRL system.

Turning to the subject of Western support for Ukraine, state-owned Rossiya 1 showed newly elected UK MP George Galloway warning (in a Russian voiceover) that Russia will use all the weapons it has in its arsenals in the event of an "existential threat", and that French President Macron and other European leaders who "fantasise" about getting directly involved in the war in Ukraine will be completely defeated.

Over on Channel One, US TV personality Tucker Carlson, lionised by the pro-Kremlin media as an eminent US voice of reason, was shown arguing that US sanctions against Russia break international rules and undermine the world's confidence in the US dollar.

Rossiya 1 and Channel One also showed Russian Duma speaker urging the German Bundestag to investigate the audio leak on which top German officers are heard discussing possible use of Taurus missiles for a strike against the Kerch Bridge between Crimea and the Russian mainland.

The involvement of German officers in such discussions is seen in Russia as "aggression and a threat to our security", and Russia "has what it takes to respond to such threats", including "the most advanced, high-tech weapons" which no other country has, Vyacheslav Volodin was shown saying on Channel One.

Putin admits falling Russian oil production

With only a few days remaining until the Russian presidential election, all three channels aired lengthy reports about Vladimir Putin attending a forum of the next generation of Russian managerial and state governance talent.

The reports mostly highlighted Putin's banter with the event's participants and their words of praise for the Russian leader - but on Rossiya 1, he was also shown casually admitting in a chat with a relatively youthful deputy energy minister that Russian oil production is declining and Russia risks losing its traditional oil markets.

"Opec+ is really helping us to keep the oil prices [high], generating revenue for our treasury, but our oil production is in fact falling," Putin was shown saying.

"And because production is falling [in Russia] but rising in other countries, such as the United States, we risk losing our markets," the president went on.

The Russian government imposed a one-year ban on the publication of oil and gas production statistics in April 2023. On 7 March, Interfax news agency said the ban had been extended until 1 April 2025.

Russian economy said to be growing strongly

In other economic news, Rossiya 1 showed Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin announcing that Russian GDP grew at an annualised rate of 4.6% in January 2024, up from the 3.5% growth reported for the whole of 2023.

"The Russian economy is successfully adapting to the challenges, regardless of the external pressure," Rossiya 1 told its viewers.

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 1800 gmt 12 Mar 24

Q: Judge Scott McAfee of Fulton County Superior Court ruled this month that Ms. Willis, the district attorney, could keep the case. But he said she could do so only if her subordinate, Nathan J. Wade, a special prosecutor with whom she had a romantic relationship, stepped aside. Mr. Wade subsequently resigned from the Trump case, which he had run for more than two years.

But in Friday’s 51-page filing to the Georgia Court of Appeals, defense lawyers argued that this was not enough. Ms. Willis and her entire office must be disqualified, they said, in order to restore “the public’s faith in the integrity of the judicial system.”

The defense lawyers maintained that the romance had created an untenable conflict of interest. Judge McAfee, in a March 15 order, found no “actual” conflict. But he said that the romance had created an “appearance of impropriety.”

Defense lawyers said the judge had made a “plain legal error requiring reversal.”

It is unclear whether the appellate court, which leans conservative, will take up the appeal of the decision by Judge McAfee, who was appointed by the state’s Republican governor, Brian Kemp. Legal analysts generally regarded his ruling on the disqualification matter as reflecting his cautious approach as he seeks middle ground in the contentious case.

Ms. Willis’s office did not comment on the latest filing, though she has zealously defended her conduct. “I’m not on trial, no matter how hard you try to put me on trial,” she told one of the defense lawyers during testimony this month, as she emphasized that it was the defendants who were on trial for trying to steal an election.

Last weekend, in the wake of the judge’s ruling, she told CNN “I’m not embarrassed by anything I’ve done,” adding that “my greatest crime is I had a relationship with a man, but that’s not something I find embarrassing in any way.”

Defense lawyers highlighted those and other similar comments in their new filing.

Judge McAfee had already given the defendants permission to pursue their appeal. But under Georgia law, the co-defendants must also secure the approval of the Georgia Court of Appeals before the matter can be heard by a panel of three appellate judges. The appeals court has 45 days to decide whether to grant or deny the appeal application.

The effort to disqualify Ms. Willis led to multiple days of hearings that delved into salacious details of her personal life. Defense lawyers argued that she had engaged in “self-dealing” by taking vacations with Mr. Wade and allowing him to pay for at least some of the cost of the trips.

They reiterated that criticism in their most recent filing. “No prosecutor has ever been so reckless and relentless in pursuit of personal gain,” they wrote.

Judge McAfee was ultimately unmoved by such arguments. But in his ruling this month, he criticized Ms. Willis for a “tremendous lapse in judgment” in dating Mr. Wade. He also pointed to lingering questions about whether Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade “testified untruthfully,” stating that the hearings had left an “odor of mendacity” hanging over the matter.

The drama over the romance served to distract from the criminal charges contained in the August indictment of Mr. Trump and 18 of his allies. The charging document described myriad efforts to overturn Mr. Trump’s 2020 election loss in Georgia, and four of the defendants have since taken plea deals.

Defense lawyers continue to claim that Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade lied under oath and in court filings. They also renewed their argument that a speech Ms. Willis gave at an Atlanta church could prejudice a jury. In that speech in January, she suggested that the criticism directed at her and Mr. Wade, both of whom are Black, was motivated by racism.

The defense lawyers argue that the appeals court needs to step in to clarify whether such behavior should result in the disqualification of a district attorney.

The Georgia case is one of four criminal cases Mr. Trump is facing, and in each of them, his lawyers have engaged in delaying tactics as the November general election approaches. A Manhattan judge recently set an April 15 trial date for Mr. Trump’s criminal case involving charges that he falsified business records to hide a potential sex scandal. Trial dates have not been set for his two federal criminal cases, in Washington, D.C., and Florida.

Judge McAfee also recently ruled that a pretrial appeal could be sought by Harrison Floyd, a co-defendant in the case who formerly led a group called Black Voices for Trump. The judge had ruled against Mr. Floyd’s contention that prosecutors did not have the authority to pursue election-related charges against him because they did not first seek a referral from the state election board.

As in the disqualification appeal, Mr. Floyd must first secure the approval of the appellate court before his appeal can go forward.

It appears increasingly unlikely that the Georgia case will go to trial before the November election, although it is also unclear whether the appeal efforts will contribute to the delay. Judge McAfee has said that he will continue to address other pretrial motions in the case regardless of what the appeals court decides to do with regard to the disqualification effort.

Q: Anchor Kamran Khan said just like in 2013, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has once again become the ruling party in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), and an opposition party in the rest of Pakistan. He remarked Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) has to decide whether his party would continue the politics of resistance. He claimed the PTI has adopted an "aggressive attitude" and its decision to appoint Ali Amin Gandapur as the chief minister of KP indicates that it has "initiated an aggressive political innings".

Khan contacted PTI politician Ali Mohammad Khan and asked him whether the PTI has decided to continue its aggressive politics. Ali Khan said the most important thing is that the mandate given to the party in elections should be accepted. He added Imran Khan does not want the party to remain in an "aggressive or battling position" all the time, but protests will continue till it gets its "right". He mentioned Imran Khan spoke with him about "truth and reconciliation" and said everyone will have to tell the truth. He questioned whether Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif would accept that he lost the election and came into power with a "fake mandate".

Ali Khan said the people of KP voted for the PTI for a third term because it had performed well. He remarked his party does not accept Shehbaz Sharif as the prime minister and that is why Gandapur has been made the chief minister of KP and he did not attend the prime minister's oath-taking ceremony. He mentioned Gandapur will perform his state duties but would continue to protest till the party's "rights" are given to it.

Relations with other countries

Khan spoke with senior political analyst Husain Haqqani and asked him whether he would agree that the world is not concerned about the issues in elections in Pakistan and wants cordial relations with the new government. Haqqani fully agreed with the view and said it has happened nowhere in the world that governments of other countries have refused to recognise a government after an election. He remarked it is a result of "political immaturity and lack of understanding" of international relations that PTI politicians were expecting that upon their expression of reservations about elections, foreign countries would not accept the new government.

Khan asked Haqqani to comment on the congratulatory messages given to Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif after his election. Haqqani said while messages are a formal activity, the swiftness with which these messages were conveyed in the context of a controversial election proves that all countries want Pakistan to be a stable country. He added Pakistan's stability is in the interest of all countries which have given loans to it. Talking about India, he said it is in a position of an "economic take off" and confrontation with Pakistan is an "irritant" for it. Therefore, he added, all countries want to engage with Pakistan and improve relations with it.

Replying to Khan's question on how Pakistan can maintain a balance in its relations with China and the United States (US) simultaneously, Haqqani said at present all countries in the world are in search of a "balanced foreign policy", and the far eastern countries have recently said that they want relations with both China and the US and would not want to get involved in any conflict between the two countries. He insisted Pakistan will also need to adopt this "sagacious attitude" and "detach emotions from foreign policy".

Speaking about the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) programme, Haqqani said Pakistan had to seek loans from the IMF repeatedly because it did not follow the IMF's conditions which were aimed at reforming its economy. He added Pakistan should complete an IMF programme to achieve economic stability. Talking about the need for internal political stability, he insisted "national reconciliation" is necessary and if there is no internal harmony, Pakistan will not be able to have any reconciliation or negotiations with other countries.

Haqqani said restoration of Pakistan's relations with the US at the highest level have begun and noted US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin and Secretary of State Antony Blinken held meetings with Chief of Army Staff Asim Munir during his visit to Washington. He expressed confidence in US Vice President Kamala Harris contacting Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif in the near future. He claimed under Imran Khan's government, there was an issue that nothing was kept confidential. He remarked in "populism", the leader wants to say everything which can earn an applause from the public but in diplomacy, "many things have to be done quietly".

Replying to Khan's question on whether the US policy towards Pakistan would change if Donald Trump (former US president) or the Republican party comes into office after the November elections, Haqqani said the US foreign policy is based on national interest and not on personalities, so a change in government may not bring any major change in the foreign policy.

Q: Ms Tabrizi was initially arrested in November and spent more than a week in detention before reportedly dying on 24 March in her father's house in Tehran, according to journalist Reza Akvanian.

The judiciary statement, however, noted that "a comprehensive inquiry had shown that no summons had been issued to her by the judicial or security institutions" just before or after the start of the Iranian new year on 20 March.

The statement said that Tabrizi had intended to leave the country on 8 January using false travel documents when she was arrested. She was reportedly released on bail on 15 January.

The statement further noted that Tabrizi did not return to prison in the two months and 10 days after that and before her death. It added that a suspended sentence had been issued against her.

It explained that, in this context, a suspended sentence meant that if she committed no crimes within two years of the issuing of the ruling, the sentence would have been revoked.

Some users argued that the establishment was responsible for her death even if it was a suicide as she died "under the heavy psychological pressure of security officers".

The statement also stressed that the father of the deceased had contacted the police on 24 March, in Shahriar County west of the capital, to say that his daughter was not waking up and was likely dead. Upon confirmation of her death, an autopsy was initiated by the medical staff.

In its concluding paragraph, the statement noted that her father had said that she had gone to the infirmary the previous night after feeling unwell where she received treatment. The exact cause of her death is not yet established pending further examination.
