Q: Anchor Marrium Zeshan said leaders and workers of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) staged protests against alleged rigging in the recent elections. She noted rallies were staged in various cities and some of the protesters, including Sardar Latif Khosa and Salman Akram Raja (prominent PTI politicians), were arrested. She mentioned Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur (PTI member) addressed a protest rally in Peshawar and demanded that Imran Khan (former PTI chairperson) should be given the right to a fair trial and the PTI's "stolen mandate" should be returned to it. She added Gandapur also demanded that a commission should be formed to look into the allegations of election rigging.

Zeshan questioned whether the arrest of people is justified when peaceful protest is a democratic right. Journalist Salman Ghani said peaceful protests are a right but the opposition has always been facing the same situation in Pakistan. He added protest and resistance politics is effective only for a certain time, and if protests continue for a long time, political workers get tired of them. He was of the view that this protest by the PTI would affect the economy of Pakistan and not the government.

Noting that the PTI could not stage a big show in Punjab, particularly in Lahore, Ghani said the party should review its actions like writing a letter to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) against the release of funds to the government. He reminded the PTI leadership that protests ultimately come to an end through dialogue.

Analyst Hasan Askari was of the view that matters are not being handled "democratically" and said principles of democracy and fundamental rights should be applied across the board. He remarked "coercive apparatus" of the state can control the protests for the time being but it would increase hatred. He criticised the government for not focusing on solving the problems of the people. He claimed there is so much despondency among the people that "80 per cent of the people would leave Pakistan if given an option".

Analyst Rasul Bakhsh Rais said the PTI cannot bring about a revolution or topple the government through these protests, nor can it change the election results. He added the party wants to reinforce an impression continuously in the country and abroad that the elections were rigged. Noting that the goal of politics is to resolve disputes, he remarked no political leader in Pakistan is ready to address the cause of political tensions.

Journalist Rasheed Safi said demand for a commission over the election results is a "realistic demand" and it would be good if it is accepted. However, he added, it is not likely that the demand would be taken into consideration. He was of the view that Imran Khan is also not likely to be given any relief. He urged the federal government to play its constitutional role in dealing with the provinces and also asked Gandapur to not use his constitutional position to promote his political interests. He warned if tension persists, it would provide an opportunity to anti-state elements to promote hatred in the province [KP], which is already in the "grip of terrorism".

Ghani disagreed with Askari's view that 80 per cent of the Pakistanis would leave the country if they are given a chance to do so. He said Pakistan did not face such issues till 2017 when it was the "24th largest economy". He claimed the economy was derailed by removing former prime minister Nawaz Sharif from power. He agreed that a commission should be formed to look into the allegations of election rigging, along with several other issues. He claimed the PTI's politics of protest is aimed at damaging the country's economy.

Zeshan noted prices of essential items have skyrocketed even before the beginning of Ramadan (the month of fasting for Muslims) and asked Ghani what could be the solution to this issue. Ghani replied it is a very sad situation that prices have doubled within two days and would further increase during Ramadan. He said this is a challenge for the new government.

Askari noted the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) government cannot control the prices because its main support base is made up of traders and businessmen. He said instead of solving the issue of inflation, the government starts distributing free items. He mentioned political activists get arrested but no shopkeeper is arrested for profiteering because the party gets votes from them.

Rais was of the view that the government should bring reforms to manage the supply of food items from farms to common consumers so that it can control hoarding and price hikes.

“We need to use election day to show that we exist and there are many of us, we are actual, living, real people and we are against Putin. ... What to do next is up to you. You can vote for any candidate except Putin. You could ruin your ballot,” Navalnaya said.

Navalny had floated the noontime concept on Feb. 1, saying it was a “completely legal and safe” way to protest and that authorities would have no way of countering it. Mass protest actions in Russia have become effectively impossible under Putin's intensifying crackdown on dissent and criticism in recent years.

Navalny was reported dead on Feb. 16. Authorities said that he became ill after a walk at his prison colony, but have otherwise given no details. Navalny had been imprisoned since returning to Moscow in early 2021 from Germany, where he had been recuperating from nerve agent poisoning that he blamed on the Kremlin.

Q: Given the anti-China fervor in Australia, he acknowledged he could come off as suspicious. So why would he not get into trouble with the authorities? He believed that it would be embarrassing for Australia to accuse of him of spying because he had been an active member of a major political party.

His confidence was absolute, and utterly misplaced. Less than two years later, in 2020, he became the first person to be charged under Australia’s broad foreign interference laws. He was accused of acting on behalf of Beijing.

Who was the suspect?

Di Sanh “Sunny” Duong, 68, was born and raised in Vietnam. He was among the hundreds of thousands of ethnic Chinese who fled that country in the 1970s. He settled in Australia and grew a business making tombstones, secured a middle-class life and got enmeshed in local Chinese community groups.

I first interviewed him in 2019 and quickly realized that Mr. Duong was prone to boasting — about his travels, about his family and about his status in society, so much so that it was difficult to take him seriously.

What did he do?

The case against Mr. Duong was not about what he did, but what he was planning to do. Mr. Duong had ties with the Chinese Communist Party, prosecutors said. He had invited an Australian government minister to a charity event, they added, with the intention of someday trying to influence him on behalf of Beijing.

During the trial, the jury was presented with two versions of Mr. Duong: Was he a savvy operator pushing China’s agenda in Australia, as the prosecution would have it, or was he, as the defense claimed, a bombastic braggart?

What was the verdict?

Mr. Duong did not testify in court. But while the trial was underway, he met me, at a pub a stone’s throw from the courthouse, to share his story.

He gave outlandish and convoluted reasons for the actions that prosecutors built their case around. One head-spinning episode involved how Mr. Duong thought he was interacting with a Chinese intelligence officer but later concluded, thanks to a TV show, that the official was not a spy. One thing was clear: Mr. Duong remained adamant that he never did anything against Australian interests.

The jury disagreed. In December, he was found guilty of preparing for or planning an act of foreign interference. Late last month, a judge sentenced him to two years and nine months in prison. Mr. Duong is expected to serve a year behind bars.
A:

The locations mentioned in the article are:

*   Australia
*   Beijing
*   Vietnam
*   China

Q: Pan-Arab outlets have discussed the significance of Trump-Putin meeting in Alaska today, with some outlets expressing cautious optimism that it could lead to a breakthrough in the Russia-Ukraine war.

UAE-based Sky News Arabia discussed the possible outcome of the summit with some political experts who noted that more efforts were necessary to reach a solution to the conflict.

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya led its morning bulletins with reports on the Alaska summit underlining its "exploratory nature". The need for a ceasefire in Ukraine and the complexity of including European interests and Zelensky's participation in talks with the US were also discussed.

Qatari flagship Al Jazeera said the summit could indicate a shift in Trump's position towards Russia and Ukraine.

We will publish a Briefing.

Gunmen attack Kurdish fighters in Deir al-Zour

A war monitor reported yesterday that clashes in Deir al-Zour province between pro-government fighters and Kurdish-led forces had left one dead and three wounded.

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) said gunmen had attacked the Syrian Democratic forces (SDF), seizing six fighters and later releasing two.

Syrian media have reported renewed clashes in northeast Syria between the SDF and pro-government forces.

This week, Turkey and Syria signed a military cooperation agreement under which Ankara will provide weapons and training for the Syrian army.

Turkey is one of Damascus's main allies since the fall of former President Bashar al-Assad.

It has threatened to take action against the SDF which controls large areas of north east Syria, unless the group integrates into Syria's army.

Palestinian factions call for 'national unity' meeting

Palestinian factions meeting in Cairo yesterday issued a joint statement in which they called on Egypt to sponsor and host an emergency national unity meeting of all Palestinian forces to discuss a "national strategy and practical programme to confront the occupation's schemes".

The statement condemned Israeli remarks on taking control of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, calling on the international community to pressure Israel to halt its operations and hold it responsible for its ongoing "violations".

The factions stressed their "full responsiveness to initiatives and proposals for a solution that meets national requirements, including an end to the aggression, the withdrawal of the occupying forces, and the lifting of the unjust blockade on Gaza".

They also expressed appreciation for "the great efforts" made by the mediators - Egypt and Qatar - in supporting "the Palestinian cause and halting the aggression" against Palestinians.

New settlements will 'bury the idea of a Palestinian state' - Smotrich

The far-right Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said plans to build over 3,000 settlements in the occupied West Bank will "bury the idea of a Palestinian state", Israeli media reported yesterday.

The controversial "E1" plan, which has been on hold for decades, seeks to extend the settlement of Maale Adumim, cutting off occupied East Jerusalem from the West Bank and separating the northern and eastern parts of the enclave.

The Maariv daily quoted Smotrich as saying after announcing the plan: "This is Zionism at its best - building, setting and strengthening our sovereignty in the Land of Israel."

Israeli media have reported that the government is expected to formally approve construction plans next week.

Smotrich's remarks draw backlash

Smotrich's remarks have provoked harsh criticism by Palestinian factions and some Arab countries.

Hamas and the Palestinian Islamic Jihad, along with other groups, issued statements to denounce the move and called on international and regional powers to work to halt the plan.

Qatar, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan also officially criticised the plans, describing them as "violation" of international law.

The Palestinian presidency also said the plan undermined any chance to implement the two-state solution.

Israeli minister visits Marwan Barghouti

The far-right national security minister Itamar Ben Gvir visited prominent Palestinian Fatah leader Marwan Barghouti, currently serving five life sentences in an Israeli prison, domestic media reported yesterday.

In a video, the first published documentation of Barghouti (also Barghuthi) in years, Ben Gvir could be heard telling him: "You won't win."

"Whoever messes with the nation of Israel, whoever murders women and children, we will wipe them out," Ben Gvir added.

Barghouti appeared shaven-headed in the video, and domestic media later cited his family as saying they were "shocked" by his appearance, adding that he looked hungry.

The Haaretz daily said the release of such footage was "very unusual" and would usually require permission from the Prison Service.

We will be publishing a Briefing.

Yemen minister criticises Houthi presence in Iraq's Karbala

A senior official from Yemen's internationally recognised government has said that the appearance of members of the Iran-backed Houthi movement in the Iraqi city of Karbala, to mark the end of the Arbaeen pilgrimage, revealed the group's "alien agenda".

In a statement yesterday, Information Minister Muammar al-Eryani made the remarks in response to photos and videos shared online purportedly showing members of the rebel group participating in the predominantly Shia pilgrimage.

The minister stressed that the government had "warned from the outset that the Houthis were... an Iranian tool implementing a sectarian project".

Anti-Houthi Suhail TV also criticised the footage, reporting that the Houthis had been distributing "millions of free meals" every day to pilgrims while "stealing from the mouths of the hungry in Yemen".

We will publish a Briefing.

Lebanese army to present disarmament plan on 2 Sep

Lebanon's environment minister Tamara al-Zein, has told the privately owned Al-Jadeed channel that the country's army will present a plan for the disarmament of armed groups, namely Hezbollah, on 2 September.

Other media outlets, including El Nashra, Nida al-Watan, Al-Markazia, L'Orient-Le Jour, widely picked up on her statements.

Zein, who is a member of Amal - a key Hezbollah ally - was one of several ministers to walk out from a cabinet session last week that approved a US proposal for the disarmament of Hezbollah and to consolidate an ongoing ceasefire with Israel.

The details of the plan are "worrying and every clause contains a trap," she further told Al-Jadeed.

Tunisia union threatens general strike in standoff with president

Tunisia's trade union has threatened to call a general strike after government supporters attacked its headquarters, escalating a standoff with President Kais Saied.

In a statement posted online on 12 August, the General Labour Union (UGTT) said that it would hold a mass rally next week to protest against the "barbaric attack".

On 7 August, protesters rallied outside the UGTT headquarters in Tunis, chanting "mafia" and "corruption". The union said some tried to storm the building in a "planned attack".

In a later video address, the president backed the protesters, saying they had no intention of violence.

Since dissolving parliament in 2021, the president has ruled by decree.

The UGTT has become one of the few organised groups able to challenge him.

We will publish a Briefing.

Q: Following last month's controversial Pakistan elections, Shahbaz Sharif, the younger brother of three-time premier Nawaz Sharif, was sworn in as the country's new prime minister on 4 March.  Speaking to Shamshad TV's Tawda Bahsona (Heated Discussions) talk show on 7 March, Kabul-based commentator Amanullah Hotaki advised the Taliban's de facto government to "always play tricks with Pakistan", saying that Islamabad "does not deserve sympathy and brotherhood".

"Pakistan does not want a centralised government in Afghanistan – it wants a weak government and war here. This has been Pakistan's policy since its very inception and formation," he added.

Hotaki advised the Pakistani new government "not to bully" Afghanistan, warning that "whoever has bullied has been caught in its traps".

"Pakistan is now paying a price for what it was seeking in Afghanistan," he added in reply to a question about which mistakes Pakistan is paying a price for, given the current crisis in the country.

"Over the past 40 years, I have [Afghanistan has] continuously been bitten by Pakistan. Why – because it is the hireling of others," he further noted, accusing Britain of being behind the victory of Sharif's family, who were believed to be the Pakistani army's favoured choice to head the new government.

He also said that Shahbaz Sharif's coalition government will "not yield any outcome", adding that tensions with its opposition will continue.

Torialay Zazai, a Germany-based Afghan analyst, accused the Sharif family, including Shahbaz's elder brother Nawaz Sharif, of "destroying" the Afghan army in the 1990s.

"Shahbaz's family is the puppet of British and American intelligence... Pakistan is not independent. Its ISI [intelligence agency] as well as army are controlled by the British and the Americans," he added.

In reply to a question about what policy the new government should adopt towards Kabul, Zazai said: "Whatever may be the policy of Pakistan, it will be against Afghanistan." "Pakistan is an enemy and will remain an enemy."

However, referring to allegations levelled by the supporters of the jailed former prime minister, Imran Khan, that the election process was rigged, he said: "I do not think their [Sharif's] government will last even a year."

Asked how good Sharif's coalition administration would prove for Pakistan, he said: "It will not have any result as they lack authority."

Zazai also accused Islamabad of backing anti-Taliban Afghan opposition politicians, calling on the ruling Taliban to strengthen domestic unity to "rescue Afghanistan".

Pro-Taliban commentator Mawlana Abdul Jabbar Stanekzai also said that "the new [Pakistani] government, as their predecessors, will remain at odds with Afghanistan".

Asked whether the Shahbaz Sharif administration would not have any influence on the country's Afghanistan policy, Stanekzai said: "They never had any influence regarding Afghanistan. As I said, it now depends on the army - whether it wants good or bad relations with Afghanistan."

Commenting on protests against election rigging in Pakistan, he said: "The Pakistani nation wants their country to be run by someone who is not a thief."

He added that the neighbouring country faces "far more problems" than Afghanistan.

Accusing Pakistan of "fuelling" civil wars in Afghanistan, the pro-Taliban commentator, however, thanked the neighbouring country for helping Afghans in the fights against the "Soviets and Americans".

Q: Ms. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., can keep control of the state election interference case that has been more than three years in the making, but only if Nathan J. Wade, a former boyfriend, withdraws from the case, which she hired him to manage.

For much of this year, headlines and hearings delving into the romantic relationship between the two prosecutors have overshadowed the case itself, in which the defendants are charged with conspiring to thwart the will of Georgia voters after Mr. Trump lost the 2020 presidential election.

Defense lawyers brought to light the relationship between the prosecutors, saying it had created an untenable conflict of interest. But Judge Scott McAfee of Fulton Superior Court rejected that argument on Friday, while sharply criticizing Ms. Willis for a “tremendous lapse in judgment.”

Here are takeaways from the ruling:

The judge found an appearance problem, but not an actual conflict.

Judge McAfee said there was not enough proof to find that Ms. Willis’s “personal relationship and recurring travels with her lead prosecutor” created “an actual conflict of interest.”

He added that “Georgia law does not permit the finding of an actual conflict for simply making bad choices — even repeatedly — and it is the trial court’s duty to confine itself to the relevant issues and applicable law properly brought before it.”

But the judge did find that “the appearance of impropriety remains” and needs to be remedied. He concluded that “the prosecution of this case cannot proceed until the state selects one of two options.” Either Ms. Willis can step aside, along with her entire office, or Mr. Wade can leave, allowing the case to proceed without further distraction.

He emphasized that the appearance problem had to be fixed.

“When this danger goes uncorrected, it undermines the legitimacy and moral force of our already weakest branch of government,” he wrote.

The ruling repeatedly criticized Fani Willis.

The judge once worked for Ms. Willis in the district attorney’s office, and by all accounts had a positive experience with her as a boss. But in the ruling, he was harshly critical of her conduct, and not just because of the optics of carrying on a relationship with a subordinate on such a high-profile case.

He also criticized public comments she has made about the case and referred to “the unprofessional manner of the district attorney’s testimony” when she testified at a combative hearing last month.

Noting that neither side offered definitive proof of when the romance began, Judge McAfee wrote that “an odor of mendacity remains” about the matter, as do “reasonable questions” about whether Ms. Willis and Mr. Wade “testified untruthfully about the timing of their relationship.” Both told the judge that it started only after Ms. Willis hired Mr. Wade in November 2021.

No financial motive was found.

The judge rejected a key contention of the defense: that Ms. Willis had benefited financially from the case, since her romantic partner was being paid to run it and had paid, at least in part, for vacations they took together.

Judge McAfee noted that Ms. Willis brought charges against far fewer people than a special grand jury had recommended for indictment, undercutting the suggestion that she was trying to inflate legal billings around the case.

“The district attorney has not in any way acted in conformance with the theory that she arranged a financial scheme to enrich herself,” the judge wrote.

The judge opened the door to a potential gag order.

The judge appeared to invite the defense to seek a gag order to stop Ms. Willis from publicly discussing the case. He said that Ms. Willis, who is Black, had publicly “cast racial aspersions” on the defense’s decision to bring her relationship with Mr. Wade to light.

He was referring to a January speech that Ms. Willis made at a local church, when she suggested that the scrutiny of her decision to hire Mr. Wade was racist. The motion alleging a conflict of interest was filed on Jan. 8 by Ashleigh Merchant, a lawyer for Michael Roman, a defendant who is a former Trump campaign operative.

The judge said the church speech was “too far removed from jury selection to establish a permanent taint of the jury pool,” but expressed concern nonetheless.

He also referred to what he called Ms. Willis’s “unorthodox decision to make on-the-record comments” to the authors of a recent book, “Find Me the Votes,” by the journalists Michael Isikoff and Daniel Klaidman, noting that she spoke to the authors “during the pendency of this case.”

Judge McAfee wrote that “the time may well have arrived for an order preventing the state from mentioning the case in any public forum to prevent prejudicial pretrial publicity.”

An appeal seems likely, and a trial distant.

Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer in Georgia, Steven H. Sadow, said, “We believe that the court did not afford appropriate significance to the prosecutorial misconduct of Willis and Wade,” adding that “we will use all legal options available as we continue to fight to end this case, which should never have been brought in the first place.”

The defense will almost certainly seek to appeal, but the judge has to grant approval for them to do so ahead of a trial.

When the case might go to trial remains unclear. Last year, Ms. Willis asked for a trial to start this August, but the judge has yet to set a date. Even with the ruling against disqualification, most legal observers believe a trial is unlikely to start this year.
A:

*   Fulton County

Q: IRNA reported that Lt Mohammad Zakhireh, a member of the ranger unit of the Khash police, was shot on the evening of 25 March, in clashes with members of a "hostile and terrorist group" on the Khash-Iranshahr road.

A later IRNA report on the same day said that the "terrorists" also shot at a civilian vehicle, killing an infant and injuring two other passengers.

The foreign-based Baluch human rights collective Haalvsh had said in a 25 March post on X (formerly Twitter) that the civilian vehicle came under fire from the police forces who "randomly" opened fire after being attacked by a group of militants.

Situated on the borders with Afghanistan and Pakistan, the marginalised and impoverished province of Sistan-Baluchestan is home to some Sunni militants, and is also an entry point for smuggled goods, drugs and arms.

The Sunni militant group Jaish al-Adl, which is active in the province and has launched repeated attacks on security forces in the region, has not claimed responsibility for the attack.

Q: Addressing a conference on compulsory military service in Tehran on 10 March, Salami, the commander in chief of the elite force IRGC, said he had received the medal in a meeting with the leader on the same day. 

The commander described the award as a clear indication of the leader’s satisfaction with the "heroic endeavours" made by the Guards Corps.

The Order of the Fath has been awarded to war heroes, military commanders and politicians, especially those linked to the eight-year Iran-Iraq war in the 1980s, directly by the supreme leader.

Mohsen Rezai, the former IRGC commander in chief, was one of the first recipients, for leading major military operations during the war with Iraq. Several other top brass including senior military adviser to the leader Yahya Rahim Safavi, political aide to the leader Ali Shamkhani and the Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces, Mohammad Hossein Baqeri, have also received the medal.

In 2016, Ayatollah Khamenei awarded Fath Medal to navy commanders for detaining 10 US navy sailors. Ten US Navy sailors were held briefly by the IRGC on 12-13 January after their boats strayed into Iranian territorial waters in the Gulf.

Q: Parliament passes resolution to declare former PM Bhutto a martyr

The National Assembly (lower house of parliament) has passed, with majority votes, a resolution declaring former prime minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto a national martyr and his death sentence illegal. The resolution was tabled by the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) member, Shazia Marri. The resolution says that the reference against Bhutto's sentence was filed in the Supreme Court by President Zardari and pursued by PPP chairperson, Bilawal Bhutto Zardari. [The Supreme Court had recently in its opinion on the case had said that Bhutto was not given a fair trial.] The Senate and the provincial assemblies (parliaments) of Sindh, Punjab and Balochistan recently passed similar resolutions. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

Former PM Khan warns of Pakistan becoming like Sri Lanka

Founder of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party and former prime minister, Imran Khan, talking to journalists at the Adiala Jail in Rawalpinidi (in Punjab province) said that the hopes of the nation were shattered by rigging at the (8 February) elections. He said that all his reservations are proving correct and now Pakistan is going to be "like Sri Lanka". Khan said that inflation will increase further and the people will be on the streets. He said that the country is being run on lies. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Awami Awaz is a progressive, secular and liberal, left-leaning Sindhi-language newspaper published from Karachi, Sindh. The daily possesses a good reputation among relatively educated and aware people. It is regarded as the "Dawn" of Sindhi-language newspapers.]

Ibrat

Pakistan fulfils conditions for IMF tranche

Pakistan has fulfilled all conditions of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to receive the last tranche of its standby programme. The finance ministry has said that the negotiations with the IMF delegation will continue from 14 to 18 March. Meanwhile, the federal Minister of Finance, Muhammad Aurangzeb, has said that Pakistan wants a bigger and long-term new programme from the IMF. He also said that the Pakistani economy will improve with this new programme. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Sindh cabinet briefed about law and order situation

Sindh's Minister of Interior, Zia Lanjar, briefed the Sindh cabinet about law and order in the province. Lanjar told the meeting that no one involved in street crime in Karachi (capital city of Sindh) will be spared. He also told the meeting that his priority is to crush the dacoits in the riverine areas of upper Sindh. He said that honest and upright police officers will be deployed to disturbed areas. Lanjar said that paramilitary forces will also be used against the dacoits in the riverine areas. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

[Daily Ibrat is a moderate Sindhi-language newspaper owned by the politically influential Qazi family of Sindh, traditionally affiliated with Pakistan Peoples Party. The daily is published from Hyderabad, Sindh. Readers over 40 years of age prefer reading Daily Ibrat.]

Kawish

Sindh rejects appointment of river authority chief

The Sindh government has criticised the appointment of the new chairperson of the Indus River System Authority (IRSA) and demanded of the federal government to withdraw this appointment. Sindh's Minister of Irrigation, Jam Khan Shoro, has strongly protested and made this demand. A former chairman of the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA), Zafar Mahmood, has been appointed chairperson of IRSA) through an ordinance issued during the previous caretaker government. Mahmood has been a strong advocate of the disputed Kalabagh dam. Three provinces - Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Balochistan - had opposed the construction of the Kalabagh dam in the past. Moreover, the appointment of the IRSA chairperson is carried out from among IRSA members from every province and the federal government. Mahmood is not from among these members, which is a violation of the IRSA Act. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 250]

Information minister says PTI opposing GSP Plus status

Federal Minister for Information, Attaullah Tarar, when addressing a press conference in national capital Islamabad on 13 March, said that the PTI has written a letter to the European Union (EU) asking to withdraw the GSP Plus status (which allows for trade concessions) from Pakistan. Tarar said that with the GSP Plus status, the Pakistani currency will be stablised. He said that the PTI does not want the economy to improve. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 200]

[Daily Kawish is the most widely read Sindhi-language newspaper published from Hyderabad, Sindh. The paper is popular among young people and has a liberal and progressive editorial policy. It is also the largest circulated daily.]

Hot Issues (Prime-Time Talk Show on Sindh TV News at 14:00 GMT)

Discussion on economic situation, IRSA chairperson

Anchor Sabeen Memon said that they would discuss the country's economic situation. She noted that an IMF delegation is to come to Pakistan for negotiations for the last installment of a standby programme. What will be the impact of the IMF conditions on the common people of Pakistan, Memon asked. In the second part of the programme, she said they would discuss the appointment of the new IRSA chairperson, who is an advocate of the disputed Kalabagh dam. Panellists included economist Jabbar Memon, and senior journalists Qurban Baloch and Khaleeq Kiani.

Memon said, "The finance minister has been appointed and it seems that he is well aware of the economic situation. There is no doubt that he is a banker and a very successful one. It has yet to be seen whether he can be an economist or not. This portfolio will be good for his CV. If he overcomes the crises of economy and climate change, then he will be successful. He has said that Pakistan will seek a long-term and extended programme. Everyone knows that we need to expand our tax base so that we can increase our revenue collection. We have to bring about reforms to our tax system and real estate, retail and agriculture sectors have to pay taxes. We need to build the trust of the people in the government. The government high officials have to give up their perks and privileges."

Kiani said, "Zafar Mahmood is the former chairman of WAPDA and this appointment seems to be a violation of the IRSA Act, which was prepared by all the four provinces. This appointment will annoy the provinces. The IRSA chairman has to be a member of IRSA from the province or the federation. I think all four provinces will have reservations on this appointment. This appointment has to be reversed. President Zardari will have to play his leadership role. Now, IRSA will be under the Ministry of Water Resources. This is a dangerous appointment, which may disturb the federation."

Baloch said, "This is an issue of giving IRSA total control of the federal government. No notification of this appointment has been issued by the establishment division. This is a violation of the IRSA Act, which says that the chairman can only be from among the members of IRSA. The Sindh Minister of Irrigation, Jam Khan Shoro, has also condemned this appointment. It seems that the autonomy of IRSA is no more and it has come under the federal government. I think that the provinces should approach the Council of Common Interests (CCI). This amendment to the IRSA Act, which allows a chairman from outside IRSA members, was done during the caretaker government."

[Sindh TV News is the second largest Sindhi-language TV channel and supports nationalist views.]

Insight with Najia Mir (Prime-Time Talk Show on KTN News at 15:00 GMT)

Discussion on economy

Anchor Najia Mir said that after the federal government, provincial cabinets have also been formed. Some new faces have been introduced, she said. Will this be able to end the political and economic crises, Mir asked. Panellists included former diplomat GR Baloch, economist Asad Ali Shah and analyst Professor Abdul Majeed Chandio. 

Shah said, "Aurangzeb is the new finance minister and is a clear-headed banker. Whatever we earn through taxes goes into debt retirement and we take more loans to run the country. Our economy is still in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). The standby agreement is ending in March and we will get the last [IMF] tranche. We need continuous support from the IMF. Unfortunately, no political party had provided an economic programme in its election manifesto. We have to see how the new finance minister tackles the economic challenges. Our politics is very polarised. I do not see any disruption to economic activity because of political disputes. The next two to three years will be very difficult for our economy. We need to get an extended programme from the IMF worth $7-8bn. With this, we have to bring reforms to our economy."

Baloch said, "Our economic structure has holes in it and there are dozens of government enterprises in loss. This is bleeding our economy. I think that the only solution is the privatising of these loss-making enterprises. The power [electricity] theft is also alarming. There should be an economic advisory board that should look into the economic quagmire. The members should be independent economists and not government servants. We have to stop the bleeding of our economy. Tax evasion is also a huge problem. Only technical experts can take tough decisions. Our economy has to stand on its own feet and for this we have to be on a treatment table for a long time. The foreign policy of every country reflects its internal strength, both political and economic. The political parties should have a grand dialogue on stabilising our economy and politics."

Chandio said, "The finance minister said that he will reduce the interest rate. The IMF wants to increase the tax base. We also need to increase our exports. We can export cotton and other agricultural products. The economy will not improve if we ourselves do not think of out-of-the-box solutions. The PPP wants a public-private partnership whereas I think that the only solution is complete privatisation. The PTI is trying to de-stabilise our economy by writing to the IMF and European Union (EU) not to help Pakistan. It is so unfortunate that no political party has an economic team. The grand political dialogue should also include regional political parties. We need to address our governance as well."

[KTN News is the most widely watched Sindhi-language news TV Channel owned by Kawish media group, which also owns Daily Kawish. The channel has a liberal position and is normally critical of Pakistan Peoples Party.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Sindhi 14 Mar 24

Q: The exercise conducted by the NATO Joint Force Training Centre in Poland is designed to train and certify headquarters of units in subordination of the Headquarters Multinational Corps Northeast (HQ MNC NE) to plan and execute wide-scale defensive operations while organizing interoperability and coordinating actions with friendly forces.

"Exercise LOLE 24 is a vital event in our combat training cycle that certifies our readiness to deliver on our designated tasks. I can say ahead of the exercise that we are ready but we want to be even more ready. We want to demonstrate with this exercise to everyone that we are united with NATO Allies in defending our families and people against any threat," said HQ MNC NE Commander Lt Col Jurgen-Joachim von Sandrart on the day of the exercise opening.

Exercise LOLE 24 takes place in three stages. During the first phase, over 800 exercise participants were improving military decision-making, as well as command and control and interoperability procedures at unit integration training.

Over the second stage, unit command posts carried out defensive and indirect impact operation planning, interact with the civilian environment and adjacent units, coordinate actions with the superior headquarters, and create tactical operational plans using a tactical command and control information system.

In the third phase a simulation system is used to put to test operational concepts created by the unit command posts. The simulation system follows the training concept developed by the Control Party to allow creation of a tactical situation for generating events and incidents and adapting to the dynamic and ever-changing situation while executing command and control procedures, taking timely tactical decisions in coordination of actions between units, ensuring uninterrupted execution of operation in coordination with the superior staff and functionality of command posts.

Source: ELTA, Vilnius, in English 0549 gmt 14 Mar 24

*   Vilnius

Q: Raza spoke with Asiya Ishaq, a member of Muttahida Qaumi Movement (MQM), and asked her whether she is optimistic about the PTI remaining in the parliament this time and playing the role of the opposition despite reservations. Ishaq replied it is good to see that the PTI has passed through an "evolutionary process". Recalling that earlier the PTI had resigned from the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament) and had suffered setbacks due to wrong decisions, she expressed hope about the party learning from its past mistakes. She commented the party again "committed a blunder" when it decided to join the Sunni Ittehad Council (SIC) and could not get a share in the reserved seats for women due to it.

Raza spoke with Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Ramesh Singh Arora and asked him how far has Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz's style of politics changed after becoming the chief minister as she was an "aggressive politician" earlier. Arora replied there is a "background" for Nawaz's aggressive politics as she and her entire family had to face persecution for several years "from [former president] General Pervez Musharraf's government to [former prime minister] Imran Khan's civilian martial law". He said through her aggressive politics, Nawaz emerged as the top crowd-puller politician of the country. He added Nawaz now stands for "performance, delivery, reconciliation and corruption-free Punjab". He noted in her first speech as the chief minister, Nawaz said she would serve the people of Punjab. He mentioned after being elected as the chief minister, she went to the opposition leader to say that she is not only the chief minister of her government, but also the opposition.

Raza asked senior journalist Saleh Zaafir how President Asif Ali Zardari would leverage his political weight during the next five years. Zaafir said as the president, Zardari has no administrative powers but being a senior politician from the Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP), which has its government in Sindh and a coalition government in Balochistan, is his "strength".

Raza asked Ishaq about her party's demand that local governments should be empowered. Ishaq said for the MQM, empowerment of local governments is very important, and it had a "one-point agenda" during talks for an alliance with the PML-N before elections that three amendments should be brought into the Constitution for this purpose. She added these amendments would be beneficial for the entire Pakistan. She mentioned the MQM has demanded that the office of the mayor should be mentioned in the Constitution like offices of chief ministers and the prime minister, the federal government should transfer funds directly to districts, and elections for the National Assembly and provincial assemblies should not be held before local government elections.

Raza asked Arora whether his party supports empowerment of local governments. Arora replied the PML-N has been a victim regarding local governments as the previous PTI government had sent all the elected local government members in Punjab home immediately after coming into power. He supported the MQM's demands and said all political parties should work jointly for such issues. Zaafir claimed political governments in Pakistan have always felt threatened by local governments. He was of the view that it would be better if funds to districts are distributed by the provinces.

Q: Anchor Shahzeb Khanzada said running a coalition government and putting the economy back on track is a major challenge for the Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N). He noted questions have been raised about the powers of the finance minister as well as Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif's decisions and his "quick U-turn" on those decisions. He said reportedly differences exist within the PML-N regarding appointment of Muhammad Aurangzeb as the finance minister. He added when Aurangzeb was appointed as the finance minister, instead of giving him the chairmanship of committees linked to important economic matters, the prime minister decided to keep them with himself or other PML-N senior members. He mentioned after criticism of this decision, chairmanship of one committee was given to the finance minister.

Khanzada spoke with journalist Shehbaz Rana and asked him why there are issues in appointing the heads of committees. Rana said in the decision to appoint Aurangzeb as the finance minister, the prime minister had a major role to play, even more than the military establishment. He noted under former finance minister Ishaq Dar, targets of an International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme were not achieved and that is why it was continuously being said that Dar would not be made the finance minister again. However, he added, due to pressure from a camp within the PML-N, Dar was given some role in economic management by giving him positions in some of the committees.

Rana was of the view that Pakistan needs to provide "united support" to the finance minister so that "hard negotiations" with the IMF for a new programme can be held.

Alleged division within PTI

Khanzada said elections for 48 seats of the Senate (upper house of the parliament) would be held on 2 April and the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has claimed that it would win two seats from Punjab. He added the PTI has alleged that its members in Punjab are being pressurised into changing their party loyalty.

Khanzada asked PML-N politician Rana Sanaullah whether his party is trying to influence PTI members in the Punjab Assembly to form a "forward bloc". Sanaullah said the PTI has got "strange kind of people elected to the assemblies" who are destroying the party. Q: An IMF statement said it "has reached a staff-level agreement with the Pakistani authorities" and noted that approval by the IMF's executive board “is considered a formality.”

The announcement came after talks between the IMF and the new government of Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif concluded in Islamabad. Pakistan’s Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb and the IMF's mission chief to Pakistan, Nathan Porter, led their teams during the talks, which began on Thursday last week.

Pakistan signed the latest short-term agreement last year to overcome one of the worst economic crises in its history that had raised fears the South Asian Islamic nation could default on the payment of foreign debts. The $3 billion bailout was signed by Sharif, who replaced former Premier Imran Khan after a no-confidence vote in parliament.

Sharif was again elected the country’s premier this month following Feb. 8 parliamentary elections.

The latest development came weeks after Khan wrote a letter to the IMF urging it to link any talks with Islamabad to an audit of the recent elections, which his Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party says were rigged. Authorities have dismissed the charge as baseless.

Pakistani authorities have criticized Khan for writing the letter, saying it was a bid to harm the country's already ailing economy. Pakistan narrowly averted a default on foreign payments last summer.

In its statement on Wednesday, the IMF said “Pakistan’s economic and financial position has improved" in recent months. However, it noted the “growth is expected to be modest this year and inflation remains well above target, and ongoing policy and reform efforts are required to address Pakistan’s deep-seated economic vulnerabilities amidst the ongoing challenges posed by elevated external and domestic financing needs and an unsettled external environment."

The IMF said Sharif's government is committed to continue the policy efforts that started under the current bailout “to entrench economic and financial stability for the remainder of this year."

It said Pakistani authorities are determined to take steps to further improve the country's economy by broadening the tax base, and through the timely implementation of power and gas tariff adjustments, while protecting the vulnerable through existing progressive tariff structures.

The IMF said Pakistan has also expressed interest in receiving a new bailout. Pakistan wants to seek a new bailout of up to $8 billion when the current one expires this month, it said.

In that incident, an armed group had kidnapped a total of 11 people. Police said the other six, including five minors, were rescued and handed over to their families. Two suspects were arrested on Saturday morning, according to police.

The killings in Manabi “remind us that the battle continues,” said Ecuador’s President Daniel Noboa on the social media network X, formerly Twitter, on Saturday.

“Narcoterrorism and its allies are looking for spaces to scare us, but they will not succeed,” Noboa said. His post contained a video of a man handcuffed and bent over, being led away forcefully by an armed police officer.

Ecuador was once considered a bastion of peace in Latin America, but in recent years has seen a surge in violent attacks.

Noboa declared a state of emergency in January, which provides for permanent operations by a security force made up of police and military. In addition, a five-hour curfew is in force in high-incidence areas such as Guayaquil.

On March 24, the 27-year-old mayor of a small town — also in the province of Manabi — was killed along with her collaborator. Brigitte Garcia and Jairo Loor were found inside a vehicle with gunshot wounds.

On Thursday, a riot in a Guayaquil prison under military and police control left three inmates dead and four injured.

Ecuador surpassed a rate of 40 violent deaths per 100,000 inhabitants at the end of 2023, one of the highest in the region, according to police.

Q: The answer, after a hearing in federal court in Brooklyn on Thursday, seemed to be that he was both.

Mr. Zelinger, 45, pleaded guilty to one count of racketeering, admitting that he had helped run an illegal gambling club and had threatened debtors to make them pay.

When he was arrested in Switzerland in 2022, prosecutors said that he had led a ruthless crew linked to an Eastern European mafia group known as Thieves in Law that wreaked havoc in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Brighton Beach, Sheepshead Bay and Coney Island.

The slew of charges against him included directing a May 2016 arson in a residential building on Voorhies Avenue where a high-stakes poker game was being held. The blaze nearly killed two teenagers and left a firefighter with career-ending injuries, prosecutors said.

The game competed with his own illegal gambling spot on Coney Island Avenue, where players were plied with free alcohol, cocaine and massages, according to court documents. Months later, as investigators closed in, Mr. Zelinger left the country permanently.

A grand jury indictment unsealed that October included charges against Mr. Zelinger and eight others; two other defendants were later added to the case. All were convicted or pleaded guilty to racketeering and related charges.

But Mr. Zelinger’s lawyer, Susan Kellman, painted a dramatically different story of his life, arguing that he was a dedicated father whose life had been upended by illness and war.

In a motion filed last year, she wrote that after moving back to his native Ukraine in 2016, he had married a woman who was diagnosed with a brain tumor after giving birth to the last of their three children.

When war broke out, it became impossible to find treatment, and she died from her illness, Ms. Kellman wrote. Mr. Zelinger was then displaced by fighting along with his children, then ages 6, 4 and 2. The family lived in their car and traveled by night to avoid the fighting, finally escaping to Slovenia before making their way to Switzerland, she wrote.

“If he’s the boss or he has links to the Eastern European mafia, whatever that is, it would have seemed to me he would have had a much easier time when he was overseas fighting for his life and his family’s life,” Ms. Kellman said at a hearing last year.

“But there was nobody there to help him.”

Once they were settled in Switzerland, Mr. Zelinger received a phone call telling him to report to a local police station to enroll the children in school, according to his account. But it was a trap. When he arrived, he was arrested, and the children were put in an orphanage. But “miraculously,” in Ms. Kellman’s words, they were rescued by the chief rabbi of Zurich, who arranged for them to be sent to live with their grandmother in Brooklyn.

Mr. Zelinger’s family was not present at the hearing on Thursday, which lasted 90 minutes as Magistrate Judge Vera M. Scanlon parsed the complicated plea agreement. Mr. Zelinger pleaded guilty to one count of racketeering but admitted to a role in other crimes, allowing those to be factored into the judge’s decision on sentencing. He wore prison khakis and a dark, close-cropped beard at the hearing and was aided by a Russian interpreter.

The maximum penalty on the charges under federal sentencing guidelines would be 20 years. But the prosecutor in the case, Victor Zapana of the U.S. attorney’s office in Brooklyn, said on Thursday that he and the defense had agreed to recommend a sentence of five to six years. That hearing is scheduled for July 18 before Judge Brian M. Cogan.

Mr. Zelinger, who moved to Brooklyn in 2001 and later became a citizen, is likely to lose his U.S. citizenship and be deported once his sentence is completed.

Q: A few important points this week:

Firstly, we continue to reboot our state institutions. Several changes have been made this week, and there are still more decisions in preparation. Today, new decrees regarding advisors were issued. I am grateful to everyone for their work. We are making the Office more functional.

Secondly, last night, as almost always during this war, our mobile fire groups, other air defense units, and the Air Force had things to do – successful target interceptions. During this day, the warriors of the mobile fire groups in Dnipropetrovsk, Poltava, Kherson, and our Odesa region distinguished themselves. Thank you!

Thirdly, our energy workers, repair teams, and construction workers have worked tirelessly throughout the week. These are the people working on recovery efforts after Russian strikes, as well as protecting energy facilities in various regions. They are many, and they literally save our country's normal life. These are thermal power plant employees, engineers, grid masters, and electricians. These are the people who restore generation and power. I would like to thank everyone who works so hard to ensure that Ukraine can live normally, with power and the ability to work, in all cities and villages.

Russian terrorists are currently carrying out such heinous attacks in an attempt to drain Ukraine's power. We sent necessary signals and concrete requests to all of our partners who have the necessary air defense systems and missiles. America, Europe, and other partners all know exactly what we need, and they all understand how critical it is to assist Ukraine in defending itself against these strikes right now. I thank all leaders who are demonstrating leadership right now, especially those who truly uphold our agreements and keep their word.

I also want to personally thank those people here in Ukraine, those workers in the energy sector, who have distinguished themselves with their work in these days and weeks. Q: “They’re movable pieces of art,” says Budapest-born, London-based decorator Gergei Erdei of his new collection of hand-painted folding pinewood screens. Part of his Objects of Desires series, the six designs include trompe l’oeil columns, wing-footed mythological figures and interlinked geometric shapes. Erdei found inspiration for his pieces, which are over seven feet tall, in a recent retrospective of the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli’s works at Paris’s Musée des Arts Décoratifs and in the lacquered screens of multimedia Art Deco creator Jean Dunand; Pompeii’s crumbling frescoes and ancient mosaics informed the mythological design’s soft, ocher hues, which were achieved through multiple coats of acrylic paint. “I keep coming back to Pompeii in my work,” Erdei says. “I find the layers faded by time so beautiful, like veils of history.”

Thought to have originated during China’s Han dynasty, screens became popular decorative pieces in Europe in the 17th century, when they were used for privacy and to divide rooms and block drafts. A couple of centuries later, Coco Chanel lined her Paris apartment with black-and-gold lacquer Coromandel screens. Erdei, who once worked as a women’s wear designer at Gucci in Rome, also wants his screens to stand out. “I see them used as a theatrical background behind a bed or a sofa, or either side of a fireplace,” he says. A bespoke screen will also make an appearance, alongside his signature acrylic murals, in his next project, the interior design of a private riad turned hotel called Le M, opening in Marrakech’s medina this summer. Objects of Desire screens from $6,700, gergeierdei.com.

The Chef Calum Franklin Brings His Savory Pies to Paris

English fare has rarely gotten its due in France, but the British chef Calum Franklin, nicknamed the “Pie King” from his years making artistically latticed savory pies at London’s Holborn Dining Room, is intent on changing that this month with the opening of Public House, his first project in Paris. Occupying what was previously an American bar-nightclub in the Opera district, the restaurant combines the brasserie format — broad and bustling dining rooms with deep booths — and the relaxed spirit of a British pub. Franklin wanted the menu to be an approachable mix featuring a selection of his signature pies (among them beef and bone marrow; Montgomery Cheddar, dauphinoise potato and caramelized onion; chicken and wild mushroom; and lobster for two) alongside pub classics like Scotch eggs, sausage rolls and sticky toffee pudding. “If we’re introducing Parisians to old-school British pies that are inspired by 600-year-old recipes and history, we have to do it gradually,” says Franklin. For the interiors, the architect and designer Laura Gonzalez wove in hand-finished oak furnishings, tartan fabrics that vary on each of the three floors and a patchwork of bright tiles. On the lower level, there’s a bar with its own entrance, while on the top floor, diners can sit in a spacious winter garden and play a round of darts or chess in the game room. It all makes for something fresh for Paris and an adventure for Franklin. “When I was young, a lot of my chef friends came to work in Paris but I was too shy; I didn’t speak French and it was all too easy to stay in London,” he says. “I’ve always regretted it because I saw how Paris changed them. Now, it’s my turn.” Public House opens March 26, publichouseparis.fr.

A Cookbook — and Seder Plates — to Celebrate Passover

Passover, the Jewish holiday that marks the Exodus from Egypt, is built around a meal — the Seder — and the story of the flight to the Promised Land that’s told with it. On the same night, everywhere in the world where there are Jews, the ritual meal takes place, though the food and flavors differ according to the local culture. “The Jewish Holiday Table,” a new collection of recipes curated by the Jewish Food Society, covers all the Jewish holidays and Shabbat, the Friday night Sabbath dinner. The recipes — and family histories — come from cooks with roots in Iran, India, Iraq and Israel, Morocco, Hungary, Denmark and the former Soviet Union. Many of the contributors’ families settled in New York, among them the Ethiopian-born chef Beejhy Barhany, who owns Harlem’s Tsion Café and contributed Shabbat dishes from her family village in Tigray. These include dabo, an Ethiopian honey bread, and messer wot, a red lentil stew. Fany Gerson, whose family migrated from Ukraine to Mexico City, where she was born, and who now makes doughnuts at her bakery Fan Fan in Brooklyn, spices up her Passover Seder, adding chiles and cilantro to the matzo ball soup and spicy tomato sauce to the gefilte fish. Her brisket is cooked in tamales. Serve the food you end up making on a Seder plate from Hayom, a Brooklyn-based company that collaborates with artists on Judaica. The conceptual artist Hank Willis Thomas has created a plate featuring a photograph of “Reach” (2023), his work with the artist Coby Kennedy that’s on display at Chicago’s O’Hare Airport, while the ceramist Frankie Aziz has designed one with her signature cobalt drawings.

A Cafe and Art Space in a Former Berlin Amusement Park

For more than two decades, the amusement park Spreepark, located along Berlin’s River Spree, was left abandoned. Its retro rides were engulfed by grass and vines, and its owner was eventually jailed for drug smuggling. In 2014, Spreepark was bought by the city of Berlin and handed over to the state-owned park management company Grün Berlin with the remit that they enliven it with culture and food. Now, the first project within the revitalized complex is open and ready for visitors: The Eierhäuschen, a recently renovated 19th-century building just outside the amusement park, contains Ei 12437, a cafe run by the restaurateur Jessica-Joyce Sidon and the chef Alexandra Strödel that began service in February, as well as the multidisciplinary Spreepark Art Space, which opens on Friday. (Its inaugural exhibition is a group show of artists — Marcus Maeder, Sabine Scho, Sissel Tolaas and Annett Zinsmeister — who were asked to research the park and present their findings.) For lunch, the beer garden serves elevated German pub dishes such as a hearty potato salad, pretzels and pickled herring and onion sandwiches. In the evenings it gets a bit more formal, with a small but sophisticated menu served in a dining room featuring parquet floors and carmine walls. The latest seasonal dishes include an Onsen tamago-style egg served with potato foam, and cabbage stuffed with Jerusalem artichoke and hazelnuts. ei-12437.berlin.

Decadent Home Textiles From the Fashion Designer Giles Deacon

Sanderson, the British company that’s been producing wallpaper since the Victorian era, draws upon a deep well of design legacy with each new collection they release — and their latest collaboration, with the London-based fashion designer Giles Deacon, is no different. Deacon looked to Sanderson’s archive of British countryside florals and added his own flourishes to fabrics and wall coverings in a soothing palette of pastels and pale earth tones. Faraday velvet takes the humble concept of chicken wire and transforms it into a twisting pattern that would feel at home within the walls of an elegant estate. Andromeda’s Cup turns its titular subject into a wallpaper motif framed by acanthus leaves and sweeping drapery. Perhaps fittingly for a couturier, many of Deacon’s prints have a handcrafted look — the Aperignon Parade wallpaper features saw-toothed stripes that appear to have been freshly made with pinking shears, while artfully rumpled bows and Deacon’s own calligraphy add an unexpected element of whimsy to the botanical Cupid’s Beau print. The designer wanted the collection to be “surprising yet classic,” he says, “always tethered to an unwavering sense of Britishness.” From $196 per wallpaper roll and $220 per fabric yard, sanderson.sandersondesigngroup.com.

A Healthy Dose of Color Renews a Hotel on the Finnish Coast

In the early 1930s, the Finnish architects Alvar and Aino Aalto completed Paimio Sanatorium, a modernist masterpiece dedicated to the treatment of tuberculosis. At Paimio, patients could recover in rooms with mint-green ceilings, take fresh air on curved balconies and walk banana-yellow stairs leading to bright communal areas. The idea of a building that might influence human well-being resonated with Aino Brandt, a founding partner and interior architect at the Helsinki-based design firm KOKO3. Tasked with renovating Original Sokos Hotel Royal in Vaasa, a maritime city said to be Finland’s sunniest, Brandt drew on the Aaltos’ “ingenious use of bold colors,” she says. The two-story lobby of the hotel’s 1980s tower — which reopened last month and now holds a lively multi-panel commissioned work by the Finnish artist Jenni Rope — is the nexus around which the hotel’s social spaces, including a cinema, a rooftop pool area with no less than three saunas, and a trio of restaurants, are organized. Above dining tables, lamps by Muller Van Severen for Valerie Objects reference the Aaltos’ preference for functional, indirect lighting. In the hotel’s 139 bedrooms (121 more rooms will be added once the second part of the hotel opens across the street in 2026), shades of yellow, deep orange and blue feature on walls, while textile patterns designed by KOKO3 and manufactured by the Finnish weaving mill Annala make carpets and cushions pop. From about $180 a night, sokoshotels.fi.

Two Artists Make a Home for Their Family, and Their Collection

Q: The incendiary law grants Indian citizenship to persecuted Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsees and Christians from a few nearby countries. Muslims are pointedly excluded.

With a characteristic thunderclap, the government of India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, made a short declaration on Monday night that it had finalized the details that would bring the law, known as the Citizenship Amendment Act, into force.

The government’s action, coming just before India announces the dates for an election expected in April and May, shows Mr. Modi delivering on a promise, and could change the electoral math in districts with Hindu refugees who stand to benefit from the law.

Politics aside, the law is not expected to significantly change the demography of India’s diverse population of 1.4 billion, at least not on its own. But it makes plain the power that Mr. Modi wields to redefine the Indian republic, steamrolling any resistance to his vision of a Hindu-first state.

The law spent more than four years in hibernation after protests by hundreds of thousands of Muslims and other Indians who were outraged by the idea that citizenship would be defined with reference to religious identity.

In February 2020, while President Donald J. Trump was on a state visit, riots broke out in the capital, New Delhi. Whole neighborhoods were devastated in the northeastern part of the city, where gas cylinders were turned into makeshift bombs and tossed into mosques. At least 50 people were killed, most of them Muslims.

A high-profile protest camp at a place called Shaheen Bagh, operated mainly by female protesters from different religious groups, carried on until late March before being dispersed. And then Covid-19 intervened, helping to suppress further protest.

The government justified the new rules as a humanitarian response to the plight of minorities in Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan, India’s three big Muslim-majority neighbors. Yogi Adityanath, a Hindu monk turned political ally of Mr. Modi, wrote on social media that rescuing communities “who are suffering from religious brutality” would bring “joy to humanity.”

It is hard for many to take this explanation at face value. For one thing, the inclusion of some countries and exclusion of others looks arbitrary. For another, Muslims persecuted because of their faith, for instance the Ahmadiyya and Shiites of Pakistan, do not make the cut for Indian citizenship. The Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Human Rights called the law “fundamentally discriminatory.”

To critics, the Citizenship Amendment Act looks like one part of a pincer movement against Muslims. It was brought to life at the same time as a national citizenship registry that would allow the government to expel undocumented residents, even if their families had lived in India for generations.

As Mr. Modi’s right-hand man, Amit Shah, said at the time, “Please understand the ‘chronology’: first the C.A.A.,” and then the registry. In other words, first non-Muslim refugees would be allowed citizenship. Then the refugees who remained would be expelled. More than 1,000 “declared foreigners” have been detained in the northeastern state of Assam.

On Monday, protests erupted there and in several other states after the government announced enforcement of the citizenship law. Shaheen Ahmed, a doctoral student in Kerala, said that he and other students came out to protest across his state.

“We were demanding the rollback of the law when police came and started beating us,” Mr. Ahmed said.

One group that rejoiced at the news is a large community of lower-caste Hindus in West Bengal, whose ancestors came to India from Bangladesh. Their support for Mr. Modi in the upcoming election could tip several parliamentary seats into the majority that he is expected to achieve anyway.

Other Hindu refugees, from Pakistan, had already been acquiring citizenship. More than 1,100 have been granted that status in Mr. Modi’s home state, Gujarat, since 2016. The point of the Citizenship Amendment Act will be to make these naturalizations possible on a national level, and more visible.

Q: But after making rapid gains in the subsequent days, Russian assaults have stalled around three contested nearby villages. Military experts cite several factors, including terrain that does not favor offensive operations, Russian troops exhausted by months of fighting and a Ukrainian army that has committed significant forces to defending the area.

Russia seems to be maintaining its initiative on the battlefield, and military analysts say its forces could still break through Ukrainian lines in the near future, especially since Kyiv’s defensive efforts are increasingly curtailed by the absence of further American military aid.

Yet for now, they say the fighting appears to have reverted to the kind of inconclusive back-and-forth battles that have characterized much of the war’s front line combat this past year.

“The capture of Avdiivka has not led to the collapse of Ukrainian lines, the possibility for the Russians to move onto open ground or even to make major gains,” said Thibault Fouillet, the deputy director of the Institute for Strategic and Defense Studies, a French research center. “There’s no decisive action or breakthrough.”

It’s a contrast to the situation that emerged from the fall of Avdiivka in mid-February. At that time, as Ukraine’s forces retreated, Russia advanced rapidly, aided in part by the absence of strong Ukrainian defensive positions. Russian troops captured three settlements and took control of nine square miles of land, according to open-source maps of the battlefield.

But in the past 10 days, Moscow has captured only a little over a square mile of land, according to the open-source maps. Its soldiers have been caught up in fighting in and around the villages of Berdychi, Orlivka and Tonenke.

Russian forces “seem to be attempting to push forward using small infantry assault groups, but are being decimated in the relatively open terrain west of Avdiivka,” said Pasi Paroinen, an analyst with the Black Bird Group, a Finland-based open-source community that assesses satellite imagery and social media content from the battlefield.

The recent fighting has also come at a cost to the Ukrainian army, which appears to have now committed some of its best troops and weapons to the fight in the area west of Avdiivka.

Its 47th Brigade, which the United States trained and equipped last year, has been defending Berdychi. A video released by Ukraine’s defense ministry purported to show the brigade using an American-made Abrams tank, one of the United States’ most advanced.

The Ukrainian army “is allocating all possible weapons” to the fight outside Avdiivka, said Serhii Kuzan, the chairman of the Ukrainian Security and Cooperation Center, a nongovernmental research group.

But three of Ukraine’s Abrams tanks have been destroyed or damaged and abandoned there in the past two weeks, according to Oryx, a military analysis website that counts losses based on visual evidence.

Ukrainian forces also suffered heavy losses as they fought off Russian assaults on Avdiivka for months.

Military experts say that Ukraine’s continued defense in the area is likely intended to give its units time to prepare and reinforce new defensive lines further west. The Ukrainian army recently published photos of fortifications that it said it was building near the Avdiivka battle zone, including 6.5-foot-deep trenches and anti-tank ditches.

“You’ve got a stronghold that’s fallen,” Mr. Fouillet said, referring to Avdiivka, “so you need time to put a defensive line back in place.”

Russia’s assault on Avdiivka resulted in heavy human and material losses for its forces. British military intelligence said that the average daily number of Russian troops killed and wounded in February, when Moscow was devoting a large number of forces to the fight for Avdiivka, had reached 983, “the highest rate since the start of the war.”

Mr. Paroinen and Mr. Kuzan noted that Ukraine’s forces have benefited from the area’s terrain. While Russian troops have been attacking Berdychi, Orlivka and Tonenke through open fields with little cover, Ukrainian units hold the high ground in the villages, making it easier to target approaching Russian soldiers.

Should Russian troops eventually capture the three villages, it is unclear what their exact next steps would be, given that the terrain is hilly and dotted with streams and reservoirs, complicating further advances.

Mr. Kuzan said that Russia’s army was currently attacking multiple places all along the more than 600-mile front line to probe Ukraine’s defenses.

“Which of them will be prioritized, for example, in two days or next week, will depend on how well they succeed in pushing through our defense,” he said. “Where they succeed in pushing through, they will deploy additional reserves to build on their success. This is their strategy.”

Q: "During times of war and during periods of mobilisation, citizens will be obliged to appear at recruitment points after receiving a notice by SMS," Khrenin said, discussing the innovations in the draft law, "In peacetime, these SMS messages will be an additional source of information for citizens. The manner in which citizens will undergo medical examinations when being summoned to military service is being simplified. Specifically, by removing the obligation to undergo a medical examination immediately before being sent to serve in the armed forces, the chances of unscrupulous citizens evading military service will be minimised".

The minister added that the age at which male citizens are initially added to military service rolls is being raised from 16 to 17 years, which will make it possible to bring the results of citizens’ medical waivers as close as possible to the time they are registered or called to serve in the military.

"The list of those obligated to serve but who are given deferrals to mobilise is being clarified and this will make it possible for the most socially vulnerable categories of citizens to obtain deferrals," Khrenin said. "The list of military registration and call-up events for which those obliged to serve can obtain the right to temporarily leave their jobs while their jobs and average wages are retained for them and compensation for travel expenses is provided is being widened. State security agencies are being given the authority to draft protocols on administrative violations against citizens on registration rolls for failing to appear to be registered without admissible reasons. Sanctions are being raised against citizens who violate rules on military registration, fail to appear for military service or who fail to appear to be registered. The maximum fine for violations of military registration rules is being increased from five to 30 base units".

The ability for citizens to participate voluntarily in defence-related work during peacetime is also being reviewed.

"Compensation for such work will be provided by paying the average wage at their place of employment or by paying out a fixed sum for those citizens who are unemployed," Khrenin said. "The obligation for local executive and administrative bodies to pay insurance and retirement premiums for citizens during call-ups and mobilisation training is being strengthened, with exceptions for citizens who have such guarantees and compensation from their places of employment." 

The minister also said that an authorised body is being established to draft state policy on preparing the economy for mobilisation. Military draft officers will be given the right to limit citizens’ rights to exit the country in ways that violate military registration rules or for evading military registration or military service. Prior to this, the restriction did not apply to military service and did not extend to the category of people "summoned to military training".
