In an attempt to calm tensions with Egypt, the delegation will also seek to offer clarifications on recent statements by Hamas leaders which have angered Cairo, Al Arabiya reported yesterday.

We will be publishing a briefing.

Israeli media pessimistic on ceasefire talks

Israeli media reported indications from political sources this morning that the Israeli government is now seeking a comprehensive, and not partial, deal for the release of all hostages, despite unnamed sources telling outlets that chances for a deal were low.

The Ynet news site said part of the talks would include negotiations on areas from which the army would withdraw and the establishment of "American-Arab supervision" of Gaza until a permanent solution on disarmament could be reached.

Channel 12 News noted that this was the first time Egypt had proposed the disarmament of Hamas amid what it said was a crisis in relations between the two.

Unnamed sources told both Ynet and the Haaretz daily that chances of reaching a deal remained low.

We will be publishing a briefing.

Gaza media office says Israel has killed 238 journalists

The Government Media Office in the Gaza Strip has published the names of the 238 journalists and media workers it says the Israeli army has killed since the start of the Gaza war.

The list was released this morning following the killing of prominent Al Jazeera reporter Anas al-Sharif in a targeted strike on a tent in Gaza City on Sunday night.

Al Jazeera correspondent Mohammed Qreiqeh and cameramen Ibrahim Zaher, Mohammed Noufal and Moamen Aliwa were also killed in the attack.

Hamas's al-Aqsa TV continued to give prominence to the killings this morning, discussing what it said was the "systematic silencing of [media professionals'] voices".

The Committee to Protect Journalists said at least 186 journalists have been killed since the start of the war.

Lebanese minister condemns Iranian 'interference'

Lebanon's Agriculture Minister Nizar Hani told leading Saudi pan-Arab channel Al Arabiya al-Hadath late yesterday that the government could summon the Iranian ambassador to Lebanon if Tehran officials continued their "interference" over the disarmament of Hezbollah.

Hani's remarks came after senior Iranian cleric Ahmad Jannati said yesterday that disarming the group was a "delusional dream".

The Lebanese government had already expressed anger on 10 August over comments by Ali Akbar Velayati, a senior adviser to Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who said that disarmament would not succeed and urged Lebanon's leaders to reject the plan.

The Lebanese government has set the end of 2025 as a deadline for Hezbollah to hand over its weapons, with has been met with resistance from members and supporters of the group.

SDF delegation in Damascus for talks amid tensions

Syria's leading news channel, Syria TV, reported this morning that a delegation from the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) had arrived in Damascus for talks with the Syrian government on implementing the 10 March integration agreement.

The report cited Al Jazeera, with neither Syrian state media nor SDF-affiliated outlets carrying any statements on the talks.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) cited its sources yesterday as saying that a "technical delegation" from the SDF-backed Autonomous Administration of North East Syria (AANES) had arrived in Damascus to find "solutions to avoid military escalation".

The SDF yesterday accused pro-government forces of "provocative movements" in Aleppo province. Damascus had earlier expressed anger over an SDF conference it said undermined national unity and which prompted it to boycott upcoming talks in Paris.

Nationwide power cut hits Iraq amid 'unprecedented' heatwave

A number of Iraqi provinces yesterday witnessed a total electricity outage as the country was hit by soaring temperatures.

The electricity ministry attributed the outages to "the unprecedented rise in temperatures, rising demand and the increase in electrical loads", the privately owned Al-Sumaria TV reported yesterday.

The ministry said it was working to gradually restore power in the affected provinces, the state-owned news agency Ina reported yesterday.

Ina also said that the temperature reached up to 50C in nine provinces yesterday.

Recurring power cuts helped spark the 2019 nationwide anti-government protests.

On X, several Arabic keywords criticising the power outage are trending in Iraq.

One user said "it is unfortunate to talk about the collapse of the electrical system… in a rich country like Iraq with its abundance of natural resources."

We will be publishing a briefing.

Coming up

- Jordan will host a tripartite meeting today between Foreign Minister Ayman al-Safadi, Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad al-Shibani and the US special envoy to Syria, Tom Barrack, focused on Syria's reconstruction and stability, according to a Jordanian foreign ministry statement issued on 10 August.

- Egyptian President Abdul Fattah al-Sisi receives his Ugandan counterpart Yoweri Museveni in Cairo for talks on ties and a number of regional and international issues of mutual interest, the Egyptian presidential spokesman said in a Facebook statement this morning.

As Egypt struggles to reach an agreement with Addis Ababa to resolve the conflict over its Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) - to be officially inaugurated in September - it is developing closer ties with other Nile Basin countries, including Uganda.

- A humanitarian aid convoy set out this morning from Egypt towards the Gaza Strip, the state-run Al-Qahera News TV reported today. A correspondent near the Rafah border crossing said the convoy was carrying thousands of tonnes of relief and medical aid.

He noted that the first part of the convoy, made up of around 50 aid lorries, had started moving to the Karam Abu Salem crossing - ready to unload there if Israeli approval was received.

Q: Malik noted negotiations with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) have entered the "final round" and it is expected that a letter of intent would be issued by the night of 19 March. He said an arrangement with the IMF is important for Pakistan to fill the gap in its "balance of payments" as other countries and institutions which gave loans to Pakistan have agreed to extend their support once the country is in an IMF programme. He mentioned Pakistan not only needs the last tranche of the current programme, but also wants to enter into a larger programme for three to four years.

Malik further noted inflation is not likely to decrease because under the IMF's conditions, the interest rate should be kept high, value of the rupee should be flexible, and power and gas tariffs should be increased.

Interview with minister of planning

Malik spoke with Minister of Planning, Development and Special Initiatives Ahsan Iqbal and asked him for how long the economy of Pakistan would remain weak. Iqbal said the current economic situation of the economy is certainly very challenging. He remarked it is not an underdeveloped economy, but an "under-managed or mismanaged economy" that can start a journey towards robust growth and development if its resources are used properly. He noted the main issue with Pakistan is its "political instability" because of which economic policies have been "reversed and disbanded" repeatedly. He emphasised political stability and continuity along with right economic policies could lead to economic progress.

Malik remarked a "civil-military dialogue" is necessary so that the military establishment stops "experiments" of intervention to install people of its choice for managing the economy. Iqbal was of the view that there is a realisation [within the military establishment] that continuity is necessary and the objective of the Special Investment Facilitation Council is to end tension and mistrust and take decisions with everyone's ownership in a "whole of government approach". He said there is need for an "economic National Action Plan" on the same lines as the National Action Plan against terrorism which was devised with a consensus from all.

Iqbal termed the meeting between KP Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur and Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif a "very positive development". Talking about Gandapur's arrest warrants, he said it may be a part of the judicial process and hoped that it would not cause any disruption that would increase political confrontation. He commented the people of Pakistan will not support any kind of "negative politics" in the current scenario. He expressed confidence that an agreement with the IMF would be finalised soon.

Arrest warrants against Gandapur

Malik asked KP government's spokesperson Muhammad Ali Saif about his reaction to the arrest warrants against Gandapur. Saif said it is a "routine action" and not a big legal or political issue as issuing bailable or non-bailable warrants during case proceedings is a normal procedure under the criminal procedure code. He claimed the Punjab government "does not want to miss any opportunity to exploit an issue against PTI members", so it would keep highlighting this issue.

Saif said the PTI would like to get the problems of KP resolved through dialogue with a "positive mind" and that is why Gandapur held a meeting with the prime minister. However, he added, it cannot be a one-sided process and the other side should also reciprocate.

Replying to Malik's question on why the KP government is demanding that Imran Khan (PTI founder) should be handed over to it from the Adiala jail in Punjab, Saif said the Punjab government has been saying that there are threats to jails in Punjab, which is a "pretext to disallow people from meeting Khan". He added if Khan is not safe in one of the largest jails of Punjab, Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz should hand him over to the KP government.

Source: Samaa TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1500 GMT 19 Mar 24

Q: The official visit by Iranian President Massoud Pezeshkian to Armenia will take place on 18-19 August, not 18-21 August as reported earlier, Armenpress state-owned news agency reports, quoting the office of the Armenian prime minister.

Pro-Moscow group calls for rally against anti-Russian protest

The Mother Armenia movement has called for a public gathering in response to a protest planned against the Russian 102nd military base stationed in Gyumri.

The call comes after the pro-Western For the Republic party announced plans to stage a protest outside the base on 23 August to call for the closure of the base and for Armenia's withdrawal from the Moscow-led Collective Security Treaty Organisation (CSTO).

In June, Yerevan had said that it had no plans to shut down the base and that under the current agreement, the lease runs until 2044.

Mother Armenia said in a statement that the pre-announced anti-Russia protest is being organised by "pro-Western forces that are pursuing anti-Armenian interests".

The movement condemned "provocative actions" aimed at undermining the presence of the Russian military in Armenia and described the base as a key component of national security.

The statement further warned that "following the fall of [breakaway] Karabakh, rising tensions in Syunik, and the de facto establishment of the Zangazur corridor [aka Trump Route - a prospective route via southern Armenia], efforts are now being directed at removing the Russian base, a step that would pave the way for Armenia's complete capitulation to Turkey and Azerbaijan".

The statement also called on the Gyumri mayor and law enforcers to prevent the anti-Russian protest, arguing that it serves the interests of Armenia's adversaries.

Washington deals draw criticism from opposition

Armenia's parliamentary opposition has described the declaration signed by the Armenian and Azerbaijani leaders in Washington on 8 August as a "new existential threat" and an act of "capitulation" for Armenia, Azaturtyun.am, the Armenian service of Radio Liberty, has said.

The Armenia faction said the peace deal with Azerbaijan, initialled in the States, legitimised Azerbaijan's "ethnic cleansing" in Karabakh, would erase the issue from the international agenda and lead the way for further Azerbaijani "aggression" through an "unimpeded corridor" - the so-called Trump Route, aka Zangazur corridor - through Armenia.

"No one can point to what exactly the Armenian interest is in this document - aside from the word 'peace' written on the paper, is there anything truly positive for Armenia?" said Artsvik Minasyan, secretary of the opposition Armenia faction in an interview with Azatutyun.

Non-parliamentary opposition figure Edmon Marukyan raised concern over the lack of a clearly defined map in the agreement, arguing that this leaves Armenia vulnerable to possible future Azerbaijani territorial claims, the report said.

Political analyst Stepan Danielyan warned that Armenia's agreement to allow Azerbaijani checkpoints in Armenia's southern Syunik Region without any Armenian control undermines Armenia's sovereignty. He also raised concern about the possible involvement of foreign private security forces.

Danielyan linked the timing of the Washington deal to the upcoming USA-Russia summit, suggesting it was used to strengthen the US position during the talks with Russia.

He also pointed to broader geopolitical risks, noting rising influence from the UK, Turkey and Israel in Azerbaijan, and warned the deal could further entrench great power competition in the region.

Former Armenian Foreign Minister Vartan Oskanian (Vardan Oskanyan) harshly criticised the "government's concessions" over the so-called Zangazur corridor, accusing the authorities of presenting a "strategic defeat" as a "strategic victory".

Oskanian said that handing over a strip of land stretching from east to west under conditions allowing unimpeded Azerbaijani access for 99 years without customs checks, border control or the right to inspect what passes through constitutes a loss of national sovereignty.

"No political manoeuvre can change this reality. You are leasing part of your sovereignty for at least two generations. This is not diplomacy; it is the sale of national dignity," he said, describing the proposed route as a "corridor of dependence and humiliation".

The website of the pro-opposition Hraparak daily says that following the Washington declaration a harsh Russian reaction was expected, with many predicting that Moscow would not forgive Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan for "ditching" it and abandoning the Russian-mediated 9 November 2020 deal. The daily, however, says that sources close to the Russian authorities say Moscow is largely indifferent to developments in and around Armenia.

According to the daily, various Russian government circles have conveyed to Armenian counterparts that no steps will be taken if the Armenian public considers the latest developments acceptable. The daily says that even Iran has sought clarity on Russia's stance to coordinate its own actions but received the same response.

Sources cited by the daily say the main reason for this attitude is that Russia is waiting to see what kind of resolution there will be on the Ukrainian front. Moscow believes that the Washington agreement has so many pitfalls that its implementation is simply unrealistic. But through internal channels, they have also made it clear to the Armenian authorities that regarding the unblocking of regional roads, they are in favour of implementing the trilateral agreements negotiated with their participation.

The daily concludes that Moscow has decided to closely observe how far Armenia's leadership will go, questioning how a government that spent four years negotiating with Russia and had a 30-year partnership could suddenly pivot to the USA. The daily says that once they understand it, they will plan their actions accordingly.

Separately, Hraparak says, citing its sources, that before signing the Washington deals, Azerbaijan not only engaged in prolonged preparatory work but also launched psychological pressure campaigns targeting Armenia's leadership, exploiting their known vulnerabilities.

Sources say that over the past month, Azerbaijani military aircraft conducted repeated reconnaissance flights along Armenia's borders, displaying "aggressive" behaviour. The Armenian government reportedly failed to grasp the real motive behind this increased activity, especially given that the Washington meetings and the intialling of the peace deal had already been agreed upon.

The daily also reports that Armenia's Foreign Intelligence Service provided a briefing to the government, warning that Azerbaijan was discussing multiple scenarios, and if "the negotiations regarding the Zangazur corridor fail, Azerbaijan, with the support of Turkey, is ready to use force to seize key parts of Syunik Region". This, the daily says, effectively put an end to all hesitation, and Pashinyan hastily went and signed everything, exclusively in the context of Azerbaijani demands. While some believe this information was deliberately leaked by Azerbaijan as part of its "cunning" politics, the daily notes that fear ultimately silenced rational voices within the Armenian leadership.

Separately, Hraparak's website says that the published text of the peace treaty between Armenia and Azerbaijan initialled in Washington contains no provisions favourable to Armenia.

The daily says that the document makes no mention of the rights of Karabakh Armenians, the release of Armenians held by Baku, the withdrawal of Azerbaijani troops from "occupied" Armenian territories, or any specific map for border delimitation. Instead, it includes clauses that are not only not aimed at establishing peace, but will also provoke internal unrest, plunge Armenia into a new period of turbulence, create new and unsolvable problems, and lay the groundwork for new concessions.

The daily highlights Clauses 8 and 9 of the treaty as particularly problematic. Clause 8 states that the parties condemn and will combat intolerance, racial hatred, separatism, and terrorism. The daily questions why such language is included, given that both countries are already party to relevant international conventions.

The answer, the daily says, lies in Clause 9, which obliges both sides to address cases of missing persons and enforced disappearances from the conflict through information exchange, noting that relevant arrangements will be negotiated and thoroughly agreed upon in a separate agreement. Thus, according to Clause 9, a separate agreement addressing all the above-mentioned issues still needs to be concluded, the contents of which and the pitfalls it may contain for Armenia are unknown.

The daily warns that this clause could enable Azerbaijan to demand criminal investigations into participants in the First Karabakh War, targeting Armenian military figures and war veterans under the pretext of implementing justice. And if Armenia rejects such demands, it could be accused of supporting separatism, undermining Azerbaijan's territorial integrity, or obstructing justice.

Furthermore, the daily warns that Baku will demand to punish all the "revanchists", those accusing Azerbaijan of vandalism and genocide, those fighting against the destruction of Armenian cultural heritage in Karabakh, and so on. All of this, the daily says, would be coordinated through a follow-up agreement, uniquely required only for these specific clauses out of the treaty's 17 clauses, suggesting their strategic importance to both Baku and, potentially, the current Armenian leadership.

Finally, the daily argues, this follow-up agreement may be used not only to suppress domestic opposition to Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan, but also to silence those opposing Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev and Azerbaijani "aggression".

Minister praises Baku-Yerevan declaration

Meanwhile, Armenian Economy Minister Gevorg Papoyan highlighted the economic significance of the Washington declaration. He noted that during the Iran-Israel war, the South Caucasus served as the only safe air route, prompting global recognition of the need for a secure land route as well. He said the new corridor will turn Armenia into a key cargo hub between China and Europe, enhancing its security importance as any disruption during future conflicts would draw greater international attention. He added that cargo transit through Armenia will generate customs revenue, infrastructure development and economic benefits. Additionally, the opening of new routes will reduce transportation costs for Armenian exports and with the reopening of the Turkish border, Armenia can access Mediterranean ports, which could further lower import and export costs.

According to Papoyan, the agreement will lead to significant economic investments and boost exports, imports and overall foreign investment in Armenia. Papoyan stated that as a transport hub, Armenia will play a key role in global trade and enhance its strategic importance and security. He said that if US companies build a railway along the potential Trump Route for Peace and Prosperity (TRIPP; aka Zangazur corridor, via southern Armenia), it would not harm Armenia but would bring major benefits and operate under Armenian law, just like the Russian Railways currently does. He said Armenia should find a formula to live peacefully with its neighbours and the agreement signed in Washington is that formula. Those who oppose it, he argued, prefer Armenia to remain a tool in the hands of other powers and reject peace. Papoyan added that the new route would also be economically beneficial for Iran, as it would allow direct access from Armenia's Meghri to Azerbaijan's Naxcivan railway, then through Armenia's Yeraskh into Armenia, enabling faster cargo transport. He noted that both Iran's president and foreign minister have confirmed they see no security risks in this arrangement.

Papoyan also noted that there are no issues with Russia regarding this matter, as Armenia is a member of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU), maintains close partnership with Russia and is a strategic ally. He emphasised that all relevant matters are resolved within this relationship.

Exiled separatist Karabakh MPs say Baku-Yerevan peace deal omits key issues

Parliamentary factions of Azerbaijan's defunct breakaway Nagorno-Karabakh region have issued a statement in response to the 8 August trilateral meeting of the leaders of Armenia, Azerbaijan and the United States in Washington.

While acknowledging past international peace efforts, the parliamentary factions criticised the dissolution of the OSCE Minsk Group and accused its co-chairs of abandoning their mediation role. They said that the lack of condemnation of the 2020 Karabakh war, which they said was started by Baku, led to further escalation and the exodus of Karabakh Armenians in 2023, and that the Minsk Group ignored the International Court of Justice resolution on the right of Karabakh Armenians to return to their homes.

The statement warned that any Armenia-Azerbaijan peace deal excluding key issues, such as the safe return of Karabakh Armenians, protection of cultural heritage, and the release of Armenian detainees held by Baku would fail to deliver a lasting peace. The statement called for a process based on justice, rights and mutual trust.

Armenia, Georgia discuss regional peace prospects

Armenian Foreign Minister Ararat Mirzoyan has told his Georgian counterpart Maka Bochorishvili in a phone call that Baku and Yerevan's Washington deals are a fresh opportunity for regional cooperation and peace, News.am said.

Commenting on the outcomes of the 8 August meetings in Washington, Mirzoyan emphasised that the agreements reached create new opportunities for regional cooperation and peace. The sides also discussed their bilateral partnership agenda.

Russia allocates 25m dollars for Armenia's school meals programme

Russia has allocated over $25m for the next phase of the School Feeding Programme (2025–30) run by the UN World Food Programme in Armenia.

Since 2010, Russia has contributed 43m dollars in total, benefiting over 102,000 schoolchildren, modernising facilities and improving attendance and performance. The UN has praised the programme's success and bilateral cooperation, the report said.

In the meantime, the Russian House culture centre in Armenia will launch a free four-month robotics course for children and teenagers starting 25 August as part of the Russian Engineering School international educational project. Participants will improve their Russian language skills, learn robotics using unique Russian methods and explore leading Russian universities and scientific achievements, Sputnik Armenia said.

Q: News report notes 'deadlock' in seat sharing in coalition

The seat sharing for Lok Sabha (lower house of parliament) elections in Mahayuti [coalition mainly comprising of Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), Shiv Sena (Chief Minister Eknath Shinde faction) and Nationalist Congress Party (NCP, Ajit Pawar faction)] in western state Maharashtra has reached a ''deadlock''. The development comes after Shiv Sena and NCP refused the formula of 30 seats, 13 and five seats for BJP, Shiv Sena and NCP respectively. The BJP has staked claim over Thane seat, contested and won by undivided Shiv Sena in 2019, impeding any breakthrough in talks. Saamana

Politicians hold discussions regarding elections

Maha Vikas Aghadi [MVA, coalition mainly comprising of Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party, NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar party and Congress party] on 25 March held a meeting at the residence of Uddhav Thackeray. Sharad Pawar and Thackeray held separate discussions over strategy to defeat the BJP in elections. Thackeray faction spokesperson, Sanjay Raut, and NCP-Sharadchandra Pawar party State Chief, Jayant Patil, were also present during the meeting. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 100]

Police bust drug factory in western city

Mumbai Police on 25 March busted a drug factory in an agricultural field of Irali village in Kavathe- Mahankal block [administrative division in Sangli district, Mumbai]. According to initial reports, 100kg mephedrone has been recovered. [Page: 1, Approximate Word: 150]

[Saamana is the mouthpiece of the Maharashtra-based political party Shiv Sena. This nationalist and right-leaning daily supports the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government on national security, terrorism and Kashmir issues. However, it is very critical of the government on economy and unemployment issues.]

Tarun Bharat

Politician remarks on party ending alliance

Sanjay Raut on 25 March said that decision of Vanchit Bahujan Aghadi (VBA) to end the alliance with the Thackeray faction of Shiva Sena a year ago was ''unilateral'' and ''unfortunate''. News report notes election plan of Hindu nationalist body

According to sources quoted in the news report, such meetings were held in every district on the same day in the second week of March, followed by block-level meetings. The district meetings were also attended by select BJP politicians. RSS and its affiliates will reportedly hold thousands of meetings in next 15-20 days across Maharashtra and make an appeal to re-elect Prime Minister Narendra Modi. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 150]

Party to announce election candidates on 26 March

Shiv Sena Member of Parliament (MP), Sanjay Mandlik, on 25 March said that seat distribution in Mahayuti is reportedly in its last stage. Chief Minister Eknath Shinde will announce Shiv Sena candidates for Lok Sabha elections on 26 March. It was reportedly said that Mandlik may not get a chance for re-election but he said that the chief minister had assured him that candidature of all of them was decided. [Page: 2, Approximate Words: 250]

[Lokmat is a popular Marathi-language daily edited by Vijay Darda, a Congress party member. The paper is mostly critical of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) government especially on its handling of Kashmir, terrorism and economic issues.]

Pudhari

Party to announce 15 election candidates

Uddhav Balasaheb Thackeray party will reportedly announce 15-16 of its candidates for Lok Sabha elections on 26 March. Party spokesperson Sanjay Raut said on 25 March that there was no dispute over seat sharing in the MVA and that people were with the coalition. [Page: 1, Approximate Words: 300]

Woman held with cocaine worth $2.3m at Mumbai airport

The accused is a citizen of Sierra Leone and arrived in Mumbai from Nairobi [capital of Kenya]. [Page: 3, Approximate Words: 120]

[Pudhari is the second-largest Marathi-language daily that is nationalist and right-of-centre. The daily backs the Indian government on issues such as national security, terrorism and Kashmir.]

According to sources quoted in the news daily New Indian Express, the BJP told Thackeray that the decision will benefit him politically. Present leadership of Shiv Sena is seemingly reluctant to handover leadership to the MNS chief but the BJP is ''firm'' on its offer, assuring Eknath Shinde that Lok Sabha elections results will have no impact on his chief minister post. Q: The jihadist group published the 19-minute message, which was packaged as a video, on 19 March via its channels on Telegram, Chirpwire and Element.

The latest instalment criticised the Algerian government for their adoption of democracy in what it described as "practical unbelief".

It was narrated by Abu Yasir al-Jaza'iri, whose nom de guerre suggests he is Algerian, as with past segments in the long-running series that first launched in August 2022.

Despite the Algerian authorities professing to be Muslim, their acceptance of democratic principles amounted to a major deviation from Islamic teachings, al-Jaza'iri argued.

He said that enacting secular legislation, which determines what is permissible or forbidden without being grounded in Sharia law, constituted a significant breach of faith.

Democracy, by vesting legislative power in people, was tantamount to the sin of worshipping other divinities alongside God, al-Jaza'iri contended.

He cited historical and contemporary Islamic scholars such as Abu Muhammad al-Maqdisi, as well as the Algerian constitution to back his argument.

Jihadist groups vehemently oppose democracy, viewing it as at odds with Islamic doctrine.

The previous instalment in the series criticised the Algerian authorities for the equal treatment of Muslims and religious minorities.

Q: Yerevan has once again ruled out any transport arrangement that would compromise Armenia's territorial integrity or sovereignty.

"Armenia has never discussed and will not discuss the kinds of options of transport links that would be incompatible with its own territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction," Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan's spokesperson Nazeli Baghdasaryan said on Facebook. She made the comments in response to what she described as "confusion" in the media about the matter.

"It is evident that there is some confusion in the Armenian media about Armenia's position regarding the unblocking of regional transport links, and the media outlets see some contradictions in the statements of Armenian officials. To some extent, this is understandable, because the topic has numerous nuances, which sometimes get more complicated with the use of certain wordings, such as renting out, lease, building lease, outsourcing. Certainly, each of the wordings can have different meanings depending on what specifically it pertains to.

"In order to make the issue easier for the esteemed representatives of the press, I would like to once again underscore that the Republic of Armenia has never discussed, is not discussing and will not discuss the kinds of options of transport links passing through its own territory that would be incompatible with the territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction of the Republic of Armenia.

"And furthermore, as part of its territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction, the Republic of Armenia is not only discussing various formulas of utilising regional transport routes, but is also eager to reach an agreement around any of the formulas," Baghdasaryan said.

"Armenia's territorial integrity, sovereignty and jurisdiction cannot be outsourced. The business management of a railway, pipeline [or] power transmission lines can be [outsourced]. Incidentally, the maintenance and management of roads in Armenia has always been outsourced to private companies. Who manages [the roads] and with what quality is another matter. But this has nothing to do with the topic discussed," Baghdasaryan added.

Armenia to temporarily shelter 'endangered' Palestinian cultural heritage

Armenia will temporarily house elements of "endangered Palestinian cultural heritage" at the Matenadaran Institute of Ancient Manuscripts in Yerevan as part of an agreement between Armenia and the Palestinians, News.am reported.

It was quoting a statement made by Armenian Deputy Foreign Minister Vahan Kostanyan at the high-level UN conference on the peaceful resolution of the Palestinian issue, co-chaired by France and Saudi Arabia, in New York. In his speech, Kostanyan reaffirmed Armenia's commitment to the two-state solution, stating that "lasting peace and stability are only possible through the existence of two neighbouring independent states".

Kostanyan also welcomed France's intention to recognise "Palestine" and the UK's intention to follow suit, noting Armenia's pride in having hosted a meeting between the French and Palestinian foreign ministers during the Yerevan Dialogue diplomatic conference earlier in 2025.

Despite limited resources, he said, Armenia has made consistent efforts to support the Palestinian people - including sending humanitarian aid to Gaza and backing the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA).

Kostanyan emphasised the importance of protecting Christian communities and heritage in both states, noting that Armenia is particularly concerned about preserving holy sites in the "Holy Land".

"Armenia hopes that the historic status quo governing the holy sites in Jerusalem will be fully upheld," he said, calling it "a cornerstone of interfaith solidarity and peaceful coexistence".

Red Cross to stop visiting Armenian detainees in Baku

The families of Armenians held in Baku have been informed by the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) that it will no longer be able to visit the detainees, Azatutyun.am, the Armenian service of Radio Liberty, has reported.

This news has caused serious concern among the detainees' relatives, as the ICRC was the only independent international organisation able to access the detained Armenians, monitor their conditions and health, provide necessary clothing and hygiene supplies, and facilitate video calls with family members, the report said.

One relative told Azatutyun that the ICRC was "the last hope" for the families and the detainees. "The only means was the Red Cross, which connected families and brought some light to these people's lives. And now this has been cut off too," the person said.

Zara Amatuni, the head of Communication for the ICRC delegation in Armenia, told Azatutyun that the last visit to the Armenians took place in June, and there have been no visits in July. According to Amatuni, the ICRC's Baku office will soon suspend operation at the request of the Azerbaijani authorities.

"Naturally, this situation is causing disruptions to our normal work process," she said.

Official data from Azerbaijan indicate that 23 Armenians are currently held in Baku prisons. Their only contact with relatives now is through phone calls arranged by the Azerbaijani authorities.

The pro-opposition Joghovurd daily cited the families of the detainees said that Azerbaijan has now fully prohibited visits to both civilian and military and political Armenian captives. Previously, limited contact was allowed once a month via video calls, but even that has been cut off, the report said.

The daily added that Baku is unwilling to make concessions, while the peace agreement with Baku promised by Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan appears increasingly uncertain.

Pundit says no unified stance in Iran on 'Zangazur corridor'

Expert on international relations Grigor Balasanyan has told News.am reformist and conservative forces in Iran no longer have a unified position on the issue of the potential so-called Zangazur corridor which is to link mainland Azerbaijan to its Naxcivan exclave via southern Armenia along the Iranian border.

Iran has long opposed the Zangazur corridor project which it says it fears would cut off its access to Armenia.

The expert noted that serious events are unfolding in Iran, where the political elite is currently divided into two factions. The reformists, led by President Massoud Pezeshkian, are no longer strongly opposed to the opening of the corridor.

"In fact, Pezeshkian recently gave an interview in which he made a controversial statement, saying that issues related to restoring routes along Iran's north-western border are trivial and not worth worrying about. In other words, the Iranian president considers the opening of the 'Zangazur corridor' an insignificant matter," Balasanyan said, noting that an opposite stance is held by the team of Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, who sharply criticise Pezeshkian, warning of destructive consequences for Iran from the corridor's opening.

The expert also said that Pezeshkian's visit to Azerbaijan's Karabakh in July for a summit of the Economic Cooperation Organisation was also symbolic following the 12-day Iran-Israel war. "Knowing well that Iranian territory is constantly shelled from Azerbaijan, choosing to attend the meeting implies agreement with everything happening against your [Pezeshkian's] state," the expert said.

Armenian president visits border checkpoint, communities near Iran

As part of his visit to Armenia's southern Syunik Province, Armenia's ceremonial President Vahagn Khachaturyan has toured the Meghri customs checkpoint at the border with Iran, where he was briefed by Deputy Head of the State Revenue Committee Karen Tamazyan on current operations and plans for a new facility at the checkpoint to boost transport links. The new facility will be ready in 2026, Tamazyan said.

Khachaturyan referred to the government's Crossroads of Peace initiative, expressing concern that the planned facility may not be adequate to support the project's full implementation or to ensure reliable transport connectivity along the Middle Corridor.

The president also visited the communities of Chakaten and Nerkin Hand, where he conversed with residents, discussed local issues and inquired about ongoing and planned government programmes in border areas. Khachaturyan visited a tunnel under construction as part of the North-South Road Corridor Project, where he observed the progress of ongoing construction work.

Also, Khachaturyan visited a military unit, reviewed living conditions and awarded several soldiers for their exemplary service.

Armenia-China defence relations

Armenian Armed Forces General Staff Chief Edvard Asryan has attended an event at the Chinese embassy marking the 98th anniversary of China's People's Liberation Army, Armenpress has reported.

Speaking at the event, Asryan stated that defence cooperation between two countries, including between the defence ministries, has developed successfully in recent years. He noted that China is currently one of Armenia's key international partners, and further development of bilateral cooperation is among the priorities of Armenia's foreign policy.

"Armenia-China relations are based on mutual respect, a high level of political dialogue and mutual understanding. Armenia is actively participating in the Belt and Road initiative proposed by the Chinese president, which aligns with Armenia's Crossroads of Peace project," Asryan said.

He said the Armenian government places strong emphasis on developing cooperation with China in the defence sector.

In this context, he highlighted that in 2023 and 2024, Armenian Defence Minister Suren Papikyan took part in the 10th and 11th Xiangshan international security forums held in Beijing to have productive meetings that helped further strengthen and expand bilateral cooperation.

Asryan added that annual bilateral cooperation programmes include delegation exchanges and expert-level working meetings across key areas of mutual interest. He said Armenia-China relations are currently at a high level, and further development is planned in several key areas.

In the field of military science, close relations have been established between the Academy of Military Sciences of the Chinese People's Liberation Army and Armenia's Vazgen Sargsyan Military University of the Ministry of Defence and National Defence Research University.

Chinese ambassador to Armenia Li Songwei said that China's global projects, such as the Belt and Road Initiative, aim to support development, and that countries like Armenia have shown interest and support.

Praising the steady development of relations between Armenia and China over the past 33 years, the diplomat said both nations respect each other's sovereignty and support one another on key national issues.

He confirmed that China will support Armenia's bid to join the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation during its chairmanship this year. Li added that Beijing is ready to deepen practical cooperation and strengthen peace and stability in the region.

In July, Armenia announced it seeks to join the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) as part of its strategy to pursue a balanced foreign policy. Prime Minister Pashinyan dismissed speculations that its possible SCO membership contradicts Armenia's position on the Moscow-led military alliance CSTO, noting that several countries are members of both organisations.

Premier's falling approval rating reportedly sparks search for new political challenges

Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan's approval rating has dropped to 13%, but Armenia's traditional opposition forces have failed to gain ground, Past daily has said. The newspaper argued that Pashinyan is now looking for a "dangerous opponent" among other forces that are capable of gaining the trust of Armenian society which is disappointed both with the ruling "velvet" government and former authorities.

Among those Pashinyan reportedly viewed as potential threats were the Armenian Apostolic Church and influential philanthropists, Past said. It said that Pashinyan deliberately provoked conflict with the Church in an effort to weaken it and reshape it to make it fit his "velvet revolution" narrative.

The arrest of influential businessman Samvel Karapetyan and his announcement to form a new political party marked a critical turning point, signaling a potential new challenge to Prime Minister Pashinyan's power, the daily said. It said that Karapetyan approaches politics as business and suggests that this approach manifests in his "in our own way" statement declared by Karapetyan's team, which has greatly unsettled the authorities. The daily concluded that unlike "insulting and imprisoning" clergymen, the new political force led by Karapetyan may prove far harder for Pashinyan to suppress.

Q: The package, pulled together from money that Army accountants cobbled from savings from contracts that came in under bid, includes air defense interceptors, artillery rounds and armor systems, senior defense officials said. Two U.S. officials said the package also includes an older version of the Army's longer-range missile systems known as ATACMS, which can travel 100 miles.

It is a stopgap measure at best, the officials said, but Ukraine is in dire need of air defense systems in particular, as Russia has continued its bombardment of towns particularly in the east.

The makeshift solution would keep advancing Russian troops at bay for only a few weeks, one official said.

Announcing the aid package at the White House, the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, said that ''Ukrainian troops have fought bravely, are fighting bravely throughout this war, but they are now forced to ration their ammunition under pressure on multiple fronts.''

He said the new package would ''keep Ukraine's guns firing for a period, but only a short period.'' Mr. Sullivan called for Congress to pass a new Ukraine aid bill ''as soon as possible.''

He said that Ukraine desperately needed the assistance to hold the line against Russian attacks, but that ''it goes without saying this package does not displace and should not delay the critical need to pass the bipartisan national security bill.''

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, in his overnight address, thanked ''the United States and all Americans who value freedom'' for their support of his country.

The Senate passed an emergency aid bill including $60.1 billion for Ukraine. But the measure faces an uncertain fate in the House of Representatives, where Republican leaders have refused to put the measure to a vote. While congressional officials say there is a critical mass of support for continuing to arm Ukraine in its fight against Russian aggression, the Republican Party is increasingly turning away from its traditional hawkish posture and belief in projecting American power and democratic principles around the world.

House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican of Louisiana who has opposed aiding Ukraine, must navigate a handful of ultraconservative lawmakers who have said they will move to oust him if he allows a vote on Ukraine aid without stringent immigration measures attached.

On Tuesday, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, urged Mr. Johnson to hold a vote on the Ukraine aid package.

''I want to encourage the speaker again to allow a vote,'' he said.

For President Biden, who has led the way in calling for the West to stand up for Ukraine against Russia's invasion and occupation, the issue has become an embarrassing one on the international stage.

The American political paralysis has led, Pentagon officials said, to critical shortages on the battlefields of Ukraine. As each day goes by without a fresh supply of munitions and artillery, and Ukrainian crews ration the shells they have, morale suffers.

''When Russian troops advance and its guns fire, Ukraine does not have enough ammunition to fire back; that's costing terrain,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''It's costing lives and it's costing us, the United States and the NATO alliance, strategically.''

Since Russia's February 2022 invasion of Ukraine, the Biden administration has sent more than $75 billion in cash and equipment to the country for its defense. Most of the aid has gone to Ukraine's military operations, keeping its government running and addressing its humanitarian needs.

The money ran out in December, and Mr. Biden asked Congress for the authority to begin a new infusion of cash and equipment that only it can approve. But many Republicans object to pouring more taxpayer dollars into the conflict.

Senior intelligence officials warned on Monday that without additional American aid, Ukraine faced the prospect of continued battlefield losses as Russia uses a network of arms suppliers and increases its supply of technology from China.

In public testimony during the annual survey of worldwide threats facing the United States, the officials told Congress that any continued delay of U.S. aid would lead to additional territorial gains by Russia over the next year, the consequences of which would be felt in Europe and in the Pacific.

On Tuesday, Denmark also announced a new $340 million military aid package for Ukraine.

Constant Méheut contributed reporting.

Constant Méheut contributed reporting.

Q: Politician says BJP 'broke PDP' to create new parties

Mehbooba Mufti, former chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir and president of Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), on 21 March said the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) "divided the PDP" and formed new political parties in Jammu and Kashmir "so as to suppress the voice of the people". Interacting with the media in Anantnag, Mufti said after the revocation of special status of Kashmir in 2019, many political parties were formed in Jammu and Kashmir whose "sole aim was to suppress the real voice" of the people of Kashmir. She said the BJP is now trying to "give power" to these parties. She said the BJP also targeted her personally. Mufti said, "I, my brother, and my aged mother were repeatedly summoned by the Enforcement Directorate and they even evicted me from my residence in the harsh winters." She alleged that Jammu and Kashmir has been turned into a prison where anyone who raises his voice for his rights is suppressed by force. [Online, Approximate Words: 175]

[Urdu-language daily Nida-I-Mashriq is a pro-separatist daily that focuses on local issues of Kashmir. The daily is critical of the state and the federal government, and favours talks with separatists and Pakistan for the resolution of Kashmir.]

Daily Chattan

Editorial says Kashmiris dissatisfied with health facilities

A 22 March editorial said people in Kashmir are not satisfied with health facilities in government hospitals, especially with the behaviour of doctors and other staff in the hospitals. The editorial said: "People are still not satisfied with the health facilities in Jammu and Kashmir. The government has been engaged in providing modern facilities to government hospitals and other health centres for the past several years. Despite this, the misfortune is that the patients are not satisfied with the behaviour of the doctors and other staff there. There is no one to take care of patients who have no influence in these hospitals. Hospitals in rural areas have become mere referral centres for patients. Almost every patient who comes here is referred to a big hospital. Rather, it has been seen many times that patients are advised to go to private hospitals. The strange thing is that it is not possible to get treatment without a recommendation in two big hospitals of Kashmir. Perhaps being aware of this, the lieutenant governor has urged that health facilities should be provided equally to every citizen and there should be no discrimination. It is difficult to say whether this advice will be implemented in government hospitals. People sitting in such hospitals have proved to be very fearless and anti-public. They do not have any kind relationship with the patients. Rather, they have become accustomed to behaving very rudely with poor patients. Fearing them, people prefer to take their patients to hospitals outside Kashmir. Hundreds of patients go to Chandigarh, Amritsar, Delhi and even Faridabad for treatment. Such patients openly appreciate the kindness of the doctors and the passion of the other staff. Patients from there advise other people that it is better to spend lakhs of rupees outside than to spend a single rupee in hospitals in Kashmir. The only reason for this is not the professional ability of the doctors there, but their compassionate attitude." [Online, Approximate Words: 700]

[Urdu-language Daily Chattan is a pro-Kashmir separatist, pro-militant daily that is popular in the northern part of Indian-administered Kashmir. The daily favours talks with Pakistan for the resolution of the Kashmir dispute.]

Daily Aftab

Editorial says poll body trying to ensure better voter turnout in Kashmir

A 22 March editorial said the Election Commission is taking measures to do away with the trend of low voter turnout in Kashmir and ensure increased voting in the forthcoming general elections. The editorial said: "The Election Commission is taking steps to ensure free, fair, transparent and terror-free polling and for this, the public is being asked to vote in maximum numbers in the parliamentary elections. It is noteworthy that the commission has declared most of the polling stations in Jammu and Kashmir as 'dangerous' and the authorities have been asked to ensure that no law-and-order problem arises there. Due to terrorism, the voter turnout has been very low, and it has not been recorded more than 20-30% in Kashmir. On the contrary, the voter turnover in Jammu has always been between 60-70%. The chief electoral officer (CEO) said more parts of the Kashmir region have been declared unsafe after a recent exercise by the authorities. Therefore, the police have been asked to increase patrolling, initiate cordon and search operations, strengthen checkpoints, hold regular meetings of officers and collaborate with other security agencies to ensure peaceful elections. The CEO said the Election Commission has done away with the terms highly sensitive, sensitive and normal to ensure better turnout. He said that to prevent the activities of terrorists, anti-national elements and miscreants in vulnerable areas and critical polling stations, they have adopted a new procedure to ensure a healthy turnout. From 1 April the security forces have been ordered to be in a state of readiness so that the miscreants and anti-peace elements could not get a chance to try their tactics." [Online, Approximate Words: 600]

[Urdu-language Daily Aftab is a pro-separatist daily that focuses on local issues of Kashmir valley. The daily is critical of the state and the federal government, and favours talks with separatists and Pakistan for the resolution of India-Pakistan dispute over Kashmir.]

Tameel-I-Irshad

Police arrest three drug traffickers in Kashmir

The Jammu and Kashmir Police on 21 March claimed to have arrested three drug traffickers in separate operations in Kashmir. A police team set up a checkpoint at Bajwani Tral in south Kashmir's Pulwama district and seized 2,000 capsules of banned drugs from a drug trafficker, identified as Mohammad Amin Malik, a resident of Lurgam Tral. In central Kashmir's Budgam district, police seized 4.6 kilograms of hashish from a drug trafficker, identified as Bashir Ahmed Hajam, a resident of Qumiroo. A police team intercepted a vehicle bearing registration number JK01AR-2030 at Awantipora toll plaza, driven by Mushtaq Ahmad Chopan, a resident of Hawal Srinagar and seized some hashish from it. Police have registered cases in all three incidents and taken up further investigation. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[Urdu-language Tameel-I-Irshad is a pro-Kashmir separatist daily that focuses on local issues in Indian-administered Kashmir. The daily favours India-Pakistan talks for the resolution of the Kashmir dispute.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Urdu and Kashmiri 22 Mar 24

Q: Anchor Nadia Mirza remarked the government seems to be unsure about whether it would be able to complete its term. She noted Rana Sanaullah, a senior Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician, recently commented that appointment of Minister of Finance Muhammad Aurangzeb and Minister of Interior Mohsin Naqvi is a "guarantee for the government's survival".

Mirza noted it is for the first time in the history of Pakistan that stability and sustainability of a newly formed government are said to be dependent on the appointment of certain personalities as finance and interior ministers. She asked senior journalist Amir Zia to comment on the situation. Zia said the [Prime Minister] Shehbaz Sharif-led government apparently seems quite strong but not only its opponents, but also the people inside the government keep asking whether it would be able to complete its tenure. He added the present government represents "unity in diversity" but there are "competing interests" at work against each other within it.

Zia criticised a statement by Minister of Foreign Affairs Ishaq Dar that trade relations with India should be restored and commented there are "no takers of peace in India" and the election campaign there is based on an "anti-Pakistan" sentiment. He added Pakistan's "stated stance" is that talks with India are not possible till the latter annuls its steps taken on 5 August 2019 regarding the status of Kashmir.

Zia was of the view that the finance minister should be empowered, but "unfortunately whenever a technocrat is appointed to the position, he does not get political support". He mentioned Aurangzeb has close links with the Sharif family, yet he is "not being fully trusted". He insisted Dar should have nothing to do with the finance ministry, and if Aurangzeb is not allowed to work freely, it would be unfair to Pakistan.

Talking about former prime minister Nawaz Sharif's future in politics, Zia said his politics suffered a "setback" in the 8 February elections and it is to be seen whether his daughter and Punjab Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz would be able to revive the politics launched by him and win the power tussle within the Sharif family. He claimed Maryam Nawaz's actions are being "overly publicised".

Speaking about the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI), Zia said the party is facing "very complex problems" but it does not look like the government can take advantage of the issues within the party.

Politics within PTI

Mirza said the PTI is facing internal issues because Imran Khan (PTI founder) is in jail and there are restrictions on the party's activities. She noted on 23 March, PTI politician Sher Afzal Marwat revealed that dissidents in his party have formed a forward group in the Punjab Assembly, but several other party members have denied the reports of division within the PTI.

Mirza contacted Marwat and asked him whether he stands firm on his statement or will he take a U-turn. Marwat commented he never takes a U-turn on his statements. He claimed his statement was based on information shared by several "responsible members" in a party meeting and statement of the opposition leader in the Punjab Assembly. He was of the view that it would be good if PTI politicians in the parliamentary party have control over the members of the assemblies.

Marwat emphasised the PTI should focus on Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and Punjab Assembly during the Senate (upper house of the parliament) elections because many "powerful people" would be contesting as independent candidates. He said the PTI should try to win at least nine Senate seats from KP and two from Punjab.

Economy

Mirza asked economist Shahid Hasan Siddiqui whether the new finance minister would be able to improve Pakistan's economy. Siddiqui said it is for sure that loans would be granted to Pakistan but the economy would further weaken. He added if the same policies continue after the 24th International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme, Pakistan would have to go into a 25th programme as well because there is a "nexus of Pakistani and foreign elite" who want these policies to continue. He was of the view that the United States (US) wants Pakistan to remain in the IMF programme for its political interests and the Pakistani elite want to continue the IMF programme to "please the US" and increase the tax burden on people under the cover of the IMF. He noted the government has not offered any new suggestions since 2001 for expanding the tax net and noted the tax to gross domestic product (GDP) ratio has declined in the last few years.

Source: Dawn News TV, Karachi, in Urdu 1700 GMT 24 Mar 24

Q: The Salvation Government's political affairs bureau announced the measures in a statement published on 7 March via Telegram and X.

The move appeared to be an attempt to address public discontent with HTS's governance in north-western Syria, where protests against its rule have taken place since February.

The statement said that the HTS-backed authority had held meetings with local leaders, activists and journalists to listen and respond to concerns.

In response to feedback, it has set up community committees to quickly implement "genuine" reforms and expand participatory governance.

The statement said other institutions were being developed for oversight and complaint resolution.

It stressed that the group's "revolutionary project" was an ongoing experiment that required collective efforts to ensure continuous improvement.

On 5 March, the HTS Shura Council issued decrees that announced that seven committees had been formed in areas such as Idlib city, Ariha, Atmeh and Jisr al-Shughur.

The decrees said the six or seven-member committees would engage with residents to address local needs and receive complaints.

They said the committees would provide assistance and facilitate communication between residents and the Salvation Government to improve services.

The announcements come amid protests in HTS-held areas that have demanded the release of detained "revolutionaries" and accused the group of torture in its prisons.

Protestors have also called for the resignation of HTS leader Abu Muhammad al-Jawlani.

This week, HTS said it released former senior member Abu Mariya al-Qahtani, who had been detained since last summer on espionage charges.

Q: First Republican: 'Main political event of the year'

Donetsk-based First Republican TV's Temy Nedeli (Themes of the Week) on 16 March led with the start of the main voting days in the presidential election (15-17 March), described by presenter Darya Parafanova as the "main political event of the year". It went on to broadcast in full President Vladimir Putin's four-minute 14 March address to the citizens of Russia, in which he underlined the importance of the election for the development of the country in the coming years.

First Republican: 'Our candidate is a strong leader'

During early voting in the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) in the period 10-14 March, voting urns and screens were set up in the open air in cities across the region, First Republican reported. Voters were said to have come out in entire families and groups of co-workers - "electricians, metallurgists, veterans and athletes".

"For working people, this format was very convenient," Parafanova commented.

In Donetsk, a group of uniformed "Donetsk Cossacks" were among the first to vote collectively, a correspondent reported.

Their leader, Ataman Sergei Bumagin, said it was convenient for them to come and vote "compactly and quickly". "We see our candidate as a strong leader," he added.

Another Cossack said they voted for "our Russia, our future, our hopes and aspirations; we think we made the right decisions".

Other voters said they voted for: "stability"; "the future, for our children, for us to have a peaceful sky at last"; "for peace on earth, for freedom, for our children and grandchildren to live in free country".

First Republican: 'Not even the threat of death stops our people'

"Terrible news" was said to have shaken Donetsk at dawn on the first of the main voting days, 15 March, when three children were said to have been killed by Ukrainian shelling.

"Not even the threat of death stops our people," Parafanova insisted.

DPR leader Denis Pushilin was said to have been one of the first to vote on 15 March. "It is the unchangingness of the path we have taken since 2014," he said afterwards. "It is the awareness of the value of this choice we made and continue to make. That we are voting today is our absolute involvement in the future of our country. It gives confidence and internal euphoria."

Other stories featured included:

- Pushilin visits "liberated" Avdiivka with the first deputy head of the Russian Presidential Administration, Sergei Kiriyenko; they meet some of the few remaining residents, who talk about the problems they face, including infrequent bread deliveries, and the lack of gas and fuel for generators; Kiriyenko assures them the administration is working on solving these problems: "Don't worry, everything will be fine," he says. "You've made it through, there's only a little bit left";

- the city of Volnovakha is said to be still "recovering" as it marks the second anniversary of its "liberation from Ukrainian neo-Nazis"; Russian specialists are "literally breathing life into homes, schools and streets"; around 250 housing blocks and social infrastructure facilities are said to have been restored by Russian builders; the hospital is said to be "unrecognisable" after being rebuilt by specialists from the northern Yamal-Nenets region.

Tavriya: 'Thank you, Russia, that we're with our family at last'

In a Novosti news bulletin at midnight local time on 17 March, presenter Pavel Miroshnichenko said that the final day of voting in Kherson Region passed "without incidents and strictly in line with the law".

In a report from Henichesk, a Tavriya correspondent noted that a "gastronomic festival" was held in the city centre right next to a polling station in the Moskva (formerly Ukrayina) cinema, making it "virtually impossible" to pass by without stopping. In addition, an orchestra was performing nearby. The polling station was said to be packed.

"I voted because I'm for Russia," a woman said. "My son lives in Moscow."

"I am very happy that it so happened that we will be living in a free country, where everything is done for people, for our children," another said. "Thank you, Russia, that we're with our family at last."

An election observer said everything was going "smoothly and quietly" and voters were "in a good mood".

International observers were also said to have found no violations.

"Judging by what I saw here, it was an absolutely transparent vote without pressure or propaganda," French observer Christian Ro said. "In essence, it was what can be called ideal democracy. This is what real democracy should look like."

In a report from Nizhny Syrohozy, a local resident said that everything was getting better compared to the way it was under Ukraine. The correspondent noted that the building where the polling station was located was derelict under Ukraine, but now it has a new facade and the interior has been refurbished.

Luhansk 24: 'People were happy that they were electing a real leader'

The leader of the self-proclaimed Luhansk People's Republic (LPR), Leonid Pasechnik, said at a meeting with Italian observers that the Russian presidential election in the LPR was "fair, open and without violations", Luhansk 24 reported in a news bulletin on the evening of 17 March.

The Italians were said not to have observed violations at polling stations and to have praised the "security, transparency and legality of the voting process", as well as the presence of medics at polling stations.

One of the Italians, captioned as Donato Lorenzo Tilly, praised the care taken for elderly voters and people with disabilities, including provision of ballots in braille.

"In addition, the foreigners noted the active involvement of young people in voting, which they said was not typical for European youth," the presenter added. "They said that there is a connection between generations, which gives hope of a bright future."

Another observer, Giorgio Deschi, noted that this was his second visit to Donbas and that he previously observed the regional elections in 2023.

This time he saw the same "calm atmosphere" and "accuracy, transparency and truth that I saw in September".

"I saw people who were happy that they were part of a big family, and that they were electing a real leader," he said.

(Deschi is reported to be the founder of the separatist movement Liberazione Triestina.)

The international experts were said to have debunked Italian media reports that Donbas people were forced to vote at gunpoint, and to have said Donbas elections were more transparent and correct than in Italy.

Source: BBC Monitoring 17 Mar 24

Q: London’s Metropolitan Police Service said Zeraati’s occupation, together with recent threats to U.K.-based Iranian journalists, triggered the counterterrorism probe, even though the motivation for the attack is still unclear.

“While we continue to assess the circumstances of this incident, detectives are following a number of lines of inquiry and our priority at this time is to try and identify whoever was behind this attack and to arrest them," Commander Dominic Murphy, head of the Met’s Counter Terrorism Command, said in a statement.

“I appreciate the wider concern this incident may cause — particularly amongst others in similar lines of work, and those from Iranian communities."

Iran International spokesman Adam Baillie said the stabbing was “hugely frightening." Although the channel’s journalists have been threatened in the past, this is the first attack of its kind, Baillie told the BBC.

“It was a shocking, shocking incident, whatever the outcome of an investigation reveals," he said.

Mehdi Hosseini Matin, Iran’s charge d’affaires in the UK, said “we deny any link” to the incident.

Police say they have disrupted “a number” of plots to kill or kidnap people in the U.K. who were seen as enemies of the Iranian government. Officers are working with intelligence agencies to disrupt future plots and provide protection for the targeted organizations and individuals, police said.

Early last year, Iran International temporarily shut down its operations in London and moved to studios in Washington, D.C., after what it described as an escalation of “state-backed threats from Iran.” The station resumed operations at a new location in London last September.

An Austrian man was convicted in December of attempting to collect information likely to be useful for terrorism after security guards spotted him carrying out surveillance on the former headquarters of Iran International. Magomed-Husejn Dovtaev, 31, was sentenced to three years and six months in prison.

Alicia Kearns, chair of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Commons, expressed concern that Britain still isn’t doing enough to protect opponents of the Iranian government.

“Whilst we don’t know the circumstances of this attack, Iran continues to hunt down those brave enough to speak out against the regime,” Kearns said on X, formerly Twitter. “Yet I remain unconvinced that we and our allies have clear strategies to protect people in our countries from them, and protect our interests abroad.”

Earlier this month, Foreign Secretary David Cameron condemned the conviction in absentia of 10 journalists from the BBC’s Persian service on propaganda charges against the Islamic Republic of Iran, calling it “completely unacceptable.”

“And also, when I last met the Iranian foreign minister, I raised the case of the fact that Iran was paying thugs to try and murder Iranian journalists providing free and independent information for Iran TV in Britain,” Cameron said in the House of Lords. “On both counts, in my view, they are guilty.”

Q: When asked why the Pakistani delegation arrived in Kabul just a week after Islamabad carried out airstrikes in eastern Afghanistan, Taliban commander Abdul Hamid Khorasani said: "If tensions and issues emerge between neighbouring countries, it [such visit] is used as a normal procedure to maintaining better political ties."

"I would like to point out that political ties between the two countries have been outstanding since the beginning of the one specific case [airstrikes] or even before it happened and till now. Ambassadors from both countries have been carrying out their tasks till now. But the problem [presumably refers to the airstrikes and the retaliatory attacks by the Taliban] was between the Pakistani military and military forces of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan [the Taliban de facto government]," Khorasan added.

He further said: "The Pakistani military committed a stupid act by hitting civilian targets. And they are executing the US's and West's ominous projects in the name of [fighting] terrorism... Mujahideen [Taliban fighters] and border units have given proper response [the retaliatory attacks] to their stupid action… Meanwhile, a delegation from Pakistan has arrived in Afghanistan to improve the relations, which is a normal process."

Khorasani said that although the Taliban administration has been seeking to maintain good relations with all neighbouring countries, neighbours have made "unfounded" allegations and Pakistan, which he said was not independent, implements the "West's projects". 

Rejecting the allegations that the Taliban backs and shelters militants who are hostile to Islamabad, he said: "It is a baseless allegation. There is no truth in it at all. I have always said in discussions that if Pakistani authorities have sufficient evidence to prove the presence of hideouts and bases of their opponents in the territory of Afghanistan, why have they not shared them with media outlets, people and the international community? It is a period of technology. They can bomb civilian houses, but why do they not video record the basses and share the clips with the Islamic Emirate and the international community? So, it is a baseless claim."

Concluding, Khorasani warned of serious consequences if Pakistan continues to carry out airstrikes or interfere in the domestic affairs of Afghanistan.

Pro-Taliban political commentator Hatif Mukhtar, who joined the debate at the TV studio in Kabul, insisted that Pakistan should alter its strategy and should not interfere in the internal affairs of Afghanistan. 

"Pakistan should understand that Afghanistan is not its colony. It is a free and independent country. Pakistan does not have the right to interfere in our domestic affairs. On the other hand, we interact with Pakistan in line with our national interests," he said.

"In the current sensitive, difficult and historical situation, our national interests suggest that we should have good relations with Pakistan. Pakistan should also have good relations with us. It is Pakistan which should pave the way for this to happen. As far as we are concerned, we do not interfere in Pakistan's internal affairs in any circumstances. The TTP is an internal issue of Pakistan," the pro-Taliban commentator said.

When asked what is the solution to address the problems between the two countries, Mukhtar said: "Pakistan can make investments in Afghanistan. As a brotherly and friendly country, Pakistan should not interfere in the internal affairs of Afghanistan. Pakistan should resolve the issue of TTP and Baluchis by themselves. We will never interfere in Pakistan's internal affairs. Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan has adopted a balanced, impartial and strategic policy under which we want to be friends with Pakistan. We want to have relations with Pakistan."

Source: Ariana News TV, Kabul, in Dari and Pashto 1400 GMT 26 Mar 24
