Q: “All I could see were sparks in my eyes,” said one of the soldiers, a sergeant, recounting how the pursuing drone blew up, leaving him and his team wounded but somehow still alive. He asked to be identified only by his first name, Oleksandr, according to military protocol.

Fighting on the plain in southern Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia region, where Oleksandr’s vehicle was hit earlier this year, has raged for 10 months now in two phases: first with Ukrainian forces on the offense, and now on defense, as Russia escalates attacks on the area where Ukraine gained ground in last summer’s counteroffensive.

Military analysts have described Ukraine’s strategy as “hold, build and strike” — holding the line in the country’s southeast, replenishing its units with fresh troops and hitting back with long-range drones attacks on oil refineries and military logistics targets inside Russia.

In Zaporizhzhia, this has meant defending an area created by last summer’s counteroffensive, a 10-mile-deep semicircle that presses into Russian-held territory, forming a bulge. Soldiers describe ruined villages, trenches and fields that are a moonscape of shell craters.

At the southern tip of the semicircle lies the village of Robotyne. Ukraine recaptured it last summer, in the high-water mark of a counteroffensive that not only failed to achieve a breakthrough, but left the Russians in a strong enough position to start pushing back across the southern front.

Ukrainian forces occupying that bulge in the front line can be attacked from three sides, creating a dilemma: Abandoning that pocket would ease the pressure on them, but it would also signal a symbolic setback in the war, losing territory they gained last year at a high cost in casualties and destroyed weaponry.

Interviewed last week, soldiers who recently fought there described small sways in the front in both directions, and being badly outgunned by Russian artillery. Overall along the frontline, Russia is firing seven times as many artillery shells as Ukraine, General Ivan Havryliuk, a deputy minister of defense, told Ukrainian media on Monday.

American weaponry that had been donated for the counteroffensive last year, including Stryker armored vehicles, has proved useful in protecting soldiers from these barrages now as they fight defensively.

But U.S. politics now threaten the supply of arms. A package worth about $60 billion in military and financial assistance has been stalled in Congress for months over objections from some Republicans. The Biden administration last week announced it would send $300 million in stopgap military assistance using funds remaining from previously approved aid.

Russian forces attacked the pocket around Robotyne and areas nearby nine times over the past day, the general staff headquarters said on Tuesday. When the Ukrainians captured the village last year, they pierced a main Russian anti-tank defensive line; now the Russians are trying to push them back and fill in that gap.

Like Bakhmut and Avdiivka, Robotyne, which had a prewar population of about 500 people, is now just ruins. Throughout the war, American officials have repeatedly raised concerns that Ukraine was holding out too long in defending such places, committing soldiers and ammunition to cling to devastated towns with little strategic value.

But for Ukraine, the area around Robotyne remains worth fighting for, at least for now.

“At some point, symbolic becomes strategic,” Yurii Sak, a former adviser to the minister of defense, said of the fighting. Defending the gains of the offensive, he said, is “important for morale, it’s important for the support of the population, it’s important for the inner belief in our potential to win.”

The combat is also more costly in casualties for the attacking Russians than the Ukrainians in their defensive positions, Mr. Sak said. “As long as that calculus continues, it supports holding the ground,” he said. “It’s war, so casualties are inevitable on both sides.”

Russia is now on the offensive along the entire frontline, which stretches in a 600-mile-long crescent from the Russian border in northeastern Ukraine to the southern Dnipro River. The Kremlin’s military has been using its advantage in ammunition, manpower and aviation.

Russia has swelled the ranks of its army by deploying squads of former convicts. It is buying artillery shells, missiles and exploding drones from North Korea and Iran to help replenish its supplies. Its planes avoid Ukrainian air defenses by dropping bombs from a safe distance that glide to their targets.

Just this year, Russia has dropped more than 3,500 glide bombs, Ukraine’s military said. Moscow’s electronic warfare instruments jam signals and scramble coordinates for Ukraine’s satellite-guided weapons.

The result has been a grinding advance that in February pushed Ukraine out of the small city of Avdiivka in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine. Since then, Russia has been attacking with a combination of ground assaults and aerial bombing at seven points along the front, according to Ukraine’s general staff headquarters.

In the northeast, Russian forces are pushing through pine forests toward the city of Kupiansk on the Oskil River, seeking to reverse gains Ukraine made in a counteroffensive in the fall of 2022.

In the Donbas, a region of rolling hills dotted with coal mines and factories, Russia has been pressing along four lines of attack, seeking to exploit openings created by capturing Avdiivka. Ukrainian forces say they are holding defensive positions to the west of the city, though Russia has captured several small villages as it tries to advance.

Near the southern city of Kherson, Russia has been assaulting a Ukrainian outpost across the Dnipro River, on the eastern bank, in an area otherwise controlled by Russia. Russian forces assaulted the position three times on Monday, the Ukrainian military said.

The position there is resupplied by boat and, like the bulge in the lines around Robotyne, it is precarious.

These fights are worthwhile, Ukrainian officials have said, because they cost Russia tens of thousands of soldiers killed and wounded, but there is skepticism in Washington.

“I understand the administration has been frustrated,” Evelyn Farkas, director of the McCain Institute, said, referring to the Biden administration.

“It’s unclear whether military decisions are purely military or influenced by political pressure or even direction,” she said.

At the training for Ukrainian troops fighting in the semicircular area near Robotyne, soldiers noted one advantage to the shift to a defensive strategy: fewer casualties. Russians now must leave their trenches to attack, while the Ukrainians are fighting from the cover of their positions.

Pulling back, said a private, also named Oleksandr, would merely leave Ukrainian troops fighting in other positions in similar conditions. “You need to defend every meter,” he said.

Still, it is a fierce fight in the south, over a landscape of open fields, muddy roads, ruins of farmhouses and countless blown-up vehicles, facing Russian forces on three sides.

Ukrainians have been fighting in the area long enough to give the positions they are defending nicknames like The Wheel, Silicon and Tank Trench.

Russian reconnaissance drones continually fly overhead, directing artillery or mortar fire on the soldiers. Aerial bombardments are common.

Small drones rigged with explosives and cameras buzz in regularly, chasing cars and sometimes people. The one that flew into Sergeant Oleksandr’s armored personnel carrier in January wounded everyone inside, but all survived. Last week, he was training to return to the fighting in the same area.

Q: For most of the past 120 years, the walrus has sat in the middle of the Natural History Gallery at the Horniman Museum and Gardens. The museum displays the collection of Frederick Horniman, a wealthy tea trader who lived in Victorian England.

The gallery, which in addition to the walrus holds other taxidermy animals, skeletons and insects, is being shuttered while the museum redevelops the space, with a focus on “environmental sustainability and a commitment to fighting the climate emergency,” according to the museum’s website. (The rest of the museum, which also includes a large collection of musical instruments and an aquarium, will remain open.)

When the gallery reopens, in 2026, visitors will be able to see the walrus in the same spot where they left him — sitting prominently in the middle of the room atop a fake iceberg, said Louis Buckley, a senior curator at the museum. The collection will include more context about how Mr. Horniman came to own the walrus. The museum’s website notes that Mr. Horniman’s wealth was “reliant on the exploitation of people living in the British Empire.”

“It’s an expression in many ways of the British Empire and its relationship with the colonies and Canada in particular,” Mr. Buckley said.

During his lifetime, Mr. Horniman amassed a collection of ethnographic objects, natural history specimens and musical instruments. When his collection grew too large to fit in his home, he commissioned architects to build a museum, which opened in 1901.

In the renovated gallery, the walrus will “encapsulate a lot of different themes we are exploring,” Mr. Buckley said. Other than a closer look at how Mr. Horniman’s objects arrived in the museum, climate change and humans’ relationship to nature will also be explored.

The walrus is the undeniable showstopper of the collection. It’s the only item in the gallery that’s not in a glass case.

Looking at it, however, might make a visitor feel a bit odd — as though something’s off.

“People describe it as a bit too large,” Mr. Buckley said.

Live walruses have skin folds and wrinkles. The one at the museum does not, though the marks of where those skin folds would be are visible. The walrus, Mr. Buckley said, “is fully plumped up, quite a bit larger than it would have been in life.”

Whoever originally stuffed the animal probably had never seen a walrus, Mr. Buckley said. After all, he added, “they’re difficult animals to observe up close.”

Mr. Horniman bought the walrus around 1886 from an exhibition in London. The walrus itself is probably from the Hudson Bay area of Canada, Mr. Buckley said, although it’s unknown who hunted and killed it.

On Sunday, the overriding mood at the museum was one of enthusiasm and walrus appreciation. Against the sounds of squealing — and sometimes crying — children on a rare sunny March day, visitors said they had made a pilgrimage that day specifically to say goodbye.

“We came to greet the walrus,” said Julia King, one of the visitors. It was her first time seeing the walrus in person. “He’s magnificent,” she said.

Ms. King said she enjoyed looking at the absurd things in life, and the walrus lived up to her expectations.

“He’s obviously the star of Southeast London,” said Sian Thomas, another visitor, who said she found the overstuffed animal important as a way to understand how we look at the world differently than people did in Victorian times, and how our scientific understanding has evolved.

As visitors passed by the walrus on Sunday, many of them took photos, explained the animal to their children and marveled at its size. The walrus’s total weight is unknown, but it takes at least five people to move him, Mr. Buckley said.

“I did not expect it to be so big,” said Kasia Kaniuka, a Londoner who was visiting the museum with her boyfriend because they had heard the gallery was closing. “It’s quite overwhelming.”

For Josh Alford, the gallery’s closure was also the main reason to visit on Sunday. He came to see the walrus from East London. “I expected it to be like a seal size,” Mr. Alford said. “That looks like a horse, to be honest.” (He was quick to add that the animal did look “cute enough to hug.”)

Some said they were sad the walrus would be going away for a while, many of them citing it as a family favorite. Others, who had no idea of the impending closure, were pleased with their serendipitous timing.

“I’m gutted,” said Kara Tritton, who grew up in the area and still lives there. She said she remembered seeing the walrus for the first time as a child, and the impression it made on her. Through the museum, she said, she also felt connected to her great-grandparents, who were local residents and who had most likely visited the walrus as well.

“I absolutely had to come today,” she said. “I’ll miss him. Two years will be a long time.”

Q: The authorities have ordered schools across the country shuttered since Monday because of a wave of excessive heat that is expected to last at least two weeks. Temperatures are forecast to reach 113 degrees Fahrenheit, far above the 90-degree highs typically experienced in the dry season from December to March.

Officials did not say how long the schools would remain closed. But the health and education ministries said in a joint statement that “any school that will be found opened during this time will have its registration withdrawn.”

Parents have also been urged to stop their children from playing outside and to monitor them for signs of heat exhaustion and heatstroke.

The sweltering temperatures in South Sudan, whose tropical climate includes both dry and wet seasons, are interrupting the onset of the academic year. Most schools in the East African nation, especially those outside Juba, the capital, are congested and underfunded and lack infrastructure such as air-conditioners to help withstand such heat.

South Sudan is highly exposed to severe climatic events, including droughts, floods and rising temperatures. These changes have exacerbated displacement, food insecurity and communal conflict in the nation of 11 million people, which gained independence from Sudan in 2011.

The heat wave is also expected to put pressure on the country’s nascent health care system, which has long grappled with limited financing and worker shortages.

South Sudan is not the only African country where extreme weather events have precipitated school shutdowns. In 2022, Malawi’s government shortened the school day in the southern Shire Valley because of rising temperatures. And in Uganda, severe floods have repeatedly forced the government to close schools over the years.

Yet in South Sudan, conflict, a worsening humanitarian crisis and a tense political environment have made it even harder to mitigate the turmoil of climate change.

South Sudan’s civil war has claimed the lives of some 400,000 people and displaced millions more since 2013. And although a tenuous political agreement has held between the country’s feuding leaders over the past few years, a growing humanitarian crisis and deadly rifts among forces within the ruling alliance have added to the uncertainty over whether repeatedly postponed elections will take place this year.

At the same time, the war in neighboring Sudan has forced the return of nearly half a million South Sudanese who had fled the conflict in their own country. Many have come back to towns and villages where their homes and farms have been pillaged and are finding it hard to rebuild their lives.

Emmanuel Lokosang, the head teacher at Jada Jedid Nursery and Primary School in the capital, said he hoped the weather would cool down soon so that students could resume classes.

“Juba is really hot,” Mr. Lokosang, whose school has over 600 students, said in a telephone interview Wednesday morning.

He added: “We hope they don’t delay for long, because the more we delay, the more it affects the academic calendar and how we can recover the curriculum.”

*   Juba
*   Sudan

Q: Italian company to establish bunkering facility in north

The State Trading Organisation [STO, a majority government-owned trading company] on 13 March signed an agreement with Vitol, an Italian company, to establish an international bunkering facility in Ihavandhippolhu, the Maldives Economic Gateway. Minister of Economic Development Mohamed Saeed and Minister of State for Finance Ahmed Mazin participated in a ceremony held to sign the agreement. STO's Chief Executive Officer Shimad Ibrahim and Vitol's Director Jay Ang signed the agreement on behalf of their respective companies. At the ceremony, Ibrahim highlighted that Vitol is the largest company in the energy sector in the world and that the project will deliver various economic benefits to both the company, its shareholders and for the government's tax revenue receipts. [Online, Approximate Words: 270]

[This is a prominent Dhivehi-language news website that generally carries objective reporting. It is owned by the Sun Media Group, the largest private media house in the Maldives.]

Avas

President nominates candidate for tax commissioner

President Dr Mohamed Muizzu proposed to parliament the appointment of the former heads of the Maldives Inland Revenue Authority (MIRA), Yazeed Mohamed and Hassan Zareer, for the position of Commissioner General of Taxation. Mohamed had been the commissioner general during former president Abdulla Yameen's administration, while Zareer had been the deputy commissioner general. The commissioner general position was made vacant after Fathuhulla Jameel, who had been appointed to the position on 31 October 2019, resigned to contest in the forthcoming parliament election on a ticket from opposition Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP). [Online, Approximate Words: 170]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website run by "Mundoo" Adam Haleem and owned by former lawmaker Abdullah Sinan. The website is generally critical of the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party and Jumhooree Party.]

Mihaaru

President nominates envoys for Singapore, Geneva

President Muizzu has proposed to parliament the appointment of Mohamed Luveiz as the Maldives' ambassador to Singapore and Dr Salma Rasheed as the Maldives' permanent representative to the UN Mission in Geneva. Rasheed is the sister of former member of parliament for Maafannu Medhu constituency, Asma Rasheed, who is contesting for the same seat in the forthcoming election, and also the aunt of Mohamed Hussain Shareef, who Muizzu has proposed as the Maldives envoy to the United Arab Emirates (UAE). Luveiz was the former minister of state for economic relations at the President's Office during former president Yameen's administration and had spearheaded much of that government's economic development agenda. Speaker Mohamed Aslam on 13 March announced that the nominations have been sent to the parliament committee on foreign relations for review. [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[Mihaaru is a Dhivehi-language daily that generally carries objective reporting and does not appear to favour any political party. The newspaper widely covers political developments, radicalisation, and counter-terrorism-related developments in the Maldives.]

Raajje.mv

MDP president denies links to local news website

President of the Maldivian Democratic Party (MDP), Abdulla Shahid, on 13 March denied claims of having links to local online news website Dhiyavaru. Shahid said this while responding to allegations made by Member of Parliament for Thinadhoo Dhekunu constituency, Abdulla Saneef, in parliament. Shahid also said "lying and defaming people by hiding behind parliamentary privileges is alien to the principles of democracy". [Online, Approximate Words: 200]

[This is the Dhivehi-language website of widely watched, privately-run television news channel Raajje TV that supports the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website provides detailed coverage of government actions and statements and sometimes criticises Chinese involvement in the Maldives.]

Vaguthu

Election body appoints new vice-president

The Elections Commission on 13 March appointed its member Ali Nashath as its vice-president. The commission said Ismail Habeeb's term had expired on 12 March after serving two terms, and as such, in accordance with the law, the commission had elected its new vice-president at a meeting held on 13 March. Nashath was first appointed to the commission on 25 July 2018, during former president Yameen's administration, and was re-appointed on 16 November 2023. [Online, Approximate Words: 180]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website that was founded by a youth group that favours the ruling Progressive Party of Maldives and People's National Congress and criticises politicians from the opposition Maldivian Democratic Party. The website generally backs China and strongly criticises India.]

Channel News Maldives

Democrats express support for anti-defection bill

The Democrats on 13 March said it supports approving the anti-defection bill with certain amendments. Party president and Member of Parliament for Henveiru Hulhangu constituency, Hassan Latheef, while debating the bill in parliament, highlighted its importance but said that articles in the bill on recall votes at the parliament committee stage must be revisited. He proposed amending the bill to include provisions to allow constituencies to decide on removing their representative. [Online, Approximate Words: 230]

[This is a Dhivehi-language news website formerly known as Voice of Free Press run by prominent journalist Ismail Rasheed. It carried original reporting, editorial and commentaries primarily on domestic political and socio-economic issues and does not favour Indian or Chinese involvement in the country.]

Source: BBC Monitoring in Dhivehi 14 Mar 24

Q: Bangladesh and Bhutan on 25 March expressed "deep satisfaction" over their bilateral relations and agreed to "further" strengthen cooperation, local media reported.

A joint statement issued after a meeting between Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and visiting Bhutanese King, Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, said the two countries laid "special" emphasis on "regional and sub-regional cooperation on trade and investment, energy and transport" sectors, popular English-language newspaper The Daily Star reported.

Three memoranda of understanding (MoUs) were signed on "establishing Bhutanese Special Economic Zone in Kurigram (district), setting up a burn and plastic surgery unit in Thimphu by Bangladesh, and technical cooperation on consumer rights", while an agreement on cultural cooperation was "renewed", according to the report.

Furthermore, the report said the two countries signed a Preferential Trade Agreement for "facilitating" trade and agreed to work together in the post-Least Developed Country (LDC) graduation period for "greater benefit" of their people.

Bangladesh also proposed importing hydroelectricity from Bhutan, for which a "trilateral agreement" between Bangladesh, Bhutan and India will be needed, the report mentioned.

The "focus" of the talks was on "trade, connectivity, and regional cooperation" and on "strengthening" relations, reputed English-language newspaper Dhaka Tribune reported.

During the meeting, the two sides expressed "deep satisfaction" over their bilateral relationship, which is based on "goodwill, friendship and understanding", the report added.

The joint statement was cited as saying that the four-day visit of the Bhutanese King is a "testament of the close ties of friendship and goodwill that so happily exist between the two countries". 

Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Hasan Mahmud told journalists after calling on the King that he requested Bhutan to "re-join" the BBIN (Bangladesh-Bhutan-India-Nepal Initiative) and increase "air-connectivity" between the two countries, Bengali daily Dainik Ittefaq reported.

On importing hydroelectricity from Bhutan, Mahmud said India will "assist" in this regard as it had assisted Bangladesh in importing hydroelectricity from Nepal, the report added. 

Mahmud also said the two sides agreed to enhance cooperation in the fields of "trade and commerce, connectivity, power, agriculture, education, culture, and people-to-people contact", prominent English-language business daily The Business Standard reported.

The developments received prominent and largely factual coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets. 

PM Hasina urges efforts to take country forward

Prime Minister Hasina on 25 March cautioned people over "conspiracies" against Bangladesh and urged them to unitedly take the country forward, local media reported.

In a televised address to the nation on the eve of the 54th Independence Day, Hasina "cautioned" the people about the "conspiracies" against the "independence, sovereignty and economic emancipation" of Bangladesh and urged them to take the country forward after facing "all hurdles", Bengali daily Dainik Inqilab reported.

During her 17-minute speech, Hasina also highlighted measures taken by her government during the past 15 years, which have led to "unprecedented" development in socio-economic sectors, according to the report.

Hasina was cited as saying that Bangladesh has become a "role model" of development and expressed optimism that it will become a "developing nation by 2026".

Highlighting the economic achievements, Hasina said the "poverty rate, which was 41.5% in 2006, has now come down to 18.7%", while the "extreme poverty rate, which was 25.1% in 2006, has now come down to 5.6%", the report further mentioned.

Bangladesh has now become "self-sufficient" in food production and electricity has reached "100%" of the houses in the country, she added.

She also said that the "Bangladesh Awami League will never allow ruining democracy that has been earned through the blood of thousands" and thanked the people for giving it the "mandate" to rule for the "fourth consecutive" term, the website of English-language newspaper The Daily Messenger reported.

Meanwhile, in a congratulatory message sent to President Mohammed Shahabuddin on Independence Day, Chinese President Xi Jinping said he attaches "great importance to the development of Beijing-Dhaka relations", Dhaka Tribune reported, citing the Chinese Embassy. 

Xi said he stands "ready to work" with Shahabuddin "to further advance high-quality Belt and Road Cooperation and deepen China-Bangladesh strategic partnership of cooperation", according to the report.

Furthermore, Xi noted that the friendship between the two "traditionally friendly neighbours" has "grown from strength to strength", the report mentioned.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken also sent a congratulatory message, saying that the "the United States is proud to be a partner of Bangladesh in dealing with many important issues of today, including the challenges of combating climate change, advancing economic development, responding to the Rohingya crisis, supporting peacekeeping operations worldwide, and addressing global health challenges", frontline Bengali newspaper Kaler Kantho reported.

"Our partnership plays an important role in ensuring a free, open, secure, and prosperous Indo-Pacific region," Blinken was quoted as saying.

The developments received prominent and largely factual coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets. 

Police dismiss alleged militant presence in Bangladesh 

Chief of the Counter-Terrorism and Transnational Crime (CTTC) unit of the Dhaka Metropolitan Police, Md Asaduzzaman, on 25 March "dismissed" reports saying that militants belonging to India's Islamic State (IS) wing had been in Bangladesh, prominent English-language news website bdnews24.com reported.

The alleged militants were reportedly arrested in Indian north-eastern state Assam on 19 March.

"This is my clear statement regarding reports of their arrest on their way to India from Bangladesh or their staying in Bangladesh that the environment in Bangladesh does not allow any militants. They don't have any hideout here," Asaduzzaman was quoted as saying.

He urged Indian authorities to inform Bangladesh "if they have any specifics on the location of the IS militants", the report said.

Furthermore, the report mentioned that Indian newspaper The Hindu had reported that the head of India's IS wing, Haris Farooqi, and his associate, Anurag Singh alias Rehan, were caught in Assam's Dhubri, near the border with Bangladesh, early on 19 March. 

A report by Indian news agency Press Trust of India (PTI) was cited as saying that they were arrested following inputs from an intelligence agency that they "would enter India through Dhubri from their Bangladesh hideout to carry out violence in India".  

Talks continue for release of Bangladeshi ship

Negotiations with Somali pirates were proceeding through a "third party" to secure the release of Bangladesh-flagged cargo ship, 'MV Abdullah', along with its 23 crew members, local media reported.

"We have regular communications with the pirates through a third party, but no remarkable progress has been made yet that can be shared with the media. The ransom amount has also not been fixed yet," Mizanul Islam, spokesperson of SR Shipping, which owns the ship, said, independent English-language newspaper New Age reported.

"We are continuing our efforts to rescue the sailors unhurt through peaceful negotiations. We are hopeful that the hostage situation will be resolved soon and we will be able to bring back the sailors before Eid," Islam said, according to a report by noted Bengali newspaper Bangladesh Pratidin. 

The development received limited coverage in frontline Bengali and English-language newspapers and online news outlets.

Source: BBC Monitoring in Bengali 26 Mar 24

Q: Six people have been reported killed and 86 others injured following intense Israeli bombardment of Yemen's Houthi-controlled capital Sanaa yesterday afternoon.

Rescue teams are still searching for the missing and identifying missing persons, Houthi-run Al-Masirah TV reported this morning, following the strikes which struck the presidential palace complex, energy facilities and power stations.

The Israeli army said that the strikes were carried out "in response to repeated attacks" by the Houthis against Israel.

On 22 August, the Iran-backed Houthi group claimed three attacks on Israel, including one on the country's main international airport.

Speaking to Qatar's Al Jazeera yesterday afternoon, Houthi political bureau member Hezam al-Assad said that "it pains us as we see our children, women and men in Gaza starving or their limbs and blood scattered", while vowing to continue targeting Israel until the siege is lifted and the war ends there.

Pan-Arab media split focus on Israeli strikes on Yemen

Key pan-Arab media outlets have taken different approaches in their coverage of yesterday's Israeli strikes on the Yemeni capital, Sanaa.

Al Jazeera website highlighted in a report yesterday that the strikes "did not deter the Houthis". It interviewed the deputy media chief of the Houthi group, Nasr al-Din Amer, who denied reports of a security or intelligence breach of the group.

Meanwhile, the UAE-based Sky News Arabia website cited Israeli statements in two reports, including statements by the Israeli prime minister and others by the Israeli army on the targets it hit in Yemen.

The Saudi-funded Al Arabiya website provided limited coverage of the Israeli strikes, highlighting figures released by the "health ministry affiliated with the Houthis" of the Yemeni casualties.

Saudi pan-Arab daily Asharq al-Awsat described the Israeli strikes as "retaliatory".

Palestinian factions condemn Israeli strikes on Yemen

Several Palestinian armed groups have condemned the Israeli strikes on Sanaa yesterday.

Hamas said in a Telegram statement that the strikes "constitute a blatant violation of Arab states' sovereignty and international law".

The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) said the strikes were "coordinated with the US", describing them as "a failed attempt to subjugate Yemen and halt Yemeni special operations deep inside the Zionist entity".

The Palestinian Islamic Jihad (PIJ) also said that the strikes were conducted "with full encouragement and support from the US".

The Popular Resistance Committees (PRC) said that "the barbaric Zionist attack on Arab and Islamic Yemen exposes the magnitude of the crisis facing the Zionist entity due to the ongoing Yemeni missile strikes".

Israeli army chief urges Netanyahu to take hostage deal

Israeli media highlighted yesterday that the army Chief of Staff Eyal Zamir and senior military officers had urged the political leadership to prioritise a hostage release deal, even if partial, over further military actions in Gaza.

The daily Haaretz reported that Zamir's position is that additional pressure on Hamas in the form of occupying Gaza City would take a long time, result in casualties among both soldiers and hostages, and further strain the "already heavy burden" placed on the military reserve system.

The report added that the military leadership criticised the government for not leveraging the army's achievements to secure a hostage release deal.

The Ynet news site reported that Hamas is still awaiting an official Israeli response, while Zamir's message to the political leadership is clear.

Ynet reported that the Hostages' Families Headquarters urged the government to take the deal.

The report added that despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's directive to launch immediate negotiations, no progress has been made.

Syria postpones elections in three provinces citing security concerns

Syria announced the postponement of parliamentary elections in three provinces, citing security concerns, domestic media reported on 23 August.

The Higher Committee for the Elections of the People's Assembly released a statement saying: "In order to ensure fair representation in the People's Assembly for the three Syrian governorates (Suweida, Hasaka, and Raqqa), and in view of the security challenges facing these governorates, the Higher Committee has decided to postpone the electoral process… until the appropriate conditions and a safe environment are available", state news agency Sana reported.

Deadly violence in the southern restive province of Suweida last month between Druze and Bedouin fighters led to government intervention, while clashes were also reported between defence ministry forces and Kurdish-led forces in northern Syria.

Pan-Arab media report on Syria-Israel talks

Pan-Arab media focused on the prospect of direct talks between Syrian interim President Ahmed al-Sharaa and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next month in New York, with UAE-owned Sky News Arabia reporting this morning that the US was spearheading the efforts.

The channel said that it followed positive developments from recent talks between Syrian and Israeli delegations in Paris organised by US envoy Thomas Barrack. It said that Syrian demands of a return to the 1974 disengagement agreement and Israel's demand to remain in certain strategic points in the tri-border Jabal al-Sheikh (Mount Hermon) area were still hampering a breakthrough in the talks.

Sharaa confirmed last night that talks with Israel were progressing, telling Sky News: "If a peace agreement serves the interests of Syria and the Syrian people, I will not hesitate to choose that option."

UN to vote on renewal of Lebanon peacekeeping force

The UN Security Council votes today to renew the mandate of the UN Interim Force in Lebanon (Unifil) for another year, while they work toward a gradual withdrawal, to enable the disarmament of Hezbollah, the full implementation of Resolution 1701 and to allow the army to deploy fully along the border with Israel. Unifil's mandate expires at the end of August otherwise.

Lebanon has continued to reiterate that it wishes for the peacekeeping mission to remain for at least two-three more years, French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported last night.

Security in the south remains uncertain as Hezbollah opposes forced disarmament against a backdrop of a weak Lebanese army and Israel's continued attacks across the country, violating a ceasefire it signed with Hezbollah in November.

UAE brokers new Russia-Ukraine POW swap

The UAE has announced the success of mediation efforts in a new exchange of prisoners of war (POWs) between Russia and Ukraine.

The new deal involved the swap of 292 POWs, 146 from each side, the UAE official news agency Wam reported yesterday.

The agency said the UAE, as a "trusted mediator", succeeded in mediating in 17 deals between Russia and Ukraine with a total number of 4,641 freed POWs.

It stressed the UAE's commitment to ensuring the success of all efforts aimed at achieving a peaceful solution to the conflict in Ukraine and alleviating the humanitarian consequences of the crisis.

Egyptians abroad to vote in Senate election run-off

Egyptians abroad are set to start voting today in the run-off round of the Senate election, according to Masrawy news website.

The voting will end tomorrow, while Egyptians at home will cast their ballots on 27 and 28 August.

The results of this round are scheduled to be announced on 4 September.

On 12 August, the results of the first round of the election were announced, with political parties allied with the government in Egypt winning 175 seats out of the 200 up for grabs in the round held on 4-5 August.

Coming up

The Saudi city Jeddah is set to host today an extraordinary meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) member states to discuss the "ongoing Israeli aggression against the Palestinian people".

Q: Anchor Kamran Khan said newly formed governments in Punjab and Sindh have completed the first month after their formation and noted that Maryam Nawaz has taken over the chief ministership of Punjab for the first time, while Murad Ali Shah has become the chief minister of Sindh for the third time and has been working in the province since the last eight years. However, he added, there is a huge difference between the performance of these two governments.

Khan said on one hand, Nawaz has been very active in the province and has announced several new projects but on the other, Shah has remained "absent from the scene" throughout the month. He noted Nawaz has been visiting public places and trying to solve the issues of the people.

Khan played a video report on Nawaz and Shah's activities during the past month. The report noted Nawaz has announced low-cost houses for people with low income, e-bikes and urban bus projects for the youth, and has decided to provide ration to the poor during Ramadan (month of fasting for Muslims). The report further said Nawaz has been overseeing all these projects and calling meetings on dozens of issues. It added she announced "safe city projects" for 18 cities of Punjab would be completed in the next three months and has launched an overseas property transfer service for the Pakistanis living abroad.

The report noted Sindh Chief Minister Murad Ali Shah visited south Karachi once in the last one month and inspected the condition of the rainwater drainage system there. It said apart from this, Shah was not seen in any public place. It further said meeting of the cabinet was held only once but an agreement for the Karachi safe city project was approved after a long wait of 16 years.

Scandal surrounding new federal minister

Khan said in the initial weeks of the new government in the centre, a scandal has surfaced which has created upheaval in the highly reputed Aitchison College of Lahore. He mentioned Punjab Governor Baligh ur Rehman, who is the chairperson of the board of governors of the college, ordered waiver of college fees and fine for two sons of the newly appointed federal minister Ahad Cheema. He added due to this, college principal Michael A Thomson resigned from his post. He noted in a letter, Thomson wrote that he would leave on 1 April and not play any role in management of the upcoming admissions.

Khan mentioned after the principal's resignation, Syed Babar Ali (senior member of the college's board of governors) also resigned in protest over political interference in the affairs of the college.

Tax reforms

Khan said a "historic step" is about to be taken by bringing the retail sector under the tax net as well as all other sectors which are currently not under the tax net. He mentioned traders in major cities would be registered through the Tajir Dost (trader-friendly) scheme. He noted Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif recently claimed 14,000bn rupees ($50bn) can be collected in taxes if the tax net is expanded to all the sectors.

Khan spoke with Zeeshan Merchant, an expert on tax affairs, and asked him whether the new scheme is implementable. Merchant said the focus these days is on "digitisation" and several changes are being made for this purpose. He added the question is whether any discussion was held with the traders for whom this scheme has been announced. He recalled similar schemes in past had failed and enforcement is the biggest issue due to which tax revenue has not increased in the past years. He was of the view that the scheme should be discussed with the stakeholders before its implementation and suggested that the system should be simplified as much as possible.

Crime rate in Sindh

Khan said the crime rate has "hugely increased" in the interior Sindh due to which freight containers cannot pass through the highways in the province and everything that needs to be transported upcountry remains stuck in Karachi. He added robbers loot trucks, freight containers and oil tankers on the main highways connecting Sindh and Punjab. He noted cases of shooting, robberies and kidnapping of transporters for ransom have increased in the last few months. He insisted a decisive operation against dacoits is necessary in this situation and it should be launched jointly by the Sindh and Punjab police.

Source: Dunya News TV, Lahore, in Urdu 1630 GMT 25 Mar 24

Q: The attackers were radical Islamists and Tajikistan nationals, but the attack itself has "Ukrainian fingerprints" all over it, the channels told their viewers, echoing remarks made by President Putin at a meeting with his security services.

The two channels also accused the West of trying to exonerate Ukraine despite the supposed evidence pointing to its complicity; of allowing the attack to happen by giving Moscow insufficiently specific warnings; and of being more worried about the harsh treatment of the suspects than about the innocents killed in the attack.

Putin doubles down on suggestions of Ukraine's complicity

The deadly attack against the Crocus City Hall concert venue may have been committed by Islamist radicals but all the evidence points to Ukraine as the organiser of this terrorist outrage despite Western attempts to exonerate the 'neo-Nazi Kyiv regime', President Putin suggested late on 25 March during a video conference call with the heads of the Russian security services.

Channel One launched straight into Putin's lengthy remarks at the start of its primetime news bulletin. Rossiya 1 showed them at the end of its programme as soon as the footage was ready to air. NTV missed them because its primetime bulletin comes out too early, but aired them at the start of its late-night news.

"The crime was committed at the hands of radical Islamists... But we can also see that using various channels, the United States is trying to convince its satellites and other countries that according to its intelligence, there are no Kyiv fingerprints to be found on the Moscow terrorist attack, and that the deadly terrorist attack was committed by followers of Islam, by members of ISIS... We know very well whose hands were used to commit this outrage against Russia and its people. What we want to establish is who gave the order," Putin was shown saying.

He repeated the earlier Russian claim that the suspects were supposedly heading for the Ukrainian border when they were apprehended hundreds of miles from Moscow, and hinted at Western complicity by suggesting that "those who have been fighting against our country using the neo-Nazi Kyiv regime as their instruments" may have been behind the latest attempt to "intimidate" Russia.

The same narrative was promoted by Rossiya 1 and Channel One in other reports about the terror attack.

Rossiya 1 showed a pundit claiming that the "signature" of the attack was uncharacteristic of ISIS terrorists, and that the attackers must have been recruited online by the Ukrainian secret services.

It is common knowledge that Ukraine has been actively recruiting agents in Russian territory, arming them and providing them with detailed plans for future attacks, the pundit said.

Over on Channel One, a correspondent also made much of the unsubstantiated claim that the attackers were heading for Ukraine when they were apprehended, ignoring reports that the place where the suspects were caught is much closer to the Russian border with Belarus than with Ukraine.

The Russian-Ukrainian border "is almost impossible to cross amid the ongoing special military operation", but the attackers were promised a warm welcome on the Ukrainian side of the border, the correspondent claimed.

Hints at Western complicity

Putin's latest remarks aside, the bulletins on Rossiya 1 and Channel One were rife with accusations against the West over its possible role in the attack and its conduct in the immediate aftermath.

In the headline sequence at the top of the bulletin, Rossiya 1 suggested that exonerating Ukraine was the paramount US concern at the moment.

"The West is afraid of finding out that Ukraine may have been complicit in the terror attack in Moscow. How will they live with that knowledge?" the channel wondered later in the programme.

"In the very first hours, when Russian investigators were only just starting to gather evidence and the attackers had not even been caught yet, the West had already settled on its preferred version of what had happened: Ukraine is above any suspicion, and the attack was committed by a branch of ISIS," the channel said in a tone of indignation.

It later suggested that US instructors had trained the Ukrainian secret services to commit precisely the kind of attacks that took place at the Crocus concert hall.

Another charge Rossiya 1 levelled at the West was that the Western warnings of an impending terror attack in Russia made in early March were deliberately vague and not actionable - and that the West therefore bears part of the blame.

The warning received from the US embassy in Moscow on 7 March "did not contain any details", and the White House is now refusing to offer Russia any assistance in the investigation, the channel told its viewers.

It then highlighted a clip in which a caller phones in to a French talk show and says in a Russian voiceover that the "MI6, US intelligence, and we the French are to blame for what happened because instead of telling the world about the impending threat, we were all too busy trying to destabilise Russia and Putin".

Treatment of the suspects

There was also much outrage on Rossiya 1 over the observation in the Western media that the suspects appear to have been badly beaten or even mutilated before they were paraded in front of TV cameras.

"According to reports in the Western media, they have more sympathy for the terrorists rather than the families of the victims," a Rossiya 1 presenter fulminated.

A Rossiya 1 correspondent later accused Germany's "traditionally Russophobic Bild newspaper" of trying to "portray the butchers as victims".

The channel itself made no secret of the suspects' physical condition when they appeared in court.

At one point it showed close-up footage of one of the suspects in court while a correspondent remarked on a huge and untidy bandage covering the man's right ear.

The channel made no mention of the graphic footage circulating on pro-Kremlin Telegram channels (and discussed with apparent approval by some of the top Russian newspapers) on which the suspect's ear is seen being deliberately cut off after he was apprehended.

Source: BBC Monitoring in Russian 1900 GMT 25 Mar 24

Q: En este reportaje en video, varios bomberos y residentes de Quilpué y Viña del Mar dijeron a los reporteros de The New York Times que la escasez de agua obstaculizó los esfuerzos para salvar casas y detener el avance del fuego, lo que los obligó a tener que salir de algunos sectores de ambas ciudades.

El incendio forestal —el más mortífero de la historia de Chile, con 134 muertos y miles de casas destruidas— ardió fuera de control casi desde el principio, impulsado por unas condiciones climáticas extremas, fuertes vientos y árboles inflamables.

Según los bomberos y los residentes, la falta de agua empeoró las cosas.

Chile, un país inmerso en una prolongada sequía, se enfrenta a continuos problemas de abastecimiento de agua para combatir los incendios forestales en zonas urbanas.

En la región de Valparaíso, que incluye Viña del Mar y Quilpué, los expertos en incendios forestales afirman que el desarrollo desordenado ha hecho que las ciudades y pueblos sean especialmente vulnerables a los incendios forestales.

“Es un problema de oferta y demanda”, dijo Miguel Castillo, profesor del Laboratorio de Incendios Forestales de la Universidad de Chile, quien trabaja con las ciudades en medidas de prevención de incendios forestales.

“Esta agua muchas veces no está disponible para el combate”, dijo y agregó que el problema había persistido durante años en la región. “Ese problema ahora aumentó”.

Esval, la empresa privada que suministra agua a la región de Valparaíso, negó que hubieran problemas con los hidrantes en la zona del incendio y afirmó que el sistema local de agua trabajó a plena capacidad.

Mientras el fuego hacía estragos, Esval dijo que había reducido el suministro de agua fuera de la zona del incendio para reforzar la presión del sistema.

Daniel Garín, un funcionario con experiencia, quien ha trabajado durante 13 años en el cuerpo de bomberos de Quilpué, le dijo al Times que los problemas de presión del agua y los hidrantes fuera de servicio ya existían antes del incendio de febrero.

A principios de enero, después de que un supermercado se incendiara en Viña del Mar, el jefe de bomberos de la ciudad, Patricio Brito, declaró a una estación de televisión local que no había agua en los hidrantes, diciendo: “La verdad es que el agua en este sector es nulo, nulo”.

Un diputado local, Andrés Celis Montt, dijo que era necesario investigar y solucionar el “grave problema” con los hidrantes antes de la temporada alta de incendios forestales, que en Chile suele durar hasta abril.

El 2 de febrero, en el barrio El Olivar de Viña del Mar, Yanet Alarcón dijo que vio con impotencia cómo el fuego se acercaba y la manguera de agua que estaba usando para rociar su casa de dos pisos se secó. Tuvo que huir, y su casa fue consumida por el fuego.

“Cuando yo pasé todavía había una llama aquí. Había llamas adentro, de hecho focos de llamas dentro”, dijo Alarcón entre lágrimas.

En Quilpué, Mauricio Miranda dijo que los bomberos no habían podido encontrar agua en los hidrantes cercanos y se quedaron detenidos esperando a que llegaran suministros mientras su casa ardía.

“Cuando llegamos después del incendio, la casa estaba consumida y no había nada de agua dentro. Eso significaba que los bomberos no tiraron agua”, dijo.

Miranda y una decena de familias del barrio de Canal Chacao dijeron que tenían previsto reunirse con Esval para solicitar una indemnización, alegando que el hecho de que la empresa no suministrara suficiente agua a los hidrantes provocó la destrucción de sus hogares.

Arijeta Lajka y Kristen Williamson colaboraron con este reportaje.

Brent McDonald es corresponsal sénior de video para el Times en Washington. Produce cortos documentales, reportajes en video e investigaciones visuales. Más de Brent McDonald
A:

*   El Olivar (barrio en Viña del Mar)
*   Canal Chacao (barrio en Quilpué)
*   Washington (donde trabaja Brent McDonald)

Q: In “The Killing” (“Forbrydelsen”), which put Danish TV on the map and made Grabol a star back in 2007, the country’s justice system was held together by her morose detective, Sarah Lund. In her two most recent series, Grabol expands her public-service portfolio. In “The Shift” she plays Ella, the head midwife at Copenhagen’s best public pediatric hospital. And in “Prisoner” she’s Miriam, a reform-minded guard at a prison threatened with closing. Whether she is catching Denmark’s murderers, delivering its babies or minding its inmates, Grabol is indispensable.

To follow Grabol’s progress through the Danish infrastructure, the American viewer will need the streaming service MHz Choice (free trials currently available), which carries “The Shift” (2022) and premiered “Prisoner” (2023) this week. The three seasons of “The Killing” are on the streamer Topic, which will merge with MHz Choice on April 1, consolidating this segment of Grabol’s catalog. (She also plays a public official in the eerie British series “Fortitude,” available on multiple streamers.)

The shows centered on Sarah, Ella and Miriam are quite different — “The Killing” is a lurid crime thriller, “The Shift,” a big-hearted medical soap opera, “Prisoner,” a grim social-problem drama — but the characters have much in common.

Each is aggrieved but indomitable, a working-class Sisyphus pushing ahead through institutional neglect and cowardice — a very squeaky wheel at work — while weighed down by personal trauma. Each is estranged from the only close family member still in her life; two become reluctant surrogate mothers to the women their troubled sons get pregnant. Perhaps Grabol has been typecast over the years, or has typecast herself. Or maybe the grouchy, standoffish, self-righteous pain in the butt is a character that resonates in Denmark.

Grabol is an economical actor, able to communicate a world of emotion through her liquid eyes and seemingly offhand movements. (She’s also blessed with a notably dramatic pair of eyebrows.) She makes all of these bottled-up, difficult women believable and, even when they push everyone away, sympathetic — you can see the layers of pain and weariness that they shelter behind and occasionally break through.

The shows share a sensibility with Grabol’s performances; they are unflashy, meticulously made, superior examples of their genres. (“The Killing” was a trendsetter in transferring the outré violence of 1990s movie murderers into TV, but it presented their offenses with a Nordic reserve.)

“The Shift” is a forthright hospital melodrama, and there’s even an amusing twist on “Grey’s Anatomy” in which Ella is followed around the hospital by her mother, an orderly who breaks into meetings to pester her daughter about her health and love life. The mostly female midwives serve the dramatic function that nurses often do in American stories, putting up with and bailing out the mostly male doctors. The show’s theme is the chronic understaffing of midwives in the public hospital, while its running motif is the staff’s obsession with food, from the critical attention paid to the pastries in the break room to the prescribing of toast and tea for all noncritical medical issues.

But in the hands of its creator and showrunner, the talented director Lone Scherfig (“An Education”), “The Shift” (the Danish title translates as “Day and Night”) has a winning sincerity and humor; it isn’t cloying, and it doesn’t traffic in bad outcomes to gin up emotion. Tricky story lines — a midwife who doubts herself when she’s gaslighted by a struggling doctor, another who sees her patients through the lens of her own history of abuse — are handled delicately. Ella fights for more midwives and finds herself pregnant at 46 (by a married doctor), but she’s chipper and funny, and Grabol gets to show a slightly softer side.

“Prisoner,” created by Kim Fupz Aakeson with Frederik Louis Hviid and Michael Noer and written by Aakeson (who, in the small world of Danish TV, wrote two episodes of “The Shift”), takes the critique of the country’s social welfare in a much darker direction. It is structured as a tragedy: Three guards at a failing prison all have fatal vulnerabilities — a secret love life, a junkie son with debts, a friendship with an inmate — that drag them down into a tense and cleverly worked-out spiral of lies and vengeance.

Grabol is primary in the ensemble of “The Shift,” but in “Prisoner” the attention is evenly split among her, Youssef Wayne Hvidtfeldt as the idealistic new guard Sammi and David Dencik as the compromised veteran Henrik. It’s largely Dencik’s show. Henrik, who vacillates between surly anger and puppy dog neediness, is the most interesting character, and Dencik (“Tinker Tailor Soldier Spy,” “Chernobyl”) is terrific.

The beat-downs, drug runs, racial animosities and inevitable spasm of group violence are all familiar, but in its six fairly tight episodes, “Prisoner” makes them credible and achieves a fair measure of the documentary-style grittiness it goes for. Grabol’s Miriam goes down some dark roads — she’s not the justice-obsessed grind of “The Killing” or the dedicated crusader of “The Shift” — but her heart is in the right place. Denmark is still lucky to have her.
A:

*   Copenhagen's best public pediatric hospital

*   Britain (from "British series")

Q: When a recession did arrive, in 2020, it was because of the Covid-19 pandemic.

But four years later, Australia has been unable to shake off some of the headwinds, including a high cost of living — the price of bread has risen 24 percent since 2021 — a choppy labor market and rising inequality. While these and similar issues are also troubling nations like Britain and the United States, they are particularly stinging to many in Australia, which has long seen itself as the “lucky country.”

Australia is among the wealthiest, most resource-rich and stable countries in the world. But millions of residents are experiencing levels of hardship not seen in many decades. They say they are struggling to put food on the table, pay for housing and health care and cover their utility bills. And many young Australians are confronting a reality that their ancestors never had to: that they will be worse off than their parents or grandparents.

Robyn Northam, 28, once dreamed of becoming a hairdresser. But rising rent and exorbitant child care costs for her two children have put training out of reach. Just two generations ago, she said, her grandmother raised a family in her own home as a single parent, while working part-time as a nurse.

“If you’re an average Australian, that’s virtually impossible,” said Ms. Northam, a content creator in Cairns who, with her partner, pays 600 Australian dollars, or about $400, a week in rent. “It’s a totally different world now.”

Australians are paying more for almost everything. The pandemic ushered in soaring inflation, which has since softened, though at 3.4 percent it remains relatively high. Rents in some Melbourne neighborhoods are up almost 50 percent year-over-year, and rental affordability is at its lowest in at least 17 years. Consumer sentiment has barely budged since tumbling in 2020.

Homeowners are also under pressure. Australian mortgages are generally fixed for a few years at a time, and as the central bank has tried to rein in prices by raising interest rates, rates have tripled to 6.7 percent in recent years.

This strain has resulted in a spike in working families seeking support. Over 16 years, said Dave McNamara, the chief executive of Foodbank Victoria, “through bush fires and pandemics, I have not seen anything on the scale that we’re currently experiencing of people from all walks of life needing food relief.”

“Things are a lot worse than they were prepandemic, and there’s little inspiration for us to be optimistic,” said Nikki Hutley, an independent economist in Sydney. “Everyone’s doing it really tough.”

Economists have long argued that too much Australian wealth is tied up in the housing market, even as shoddy policy, construction shortages and high immigration have brought an already low housing supply to a crunch point.

Polling by the think tank Per Capita last year found that fewer than one in four Australians who did not own a home expected to be able to do so. “That’s not necessarily the be-all and end-all, if you’ve got a really stable rental system,” said Ms. Hutley, “but we have terrible laws in this country.”

Australian renters have fewer protections than in most other wealthy nations. Though laws vary between states, landlords have relatively few constraints on how much they can raise rent; renters face regular “inspections” of their homes; and the government offers large tax concessions for landlords.

A shortage of rentals has also sent rents skyrocketing in some neighborhoods, pushing young people farther and farther out of cities. In Sydney, the exodus of young families, one recent report warned, risks creating a “city with no grandchildren.”

Talitha Vermeulen, 25, has been looking to move within that city with her partner for the last four months. Often, available properties are leased before viewings can even occur, she said. “It’s just been frustrating to not even get a chance to see the place.”

With its wealth, stability and natural resources, Australia has more advantages than most other nations — life expectancy rates and wages are still among the world’s highest, with wage growth outstripping inflation last year. The stock market is trading near record levels.

Yet it is not evident that it is living up to its ample potential, said Julianne Schultz, an academic and the author of “The Idea of Australia.” “The thing that I keep coming back to is: It could be so much better,” she said, adding: “It’s a sort of lack of ambition.”

Though Australians often proudly refer to “the lucky country,” the comment by the academic and writer Donald Horne was originally intended as one of reproach to the country’s leaders, whom he saw as incurious and unimaginative.

And despite the country’s plentiful bounty and its oft-stated love of egalitarian values, Australia’s wealth is increasingly unevenly distributed, as the nation joins the ranks of others confronting rising inequality and economic and generational strains.

Economic unhappiness has translated to the lowest levels of “life satisfaction” since records began 22 years ago, according to the Australian Unity Wellbeing Index. The high cost of living, troubling global politics and rising inequality are all contributing factors, said Kate Lycett, the lead researcher. “It’s a huge number of people who are struggling to make ends meet,” she said.

On a recent Monday morning, people waited outside a food bank at a church in Richmond, a neighborhood of Melbourne. The food bank helps more than 100 households, and demand has increased sharply over the last six months, said Francis Flood, the coordinator.

“We’ve seen a lot of people who work but can’t make it through to the end of the month,” he said. “We’re definitely helping people who, if you saw them on the street, you wouldn’t think would be using a food bank.”

Even some who own their homes outright are struggling. Tracey Shepherd, 60, lives a short walk from the beach, in picture-perfect Surfers Paradise, Queensland. A former public servant, she has health issues that have made finding permanent work a struggle, and she is surviving on her retirement savings while she awaits a decision on a disability benefit.

With the high price of groceries and increases in maintenance fees on her apartment, life feels precarious, she said. “When I was younger, they’d say we’re the lucky country. It’s not like that now.”

Q: Vladivostok residents have been visiting the monument to victims of political repressions to pay tribute to opposition leader Alexei Navalny who died in a penal colony, PrimaMedia news agency reported. His photo appeared at the monument, people came and brought candles, carnations and roses. Police present at the monument took down personal details of those who came to the monument explaining it by security considerations. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 17 Feb 24)

'Patriotic' motor rally

On 13 February, PrimaMedia news agency reported on the course of a "patriotic" motor rally from Vladivostok to Russia-occupied Luhansk, organised by the regional branch of the Russian Historical Society and the association of indigenous peoples of the Far North, Siberia and the Far East. Two cars are participating in the motor rally and they have already passed Tomsk, Barnaul and Novosibirsk. On their way the motorists met representatives of regional branches of the Russian Historical Society and People's Front and picked up some humanitarian aid collected for participants in "the special military operation" in Ukraine. In Novosibirsk, the rally participants met students of the Novosibirsk State Teachers' Training University and told them about the purpose of the rally. (PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 13 Feb 24)

Crime

A Vladivostok court has given a CPRF activist a suspended sentence of one year, OTV Prim TV reported on 15 February. Maxim Chikhunov used a tube from a grenade launcher to imitate shooting at a plate to monarchist and leader of the White Movement in Siberia and the Far East Mikhail Diterikhs back in 2022. The prosecutor's office is not content with the sentence as it asked for five years in prison and plans to appeal against the verdict as too lenient. (OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 15 Feb 24; PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 15 Feb 24)

Presidential envoy visits Vladivostok

Presidential envoy to the Far Eastern Federal District Yuri Trutnev has arrived in Maritime Territory on a working visit, OTV Prim TV reported on 15 February. Trutnev discussed the implementation of major investment projects with the regional authorities. As of today there are over 2,000 investment projects with state support being implemented in the region.

Over 10 years a total of 718bn roubles has been invested in projects in the region, Trutnev said and recalled: "Ten years ago we started work on the development of the Far East with the setting up of a system of attracting investment. I am sure that now it is key to economic and social development. Thanks to this we have managed to exceed the majority of indicators of economic growth compared to an average level across Russian regions".

Maritime Territory is among the leaders in the Far East based on the attraction of investments and creation of new jobs, OTV Prim TV continued the next day. A lot of investment projects are linked to the development of Maritime Territory's logistics potential which is especially important now in the light of Russia's turn to the east. The new reality requires the expansion of transport corridors and introduces new requirements for ports, roads and other infrastructure, Trutnev said.

The participants also discussed the implementation of projects in shipbuilding, agriculture and tourism, which envisage the investments of 290bn roubles. (OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 15 Feb 24; PrimaMedia news agency, Vladivostok, 15 Feb 24; OTV Prim, Maritime Territory Public TV news, 16 Feb 24)

Source: BBC Monitoring 18 Feb 24

Q: Last week, the Russian authorities said that said six suspected IS fighters were killed in an anti-terrorist operation following a clash in the town of Karabulak in Ingushetia on 2 March. They said that the men had been behind an attack on a traffic police post and the killing of three police officers in March 2023.

On 10 March, the pro-IS Telegram channel "Tafa'ul Mustamir" (Constant Interaction) shared the 02:46-minute video. It was subsequently promoted by another prominent pro-IS media outlet, "Bariqa News Agency".

The video features one man who holds a rifle, with the trademark black IS banner behind him, as he "renews" his pledge of loyalty to IS leadership.

He delivers his message in very good Arabic, but with a slight accent, indicating he is not a native speaker of the language. The video does not indicate the date of recording.

While the speaker does not identify himself nor speaks about any specific events in the clip shared online, the post by Tafa'ul Mustamir identifies him as "Abd al-Karim al-Ingushi [from Ingushetia]". It says he and his "brothers" (fellow militants) "died fighting the criminal Russian authorities in Karabulak, Ingushetia"

The speaker, however, does indicate that he is a member of IS's so-called Caucasus Province branch, which is one of the least active of IS's global affiliates. The last time that branch claimed an attack was on 28 December 2020, when it said one of its militants killed a police officer in Chechnya.

The message

In the short video, the speaker says "we the mujahidin of the Caucasus wilayah [IS branch]" urge IS's "caliph", Abu Hafs al-Hashimi al-Qurashi, to be resolute on the path of jihad and "be fair on all matters". He tells him to "march on", assuring him "there are men behind you [who have your back]".

Following from that, he "renews" his pledge of allegiance to Abu Hafs.

The speaker then turns to address "our brother mujahidin everywhere, particularly those in Syria, Khorasan [Afghanistan-Pakistan region] and Africa", expressing his "love" and "solidarity".

He also tells his fellow jihadists in these branches to avoid divisions and differences, adding that "we must be like a single body against the infidels".

It is unclear if this was general advice against disunity, or implies possible internal divisions across some branches. The same goes for the advice to Abu Hafs to be "fair to all" and firm on the path of jihad, and whether that too was general advice or implied some deeper meaning.

The speaker concludes his message by addressing male and female prisoners affiliated to IS, telling them "we have not forgotten about you nor ever will", adding that "freeing you is our priority".

Such messages to IS-linked prisoners is a staple of IS leadership addresses, which often tell the group's followers worldwide to make the freeing of prisoners their "topmost priority".

IS itself has not shared the latest video nor indicated any involvement in the 2 March clashes in Ingushetia.

Source: Telegram messaging service in Arabic 2128 gmt 10 Mar 24

Q: Secretary of the Supreme National Security Council (SNSC) Ali Larijani this morning arrived in Lebanon following a two-day visit to Iraq.

Before departing, Larijani told reporters that "the Resistance is part of the fabric of the people of the region" and called it to be supported.

Iran refers to the pro-Iranian groups across the region as the "Axis of Resistance", or simply the "Resistance".

Ahead of Larijani's departure, some Iranian outlets highlighted Lebanese users on X apparently welcoming him with pro-Iranian hashtags.

Hassan Kazemi Qomi, a former ambassador to Iraq (2006-10) and ambassador to Afghanistan (2022-24), told Iranian state TV yesterday that the US and Israel seek to disintegrate regional states like Syria, Iraq and Yemen, and that "Resistance groups are the only obstacle".

He also said accusations that Iran commands "proxy forces" are false. Groups like Hezbollah defend their nations, while Israel "is the West's true proxy for destabilisation", he said.

Kazemi Qomi also said demands to disarm "Resistance" factions aim to clear the path for US-Israeli domination, but "regional peoples will never accept surrender or partition".

Online anger after government spokesperson downplays Zangazur corridor

Iranian online users criticised government spokesperson Fatemeh Mohajerani who during a news conference yesterday, pointing to the map, dismissed concerns regarding the so-called Zangazur corridor, saying it was just a "little part" of Iran's borders.

A prominent anti-establishment user said on X she would say the same about three islands in the Gulf, controlled by Iran and claimed by the UAE, maintaining that "reformists" do not care about national interests.

Hardline users were equally critical of her, with one saying that "it would be no surprise if tomorrow they declare the Persian Gulf a small, insignificant speck of water".

A hardline journalist said that "Iran is losing the war of corridors".

Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi yesterday told his Armenian counterpart Ararat Mirzoyan by phone that the new route agreed in the recently signed US-brokered Armenia-Azerbaijan deal "must not cut Iran's access to other communication routes".

Iranian outlets also cited Armenian media as saying yesterday that President Pezeshkian would visit Armenia on 18-21 August in the wake of the deal.

Police say Iran arrested 21,000 during Israel war

Police spokesman Brig Gen Saeed Montazerolmahdi said yesterday that 21,000 individuals were arrested during the 12-day Iran-Israel war in June. He did not say how many were released.

Montazerolmahdi added that the police detained 2,774 undocumented foreign nationals, uncovering 30 special security cases from their phones. They also arrested 261 people suspected of espionage, and held 172 individuals for unauthorised filming.

Iranians react to Netanyahu's address on water issues, call for uprising

Many Iranians have reacted to a video posted on X on 12 August by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In it, he addressed Iranians in English, saying Israel will share water desalination technology with Iran as soon as Iran is "free", and calling on them to take risks for their future and hit the streets in protest.

"I stand with you, Israel stands with you, the entire world stands with you," he says in the video with Persian subtitles, concluding the address with a phrase "Iran for Iranians" in Persian.

A prominent anti-establishment user said Netanyahu's address implied that a "resumption of clashes" between Iran and Israel was expected in a very near future.

Another anti-establishment user claimed that Iran has suffered a defeat in propaganda war much worse than in the battle, as Netanyahu "has turned himself into the most popular non-Iranian political figure among the Iranian people".

Meanwhile, some pro-establishment users pointed to Israel's own drought problems.

One user, referring to Netanayhu's remarks on helping Iran with the water problem, published a photo of thirsty Palestinian children drinking water from a pipe, while hardliners used the chance to blame pro-reform President Massoud Pezeshkian for the water issues.

Prominent hardline conspiracy theorist Aliakbar Raefipour warned that the message meant Israel will now "activate the internal and border unrest that they failed to provoke during the 12-day war".

Coming up

Chief of the South African National Defence Force Gen Rudzani Maphwanya is on a visit to Iran. He has already met Iranian Army Commander Maj Gen Amir Hatami.

"I don't know of any legal restrictions. The operational use of the Polish army is foreseen in NATO plans, it is a NATO issue. It is not a matter of our bilateral relations, it is a NATO matter," the army chief said. "As far as I know, the task of the Polish army is clearly defined on our territory as well, and I do not see any problem with that."

In his words, Poland, like other NATO countries, is guided by all the articles of the North Atlantic Treaty, including Article 5.

"There is no doubt that we will stand together anywhere, if necessary. (...) And on the issue of sending troops, they will be here," Rupsys said.

The Dragon 2024 exercise is aimed at testing allied ability to carry out deterrence and defence tasks by countering aggression by a potential enemy against NATO countries and conducting combat operations combining land, air and maritime components.

The exercise is one of the components of this year's NATO Steadfast Defender 2024 exercise.

According to the Lithuanian army, the centerpiece operation of Dragon-24 is the deployment of the Very High Readiness Joint Task Force to assist an ally in the event of aggression, which will also highlight the nuances and potential challenges of military mobility across national borders. When the exercise ends, the German enhanced Vigilance Brigade battalion will relocate for continued training in Lithuania as of March 7.

A platoon from the Lithuanian army's Iron Wolf Infantry Brigade's reconnaissance company with JLTV all-terrain vehicles is currently participating in the exercise in Poland. In total, 20,000 troops and 3,500 pieces of military equipment from ten NATO countries are participating in the exercise.

The exercise is taking place in Lithuania amid a debate on whether Poland's own laws would allow it to defend Lithuania in the event of an attack on it.

Lithuanian Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte said last week that Poland's legal restrictions "do not impose an obligation" to send troops abroad, even in the event of war, which would also apply in the event of an attack on neighbouring Lithuania.

Later, the prime minister added she did not mean that "the Poles will not defend us", but rather that she was referring to specific legal constraints, which she was seeking to resolve with Poland at the "political level". The prime minister also said that she could not specify which restrictions she was referring to.

Speaking earlier in the day, Kestutis Budrys, an adviser to Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda, said that a defence plan for the Suwaiki Corridor was drawn up back in 2022, and Polish troops would also defend the territory in Lithuania, so there is no legal restriction on it.

Nauseda said on Monday that join Lithuanian-Polish army exercises were meant to make sure that both countries act together.

For his part, Polish Prime Minister Donald Tusk, who visited Lithuania on Monday, said that Lithuanian-Polish solidarity was unquestionable. He also added that the Polish and Lithuanian foreign and defence ministers would soon "decide on all the details so that there are no communication issues and uncertainties", to avoid speculation on the issue.

NATO's Article 5 stipulates that an armed attack on one or more of allied countries will be considered an attack on all of them. According to this article, all NATO members must agree to take action to help the attacked ally. However, any action requires the agreement of all NATO countries.

So far, this article has been activated once, in 2001, after the September 11 terrorist attacks in the US.

Source: Baltic News Service, Tallinn, in English 1349 gmt 5 Mar 24
A:

*   Poland
*   Lithuania
*   Suwaiki Corridor
*   US
*   Tallinn
