Q: Pero la decisión sobre la fecha se produce un mes después de que el más alto tribunal del país excluyera de la votación a la principal candidata de la oposición, lo que hizo que muchos se preguntaran hasta qué punto serán unas elecciones libres y justas.

Sin embargo, el anuncio del gobierno del presidente Nicolás Maduro implica al menos un cumplimiento parcial del compromiso adquirido con Estados Unidos de celebrar comicios este año a cambio del levantamiento de las sanciones económicas paralizantes.

En octubre, Maduro firmó un acuerdo con la oposición del país y se comprometió a trabajar por unas elecciones presidenciales libres y justas. En el acuerdo, Maduro dijo que celebraría elecciones antes de finales de año, y Estados Unidos, a su vez, levantó algunas sanciones como muestra de buena voluntad.

Pero pocos días después, Maduro vio cómo una candidata de la oposición, María Corina Machado, ganaba más del 90 por ciento de los votos en las elecciones primarias organizadas por la oposición, que no tuvieron la participación del gobierno. Los decisivos resultados acentuaron su popularidad y plantearon la posibilidad de que pudiera derrotarlo en unas elecciones generales.

Desde entonces, el gobierno de Maduro inhabilitó a Machado para postularse, por lo que considera como irregularidades financieras ocurridas cuando era diputada nacional, y ha detenido a varios miembros de su campaña. En los eventos de Machado, se han presentado hombres en motocicleta que han atacado a sus simpatizantes.

La flexibilización temporal de las sanciones estadounidenses al sector del petróleo y el gas expira el 18 de abril, y el gobierno de Joe Biden podría optar por volver a imponerlas.

El anuncio del martes “deja meridianamente claro que Venezuela no celebrará elecciones libres y justas este año” y “prácticamente garantiza que el gobierno de Biden volverá a imponer sanciones”, declaró Geoff Ramsey, experto en Venezuela del Atlantic Council, institución de investigación con sede en Washington.

El chavismo, el movimiento de inspiración socialista que lidera Maduro, ha controlado Venezuela durante 25 años. En 2013, Maduro llegó al poder tras la muerte de su predecesor, el presidente Hugo Chávez, y se mantuvo en el poder tras unas elecciones celebradas en 2018 cuyos resultados se consideraron ampliamente fraudulentos. A esas elecciones siguió un periodo de aislamiento internacional, en el que muchos países siguieron el ejemplo de Estados Unidos y se negaron a hacer negocios con Venezuela.

La fecha de las próximas elecciones, el 28 de julio, es el cumpleaños de Chávez. El anuncio se produjo en la fecha de su muerte, el 5 de marzo.

Phil Gunson, analista de International Crisis Group quien está radicado en Caracas, la capital del país, dijo que es probable que esa decisión busque aprovechar el legado de Chávez para reforzar la capacidad de elección de Maduro, quien es profundamente impopular.

Los candidatos de la oposición tienen hasta el 25 de marzo para inscribirse. No está claro si el partido de Machado intentará insistir en su candidatura o si buscará apoyar a otro candidato.

Es probable que una oposición fragmentada pueda ser una ventaja para la candidatura de Maduro.

“La combinación de una oposición dividida, una fuerte abstención y unos oponentes débiles le da la mejor oportunidad de ganar sin tener que cometer fraude”, dijo Gunson.

The right-wing Channel 14's political correspondent Tamir Morag cited sources familiar with the matter as saying that "Israel will not compromise on a partial deal."

Morag added that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seemed "eager to launch the military move and is pressing the IDF to bring forward the timetable".

We will publish a briefing.

Syrian and Israeli officials meet in Paris

Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad al-Shibani met an Israeli delegation in Paris yesterday, Syrian media reported.

Syrian state news agency Sana reported yesterday that the meeting had focused on "several issues related to supporting stability in the region and southern Syria".

The report said that the meeting had been held with US mediation as part of diplomatic efforts to "enhance security and preserve its unity and territorial integrity".

Meanwhile, Istanbul-based Syria TV highlighted a meeting between US Special Envoy Thomas Barrack and the spiritual leader of the Druze community in Israel, Mowafaq Tarif, in Paris yesterday.

The cleric posted on his Facebook page that he and Barak had discussed "issues related to Suweida", where deadly clashes have occurred in recent weeks between Druze and Sunni tribal forces.

Syrian state news agency reboots

The Syrian state news agency Sana has relaunched this morning with a "new look".

The agency, which was a key source of government news under the Assad government, has undergone "a comprehensive restructure" to renew infrastructure, "recruiting new talent and adopting a digital transformation plan", according to the state-run Al-Ikbariyah al-Suriyah TV channel.

According to Sana's director general, the news agency will be opening bureaux abroad and providing content in a number of foreign languages, including English, French, Spanish, Turkish and Kurdish.

The site appears to have ceased publishing news in Hebrew, Russian and Farsi. There did not appear to be new content overnight.

Sana continues to maintain a presence on various social media.

Lebanese PM meets Jordanian king

Lebanese Prime Minister Nawaf Salam met Jordan's King Abdullah II in Amman yesterday, where talks focused on bilateral relations, regional security, and reforms in Lebanon.

Lebanese state-run NNA reported that during the meeting Salam described Lebanese-Jordanian ties as "strategic" and thanked Amman for its "continued support, particularly for the Lebanese army and in international forums".

He also briefed the king on government efforts to "reactivate state institutions through reforms and strengthen security, sovereignty and stability". He has been actively pushing for the handing over of Hezbollah weaponry to the Lebanese military.

Salam condemned Israeli actions in Gaza and Benjamin Netanyahu's remarks on "Greater Israel", calling them a "direct threat to Arab national security".

He referred to the 2002 Arab Peace Initiative, which calls for normalisation and an Israeli withdrawal from occupied territories, and insisted that Syria should retain its territorial integrity.

We will publish a briefing.

Maronite patriarch condemns Hezbollah

Lebanon's Maronite Catholic patriarch, Cardinal Beshara Boutros al-Rahi harshly criticised Hezbollah, accusing the group of "emptying the resistance of its true meaning" and subordinating Lebanon to Iran.

He dismissed Hezbollah leader Naim Qassem's recent remarks as "escalatory rhetoric" and insisted "there will be no civil war in Lebanon."

He added that the Lebanese army "protects all Lebanese without distinction" and urged Hezbollah to embrace its "Lebaneseness."

Q: The bill passed by 400 votes to 10, with a handful of abstentions, and now the legislation goes to the Senate. If it passes there, and if Thailand’s king approves it, the country will become the first in Southeast Asia to recognize same-sex marriages. In Asia more broadly, only Taiwan and Nepal have done so.

Thailand’s bill describes marriage as a partnership between two individuals, rather than between a woman and a man. It will also give L.G.B.T.Q. couples equal rights to various tax savings, the ability to inherit property and the power to give medical treatment consent for partners who are incapacitated. The draft will also grant adoption rights. Thai law currently allows only heterosexual couples to adopt, although single women can adopt children with special needs.

“The amendment of this law is for all Thai people. It is the starting point to create equality,” Danuphorn Punnakanta, a lawmaker who chairs the lower house’s committee on marriage equality, told Parliament. “We understand that this law is not a universal cure to every problem, but at least it’s the first step toward equality in Thai society.”

The legislation has been more than a decade in the making, with obstacles stemming from political upheaval and disagreements as to the approach to take and what to include in the bill. In December, Parliament passed four proposed draft bills on same-sex marriage; one was put forward by Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin’s administration, and three additional versions by the Move Forward Party, the Democrat Party and the civil sector were considered. These four were combined into a single draft that was passed on Wednesday.

“This is the greatest victory,” said Nada Chaiyajit, a law lecturer at Mae Fah Luang University, Chiang Rai, who has supported the law from its beginnings. “We have been working hard with the committee. This is not only about L.G.B.T.I.Q., this is about everyone. Equality.”

Thailand is one of the most open places in the world for L.G.B.T.Q. people, though some elements of its Buddhist-dominated culture are socially conservative.

Q: The remarks also contrasted with an internal White House review of the administration’s decisions which found that President Joe Biden’s decisions had been “severely constrained” by previous withdrawal agreements negotiated by former President Donald Trump and blamed the military, saying top commanders said they had enough resources to handle the evacuation.

Thirteen U.S. service members were killed by a suicide bomber at the Kabul airport's Abbey Gate in the final days of the war, as the Taliban took over Afghanistan.

Thousands of panicked Afghans and U.S. citizens desperately tried to get on U.S. military flights that were airlifting people out. In the end the military was able to rescue more than 130,000 civilians before the final U.S. military aircraft departed.

That chaos was the end result of the State Department failing to call for an evacuation of U.S. personnel until it was too late, Milley and McKenzie told the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

“On 14 August the non-combatant evacuation operation decision was made by the Department of State and the U.S. military alerted, marshalled, mobilized and rapidly deployed faster than any military in the world could ever do,” Milley said.

But the State Department's decision came too late, Milley said.

“The fundamental mistake, the fundamental flaw was the timing of the State Department,” Milley said. “That was too slow and too late."

In a lengthy statement late Tuesday, the National Security Council took issue with the generals' remarks, saying that Biden's hard decision was the right thing to do and part of his commitment to get the U.S. out of America's longest war.

The president “was not going to send another generation of troops to fight and die in a conflict that had no end in sight,” the NSC said. “We have also demonstrated that we do not need a permanent troop presence on the ground in harm’s way to remain vigilant against terrorism threats.”

The statement said the president and first lady still mourn for those lost at Abbey Gate and are “enormously proud of the men and women of our military, our diplomats and the intel community who conducted that withdrawal,” the NSC said.

In the hearing, which was prompted by a lengthy investigation by the House Foreign Affairs Committee into the decisions surrounding the evacuation of Kabul, McKenzie spoke at length about his discomfort in how little seemed to be ready for an evacuation, even raising those concerns with Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin.

Evacuation orders must come from the State Department, but in the weeks and months before Kabul fell to the Taliban, the Pentagon was still pressing the State Department for evacuation plans, McKenzie said.

“We had forces in the region as early as 9 July, but we could do nothing" without State ordering the evacuation, McKenzie said, calling State’s timing “the fatal flaw that created what happened in August.”

“I believe the events of mid and late August 2021 were the direct result of delaying the initiation of the (evacuation) for several months, in fact until we were in extremis and the Taliban had overrun the country," McKenzie said.

Milley was the nation's top-ranking military officer at the time, and had urged President Joe Biden to keep a residual force of 2,500 forces there to give Afghanistan's special forces enough back-up to keep the Taliban at bay and allow the U.S. military to hold on to Bagram Air Base, which could have provided the military additional options to respond to Taliban attacks.

Biden did not approve the larger residual force, opting to keep a smaller force of 650 that would be limited to securing the U.S. embassy. That smaller force was not adequate to keeping Bagram, which was quickly taken over by the Taliban.

The Taliban have controlled Afghanistan since the U.S. departure, resulting in many dramatic changes for the population, including the near-total loss of rights for women and girls.

The White House found last year that the chaotic withdrawal occurred because President Joe Biden was “constrained” by previous agreements made by President Donald Trump to withdraw forces.

That 2023 internal review further appeared to shift any blame in the Aug. 26, 2021, suicide bombing at Hamid Karzai International Airport, saying it was the U.S. military that made one possibly key decision.

“To manage the potential threat of a terrorist attack, the President repeatedly asked whether the military required additional support to carry out their mission at HKIA,” the 2023 report said, adding, “Senior military officials confirmed that they had sufficient resources and authorities to mitigate threats.”

___

AP White House Correspondent Zeke Miller contributed to this report.

Q: DAY 1,268 OF RUSSIAN INVASION OF UKRAINE

Five principles to end war

Yesterday President Volodymyr Zelensky and European leaders agreed on five principles to end the war in Ukraine, the Suspilne public broadcaster reported on its website. It noted that the decision was taken on the eve of the 15 August Trump-Putin talks in Alaska.

The principles are as follows:

1. Anything concerning Ukraine must be discussed with Ukraine.

2. Preparations should be made for a trilateral format of talks (Zelensky-Trump-Putin).

3. A ceasefire and security guarantees for Ukraine.

4. Russia cannot have veto power over Ukraine's EU and Nato membership prospects.

5. Sanctions pressure on Russia will have to be ratcheted up if it does not agree to a ceasefire during the Alaska talks.

"Ukraine and its European partners have agreed on five joint principles regarding peace negotiations and conveyed them to US President Donald Trump," the Ukrainian president's official website commented.

For his part, Zelensky voiced confidence after virtual talks with Trump and European leaders that a ceasefire in Ukraine should become a key subject of the Alaska summit.

Reaction to principles

The five principles did not go down well with some Ukrainian commentators.

"Zelensky, Trump and EU leaders agreed on the five principles for talks with Russia. Trump and principles... Trump and agreed on... They are like kids upon my soul!" journalist Raul Chilachava said on Facebook.

"And what will happen to Donbas? To Kramatorsk, Druzhkivka and Slovyansk? No information," blogger and army serviceman Yuriy Kasyanov posted on Facebook.

"Zelensky's new 'peace formula', 'peace summit', 'security guarantees' and 'victory plan' rolled into one," an X user commented sarcastically.

Coalition of the Willing

Zelensky hailed the outcome of the sixth meeting of the Coalition of the Willing.

"Together with our partners, we supported the efforts of US President Donald Trump to end the war, stop the killings, and achieve a just and lasting peace. I am grateful to the partners for our shared position: the path to peace cannot be determined without Ukraine, and negotiations can only yield results if they take place under a ceasefire," he said on X in English.

"During the meeting, we coordinated the next steps and agreed to continue working in close contact between Ukraine, all of Europe, and the United States. I thank everyone who is working to bring this war to a just end."

Situation near Dobropillya

The situation around the population centre of Dobropillya, Donetsk Region, where Russian advances were reported in the past days, remains a major media story.

The spokesman for the Dnipro operational-strategic group of forces, Viktor Trehubov, told Suspilne on 13 August that the situation near Dobropillya "is tense but under control", with Ukrainian forces seeking to encircle the Russian forces.

"As of now, reserves have been deployed to hold back and annihilate the Russians there. Work is being carried out to encircle, squeeze out and annihilate them. Competent forces have been deployed, although, in my opinion, the very fact of this situation is quite unpleasant," Trehubov said.

The 1st Azov Corps of the National Guard of Ukraine, which has been reportedly deployed to the Dobropillya area, said on Telegram late on 13 August that "the enemy is suffering significant losses" as a result of "actions" carried out by it and other units.

"As a result of the fighting, 151 occupiers have been liquidated in the corps' area of responsibility. Over 70 invaders have been wounded. Also, eight Russian servicemen have been taken captive over this period," Azov said.

An analyst with the DeepState OSINT project, Roman Mykula, struck and upbeat note in an interview with the Apostrof TV.

"As for Dobropillya, the situation is currently improving. Defence forces are seeking to stabilise the situation, and as soon as one can report the results, of course, everything will be put on the [DeepState] map," he said.

The head of the Ground Forces Reservists' Council, Ivan Tymochko, said that "countermeasures are being taken" near Dobropillya, the TSN.ua website reported. Tymochko predicted that the situation "will become more understandable" by the end of the week.

Situation in Sumy Region

In Sumy Region, the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU) "have liberated three villages and advanced by hundreds of meters over the past day", the pooled TV service said this morning in an upbeat report captioned "The front in Sumy Region: the AFU is liberating territory".

Military expert Serhiy Bratchuk was shown saying that Ukrainian forces had carried out "some successful operations" and forced Russian troops to retreat to the border. He also voiced hope that eventually "we will see a better situation on the battlefield".

The TV noted that some 25 Ukrainian population centres are currently in the "active combat zone".

"Some villages have been completely destroyed," it added.

War update

There were 148 combat engagements between Ukrainian and Russian troops on 13 August, the Ukrainian General Staff reported on Facebook the following morning.

The Pokrovsk sector was the hottest spot on the front line in Ukraine, with 56 Russian attacks reported there.

Fourteen clashes were reported in the Novopavlivka sector, 14 in the Siversk sector, 13 in the Lyman sector, seven in the Toretsk sector, six in the Northern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Sumy Region) and the Kursk sector, five in the Southern Slobozhanshchyna sector (covers parts of Kharkiv Region), four in Kherson Region, three in the Kramatorsk sector, three in the Kupyansk sector, one in the Orikhiv sector and one in the Hulyaypole sector.

Russia carried out two missile and 87 air strikes using four missiles and 154 glide bombs, and shelled Ukraine 5,758 times, including 82 times with MRLS. Russian forces also used over 4,400 kamikaze drones.

Ukrainian aviation, rocket and artillery troops hit eight Russian clusters of personnel and materiel, two artillery pieces, a fuel-and-lubricant depot, a command post and a radar, the General Staff added.

Zapad 2025

The number of Russian troops already deployed to Belarus ahead of the Zapad (West) 2025 drills "is not big", the Ukrinform news agency quoted the spokesman for the State Border Service as saying.

However, Andriy Demchenko noted that there is still a month before the start for the war games, and Ukraine keeps closely monitoring the situation.

"What must concern us the most [...] is the data about forces Russia can deploy to Belarus. It will determine the threat to our country," he said.

He also warned that Russia may use the drills to force the Ukrainian command to deploy additional forces to the Belarus border.

Q: The Hamas-run Government Media Office (GMO) issued a lengthy statement on Telegram yesterday which it said "refuted the Israeli occupation's false narrative" about the attack on Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis in southern Gaza on 25 August.

Israeli media reported that the "double-tap" attack that killed 20 people in Gaza had targeted a camera placed on the hospital's balcony and used for observing Israeli forces.

The statement argued that the camera had belonged to cameraman Hossam al-Masry, who had been killed in the attack, and it was "clearly visible like the sun… broadcasting live for media outlets".

The GMO denounced Israel's "criminal tactic", saying that the second strike on the hospital had "intentionally hit" civil defence teams, journalists and humanitarian workers, "most of whom were killed in the second strike, not the first one".

Israeli media highlight mass protests

Israeli media this morning continued to cover yesterday's mass protests calling for the release of hostages being held in Gaza.

The Ynet news site reported that the hostages' families and protesters had condemned the government for postponing discussion of a hostage deal.

The outlet highlighted a backlash by the families following reports that ministers had shortened a cabinet meeting in order to attend a "lavish" dinner.

Ynet quoted a hostage family member as saying: "Instead of sending an urgent delegation to negotiations, they discussed expanding the operation [in Gaza] and hurried off to celebrate at dinner."

Right-wing pro-Netanyahu Channel 14 reported last night said that the protestors had disrupted its broadcasting from the "Hostages Square" in Tel Aviv in a "threatening manner", and called the act "anarchy".

Qatar says Israel has not yet responded to Gaza deal

Spokesman for the Qatari foreign ministry Majed al-Ansari yesterday said that Israel had not yet provided any official response to the latest Gaza ceasefire proposal presented by the mediators.

He noted that Hamas had earlier announced its approval of the new proposal "which largely aligns with previous Israeli demands", Qatari foreign ministry quoted him as saying in his weekly press briefing.

Ansari said that the "ball is now in the Israeli court", adding that Qatar was urging "international parties to exert pressure on Israel to respond to the mediation proposal".

In an early morning bulletin, the UAE-based Sky News Arabia highlighted the Israeli security cabinet's "ignoring a discussion of the mediator's proposal to stop the war".

US envoy comments spark condemnation in Lebanon

US Special Envoy Thomas Barrack's scolding of journalists during a press conference in Beirut has been widely criticised by Lebanese media outlets.

Prominent Lebanese broadcaster MTV reported yesterday that Barrack had described the behaviour of journalists during the press conference as "animalistic" and reportedly told them to "shut up for a moment" and be "civilised".

MTV said that his comments had been "met with widespread rejection and criticism".

His press conference came following a meeting between a US delegation and Lebanese President Joseph Aoun, amid discussions over the possible disarmament of Hezbollah.

State news agency NNA reported that the Lebanese presidency had issued a statement expressing "regret" over the "words that were unintentionally uttered".

Iranian hardliners have also seized on Barrack's words. Separately, Saudi-owned Asharq al-Awsat published an interview with Iranian Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi in which he insisted that Iran was not interfering in Lebanon, and saying that it was against the break-up of Syria.

We will publish a briefing.

Israeli drone strike in Syria kills six soldiers

Syrian media have confirmed that six Syrian soldiers were killed in an Israeli drone strike south of Damascus yesterday.

Syrian state-run news channel Al-Ikhbariyah al-Suriyah reported that the strike had targeted an area near the town of al-Kiswah, 13 kilometres south of the capital.

The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights noted that the drones had targeted the vicinity of Matleh in Rif Dimashq province on the road between Damascus and the Druze-majority province of Suweida, stopping the movement of traffic on the road.

Al-Ikhbariyah reported that a civilian had also been killed in a drone strike yesterday in the village of Taranja (also Turnejeh) to the southwest, inside the buffer zone that formerly separated Israeli and Syrian forces in the Golan Heights.

On 25 August, the Syrian foreign ministry described as a "dangerous escalation" an Israeli military incursion in the same area.

See also our Turkey Watchlist for coverage of Turkish condemnation of the strikes and President Erdogan's calls for Kurdish forces to join the Syrian military.

Houthi media spotlight missile attack on Israel

Houthi-run media highlighted a reported missile attack from Yemen targeting Israel late last night.

The group's Al-Masirah TV said a missile fired from Yemen had caused "disturbances in occupied Palestine", pointing to Israeli media reports.

The Israeli military said that its air force had intercepted a missile launched from Yemen, adding that alerts had been activated in the country in accordance with protocol.

Al-Masirah said that "millions of settlers" had rushed to shelters, and that operations at Ben Gurion Airport had been halted.

The outlet also shared a video which it said showed the missile flying over Israel.

It added that the group was expected to issue a statement on the attack "shortly".

Coming up

- US special envoy Steve Witkoff said in an interview with the US right-leaning Fox News network that President Trump would host a meeting today at the White House during which a "very comprehensive plan" for post-war Gaza will be discussed. Witkoff's remarks during the interview were widely reported by mainstream Israeli media, including the Ynet news site and public broadcaster Kan.

Voting for Egyptians abroad also spanned two days and concluded yesterday. The final results are due to be announced on 4 September. During the first round of voting, political parties allied with the ruling authorities won 175 seats out of 200.

Q: Zulfiqar spoke with Aminullah Kakar, deputy commissioner of inland revenue in Quetta, and asked him to explain the Tajir Dost scheme. Kakar said it is a scheme to bring small traders in the retail sector under the tax net. He noted even though traders and shopkeepers contribute to the economy of the country, they have no contribution in the taxes. He mentioned first the retailers would be registered and then tax collection would be started from 1 July.

Kakar said other sectors like agriculture and service sector are also not included in revenue collection and the government is now trying to bring them under the tax net. He noted the government has made the system easier for traders. He emphasised "tax culture" should be promoted in the country and said automation and digitisation of the tax collection system are needed.

Zulfiqar asked journalist Mehtab Haider about the objective of the tax scheme for retailers. Haider said similar schemes were introduced in the past as well and this time a new effort has been made to launch a "simple and easy" scheme. He mentioned the registration process would begin from 1 April and tax collection would be started from 1 July. He noted the number of retailers in Pakistan is around 3.5 million and the scheme is being launched in six major cities in its first phase. Talking about Pakistan's plan to float the Panda Bond, he said the government has decided to tap into the Chinese market by launching these bonds.

Zulfiqar asked Nawabzada Riaz Nosherwani, chief executive officer of the Royal Minerals Company, to comment on the new tax measures. Nosherwani said taxation is a "two-way traffic" and noted the mining business in Balochistan is the highest contributor to the revenue. He mentioned raw materials like iron ore, manganese, and chromite are exported and the government collects additional taxes on this export. He appreciated the government for finally announcing some steps to support the mining sector.

Nosherwani said the government's focus is more on foreign investment and argued that consortiums of local investors should be encouraged because foreign investors take money out of the country. He noted lengthy bureaucratic procedures and lack of continuity in policy are the major hurdles for foreign investors in Pakistan. He was of the view that Pakistan should try to look at other countries besides China for investments in the country.

Zulfiqar asked Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) politician Sakina Abdullah Khan how her party views the situation of terrorism in the country and how far the National Action Plan against terrorism approved in 2014 has been implemented. Khan said the 20 points of the National Action Plan include clauses regarding "criminal justice". She noted security agencies take action and catch militants, but the justice system is not able to punish those elements, so they are released. She insisted these "flaws in the mechanism" require changes through legislation.

Khan noted "terror groups" have been banned but they re-emerge with new names. She further noted Islamic seminaries have been registered and regulated but there is a need to bring changes in the curriculum of mainstream schools as well. She said websites of the banned groups have been blocked but freedom of expression of other people should not be curtailed in this process. She appreciated the new Chief Minister of Balochistan Sarfraz Bugti (PPP member) for having an "excellent experience" as the home minister of the province and managing it well.

Q: On Friday, an American jury in Federal District Court found Mr. Hernández guilty of conspiring to import cocaine into the United States and of possessing and conspiring to possess “destructive devices,” including machine guns.

After the verdict was delivered, Mr. Hernández, who faces a mandatory prison term of at least 40 years and is scheduled to be sentenced on June 26, rose to his feet and stood quietly with folded hands as the jurors filed from the courtroom.

During his first presidential campaign in 2013, Mr. Hernández, a member of the right-wing Honduran National Party, portrayed himself as a law-and-order candidate who could stem the epidemic of drugs and crime that had suffused the country.

But according to prosecutors in the United States, Mr. Hernández was allied with the same forces he purported to oppose. A string of witnesses testified during a conspiracy trial in Manhattan that Mr. Hernández’s political success was fueled by drug proceeds funneled to him by cocaine traffickers whom he treated as business partners.

Prosecutors have said that Mr. Hernández received millions of dollars from trafficking organizations in Honduras, Mexico and elsewhere, including from Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, who was a Mexican drug lord and the former leader of the Sinaloa Cartel. In return, prosecutors added, Mr. Hernández allowed vast amounts of cocaine to pass through Honduras on its way to the United States.

He boasted that he would “stuff the drugs right up the noses of the gringos,” according to U.S. prosecutors.

Evidence and testimony presented during Mr. Hernández’s trial painted a dismal picture of a country where drugs and politics had long been intertwined and people working in politics routinely demanded and accepted bribes.

Rows of benches in the trial courtroom were filled each day with Hondurans who said they had come to watch Mr. Hernández face a judicial process of the sort some doubted could have taken place in his home country.

Some of those spectators laughed derisively when Mr. Hernández, wearing a businesslike dark suit, testified near the end of the trial, insisting that he had no connection to drug trafficking and that the witnesses who had testified to the contrary were “professional liars.”

A defense lawyer expanded upon that idea during his summation, running through a list of crimes — including a total of 224 murders — associated with several former traffickers who took the stand as government witnesses.

“This was a cast of characters you have never seen before and the likes of which you will never see again as long as you live,” the lawyer, Renato Stabile, said. “Through the trial these people have told you they were liars. They have told you they were murderers.”

But a prosecutor, Jacob H. Gutwillig, told jurors that Mr. Hernández had accepted “cocaine-fueled bribes” from cartels and “protected their drugs with the full power and strength of the state — military, police and justice system.”

Although former foreign leaders sometimes go to trial in the United States, they are not often prosecuted for drug-related offenses. The closest parallel to Mr. Hernández is Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the former leader of Panama, who in 1992 was found guilty in federal court in Miami of allowing the Medellín drug cartel to ship cocaine through his country to the United States in exchange for millions of dollars in bribes.

By the time Mr. Hernández stepped down from the presidency in 2022, he was a deeply unpopular figure in Honduras. His administration had done little to blunt the effects of crime or to create a stable economy, leading many citizens to leave the country. Mr. Hernández’s successor as president, Xiomara Castro, accused him of having turned the nation into a “narco-dictatorship,” and thousands of Hondurans celebrated when he was extradited to New York three months after leaving office.

There were celebrations outside the courthouse in Lower Manhattan, too, after the guilty verdict was announced. Dozens of people waved Honduran flags and chanted in Spanish. One woman held aloft a sign that read: “No clemency for narcopolitics.”

Photographs of people who were said to be victims of cartel violence were displayed along with an orange prison jumpsuit with handcuffs connected by a long chain.

Standing in the middle of the crowd, Carlos Hernandez, 32, said he had left Honduras while he was still a teenager to escape the violence and poverty there.

“This is historical,” he said of the verdict. “This brings the Honduran people a sense of justice they have been fighting for for a long time.”

Mr. Hernández’s trial was relatively straightforward, based mainly on testimony from witnesses, including a Honduran drug investigator and the former traffickers, including two men who said they had pleaded guilty to grave crimes and are facing potential life sentences in American prisons.

The investigator, Miguel Reynoso, testified that he was present when the Honduran authorities stopped a group of vehicles with hidden compartments and found firearms, grenades and nearly $200,000 in U.S. currency wrapped in plastic. The authorities also found notebooks with Mr. Hernández’s initials that prosecutors in Manhattan said detailed drug transactions.

Mr. Reynoso testified that the notebooks were placed into sealed plastic bags and that he brought those, seals intact, to prosecutors in the United States in 2019.

Among the former traffickers who took the stand was Amilcar Alexander Ardon Soriano, who testified that he had served as the mayor of the municipality of El Paraíso while running drugs, participated in torture and murdered two people, and that he was responsible for the deaths of more than 50 others. He said that he had asked lawmakers whom he had previously bribed to vote for Mr. Hernández as the president of the Honduran Congress. In return, Mr. Ardon said, Mr. Hernández promised to protect him from prosecutors.

Mr. Ardon added that he gave $500,000 in drug proceeds to Mr. Hernández’s presidential campaign in 2013 and had bribed people in El Paraíso to vote for him. He also said it was his understanding that El Chapo had agreed to provide that campaign with $1 million.

Devis Leonel Rivera Maradiaga, a former leader of the brutal Honduran gang Los Cachiros, was probably the most notorious witness to take the stand. He began secretly working with American authorities a decade ago and admitted to being involved in the deaths of 78 people, including two journalists and an official who was serving as Honduras’s antidrug czar.

In 2012, Mr. Rivera testified, he had bribed Mr. Hernández with $250,000 delivered to his sister, Hilda, in exchange for protection of the Cachiros.

Asked by a defense lawyer whether he felt any remorse over the people he had harmed, Mr. Rivera replied that he was sorry for everything he did as a member of what he called “a dangerous gang,” including his payment of bribes to “corrupt” police officers and politicians.

“They should have tried to catch us,” he said, adding that instead “they allied with us.”

Nate Schweber contributed reporting.

Q: Speaking on the private Shamshad TV's Tawda Bahsona (Heated Discussions) talk show on 19 March, Kamran Aman, a Kabul-based commentator and former colonel, described the strikes in Khost and Paktika provinces as a "blatant and shameless aggression by the Pakistani army".

"The Afghan nation should give a decisive response to it," he said.

Aman called on clerics to issue a "fatwa [islamic verdict] of jihad against the enemy", saying that "it is obligatory on the entire nation to defend their land and dignity."

"Aggression should be responded with aggression," the commentator further said.

When asked against whom jihad is obligatory, Aman said: "Against any country which encroaches into Afghan territory and kills Afghans - even if it is one Afghan."

He lauded the Taliban's retaliatory ground attacks but called on the group to set up a national committee to strengthen unity and prepare plans to tackle future attacks by the neighbouring country.

"Yesterday, they did what they could – Well done. I wish I had been there at that time as well. We are awaiting the order of the honourable defence minister to say - Afghans, come out for the war," he said, answering a query about his thoughts on the Taliban's retaliation.

In reply to a question about the consequences for Pakistan, if it repeats attacks in the future, the former colonel said: "It would have a very heavy price for the Pakistani nation – a price they would end up paying for the actions of a few of their government authorities."

Commenting on the military capability of the two countries, Aman lauded the "high morale" of Taliban forces, saying that Pakistani forces have "rockets but lack faith and morale".

Another Kabul-based commentator, former Taliban ambassador to Pakistan Mawlawi Abdul Salam Zaeef, also called for unity among Afghans but suggested diplomatic efforts to resolve the issue with Pakistan.

"We should never get into a fight with Pakistan," he said. "There must be a reciprocal reaction to an action, but not more than that. Moreover, efforts should be stepped up for national unity," he added.

Zaeef warned Islamabad to "realise that Afghanistan is not a geography which would submit to others' orders", adding: "The use of force is a futile attempt here. There must be mutual respect instead."

He blamed the current economic crisis in Pakistan on its "despotic army", saying that it has political and security issues with all its neighbours, including Afghanistan, India, Iran and China.

The former Taliban diplomat further said that by attacking Afghanistan, the "despotic" Pakistani army "wants to divert Pakistani people's attention from its failures, incompetence and political instability in Pakistan".

When asked about the international community's "silence" on the Afghan-Pakistan tensions, Zaeef accused other countries of trying to "use" the deterioration of relations between the neighbouring countries as a tool to put pressure on the ruling Taliban, but advised the group to contemplate about its priorities, including engagement with the world, education and "nation building".

Asked whether Pakistan would change its policy towards Afghanistan, he said that Islamabad's approach towards Kabul will "never change as long as Pakistan's military is its policy-maker."

A commentator from Germany, Torialay Zazai, also urged the Taliban to strengthen internal unity and "encourage national mobilisation against Pakistan."

He called on the Taliban leadership to "retaliate to one bullet with 10", adding that "now the situation is not for dialogue". Zazai accused Pakistan of "trying to show to the world that there is no stability in the region", saying that Islamabad "wants to extract money from the international community" on the Afghan issue.

"If the world wants to eliminate terrorists in the world, they should partition and isolate Pakistan. This will free the world of terrorism," he further said.

Another Kabul-based commentator, Shahzada Massoud, also called on the Taliban to strengthen national unity.

"The most urgent thing the Islamic Emirate [Taliban administration] needs to do at the current juncture is to convene a traditional Loya Jirga [traditional grand assembly of elders] and decide on all issues, including engagement with the international community," the commentator said.

According to him, the ruling group should do some of its "homework", including lifting their ban on women's education, which he believed was crucial for their international recognition. Describing Pakistan's air strikes as a "blatant violation of Afghanistan's national sovereignty", Massoud said: "This was not their first attack, neither would it be the last. Pakistan has often shelled Kunar, Paktia, Paktika."

"Pakistan is weak at the moment, although we wish it was not so. Its economy is stagnating, and political stability is worsening. In other words, what remains of Pakistan now is just its skeleton," he said, answering a question about the consequences for Pakistan.

Source: Shamshad TV, Kabul, in Pashto 1740 GMT 19 Mar 24

Q: Israeli media this morning discussed Canada's announcement that it will recognise a Palestinian state, subject to several changes it is demanding from the Palestinian Authority (PA) including holding elections.

The website of Channel 12 News said the move was part of a "political rift against Israel".

The main headline on the front page of the mass circulation daily Yediot Ahronot said: "This is how we lost the world", calling recent international moves to recognise a Palestinian state a "political tsunami that is only intensifying".

Meanwhile, PA President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the move, thanking Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney in a phone call. A statement by the official Palestinian news agency Wafa also mentioned holding elections, which would be the first time in nearly 20 years.

Hamas has not yet been observed to respond to Canadian or UK plans to recognise a Palestinian state.

We will file a briefing.

Witkoff reportedly in Israel for meeting with Netanyahu

US Middle East special envoy Steve Witkoff will reportedly meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel today to discuss the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip and prospects for a ceasefire deal after weeks of stalled talks.

An unnamed political source told Channel 12 News: "The window of opportunity for a deal is now closing. Israel will not be patient for long."

According to Channel 12 News, Witkoff might also visit Gaza to assess aid centres run by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF).

Meanwhile, several videos circulated on social media showed US healthcare workers in Gaza calling on Witkoff to visit hospitals in the Palestinian territory to see conditions there.

Director general of the Gaza-based health ministry Munir al-Barsh also invited Witkoff to Gaza, saying: "Come and witness what siege, bombing, and starvation have done."

Egypt warns against 'campaign' to undermine its support for Gaza

Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly has warned against a "systematic campaign to undermine and distort Egypt's role in the Palestinian cause", emphasising that Egypt remains committed to delivering humanitarian aid.

His remarks yesterday followed statements attributed to the Central Emergency Committee in Gaza and carried by pan-Arab outlets that said Egypt's official statements about the entry of aid into the strip "do not reflect reality". The committee urged Cairo to publish statistics for aid entering Gaza through the Rafah border crossing instead of "creating the illusion of solidarity".

The Egyptian army spokesperson said in a statement yesterday that four military aircraft took departed to air drop tonnes of food aid in Gaza. Domestic media also reported that a fourth humanitarian aid convoy reached the Karm Abu Salem crossing, adding that Israeli delays have slowed the entry of life-saving supplies.

Pro-government pundits spoke with pan-Arab media to defend Egypt's position, with one political analyst accusing the outlawed Muslim Brotherhood of taking part in the campaign.

We will file a briefing.

Israel strikes missile base on Syrian coast

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported a series of explosions overnight at a missile store near the coastal town of Jableh.

The SOHR, a reliable monitor of the Syria conflict, posted footage of the blast at the army's 107 Brigade base in the Zama area.

Immediately following the fall of the Assad government in December, Israel targeted aircraft and weaponry across Syria, and have since carried out multiple further strikes.

The new Syrian authorities have cautiously engaged with Israel since taking power.

The Israeli military has not yet commented on the strike.

We will be watching for further reaction.

Hezbollah chief says group's weapons exist to resist Israel

Chief of the Lebanese group Hezbollah, Sheikh Naim Qassem, said in a speech last night that its weapons are for "resisting Israel" and are not intended for domestic use.

His remarks, relayed by the Hezbollah-run Al-Manar TV, come against the backdrop of calls, spearheaded by US efforts, for the group to lay down its weapons.

"Today, everyone who is demanding the handing over of weapons is demanding that they be handed over to Israel," Al-Manar TV quoted Qassem as saying.

Qassem described the group's weapons as a "force for Lebanon", saying "we are ready to discuss how these weapons can be part of Lebanon's strength".

He also accused US special envoy Tom Barrack of using threats in order to help Israel.

Coming up

Syrian Foreign Minister Asaad al-Shibani will meet his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, in Moscow today, the Istanbul-based Syria TV reported. The outlet cited Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Vershinin as saying that Shibani and Lavrov will hold "very extensive" talks on trade and political relations.

Vershinin further said that "contacts regarding Russian bases in Syria are ongoing", adding that the Russian bases "are a stabilising factor in the region and play a humanitarian role in Syria".

Syria TV described the visit as "the most significant development in relations" between the new Syrian government and Russia.

Q: Defense lawyers needed permission from the judge, Scott McAfee of Fulton County Superior Court, to pursue an appeal, and he granted it in a two-paragraph order. Whether it slows down the election interference case against Mr. Trump and his 14 co-defendants remains unclear.

The Georgia Court of Appeals must still decide if it will weigh in on whether Ms. Willis has an untenable conflict of interest stemming from a romantic relationship she had with a lawyer she hired to run the Trump case, and on other related matters.

Judge McAfee wrote in his brief order that he “intends to continue addressing the many other unrelated pending pretrial motions” while the higher court decides what to do.

If the appeals court declines to take up the question, the matter will be resolved quickly. If it decides an appeal is warranted, the matter could take months to clear up.

In a statement, Jeff DiSantis, a spokesman for Ms. Willis’s office, said that prosecutors would continue to work on the case.

“As the case is not stayed during the appeal, this office will work to move it forward to trial as quickly as possible,” Mr. DiSantis said. “We will limit our comment on the appellate matter to what we file with the Court of Appeals during the briefing process.”

Steven H. Sadow, Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer in Georgia, called the order “highly significant” in a statement on Wednesday, adding that the defense was “optimistic that appellate review will lead to the case being dismissed and the D.A. being disqualified.”

No trial date has been set in the broader case; the district attorney’s office had sought to begin a trial in early August, about a year after Ms. Willis brought charges, but few expect that to happen now.

The case charges Mr. Trump and a number of his allies with conspiring to circumvent the will of Georgia voters in 2020. But the details of the case have been overshadowed this year by hearings delving into a romantic relationship that Ms. Willis had with Nathan J. Wade, the lawyer she hired to run the Trump case.

Last week, Judge McAfee ruled that Ms. Willis and her office could continue leading the prosecution so long as Mr. Wade stepped away from it. Defense lawyers, who brought the relationship to light in court filings, had sought to disqualify Ms. Willis, saying she had an untenable conflict of interest.

Judge McAfee disagreed, but rebuked Ms. Willis in his ruling for a “tremendous lapse in judgment.” He also found an “appearance of impropriety,” which he said required Mr. Wade to withdraw in order for Ms. Willis to keep the case.

Mr. Wade resigned from his post as a special prosecutor hours after the ruling on Friday.

Under Georgia law, the defense lawyers now have 10 days to file an application to the appeals court arguing why an appeal is necessary. The district attorney’s office will have 10 days from the filing of that application to respond.

The appeals court will have 45 days from the defense filing to say whether it is going to take the case or not.

Q: A two-bedroom, two-bath industrial loft entered through a private courtyard near the Canal de l’Ourcq

This two-bedroom loft is in the vibrant La Villette district, formerly a neighborhood of slaughterhouses in northeast Paris that has been undergoing redevelopment since the 1980s. The 136-acre La Villette Park, with concert halls, museums, theaters, event spaces and other cultural venues, is less than 10 minutes away on foot. A comparable walk in the other direction arrives at the Bassin de la Villette, the largest artificial lake in Paris, and a bohemian area offering shops, restaurants and bars, boating and other attractions.

There are cafes, groceries, shops and parking garages in the immediate area. Metro stops in the area include Crimée, Ourcq and Corentin Cariou, with the trip to central Paris typically taking less than 30 minutes.

Size: 1,959 square feet

Price per square foot: €710 ($777)

Indoors: This commercially zoned loft has the feel of a townhouse on three levels. The front door opens to a landing overlooking a light-filled living area with 18-foot industrial-style glass ceilings. The space has a slightly raw feel with metal beams, skylights and exposed stonework.

From the landing, a small staircase ascends to a mezzanine bedroom with floor-to-ceiling glass windows overlooking the living area. Beneath the bedroom is a large open kitchen with white cabinetry and a center island.

Opposite the main entrance, a wood-and-metal staircase climbs to a second bedroom with large interior-facing windows and an en suite shower room with separate toilet, all cantilevered over a library and office space.

The home’s lowest level, partially visible through a glazed floor, has a laundry room, cinema room and another large room that could serve as a primary bedroom with adjoining bathroom.

Outdoor space: The loft, which is in the backyard of an early 20th-century building, is accessed through a private 129-square-foot courtyard.

Attractions include the half-acre Jardin d’Anne Frank and various museums, including the Museum of the Art and History of Judaism. The quirky Passage de L’Ancre is a hidden pedestrian thoroughfare.

A wall of exposed stone, old timber beams, metal I-beams and a column add to the space’s slightly gritty feel.

A kitchen in a contemporary marble design opens to the main living area. All floors are polished concrete. Beyond the kitchen, a space topped with a slanted glass roof is used as a library and office. A workshop-style glass partition separates it from a bedroom adjacent to a bathroom.

From the entrance landing, concrete stairs ascend to a mezzanine floor with two open sides running the length of the apartment. The mezzanine floor has an open-sided bedroom with en suite bathroom and a walk-in wardrobe large enough to be converted to a third bedroom.

Île Saint-Louis | €1.395 million ($1.5 million)

A two-bedroom, two-bath apartment in a historic building on Île Saint-Louis

This apartment is on Île Saint-Louis, one of three islands in the Seine River in Paris. An elegant representation of 17th-century classical architecture, Île Saint-Louis has a tranquil neighborhood feel in the midst of the city’s bustle, and easy access to many Paris offerings. Four bridges connect the island with the Right and Left Banks, and there’s a footbridge to the larger Île de la Cité island.

Landmarks include 17th-century urban mansions, such as Hôtel Lambert and Hôtel de Lauzun, and the Saint Louis en L’Île church. There are cafes, restaurants, bars, groceries and other shops, including the famous Paris ice cream parlor, Berthillon.

Q: Denmark currently has up to 9,000 professional troops on top of the 4,700 conscripts undergoing basic training, according to official figures. The government wants to increase the number of conscripts by 300 to reach a total of 5,000.

The country is a member of the NATO alliance and a staunch supporter of Ukraine in its war against Russia’s invasion.

Foreign Minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen stressed that “Russia does not pose a threat to Denmark.”

“But we will not bring ourselves to a place where they could come to do that,” Løkke Rasmussen said.

All physically fit men over the age of 18 are called up for military service, which lasts roughly four months. However, because there are enough volunteers, there is a lottery system, meaning not all young men serve.

In 2023, there were 4,717 conscripts in Denmark. Women who volunteered for military service accounted for 25.1% of the cohort, according to official figures.

Defense Minister Troels Lund Poulsen said the new system would require a change in the law, which he said will happen in 2025 and take effect in 2026.

The security policy situation in Europe “has become more and more serious, and we have to take that into account when we look at future defense,” Lund Poulsen said. “A broader basis for recruiting that includes all genders is needed," he said, adding it will create "a more versatile and more complete defense.”

Under the plan for which there likely is a majority in the Danish parliament, conscripts will first spend five months in basic training, followed by six months in operational service along with supplementary training.

In 2017, neighboring Sweden instituted a military draft for both men and women because the Swedish government spoke of a deteriorating security environment in Europe and around Sweden. The Scandinavian country had previously abolished compulsory military service for men in 2010 because there were enough volunteers to meet its military needs. It never had a military draft for women before.

Norway introduced a law in 2013 applying military conscription to both sexes.

Q: Climate activist ends 21-day protest fast in Leh

Noted climate activist Sonam Wangchuk on 26 March ended his 21-day-long hunger strike in support of the demand for statehood for the Ladakh region and its inclusion in the Sixth Schedule of the constitution. The Sixth Schedule contains provisions related to the administration through autonomous district councils. At the end of his fast, Wangchuk made a fresh appeal to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah to safeguard the fragile ecosystem of Himalayan mountains in Ladakh and the unique indigenous tribal cultures of the region. The climate activist said, "We do not think of Modi and Shah as just politicians, we would rather like to think of them as statesmen and for that they will have to show some character and some farsightedness." BSF says more troops being deployed in Kashmir for elections

The IG BSF said with the snow melting at high mountain passes, the chances of militant infiltration from Pakistan increase. He said the melting snow also opens up rivers further increasing infiltration attempts from across the border. The IG BSF said, "We are taking this into account and are adjusting our security deployment accordingly." Yadav said the BSF has its predominant role at Line of Control (LoC) along with army to make the LoC grid strong and foil any possible infiltration. [Words: 150]

Q: Iran, E3 to hold nuclear talks in Geneva today

Iran and the three European signatories to the 2015 Iran nuclear deal (JCPOA) - France, Germany and the UK (collectively, the E3) - will hold a meeting today in Geneva on the deputy foreign ministerial level.

The meeting comes amid warnings by the E3 that they will activate the so-called snapback mechanism of the JCPOA to reinstate UN sanctions on Iran if Tehran fails to show progress in nuclear talks with the US.

US-Iran nuclear talks have been stalled since the 12-day Iran-Israel war in June. Talk about the snapback mechanism has intensified ahead of the October deadline when the UN Security Council Resolution 2231, passed in 2015 to endorse the JCPOA, expires.

The state radio channel (VIRI) said that Deputy Foreign Minister Majid Takht-Ravanchi will lead the Iranian delegation today. VIRI noted the 22 August phone call between Foreign Minister Abbas Araqchi and his E3 counterparts, in which Araqchi rejected the E3's "legal and moral authority" to activate the snapback.

China and Russia, other signatories of the JCPOA, oppose the activation of the mechanism. President Massoud Pezeshkian also spoke by phone with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin yesterday, assuring him that Iran has never sought to build nuclear weapons.

Iran rejects Trump's post on Tehran's nuclear programme

Foreign Ministry Spokesman Esmail Baqai yesterday criticised Trump for reposting an old interview by a former Iranian MP, accusing the US president of distorting facts to justify US strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.

Baqai said Trump was ignoring his own intelligence chief's assessments, referring to Tulsi Gabbard's testimony in March that Iran was not building a nuclear weapon, and instead relying on personal remarks by a former Iranian lawmaker.

Baqai's remarks came in response to Trump sharing a clip without a comment, originally posted by influencer Mario Nawfal, of Ali Motahhari, former deputy parliament speaker, saying in 2022 that Iran had initially aimed to develop a nuclear weapon but failed to complete the project or conduct a test.

Motahhari, who left the parliament in 2020, dismissed Trump's post, saying that he was not an official at the time of the interview and adding that the US president "seemed to lack evidence and so resorts to the personal comment of an ordinary individual".

Foreign minister in Saudi Arabia for Gaza ministerial

Foreign Minister Araqchi yesterday addressed an emergency meeting of the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) about the Israel-Gaza war, urging Muslim countries to take concrete steps to halt "genocide" in Gaza.

On the sidelines of the Jeddah ministerial, Araqchi met his Egyptian, Saudi, Iraqi, Pakistani, Turkish and Algerian counterparts as well.

Separately, Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Baqai yesterday condemned a deadly Israeli strike on Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis.

Parliament speaker backs president after leader's endorsement

Conservative Parliament Speaker Mohammad Baqer Qalibaf this morning called on hardline factions to stop talking about President Massoud Pezeshkian's alleged "incompetence", saying that they were "playing into the enemy's hands".

Qalibaf's remarks come after Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei publicly backed the "hardworking" president on 24 August amid mounting criticism from hardliners against him and his reformist backers.

Some reformist newspapers complained that the attacks against Pezeshkian continued even after Khamenei's backing, accusing the hardliners of trying to "destroy the government".

Pro-reform daily Sazandegi named Saeed Jalili, Pezeshkian's hardline opponent in the 2024 election, Peyman Jebeli, the head of the state broadcaster, and several hardline MPs as members of the "distortion movement".

At the same time, Qalibaf in his speech rebuked a recent controversial statement by the major reformist group, Reform Front, while Judiciary Chief Gholamhossein Mohseni Ejei yesterday strongly condemned it.

While reformist daily Hammihan criticised the judiciary's "political statement", ultraconservative daily Keyhan welcomed Ejei's remarks, warning that "failing to deal with its statement-writing servants will give the enemy a foothold".

The leader of the Reform Front, Azar Mansouri, yesterday defended the group's statement calling for direct talks with the US and suspending uranium enrichment, saying that the proposal was rooted in national responsibility.

Outcry after comedian mocks Persian epic poet Ferdowsi

Comedian Zeynab Mousavi has faced a wave of criticism after posting a video parodying verses from Ferdowsi's epic poem, the Shahnameh, with coarse and sexually explicit language.

The clip, widely shared on X and Instagram, was condemned across the political spectrum as an affront to a cornerstone of Persian literature and culture. Many users described it as an "insult", saying the Shahnameh is a national symbol that should not be subjected to crude mockery.

Mousavi's Instagram account was taken offline amid the uproar, though it is unclear whether she removed it herself or whether it was deactivated following user complaints.

This morning, Iran's judiciary announced that a case had been opened in Tehran's prosecutor's office for the controversial comedian, after pro-establishment media outlets also weighed in yesterday to report the story and criticise Mousavi.

The controversy has reignited debate online under various hashtags such as #Ferdowsi and #Shahnameh.

Some users argued that comedians should be free to joke about any subject, while others accused Mousavi's defenders of hypocrisy for supporting satire of Ferdowsi while opposing jokes on other topics.

Q: Israeli media revealed last night an internal Israeli army document saying that "Operation Gideon's Chariots"- a ground offensive that Israel launched in Gaza in May - has "failed", citing "ineptitude" in humanitarian planning, exhaustion of forces, and loss of international legitimacy.

Israel Channel 12 reported that despite the chief of staff's words that the operation was successful, the document states that "we failed", and that "Israel made every possible mistake when waging a war".

The document said "war goals were not achieved, Hamas was not defeated… the hostages were not returned," though it listed achievements such as "severe blows" to Hamas infrastructure and leadership, the Israeli news site Ynet reported.

Channel 12 reported that the document cited failures in planning and delivering humanitarian aid, which enabled Hamas to wage a "false but effective starvation campaign".

The channel quoted the army spokesperson as saying that the materials were shared "without the approval of the relevant authorities".

Houthis vow revenge against Israel for killing of top officials

Yemen's Houthis vowed retaliation against Israel in a series of statements following confirmation that top government officials were killed last week in Israeli strikes on Sanaa, including Prime Minister Ahmed Ghaleb al-Rahawi.

Houthi Chief of Staff Maj Gen Mohammed al-Ghamari said yesterday that Israel had "opened the gates of hell upon itself", and that the movement's response would be "harsh and painful, with effective and influential strategic options", Houthi-run Al-Masirah TV reported late last night.

It follows a televised address by leader Abdulmalek al-Houthi earlier in the day, offering condolences over the deaths of Houthi government officials. He said that the Houthi military forces' campaign against Israel "whether with missiles, drones or the naval blockade" was "continuing, steady and escalating".

Gaza ceasefire talks continue as mediators wait for Israeli response

Egypt is reportedly continuing talks on a ceasefire in Gaza, waiting for a response from Israel to a recently submitted proposal.

The UK-based, Qatari-funded Al-Araby Al-Jadeed website quoted an informed Egyptian source yesterday as saying that Egyptian intelligence officials are "continuously" communicating with the Israeli side regarding the negotiations.

The source added that the US had requested Egypt and Qatar to put pressure on Hamas to reach a "formula" concerning its future and the fate of its military wing, as part of consultations aimed at opening channels to persuade the Israeli prime minister to resume talks.

The website also quoted a senior Hamas member as saying that the group is still communicating with mediators while waiting for the Israeli response to the latest ceasefire proposal, which it has accepted "unconditionally".

Lebanese media report Israeli 'belt of fire' attacks on south

Southern Lebanon's Nabatieh region was rocked by intense Israeli bombardment early yesterday, killing one person, with Lebanese media describing the strikes as a "belt of fire".

The first ten strikes, using "highly explosive missiles", had hit the Ali Taher hills, causing houses to "shake from the impact of the explosions", followed by more drone strikes, French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported. It said that one person riding a motorcycle was killed by a strike.

In a statement, the Israeli army claimed it had targeted Hezbollah-linked underground infrastructure "where military activities were observed".

Yesterday, L'Orient-Le Jour also reported that Israel had dropped "propaganda leaflets" in the southern border village of Aita al-Chaab, "threatening any person carrying out reconstruction work for Hezbollah".

Syrian media report Israeli incursions in Quneitra

Syrian media reported two separate Israeli military incursions into Syria's southern border province of Quneitra yesterday.

State-run Al-Ikhbariyah al-Suriyah TV reported that dozens of Israeli military personnel entered the village of Al-Asha where it conducted searches of residential homes.

Meanwhile, the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) reported that an Israeli contingent consisting of six armoured vehicles and dozens of soldiers entered the town of Jabata al-Khashab in the northern parts of Quneitra where they set up a checkpoint and searched residential homes before withdrawing.

The latest incursions follow Israel's killing of six Syrian soldiers last week in a drone attack south of Damascus, just days after President Ahmed al-Sharaa announced that the two countries were holding "advanced" talks.

Lebanese Speaker calls for calm dialogue over Hezbollah arsenal

Lebanon's influential parliamentary Speaker Nabih Berri called for a "calm and consensual dialogue" over Hezbollah's arsenal.

In a televised speech aired on the state Tele Liban channel marking the anniversary of the disappearance of Shia Imam Moussa al-Sadr in 1978 in Libya, Berri said that "dialogue is the only way to find a solution", coming a day before the army is set to present a detailed timetable for the Iran-backed group's disarmament.

The call comes amid a tense atmosphere in Lebanon, with US pressure being exerted for Hezbollah's swift disarmament, continued and escalating Israeli attacks on the south and leading Hezbollah figures "continuing to radicalise their position regarding disarmament", French-language daily L'Orient-Le Jour reported last night.

Syrian Kurdish forces arrest dozens in anti-IS raids

The Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) made 51 arrests of suspected members of the Islamic State (IS) group over the weekend, as it concluded a security operation targeting the group in the north-east Syrian province of Hasaka.

The SDF - which controls much of Syria's north-east - said in a Facebook statement on 30 August that the suspects had been involved in "attacks on civilians" and on security centres and public facilities.

It added that it also dismantled "dangerous terrorist networks", a number of which had allegedly been plotting attacks on the SDF-run Al-Sinaa prison - which houses IS members - and on the al-Hol camp, where families linked to IS are detained.

Last night, the SDF also reported on X that two IS suspects were killed in a foiled attack on a checkpoint, north of Raqqa province.

Q: “I assured Secretary Blinken that Kenya will take leadership of the U.N. Security Support Mission in Haiti to restore peace and security," Ruto said.

Kenya's Foreign Affairs Principal Secretary Korir Sing'oei on Tuesday said Kenya had put on hold the deployment of 1,000 of its policemen until a clear administration is in place in Haiti. The announcement came after Haiti Prime Minister Ariel Henry said he would resign once a presidential council is created.

Kenya had agreed last October to lead a U.N.-authorized international police force to Haiti, but the country’s top court in January ruled it unconstitutional, in part because of a lack of reciprocal agreements on such deployments between the two countries.

Ruto said that he and Henry had witnessed the signing of the reciprocal agreements between Kenya and Haiti on March 1, clearing the path for the deployment.

Under the plan, the U.N.-backed multi-national police led by Kenyan officers was to help quell gang violence that has long plagued Haiti. But violence escalated sharply since Feb. 29, with gunmen burning police stations, closing the main international airports and raiding the country’s two biggest prisons, releasing more than 4,000 inmates.

Scores have been killed, and more than 15,000 are homeless after fleeing neighborhoods raided by gangs. Food and water are dwindling and the main port in the capital of Port-au-Prince remains closed, stranding dozens of containers with critical supplies.

After returning from a trip to Kenya where he had gone to salvage plans for the African country’s deployment, Henry has been locked out of his own country and has remained in Puerto Rico since last week.

Q: Helmand is Afghanistan's major river and runs into Hamoun wetland in Iran's parched Sistan-Baluchestan Province, which shares international borders with Afghanistan's southwestern Nimruz province. 

Zabihullah Mujahid, spokesperson for the Taliban government, said that the government is committed to the Afghanistan-Iran water treaty, adding that they released the water to flow to Iran because the recent rains have filled the reservoir.

"We continuously try to ensure that reservoirs are full of water in Afghanistan. We have considered our commitments with Iran and fulfilled them; therefore, we released the water," Mujahid added.

Iranian officials have repeatedly called on the Taliban to give Iran its rightful share of water from Afghan water streams, but some commentators said that priority should be given to Afghan people's rights.

"The Afghan government has decided to make some water available to our neighbours, but it should be done after making political and economic calculations so that the Afghan people's rights are protected," said Fahim Faramarz, an economist.

However, farmers in Afghanistan's southwestern Nimruz province complained that they faced drought for years. Therefore, they should be given priority in irrigating their farmlands.

"Priority should be given to farmers in Nimruz province. We experienced drought for two years, which has caused huge financial loss," said Gul Ahmad, a farmer.

"First, we should receive sufficient water to irrigate our crops and farmlands. Once we get enough water, we will not mind giving some water to our neighbours," said Ahmad Khan, another farmer.

"Drought has affected us badly. We have lost our crops and weather," said Noor Ahmad, another farmer.

Afghanistan and Iran signed the Helmand [also known as Hirmand] River Water Treaty in 1973. Based on the agreement, Afghanistan will supply Iran with 26 cubic meters of water per second or 850 million cubic meters annually.

See also: Briefing: Afghanistan, Iran tension over water remains unresolved despite visit

Explainer: Iran-Afghanistan disputes over water resources

Q: Raza asked Pakistan Muslim League-Nawaz (PML-N) politician Qaiser Ahmed Shaikh whether he would be assigned a ministry related to business and economy. Shaikh agreed and remarked one can perform only if he is assigned a task in which he has a background and experience. He noted "business confidence" in Pakistan is at the lowest ebb and the main task before the government at the moment is to fix the economy. He mentioned the prime minister spoke in detail about the economic issues and expressed the resolve that his government's full-fledged attention would be on the economy.

Raza asked Pakistan Peoples Party (PPP) politician Nadir Gabol whether his party would join the cabinet at a later stage. Gabol replied Bilawal Bhutto Zardari (PPP chairperson) has repeatedly stated that his party would not join the cabinet but would support Shehbaz Sharif's government on an "issue to issue basis". He said the objective of it is to give Sharif a chance to focus on governance and select a cabinet of his choice. He added the PPP wants that relief should be provided to the people and the issue of terrorism should also be addressed.

Gabol said the PPP might review its decision about joining the cabinet after a few years if the situation improves. He explained his party does not want to join the cabinet because its ideology is very different from that of the PML-N as the former is a "progressive centre-left party".

Raza asked analyst Sana Mirza whether political stability is expected since Asif Ali Zardari from the PPP has been elected as the president and the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) has also joined the parliament. Mirza replied, "If we think that the PTI will sit quietly because it is now in the parliament, it is wrong". She noted after elections, the PTI claimed that its right has been taken away as other parties have formed a government.

Mirza claimed the PTI will not let the parliament work if its demands are not addressed. She noted Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Chief Minister Ali Amin Gandapur has demanded that a commission should be formed to look into the election results and the 9 May incidents (violent protests by alleged PTI members after the arrest of the then-chairperson Imran Khan) but it would be a lengthy process. She further noted PTI politician Asad Qaiser claimed if a "certain personality [referring to former chief minister of Punjab Mohsin Naqvi]" is appointed as the interior minister, "doors of talks would be closed permanently". She said the PTI has alleged that Naqvi played an important role in the rigging of elections in Punjab.

Mirza said the people included in the cabinet are those who can work with Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif. She claimed the [military] establishment also had some influence in the selection of the cabinet. She was of the view that a "technocrat government" is needed at the moment to solve the economic problems of the country.

Shaikh noted the allegations of election rigging have been levelled by the PTI in every election. He appreciated the PPP's decision to support the PML-N government and said by not joining the cabinet, PPP has allowed the PML-N to form its government and adopt its manifesto. He termed it a "favour by the PPP" and expressed hope in the two parties working in coordination with each other.

Shaikh said Prime Minister Sharif is "dedicated" and "determined" to solve the economic problems, increasing exports, and promoting industries. He remarked the government's direction will become clear in the next few months. He was of the view that the PTI would not continue its protests for a very long time because that would make it unpopular among its voters. He opined the government would decrease the interest rate gradually because an interest rate over 10 to 12 per cent would be unfavourable for business development.

Gabol said President Zardari would not have executive powers but he would play a different role. He recalled during his previous tenure, Zardari had contributed significantly to economic matters.

Shaikh disagreed with the view that the government would not be stable and insisted Pakistan is at a "make or break stage". He said the country cannot continue taking more loans, so all stakeholders will have to sit together. He was of the view that "drastic changes" would be brought by the new government regarding allocation of funds to different areas. He also mentioned election reforms would be discussed in the National Assembly (lower house of the parliament).

Mirza said the team chosen by Prime Minister Sharif includes people who have proven themselves as good administrators. She was of the view that Sharif is the "ultimate choice for prime ministership" at the time when Pakistan is facing many issues and he should try to perform with a "limited team".
